column2: MASLOW--Carol. The Board of Directors, Faculty and Staff are deeply saddened by the loss of Carol Maslow, Trustee Emeritus, and wife of our esteemed board member, Arthur Maslow. We extend sincerest condolences. The Ackerman Institute for the Family

MILLER--Herbert Kenneth, April 5th, 1921 - February 1, 2014 died at Kendal House, Sleepy Hollow, New York. Herbert earned his PhD in biochemistry from Columbia University and was a Professor at Manhattan College. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Audrey Miller; two children, Emily Zeigler of Beaver Creek, Colorado, and Jonathan Miller of Cambridge, Massachusetts; and two adult grandchildren, Abigail Miller of Brooklyn, NY, and Benjamin Miller of Boston, Massachusetts. His family and friends will remember him for his intelligence, sense of humor and charm. Donations in his memory may be sent to Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, 31 Glengary Road, Croton-on-Hudson, NY 10520.

MASLOW--Carol Rosenthal. Feisty, loyal, strikingly elegant, bold, blonde and irreverently witty, best friend of husband Arthur, daughter of Doris and Eddie and mother of Toni and Mark, died on February 2nd after a sudden battle with cancer at the age of 78. Loving and generous, Carol will also be dearly missed by her extended family including Cindy, Lizzie and Gerry, Thom and Cheryl, her siblings and their spouses Ellen, Peter and Beth, Pat and Larry, and grandchildren Noah, Morgan, Sara, Brian, Caroline, Rachel and Hannah. Born in 1935 to Edward and Bea Rosenthal, who died due to complications from childbirth, Carol was raised by Eddie and Doris on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and graduated from The New Lincoln School and continued onto Connecticut College for Women. Married to Steven J. Ross at the age of 19, Carol moved back to New York earning her BA from Finch College. Carol raised daughter Toni, artist, restaurateur and mother of Noah and Sara, and son Mark, music producer, husband of Cindy and father of Morgan, Brian and Caroline. Carol went back to school as an adult. Demonstrating what became defining characteristics of determination and perseverance Carol earned her Masters of Social Work from NYU in 1984. Carol was committed to improving the lives of others. After earning her Masters, Carol worked with the homeless at Manhattan State Psychiatric Hospital. Later she became a Trustee of Beth Israel Hospital. Carol had an over 35 year affiliation with the Ackerman Family Institute serving in a multitude of roles from video technician to Chairman of the Board. It was at the Ackerman Institute that Carol met Arthur Maslow and over the ensuing years they fell in love, married in 1979, and remained soul mates for 34 years. Celebrating life's milestones with her children, grandchildren and extended family was one of Carol's greatest joys. For many years Nantucket became a wonderful second home filled with sunsets, gardening and adventures with Arthur's "fleet." Later years were split between Manhattan and Jupiter Florida interspersed with frequent exotic trips abroad. Laughter abounded as Carol punctuated every interaction with her wry one-line observations that cut right to the essence. Carol's life was honored by family and friends at a memorial service Wednesday, February 5th at 10:00am at the Stanley Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center 165 W. 65th Street, 10th Floor. Donations in Carol's memory may be made to the Carol R. Maslow Charitable Trust c/o Jewish Communal Fund, 575 Madison Avenue, Suite 703, New York, NY 10022.

PROCKOP--Elinor S.,of Philadelphia, died peacefully from the effects of cancer on Sunday, February 2nd, 2014. Born Elinor Sacks in New York on May 16th, 1930, Ellie attended Radcliffe College and then earned a PhD in experimental psychology from Harvard University in the 1950's before marrying Darwin Prockop and settling with him in Philadelphia. In 1972, Darwin, Ellie and their two young children moved to Princeton, NJ, where Ellie became advisor to premedical students at the university. Darwin and Ellie moved back to Philadelphia in 1986. To the end Ellie remained comfortable in the home she loved, in the company of her family. She is survived by Darwin, their daughter Susan and her wife Kristie Gordon (of New York City), a son David and his wife Hope and their children Molly and Lyle (of Groton, MA). A memorial service will be held at a later date.

RICHARDSON--Rita (nee Griswold), a long time resident of Darien, CT, died February 4, 2014, aged 90. Wife of the late George "Rick" Richardson, loving mother to Debbie Thomas of Melbourne, Australia and George O. Richardson, III of New Canaan, CT. Much-loved Grammy to Erin, Charles, Cameron and Oliver. Service to be held at 10am, February 11, at the First Congregational Church, Darien, CT.

ROGERS--Louise Gordon, 91, artist, sailor, died peacefully on February 2nd. Daughter of the late Charles Gordon and Edna Krause Gordon, she was predeceased by her beloved husband Harry Peter, son Gordon, sisters Jane and Sara and brother Henry. A Manhattan resident, she spent many summers in Cutchogue, Long Island. An award-winning painter, illustrator of children's books, she was a member of the Pen & Brush Club and The Art Students League. She was a long-time member of the City Island Yacht Club. She attended Smith College and is an alumna of Elmira College. In 1970, with neighbors, she was instrumental in gaining early landmark designation for a row of mid-19th century row houses, including hers, in Chelsea. She is survived by nieces and nephews, her cherished Victoria Leacock Hoffman, grandson Harry Hoffman, and many dear friends. Memorial service to be announced.

DUBOFSKY--Robert. We are saddened by the loss of our long time friend, a pillar of the community. Our thoughts and prayers are with Betsy, Ned and Lindsay, Nancy and Stephen. Levien and Scheinman Families

GOLDSMITH--Henry, died peacefully on Wednesday, January 29 in Palm Beach Florida. Born in Berlin in 1915, he escaped the anti-Semitism coincident with Hitler's ascendency to power in 1933. He worked in Antwerp and Liverpool as a cotton broker and then came to New York in 1937 where he worked for the Wall Street firm of J.S. Bache And Company. He enlisted in the Army in 1942, was quickly transferred to the renowned Intelligence and Interrogation School at Camp Ritchie, Maryland, was commissioned as an officer, and acted as an instructor. He was then transferred to the counter-intelligence unit in England and shortly after V-E Day, he interrogated top German officers prior to the Nuremburg trials. While in the service he met and married Janet Fox, a Broadway actress, and the niece of Edna Ferber. They remained married until her death in 2002. After the war he became Executive Vice President and General Manager of Greystone Press, a pioneer in monthly mail order books and records. He was a militant activist in favor of universal health care and a democratic society. He loved "piping" hot food, boats, bridge, Shelter Island, and the Palm Beach Towers where he served as board president until shortly before his death. He leaves his loving and beloved partner, Anita Seltzer, his devoted daughter, Julie Gilbert Holof, and his son-in-law Bob Holof. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Actor's Fund and/or Mashomack Preserve on Shelter Island, New York.
KOVACS--Barbara. Deepest condolences to the Kovacs family and Alecia Wesner. Barbara, you are always in our hearts, Justine Stamen Arrillaga and John Arrillaga.

GOLD--Nelle, passed away on February 4, 2014, age 101. Loving mother of Gilbert J. Wise (Sharon). Beloved grandmother of Avery Harrison Wise, Aubrey Jayson Wise. Born in Chicago Illinois, to Aaron and Esther Siegel. Her sisters Anne, Dorothy, Mary predeceased her. She has a surviving sister Blanche Fried. Aunt to Sherman Weissman (Sambra) Barbara Levin, Burton Fried (Debbie). Nelle was devoted to her many great nieces and nephews. Two husbands John Wise and Maurice Gold also predeceased her. During World War II she served with the American Red Cross and subsequently the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross. Despite visual and auditory impairments, she served as a volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and was actively involved in the Council of Jewish Women and Jewish Guild for the Blind. She will be interred in Waldheim Cemetery, Chicago, Illinois. The family is grateful to Elizabeth and Laura for their devoted care. Shiva will be observed in Nelle Gold's apartment on Tuesday and Wednesday from 3:00-7:00pm.

HOGAN--Joan McCarthy, passed away peacefully of natural causes in Hingham, Massachusetts, at age 93. She leaves behind her loving son Dennis and daughter-in-law Joan of Hingham, and granddaughter Hannah of New York City. Joan was born in Park Slope, Brooklyn, to Charles and Alice McCarthy. The oldest of four children, her sisters Peggy and Lynn and brother Charlie pre-deceased her. Known for her intelligence, hard work and self-reliance, she had a lifetime of achievement that included a scholarship to St. John's University and a thirty-year career at Conde Nast Publications, most of it as Market Research Director. She was a pioneer as a college graduate, professional woman and single mother. Joan was a lifetime participant in women's organizations, and her positions and honors included AAF Advertising Woman of the Year in 1975, President of Advertising Women of New York, and Vice President of the National Council of Women. Joan loved classical music, jazz, modern art, and New York. She also loved the beach and lived for many years at Breezy Point, New York and Ocean City, New Jersey before moving to Ventura, California, which she enjoyed for over twenty years. She spent her final years in Massachusetts, near her son and his family.
LEIST--Fred, RIP old friend, my dad's okay buddy. Gone but never forgotten. You are a shining star now looking down forever. Love, PH

KOSKI--Marion, on February 7, 2014. Beloved wife of late husband Hy Koski, mother of Michael, Barry, Gene and Andy, sister of Martin, Edythe, Dan and Gladys, grandmother of Melissa, Max, Gregory and Annette, mother-in-law of Ginny, Linda and Nana'. You will be in our hearts forever.

MALTZ--Louis. 99 years young! Born May 11, 1914, passed away February 6, 2014. Veteran of the US Army. Served in WWII. Beloved husband to the late Rose Maltz, devoted father and father-in-law to Elliott, Tina, Renee, and Nelson, cherished grandfather to Gregory, Darren, Justin, Brooke, Liza, Ali and great-grandson Jagger. He touched the lives of so many people. We will miss him so!

HEMENWAY--Russell D.,died peacefully at home on January 30, 2014. He was 88. Russ Hemenway was, for more than fifty years, a true warrior spirit in American politics, combating the power of the radical right from the days of Joe McCarthy to the contemporary influences of extreme conservatism. From 1966 until his death, he was the National Director of the National Committee for an Effective Congress, founded in 1948 by Eleanor Roosevelt. He was the father of campaign finance disclosure reform in the early 70's. He was born on March 24, 1925, in Leominster, MA, to Bess and Alan E. Hemenway. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1949 and continued his education at The Institut d'Etudes Politiques in Paris. Hemenway served in the Navy during World War II aboard the heavy cruiser USS Pittsburgh. He married Catherine Casey in Paris in 1951, and was widowed by her in 1999. Their daughter, Anne Hemenway, survives him. He is also survived by a son, Brent G. Hemenway, two grandsons, Alexander and Maverick Douglas, a sister, Joyce H. Brown, a son in law, John H. Wilson, a daughter in law, Christina Morales Hemenway, and five nieces, Elesse T. Brown, Valentine L. Judge, Phoebe Legere, Jane L. Jackson, and Alison L. Fraser. Mr. Hemenway was pre-deceased by his sister, Winifred Ledger and his brother, Richard Hemenway. A service will be held on February 14 at 2pm at St Thomas Church, 1 W 53 St. NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The NY Public Library. Links to obituaries can be found at: www.dapsonchestney.com

LOCKSLEY--Gordon, private art dealer, contemporary art collector and bon vivant, passed away quietly in Fort Lauderdale, Florida on February 1, 2014. He was 84. Mr. Locksley is remembered for his keen wit and wry sense of humor, his thoughtful generosity and devotion to friends, family and the art world. He is survived by his spouse, Wayne Boeck and long time partner George Shea. Mr. Locksley was born in Chicago, Illinois on August 27, 1930 to Sheila and William Locksley (Lukowitz). Gordon's father worked in pharmaceutical sales for Max Factor and instilled a love of fragrances and their histories in his young son. His grandparents, Isadore and Ella Lukowitz, came from Poland, emigrating before World War II and were renowned for their bakery, which provided Chicago residents with their famous onion rye bread. As a teenager, Gordon developed a love of opera, through weekly radio programs and later, a passion for Broadway musicals. Surrounded by his mother and aunts, Gordon was tutored in the art of cooking and acquired a passion for fine dining and entertaining, which lasted throughout his life. As a young man, Mr. Locksley lived briefly in Columbus, Ohio and then moved to Minneapolis, where he arrived on a bus in a snowstorm, wrapped in an opera cape.and in 1954 met Dr. George Shea, a professor of Japanese language and literature at the University of Minnesota. Together they opened the Red Carpet Beauty Salon and College, where Gordon styled hair, and where he eventually began selling art, first on the salon walls and then in a private space which came to be known as Locksley Shea Gallery, one of the leading spaces for contemporary art in Minneapolis, in the 1960s and 70s. The Locksley Shea Gallery hosted exhibitions by many of the leading names in contemporary art; Christo, Andy Warhol, Donald Judd, Brice Marden, Ellsworth Kelly and Robert Rauschenberg all came for the opening night party of their exhibitions. Legendary parties; Christo wrapped two nude models in cellophane one night, Warhol and his entourage arrived by limousine, there were outrageous costume parties with live bands, multiple bars, dancing and gogo dancers. Gordon was a partner in Sutton Place, the first gay bar in Minneapolis. He and his attorney, Elliot Kaplan, worked tirelessly with local licensing authorities and the city council to create higher visibility for gay rights and equality. In 1974, following a downturn in the art market, a historic snowstorm and a notably large piece of business, Gordon and George Shea departed Minneapolis for Rome, Cannes and Paris where they lived until 1994, when they returned to the US and settled into an A. Quincy Jones designed estate, which was featured in the movie "Oceans Eleven," in Palm Springs. In 1998, Mr. Locksley met Wayne Boeck and moved to Fort Lauderdale, Florida, where they were married in November 2013. Selections from the Locksley Shea Art Collection are currently on view at the Minneapolis Art Institute. Mr. Locksley's ashes will be scattered on the mountainside above Palm Springs, California. There will be no memorial service.

HAGGERTY--Rita, PhD,Dr. Rita Haggerty, 65, a beloved neuropsychologist and teacher, died suddenly on February 4, 2014 after a brief illness. A graduate of Fordham University in 1970 with a B.S. in Psychology, she received her PhD. in Psychology in 1976 from Stony Brook University. She had a lifetime career at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center as Assistant Professor of Clinical Psychology, training generations of pediatric neuropsychologists. Dr. Haggerty also had a private practice working mainly with children. The family will receive visitors on Tuesday, February 11, 2014 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, NY. Mass and burial will be held on February 12, 2014 at 10am, St. Catherine's Church, 25 Second Avenue, Pelham, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to JDRF or The National MS Society.

KOVACS--Barbara. The Board, staff, and students of The TEAK Fellowship are deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and champion, Barbara Kovacs. Our thoughts are with her daughter, Elizabeth, her son, Peter, her grandchildren, and her friend, Alecia Wesner.

LONG--Callie Rose. It is with great sadness that we say good bye to Callie Rose Long, 27. Callie spent the majority of her short life in Aspen, CO before graduating from Suffield Academy in CT. She was attending Colorado University, where she would have completed her degree in International Business this week. Callie was working toward her dream of a career in the international fashion industry. She had a flair for fashion and design for which she attended the Art Institute. Callie will be deeply missed by her mother Jackie Long, Boulder, formerly employed by Halter Ranch Vineyard, Wyss Foundation and consultant to HJW Foundation, grandmother, Doris Long, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Aunt Cindy Long, Fort Lauderdale, cousin, JR Hopwood, Denver, and numerous friends she gathered along the way. She was welcomed into Heaven by her loving and adoring grandfather, Edward Long. Callie's beautiful smile and contagious love of helping others will remain in our hearts forever. A gathering to celebrate Callie's life was held in Aspen, CO on December 29, 2013. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to www.CalliesBackyard.org, her organization for at-risk youth and victims.
HAYNES--Ana Lucia "Lulu", 4, of Montclair, NJ, died gracefully on January 18, 2014 in New York City. Her family loved her dearly, especially her brother Jimmy. Lulu lived large and inspires us today.

HEYMAN--Anne. We are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our friend and client, Anne Heyman. Her loss is felt by all who knew her, including her extended family of 500 children in Rwanda. She will continue to inspire us by her exemplary work in tirelessly and selflessly improving the lives of others. Our heartfelt condolences to Seth, Jason, Jenna, Jonathan and the entire Heyman and Merrin Families. The Partners and Staff of Anchin, Block & Anchin LLP
LOCKSLEY--Gordon. We have lost a most special and unique friend. His intelligence, humor and thoughtfulness will always be with us. Colombe Nicholas Leonard Rosenberg

HIRSCH--Shay Yandell. June 8, 1947 to February 3, 2014. A beloved mother, wife, grandmother, social worker, friend, marathon runner, skier, writer, advocate, hiker, traveler, defender of the vulnerable and cancer warrior, passed away peacefully at home, surrounded by family, on February 3rd. Shay grew up in Boise, Idaho, where she was a 1965 graduate of Boise High School. Her childhood in the American West sparked a lasting love of nature. She entered a career in social work after graduating from Whitman College in 1969, and she devoted her life to others. In 1973, she married Greg Scrivner; the couple's two sons, Ian and Sean, were born in Alaska. After living in France, Ireland, Colombia, and New Jersey, Shay returned to Boise, where she became the director of YWCA's shelter for battered women, now called the Women's and Children's Alliance. At the 1988 New Jersey Waterfront Marathon, George Hirsch, who had met Shay only the day before at a marathon expo, and who was irrevocably lovestruck, ran through the crowded field of a race for which he had not registered until he found her. They ran the remaining 21 miles together, and they married the next year. Shay relocated to New York City, but the Hirsches maintained strong ties to Idaho, and they kept a home in Sun Valley. For the past eleven years, Shay wrote eloquently of her fight against multiple myeloma, an incurable blood cancer. Through two stem cell transplants and through more recent encounters with myelodysplastic syndrome and acute myeloid leukemia, Shay faced wave after wave of indignities with dignity and grace. She ended each post about her cancer battle by saying "Onward!" She embraced every part of life as an adventure, even the difficult ones. The impact of Shay's life is "incalculably diffusive," as George Eliot once wrote. Shay's memory will be held closely in the hearts of her husband, George A. Hirsch, the chairman of the New York Road Runners; her son Ian Scrivner and spouse Cinzia Dinoi; her son Sean Scrivner and partner Rachel Teannalach; her stepsons David and William Hirsch; her father Robert Yandell, brother Robert Yandell, and brother John Yandell and spouse Julie Yandell; her grandchildren Anjali Hirsch and Rhys Scrivner; and her nephews Christopher and Nicholas Yandell. A celebration of Shay's life will be held in March.

KOEGEL--William F. Bill Koegel, a resident of Somers, New York and Vero Beach, Florida, died on February 3rd in Florida. He was 90. After seven years living outside of Chicago (long enough to become a lifelong Cubs fan), he grew up in Bronxville, New York and proudly attended Williams College, in the class of 1944 (but actually graduating in September 1946 due to service in the First Army of the United States in Europe in the Second World War). After graduating from the University of Virginia Law School in 1949, he joined the New York law firm of Dwight, Royall, Harris, Koegel & Caskey, where he spent his entire professional life, retiring in 1989 as a senior partner and head of the litigation department (the firm then being known as Rogers & Wells). From 1952 to 2007, he resided in Scarsdale, New York where he was active in a range of civic affairs. In 1946 he married Barbara Bixler, whom he had met in 1941 while she was attending Smith College. She died in 1968. In 1969 he married Ruth Swan Boynton, who died in 1983. In 1984 he married Irene Lawrence, who survives him. Also surviving him are: his older sister, Ruth Macreery; his two sons: John Koegel of New York City (and his wife Lesley) and Robert Koegel of Rochester, New York (and his wife Mary); and six step-children: Whitney Boynton, Thomas Boynton, Barbara Hinman, Beverly Orser, Geoffrey Lawrence and Amelia Kelly. He is also survived by four grandchildren, seven step-grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, one great-step grandchild, and seven nieces and nephews. His generous, loving spirit will remain in the hearts of everyone who has been fortunate enough to know him. A service will be held at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, located at 6 Greenacres Avenue in Scarsdale, New York on Saturday, February 15 at 2pm. He will ultimately rest with predeceased family members at the Amawalk Hill Cemetery in Yorktown Heights, NY.

KREMER--Michael. The family of Michael Kremer sadly announces his passing on January 28, 2014. Devoted husband of the late Hannah Goldfarb Kremer, beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Born in Grodno, Belarus, he survived the Grodno and Bialystok ghettos and Stutthof, Auschwitz and Buchenwald concentration camps, and with Hannah built a new life. Founder of Atlas-Acon Electric in New York, still a family-run business. Board member of Greater Miami Friends of the IDF, former Board member of the Bialystok Center and donor to establish the Michael and Hannah Kremer Physiotherapy and Occupational Therapy Center at Sheba Hospital, Tel HaShomer, Israel. Donations may be made to the Friends of the IDF, Greater Miami chapter. We miss you every day. Goldschmidt, Bernstein, Grossman and Kremer families.

LOPEZ--Jo Willa Gramling. Lawyer and philanthropist, died on February 7, 2014 in Gramling, South Carolina, after a battle with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). Ms. Gramling Lopez was a native of Gramling, South Carolina, which her grandfather helped found in the late 1800s. Born September 3, 1948 to Bennie and Annie Lou Gramling, she graduated Wellesley College in 1969, as well as Georgetown Law in 1972, before moving to New York to become the first female lawyer hired at Merrill Lynch in 1973. Ms. Gramling Lopez made her entire 30 year professional legal career at Merrill Lynch. She was instrumental in developing the firm's banking and trust businesses-including its first banking venture in the 1970s, the acquisition of Merrill Lynch International Bank Limited, as well as several foreign and domestic banks-all in the restrictive Glass-Steagall era. She also led the consolidation of several state-chartered trust companies into a national charter, allowing for trust services to be offered nationally. These innovative legal strategies ultimately contributed to banking reform in 1999 with the Graham-Leach-Bliley Act. Ms. Gramling Lopez returned to her native Gramling in 2004. She continued her philanthropic efforts started in New York with the Junior League (where she served as President from 1984 to 1986) by joining South Carolina's Guardian Ad Litem program. She later became the Executive Director of the Children's Advocacy Center of Spartanburg, South Carolina in 2011. Through her efforts, the CAC was officially recognized by South Carolina's Secretary of State as an "Angel" charity. A noted animal lover, she is survived by her two sons, Ben and Andy Lopez, her sister, Lucy Gramling Crowley, and her eight animal children- Apollo, Buddy, Jackie, Jessie, JT, Lulu, Mikey, and Zeus. Funeral services will be held at 3:30pm Sunday, February 9, 2014 at Gramling United Methodist Church, Gramling, SC. Burial will be in the church cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family prefers that donations be sent to Miss Jo's Children's Fund, care of the Spartanburg County Foundation, Spartanburg, SC. For directions or to give condolences, please contact Petty Funeral Home, Landrum, SC.
GRABISCH--Charlotte, 70 years of friendship, I will miss you. Rest in peace. Love, Claire

LEFEVRE--Charlotte G. (Chotsie), a resident of East Dorset, VT and formerly of Chappaqua, NY, passed away January 30, 2014 at her home in East Dorset. A celebration of her life will be held in the spring. To send the family personal email condolences please visit www.sheafuneralhomes.com.

ICHNIOWSKI--Casey. The Board of Overseers of Columbia Business School expresses deep sorrow at the passing of Casey Ichniowski, the Carson Family Professor of Business at Columbia Business School. Professor Ichniowski was a highly effective and collaborative division chair, superb teacher, outstanding researcher, and good friend. During his thirty years of service, he made innumerable contributions to the School's curriculum, especially in the areas of managerial negotiations and sports industry management. His passing is an enormous loss. Columbia Business School extends its profound sympathy to the Ichniowski family. Glenn Hubbard, Dean, Columbia Business School.

LEVINE--Ethel, 101, born December 12th, 1912; died January 25. She worked as an elementary school teacher until 1975. An eternal optimist. Survived by children Sharon Springer, Diane Schank, and Theo Levine.

HAGIN--Rosa A. "Rah", PhD, 92 years old, died Friday, February 7, 2014 at her home. She lived in Manhattan, NYC, NY and Cranford, NJ before moving to Hardyston Twp., NJ 12 years ago. Dr. Hagin was a educational psychologist, teacher and advocate for children and adults with learning disabilities. She worked at Fordham University and organized the school Consultation Center there which has been named for her. She also had a private practice for children and adults. Dr. Hagin was predeceased by a nephew, Keith Deckhut and is survived by her sister, Millicent Deckhut, niece Susan Killacky, grandnieces and nephews, T.J., Christopher and Emily Killacky, Rob and Tracy Deckhut. Visiting will be Monday, February 10, 2014 at F. John Ramsey Funeral Home, One Main Street, Franklin, NJ from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral service will be Tuesday, February 11, 2014 at the funeral home at 10am. Interment to follow at Fairview Cemetery, Westfield, NJ. Donations to Special Olympics, 1133 19th St NW, Washington, DC 20036. Information at: fjohnramseyfuneralhome.com

HARRIS--Bernard (Bernie) B. Farewell my precious brother. Kind of heart and deeds, WWII Solider in Battle, handsome, loving and devoted family man, businessman and humanitarian. Estelle Cohen and Family

BERLINER--Esther Ann, 93. "Skippy," avid gardener, political activist and environmentalist, died February 4. Predeceased by her husband, Dr Benjamin C. Berliner, and survived by her four children, nine grandchildren, and seventeen great-grandchildren, she was beloved by them all. A celebration of her life will be held at her daughter's home on April 27 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please donate to The Nature Conservancy.

CLARK--Sandra "Sandy." Born Sandra Levin, April 15, 1932, in Brooklyn. Died February 1, 2014 of natural causes. Predeceased by husband Dr. Daniel Clark. Survived by daughters Nanu Clark and Laurie Beth Clark.

BUSH--Harold, age 83. Treasured and missed by wife Ruth, daughter Melanie, granddaughter Magda, and generations of New Yorkers whom he touched with his generosity and humor. Memorial 5pm, February 19, McBurney YMCA, 125 West 14th Street.

CAZORT--Mimi, Formerly Mary Ann, born Mary Antoinette, on August 26th, 1930; daughter of Alan Garner Cazort and Mary Lillian Carpenter; sister of Virginia Garner, Cecile Merriweather and Jean Celeste; student of Little Rock High School, Hendrix College, Washington University and The University of Michigan; wife of James J. Taylor and subsequently of Robert A. McLarty; mother of Anna Virginia and Alan Jamieson; adored grandmother of Ginger, Willa and Jem Taylor; Doctor of Philosophy; Curator Emerita of Prints and drawings at the National Gallery of Canada, author of books, articles and exhibit catalogues, including "The Ingenious Machine of Nature," "Mauro in America," and "Mr. Jackson's Mushrooms;" avid reader of Twain and countless others; foremost authority on Bolognese painters of the 17th and 18th centuries; passionate scholar of art history, the study of anatomy, the history of drawing and the relationship between all three; eternally curious, engaged, humorous, articulate, and warm - passed away in the late afternoon of January 27th, 2014, in Los Angeles, CA, while reading. The book was W.J. Cash's "The Mind of the South." Reports of her death, sadly, have not been exaggerated. She will be remembered, celebrated and missed beyond measure. Donations in her name to your local public library would be welcome and appreciated.

COHEN--Sheldon N. (Shelley) 83, beloved husband for nearly 53 years to Doris (Koppelman), devoted father to Karen Caine and Alison Cohen, and father-in-law to Cy Caine, adored and adoring "Bops" to Alex, Max and Brian Caine, and Katelyn and Connor Jang, devoted brother to Ted and the late Evelyn Stern and Harriet Leavitt, dear uncle and friend to many. Services will be held on Sunday, February 9th at 11:45am at Riverside Chapel 180 W. 76th Street, New York. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice.

CRARYHorace Ingraham, passed away peacefully in his home on February 7, 2014 at the age of 89. A resident of New Canaan for the past 58 years, he was President and co-founder, with Dr. David S. Brown, of the New Canaan Medical Group. From their initial partnership, the Group grew to include 11 physicians and a medical lab at the time of his retirement. House calls were made at all hours of the night and on weekends and were an important part of the practice. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1924 to Miner D. Crary and Edith Ingraham Crary, he was the last surviving grandchild of Jerry, a Civil War veteran, and Antoinette Crary. He was raised in Warren, PA and their family home on Duck Island, in Northport, NY. He graduated from Deerfield Academy and received a B.A. from Amherst College in 1946. During World War II, and while at Amherst, he entered the Navy reserve, which included a year at Williams College as part of the wartime accelerated program. He obtained his Doctor of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, interned at Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, NY and did his residency at Rhode Island Hospital. His training was interrupted by the Korean War, during which time he served in Portland, OR as a Captain in the U.S. Air Force. Following military service, he completed his training with a cardiology fellowship at Johns Hopkins, before starting an internal medicine practice in New Canaan, CT. Horace was active in the medical community. He was the last volunteer Chief of Medicine at Norwalk Hospital and was instrumental in the founding of Waveny Care Center and was a member of its Board of Directors. In addition, he was chairman of the Medical Advisory Committee at the Visiting Nurse Association. He was also active in retirement, serving as President of the Greenwich Research Partners, a local investment club, and was a board member of the Senior Men's Club. His financial skills and interest in investments defied the common doctor stereotype. Being an avid athlete, he won tennis and squash tournaments in college and after, fly fished for salmon and took up paddle boarding in his 80's. In his later years golf became his passion. He had three hole-in-ones. He was predeceased by his loving wife of 61 years, Arline G. Crary, his brother Miner D. Crary, Jr. and his sister Winifred A. Valens. He is survived by his four children: Jane, Horace, Jr. and his wife Susan, Dianne and Robert, three grandchildren: Gardner, Nicholas and Ian, as well as his dear friend Margaret M. Campbell. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends and former patients. Services will be held at 11am on February 13th at St. Marks Church in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Visiting Nurse and Hospice of Fairfield County (www.visitingnurse.net) or Waveny Care Center (www.Waveny.org).

BONHEUR--Hooshang, PhD, of New York, passed away on January 29, 2014 with his family by his side. He was a man who had a lifelong passion for learning and stood by his principles with conviction and without fail. He had a gentle warmth that could easily be heard in his voice, felt in his touch and seen in his smile. An accomplished clinical psychologist, he dedicated his professional career to his work as a forensic psychologist at the Supreme Court of the City of New York. Most important to him, he was a devoted and loving father to Jennifer and Craig, an adored grandfather to David and Adam, a cherished brother, uncle, cousin and friend. He was the man who taught us to "always do what you know and feel to be right" and emphasized how important it is to "make sure you leave this world a little better than how you found it". He most certainly did just that. His legacy will live on in all who knew him. Thank you Baba Hooshie, for enriching our lives every day and for being the man you'll forever be in our hearts.

BONVILLAIN--Ruth, 99, died peacefully at her home in New Malborough, MA, on February 3, 2014 where she resided with her daughter Nancy. She was born January 1, 1915 in New York City. Ruth worked for the Jewish Family Service in Brooklyn for many years before opening her own therapy practice in 1970. She continued her work until the young age of 92.

CAMMANN--Nora Francke, 82, on Friday, January 31st, peacefully at her home in Bridgehampton, NY after a long bout with cancer. She leaves her husband, Fred; two sons, Peter and Philip; a granddaughter, Grace; a brother, Albert Francke; and many cousins, nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at noon on Friday, February 7th, at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Bridgehampton.

FRIEZE--Lyman B. IV, passed away on January 25, 2014, after a long illness. He was the son of E. Beach Crowell Frieze (deceased 1973) and Marie E. Gorman Frieze (deceased 1991). Lyman B. Frieze, IV was a descendant of General Lyman B. Frieze, whose grandfather was a Captain of Minute Men in the Revolutionary War. General Frieze served under Governor William Sprague of Rhode Island as Chief of Staff, and was later commissioned by President Lincoln as Collector of Internal Revenue in 1863. Born in Staten Island, NY, Lyman B. Frieze, IV spent his childhood in Garden City, Long Island, where he attended Buckley Country Day School and graduated from St. Pauls School where he played football. While in the army, he served as a medic in the burn unit and was stationed at Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio, Texas. Lyman B. Frieze, IV then attended Yale University, where he continued to play football. His entire business career was at Citibank, N.A., where he began as a Portfolio Manager in the Personal Trust & Estates division at First National City Bank. Ultimately he became a Managing Director of Asset Management at Citigroup. He was an avid runner and member of The New York Athletic Club. He enjoyed spending summers in Edgartown, MA, where he served as treasurer of the Down Harbor Association. After retiring to Florida, he enjoyed playing tennis at the Longboat Key Club. He is survived by his loving wife Donna and their daughters Pamela Crowell Frieze of Boston, MA, and Allison Wallace Frieze of Denver, CO. He will also be missed by his in-laws Mrs. Mary W. Lee of Convent Station, NJ, and Mr. and Mrs. Burt D. Coultas of Milford, PA. Donations may be made in the name of Lyman B. Frieze, IV to the American Cancer Society.

DAVIS--Elizabeth Menzel, 84, of Belmont and Woods Hole, MA, died of leukemia on February 1, 2014 surrounded by her three children. She grew up in Cambridge, and graduated from the Buckingham School '47 and Radcliffe College '51. Violinist, violist, teacher, conductor--classical music filled her life. During summers in Woods Hole she co-directed Gilbert and Sullivan operettas and conducted the Woods Hole Cantata Consort. Even as her health failed, she played quartets and attended music camps. Arguably, her greatest talent was making world-class 1:12 scale violins from rare woods and eye surgical thread, each outfitted with functioning tuning pegs and a tiny label bearing her name painted with a one-hair brush. Liz lived at the center of a rich social world, and many people thought of her as a second mother. The daughter and wife of renowned scientists, she maintained deep ties to the scientific community. Outspoken and widely read, she was also a fierce critic of the anti-science movement. Married to Bernard D. Davis (d. 1994), daughter of Donald H. and Florence K. Menzel, she is survived by sons Franklin and Jonathan of Newton, MA, daughter Kate of New York City, sister Suzanne Lindeman Snyder of Austin, TX, and six grandchildren, Juliet and Jonah Ryan-Davis, Jeremiah and Rowan Davis, and Quentin and Katrina Heilbroner. A memorial will be held this summer in Woods Hole.

FREIDES--Barbara Greene, long time resident of Larchmont, NY, passed away peacefully February 1st, 2014. She was 78 years old. Barbara was born to Henry and Augusta Greene on November 25th, 1935, in Brooklyn, NY before moving to Kew Garden Hills and then Forest Hills for her teenage years and young adult years. She then settled in Mamaroneck and then Larchmont, NY. She was predeceased by her husband, Jack Freides, whom she married November 23rd, 1961. He died on March 1st, 2006. She is survived by her loving sister Sybil Goldman; sons Drew Freides and Randy (Judy) Freides; along with her two cherished grandchildren, Rebecca and Adam Freides. She was first and foremost a devoted wife and mother, but also worked as an accountant for over 50 years, until she retired only last year. Her passion was traveling the world, which took her to almost every continent. Contributions in lieu of flowers, can be made to the Westchester Jewish Center, 175 Rockland Ave, Mamaroneck, NY 10543.

BENJAMIN--Joseph N.,died February 5th at the age of 95. He was the beloved husband of Ranana, loving father of David (Martine), Laura, and Daniel (Beth), the devoted grandfather of Alexander, Nicolas, Geoffrey, Andrew and Joshua, and proud great-grandfather of Oliver. A pioneer in the field of high fidelity and stereo equipment, he was the founder and president of Benjamin Electronics. A world traveler, avid sailor and tennis aficionado, his wit, good humor and gentleness will be missed by all. Please send donations to Daughters of Miriam (Clifton, NJ) or St. Jude's Fund.

BONACUM--Dorothy Agnes, of Islip, L.I.,formerly of Babylon, L.I., on February 5, 2014. Beloved wife the late John J. Bonacum. Loving mother of John J. Bonacum III (Madeline Rivlin), Dr. James J. Bonacum (Dr. Erika Suzuki), Dr. Julia T. Bonacum (Dr. Jeffrey Rade) and Anne Bonacum (Steven Boxer). Devoted grandmother to Cynthia, Emily, Matthew, Grace, Owen and Emmett. Reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy. (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy.). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, Wednesday 10am at Our Lady of Grace R.C. Church, West Babylon, L.I. Interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Our Lady of Grace Parish Social Ministry, 700 Albin Avenue, West Babylon, NY 11704. Visiting Monday 7pm until 9:30pm and Tuesday 2pm until 4:30pm and 7pm until 9:30pm.

STIEFEL--Leontine, 95, died February 2. An avid reader, pianist, and ballet dancer, Tina developed a love of the Greek and Latin classics and an interest in medieval history. She taught high school and college history and published articles and a book on the history of science. Tina was married to Eli Stiefel; she leaves a son and daughter, Richard and Nancy Stiefel, three grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

ESBIN--Jerry, February 10th Happy Birthday! Its been 5 years and we miss you more each day. The movie of your life makes us all proud, supporting actors. Love always, Judy, Scott, Beth, Randi, Peter, Tyler, Zachary, Casey, Bennett and Sydney

WEINER--Richard, (May 10, 1927 - January 29th, 2014) was one of the true pioneers in the public relations field. His work to launch the Cabbage Patch Kids as well as other contributions led him to win the Public Relations Society of America Gold Anvil for lifetime achievement, among his many awards. He was the author of 23 books, including Webster's New World Dictionary of Media and Communications and Professional's Guide to Public Relations. His most recent passion was the topic of gossip including a book and an October, 2013 TED Talk. In addition to his career, family and friends meant the world to Dick. He was married to Chick Weiner for fifty-seven years. He is remembered as an excellent husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and a friend to many.

PERL--Otto. Beloved husband of over 70 years to Susanne, proud father of Lawrence, Monica, and Martin. Cherished "Papa" of Michael, Ze'ev, Elyse, Michal, Doron, Leia, Daniel, and Ella. Born in Vienna in 1915, Otto survived Dachau and Buchenwald, immigrated to the US in 1940, and served in US Army counterintelligence at Camp Ritchie. He created a world-renowned custom tailoring business on East 64th St. that served captains of industry and such cultural luminaries as Leonard Bernstein, Joe DiMaggio, and Luciano Pavarotti. Contributions in his memory can be made to HIAS.
WIBERG--Ruth, Two years without your smile, zest for life, sparkling personality & precious friendship - in our prayers & hearts always

OSTROVSKY--Everett Serge, April 18, 1924 February 7, 2014. A gift to all who knew him. Eternally young, he never lost sight of the simple joys in life or abandoned his childlike wonder. A PhD graduate of the Sorbonne, author of five books, and student of Jean Piaget, his work as a clinical psychologist was marked by great humanity, empathy and insight. He is survived by his loving wife of 47 years Michaela, two daughters Ruti and Nina, grandchildren Carla, Jason, Leor and Yael, and great-grandson Leo.

DUBIN--lrene Wasserman, Passed away on Sunday, February 9, at 101 years of age, in Shrewsbury, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, they shared a life of family, work and travel for 65 years. Born in New Haven, CT, where she also met her husband, she later moved with him to Bennington, VT, where they owned and operated Carroll's Drug Store for 33 years. An active member of the Bennington community, lrene served as treasurer of the Bennington Hebrew Congregation women's auxiliary and was a member of the Altrusa Club, an international women's service organization. In 1969, they moved to Hamden, CT, and then on to Delray Beach, FL, where they stayed until 1995, then to Freehold, NJ, until her husband's death in 1999. Since then, she has resided in Shrewsbury, NJ. Wherever she lived, lrene made friends and kept them throughout her life. She was a loving wife, mother, sister, grandmother and great-grandmother and will be deeply missed by her children: James (Susan) Dubin and Harriet (Steven) Straus; grandchildren Jacob (Sarah) Straus, David Straus, Alexander Dubin and Elizabeth (Alexander) Pugatch; and great-grandchildren Lillian and Benjamin Straus. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, February 11, at 10am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY. Donations may be made to the Lighthouse Guild lnternational, 15 west 65th St., New York, NY 10023 or Congregation B'nai lsrael, 171 Ridge Road, Rumson, NJ 07760.

HAGGERTY--Rita, PhD,Dr. Rita Haggerty, 65, a beloved neuropsychologist and teacher, died suddenly on February 4, 2014 after a brief illness. A graduate of Fordham University in 1970 with a B.S. in Psychology, she received her PhD. in Psychology in 1976 from Stony Brook University. She had a lifetime career at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center as Assistant Professor of Clinical Psychology, training generations of pediatric neuropsychologists. Dr. Haggerty also had a private practice working mainly with children. The family will receive visitors on Tuesday, February 11, 2014 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, NY. Mass and burial will be held on February 12, 2014 at 10am, St. Catherine's Church, 25 Second Avenue, Pelham, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to JDRF or The National MS Society.

BLACK--Rachel, The community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, mourns the loss of opportunity to better know this spirited, dynamic, French lady - a survivor, a scribe, a dancer - who was with our congregation all too briefly. Our hearts go out to all her family.

MORGAN--Col. Tom Graham, On January 22, 2014, of Falls Church, VA died after a short battle with cancer. Tom was a devoted and loving husband of Kenneth Youngert for 27 years and formerly of Margaret Ann Morgan. He was a dedicated and supportive father of Elizabeth Morgan of Boston and Cricket Sutton of Seattle. He is also survived by two precious grandsons, Casey and Garrett and his two beloved dogs, TG and Scooter. Tom earned his Bachelor's degree from Cornell University and later went on to earn his Law degree from Albany Law School and his Masters in Law from George Washington University. Col. Morgan served in the United States Army for 4++ years and remained in the Army Reserve for 23 years. He worked for 38 years as Associate Deputy General Counsel for the Department of Defense at the Pentagon. He retired in 2005 but continued as an expert consultant for the DOD. Col. Morgan was awarded the Meritorious Service Medal for service with the Military Personnel Law Team. Tom was hard working, generous and kind. He had a genuine love of life and others (and dancing). He will be remembered for his warm heart, infectious smile and vivacious personality. Tom will be missed by many but his legacy will live on through all those who loved him. Tom's memorial service will be held on Monday, February 17, 2014 at 11am at St. John's Episcopal Church, 3240 O St NW, Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Make A Wish Foundation.

CRARYHorace Ingraham, passed away peacefully in his home on February 7, 2014 at the age of 89. A resident of New Canaan for the past 58 years, he was President and co-founder, with Dr. David S. Brown, of the New Canaan Medical Group. From their initial partnership, the Group grew to include 11 physicians and a medical lab at the time of his retirement. House calls were made at all hours of the night and on weekends and were an important part of the practice. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1924 to Miner D. Crary and Edith Ingraham Crary, he was the last surviving grandchild of Jerry, a Civil War veteran, and Antoinette Crary. He was raised in Warren, PA and their family home on Duck Island, in Northport, NY. He graduated from Deerfield Academy and received a B.A. from Amherst College in 1946. During World War II, and while at Amherst, he entered the Navy reserve, which included a year at Williams College as part of the wartime accelerated program. He obtained his Doctor of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, interned at Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, NY and did his residency at Rhode Island Hospital. His training was interrupted by the Korean War, during which time he served in Portland, OR as a Captain in the U.S. Air Force. Following military service, he completed his training with a cardiology fellowship at Johns Hopkins, before starting an internal medicine practice in New Canaan, CT. Horace was active in the medical community. He was the last volunteer Chief of Medicine at Norwalk Hospital and was instrumental in the founding of Waveny Care Center and was a member of its Board of Directors. In addition, he was chairman of the Medical Advisory Committee at the Visiting Nurse Association. He was also active in retirement, serving as President of the Greenwich Research Partners, a local investment club, and was a board member of the Senior Men's Club. His financial skills and interest in investments defied the common doctor stereotype. Being an avid athlete, he won tennis and squash tournaments in college and after, fly fished for salmon and took up paddle boarding in his 80's. In his later years golf became his passion. He had three hole-in-ones. He was predeceased by his loving wife of 61 years, Arline G. Crary, his brother Miner D. Crary, Jr. and his sister Winifred A. Valens. He is survived by his four children: Jane, Horace, Jr. and his wife Susan, Dianne and Robert, three grandchildren: Gardner, Nicholas and Ian, as well as his dear friend Margaret M. Campbell. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends and former patients. Services will be held at 11am on February 13th at St. Marks Church in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Visiting Nurse and Hospice of Fairfield County (www.visitingnurse.net) or Waveny Care Center (www.Waveny.org).

SWARTZ--Howard, 86, of Longboat Key, FL, formerly of New City, NY, passed away peacefully on February 9. Howard was born in Albany, NY, on January 24, 1928, the fourth child of Morris and Molly Swartz. He married his beloved Goldie Brenner on September 3, 1950, and lived in the Albany area where Howard worked for the New York State Department of Labor until 1964, when he and his family moved to Rockland County, NY, and settled in New City, NY in 1965. In 1972, he formed and became president of Industrial UI Services, an unemployment insurance cost control firm, where he served until 1989, when he and Goldie retired and moved to Longboat Key, FL. Howard was an active bicycle rider often riding up to 40 miles a day and going on several major bicycle trips in the United States and in Europe. After he lost most of his sight, he and Goldie would ride a tandem bike for miles with Goldie in front. He loved baseball and basketball, and would spend hours listening to games. He especially loved listening to Vin Scully announce Dodger games, staying up late into the night just to hear him. Most of all he loved spending time with his family, including attending annual family reunions. He was also extremely proud of establishing with Goldie the Goldie Brenner Swartz and Howard Swartz Scholarship Fund at SUNY Albany which provides scholarship assistance to disabled students, primarily to students with vision impairments. The scholarship has assisted many students who would otherwise have been unable to complete their undergraduate studies. The scholarship has provided a dozen students in the last six years the opportunity to complete their undergraduate studies. Howard was predeceased in 2010 by his wife Goldie, who he loved dearly and talked about every day. He is survived by his son Mark and wife Iris of New City, NY, son Barry and wife Karen of Clarence, NY, grandsons Michael Swartz, Adam Swartz (and wife Melissa) and Jonathan Campbell (and wife Jenna), and many cousins, nieces, nephews and friends. He was predeceased by his sisters Sylvia and Anna, and by his brother Billy. Following a funeral service in Albany, NY, a period of mourning will be held at the home of Mark and Iris Swartz, 35 Ruth Drive, New City, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Swartz Scholarship Fund by making checks payable to The University at Albany Foundation, UAB 226, 1400 Washington Ave., Albany, NY 12222, and indicating Swartz Scholarship in the memo portion of the check. Servcies by Levine Memorial Chapel, Albany, NY

DUBIN--lrene Wasserman, Passed away on Sunday, February 9, at 101 years of age, in Shrewsbury, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, they shared a life of family, work and travel for 65 years. Born in New Haven, CT, where she also met her husband, she later moved with him to Bennington, VT, where they owned and operated Carroll's Drug Store for 33 years. An active member of the Bennington community, lrene served as treasurer of the Bennington Hebrew Congregation women's auxiliary and was a member of the Altrusa Club, an international women's service organization. In 1969, they moved to Hamden, CT, and then on to Delray Beach, FL, where they stayed until 1995, then to Freehold, NJ, until her husband's death in 1999. Since then, she has resided in Shrewsbury, NJ. Wherever she lived, lrene made friends and kept them throughout her life. She was a loving wife, mother, sister, grandmother and great-grandmother and will be deeply missed by her children: James (Susan) Dubin and Harriet (Steven) Straus; grandchildren Jacob (Sarah) Straus, David Straus, Alexander Dubin and Elizabeth (Alexander) Pugatch; and great-grandchildren Lillian and Benjamin Straus. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, February 11, at 10am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY. Donations may be made to the Lighthouse Guild lnternational, 15 west 65th St., New York, NY 10023 or Congregation B'nai lsrael, 171 Ridge Road, Rumson, NJ 07760.

OKSNER--Patricia Kinzler. 92, died peacefully at home on Sunday, February 9th, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Robert Oksner. Adored mother of Rebecca (Ronald) Berger, Margaret Jecko and Amy (James) Kendrick. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother.

GROMISCH--Donald S.,M.D., passed away on February 9, 2014. He was the son of Wilbur G. and Lillian S. Gromisch. Don was an extraordinary physician and academician, graduating from New York Medical College with highest honors in 1960 and achieving the rank of Professor of Pediatrics by the age of 40. He was Chief of Pediatrics at Metropolitan Hospital, Director of Pediatrics at Lincoln Hospital and Chairman of Pediatrics at Nassau County Medical Center, as well as a member of the Redbook Committee of the American Academy of Pediatrics. He received the Medal of Honor from New York Medical College in 1995. Don was a devoted sailor, acting as Commodore of Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club during 1997-1998, as well as a member of The New York Yacht Club. He was a devoted husband to Alice Gromisch and father to Dr. Mark Gromisch (Maryann) and Dr. Hollis Potter (Dr. William) and grandfather to five. The memorial service will take place at 10am at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, NY on Saturday the 22nd of February at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting donations to St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor or the Oyster Bay Sailing Foundation.

Also survived by many loving great-grandchildren and many close family and friends. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Hackerman Foundation, c/o Tammy Fanning, 300 East Joppa Road, 8th Floor, Towson, MD 21286. Family in mourning privately and receiving visitors at Beth Tfiloh Congregation on Sunday, February 16, from 12-6pm. Services by Sol Levinson & Bros., Inc. www.sollevinson.com

OLIVEIRA--Maria "Mae," of New York City, died at the age of 93 on February 9, 2014. She is predeceased by her husband Francisco DeOliveira. She was the loving mother of her two surviving sons Joe and Frank, devoted grandmother of Michelle, Joseph, Brian and Laura. Proud great-grandmother of Gavin, Joseph, Chase, Juliet and James. Funeral services will be held at Perazzo Funeral Home, located at 199 Bleecker St, New York, NY, between 6th Ave and Macdougal St, 212-777-7108, on Tuesday, February 11 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held on February 12, at 10am, at St. Anthony's Church, located at 154 Sullivan St, New York, NY. Burial will be in her native Portugal where she will join her husband. Her loving and generous spirit will be remembered, celebrated and missed by her family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations in Maria's memory may be made to The American Cancer Society.

DAWSON--Mary P. Passed away peacefully on February 8th, 2014 in Manhattan at the age of 89. Perpetually warm and gregarious, she spent her final days in the loving company of family and dear friends. Mary leaves behind an everlasting legacy of faith, compassion, love and selflessness that will continue to live in the hearts of those who hold her dear. She lived a meaningful and full life, at the center of which was her beloved family and countless friends. Of her friendships, many were old and dear; but, new ones were always being forged - few were impervious to her boundless charm. A woman of admirable spirit and energy, Mary will be remembered as a loving, dedicated and often whimsical mother, grandmother, great grandmother and cherished friend. Born in New York City, Mary was raised in Hollywood, CA and lived in Illinois, Oklahoma, and Washington, before raising her own family in Winter Park, FL. A strong and loving woman, Mary's dedication to her family was unwavering - she was an extraordinary caregiver to her mother and in turn, an outstanding mother to her children. In addition to family life, she also led a distinguished banking career, becoming one of the first female Vice Presidents of a Central Florida bank before retiring and returning to New York City. Incredibly well-read and an avid lover of music and the arts, Mary remained active in her later years. She dedicated her time to volunteer work at the Morgan Library and the Richard Tucker Music Foundation in addition to playing the occasional "Mary Poppins" to her grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband Lt. Colonel William Dawson; survived by her two children and their spouses, Linda Sachs (and her husband, Michael), and Rodney Dawson (and his wife, Janet); her five grandchildren, Blake (and her husband, John Paul), Courtney and Steven Sachs, and John (and his wife, Christina) and David (and his wife, Shannon) Dawson (and their mother, Barbara); and four great-grandchildren, Cole, Dillon, Brody and Naomi Dawson. Mary cherished all those she knew and in turn, those she touched are grateful for her love. Her generosity of spirit knew know no bounds. Friends are invited to a Viewing with the family from 12:30 to 1:30pm immediately followed by a Memorial Service on Thursday, February 13th at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E 89th Street in Manhattan. Following the Service, a reception celebrating Mary's life will be held nearby.

JORDON--Sydelle Gulkin, died peacefully February 8 at age 96 surrounded by her loving family. The most amazing mother of Lucie and Steve Kass, Dorothy Jordon and David Ferber and David and Madelyn Jordon, loving aunt of Carol Wolfe Breen, incredible grandmother of Glenn and Amber Schneider, Corey and Shari Schneider, Jordon Ferber and Alexius Diana, Haley and Greg Kraut, Jenny and Zach Messner and Shelby Jordon, and the greatest great-grandmother to Cooper, Riley, Jaxon, Jacob, Charlie and Isabella Schneider and Dillon and Charlie Kraut. She was predeceased by her husband, Charles Jordon, and two grandsons, Eric Schneider and Russell Ferber. She was the matriarch of our family: wise and gentle, kind and loving, supportive and so unbelievably smart. Special thanks to her caregivers, Jackie Stewart and Dorothy Pauling, who took such good care of her in recent years. Graveside services 1pm at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Queens, February 11. Donations in her memory to FJC/The Russell Ferber Foundation, 520 Eighth Ave., NY, NY 10018.

HACKERMAN--Willard. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express deep regret at the loss of Willard Hackerman of Pikesville, MD. He was the first president, and a devoted member, of the ATS Baltimore Chapter, and also served on the National Board of Regents and the Technion International Board of Governors. A longtime leader in the Baltimore Jewish community, his support of the Technion included the Johns Hopkins/Technion Center for Biomechanical Engineering, and the Baltimore Chapter Project Solid NMR Laboratory for the Study of Protein and Materials. Together with Lillian, his beloved wife of 72 years, Mr. Hackerman was a Technion Guardian, signifying the highest level of support. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lillian, daughter Nancy, son Steven, and the entire Hackerman family. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

BAUMEL--Madeline. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Madeline Baumel, of blessed memory, who was beloved by all who knew her, and who with her late husband, Murray Baumel, z'l, established The Murray and Madeline Baumel Judaic Faculty Incentive Award to further advance and strengthen Jewish Studies at Yeshiva University. Heartfelt condolences are extended to their children, Dr. Norma Baumel (and Rabbi Howard) Joseph, Elaine Kramer, their grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May the entire Baumel family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

GRAU--Jacqueline Schweitzer, died on February 8 after a lengthy illness. She was 93. Mme. Schweitzer Grau was born in Paris of Patrice Schweitzer and Mary Starachi. In 1971 she married George H. Grau of New York in Paris and moved to New York. She is survived by her cousin, Monique Coutenier of New York, and her godson, Herve Le Guyader of Bourdeaux. She was a successful concert pianist who performed in Europe, New York and New England. In 1946 she won the Prix de New York, followed by a critically-acclaimed recital at Town Hall. In France her career included appearances with the Radiosymphony, French National and Pasdeloup Orchestras. In New York she taught for many years at the United Nations International School and gave private lessons. She recorded a CD, "French Piano Music," in 1981. Her funeral Mass will be said at 9:30am on Thursday, February 13 at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71st Street, interment to follow at Trinity Church Cemetery. A viewing will be held from 2:00 to 5:00pm on Wednesday, February 12 at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, NYC. Donations in her memory may be made to the Church of the Blessed Sacrament or Fund for the Aged Inc., Manhattan Campus, 120 West 106th St.

HAGGERTY--Rita, Ph.D. She helped many and taught us all. Her expertise and her gentleness remain our ideal. Eric R. Marcus, MD Director, Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research
