RUTH--Geraldine. Following a recent illness, Geraldine "Gerry" Ruth passed away on February 12 as she wished, at her home in New York. She was born March 8, 1932, in New York City where she was a life long resident. She had a loving and devoted marriage to Jim Ruth, a professional cartoonist and a Vice President at Manufacturer's Hanover Bank in charge of artwork and video presentations. Gerry's professional career was as a librarian. With her husband she was actively involved in the entertainment and social life of New York. Their clubs included The Lambs, The Sons of the Desert. At her passing she was an officer of The Lambs, its Historian. She was a longtime active member of the Ziegfeld Club, serving as its treasurer, and of the Twelfth Night Club where she was a member of its board of directors. During a low period in the fortunes of The Lambs, she worked with her husband to help keep this venerable club alive. When financial difficulties during the 1960's forced the suspension of its newsletter, The Lambs Script, which had been founded in 1932, she and Jim produced an interim publication to keep club members informed. With the reinstatement of The Lambs Script in the 1990's, they contributed a regular column, "News of The Lambs." After Jim's passing in 2005 she continued the column under her own by-line. A very social person, she met regularly with friends at The Lambs or Sardi's Restaurant. An avid movie buff, she went with friends on Turner Classic Movie cruises, and at the drop of a hat it was like her to fly off to Hollywood for a movie festival. This kindly, caring, gifted and giving lady will be sorely missed and never forgotten by her many friends, one of whom once told her, "You know, Gerry, you are not just loved. You are beloved." She is survived by a brother-in-law, Jack Ruth, of Queens. Her many friends were her family. A memorial service will be held at the Three West Club in New York, to be announced. She will be interred next to her husband at Resurrection Cemetery, Staten Island, NY.

ROBERTS--Allene Singho, passed away on January 27, 2014. From fashion model to corporate executive to activist who received a Community Service Award from President George H.W. Bush, Allene has remained an inspiration to the African American community and to all of her surviving loved ones.

DWYER--Frances Turecamo, 85, of Manhasset, NY, passed peacefully at home on February 14, 2014 surrounded by her loving family. She was predeceased by her husband of 49 years, Matthew P. Dwyer, Sr. They were married in 1952. Born in Brooklyn and raised mostly on Long Island, she was the youngest child of Bartholdi and Marie (D'Albora) Turecamo, who both emigrated from Italy as children. Fran graduated with honors from Georgian Court College (New Jersey) in 1950. She raised her five children in Bay Shore, Manhasset, and Westhampton Beach. Fran was a beloved volunteer at St. Francis Hospital for 39 years. A devout Roman Catholic, Fran was perseverant, inspirational, and spirited. A true "Greatest Generation" mom, she cherished her children, Matthew, Jr. (Meg), James, Marie Adams, Frances Skeris (Russ), Catherine Ruddy (Mark), and adored her seven grandchildren, Jake and Molly Dwyer; Cate Brinch (Adam); Tyler Adams; Carl and Heidi Skeris; and Christopher Ruddy. She loved Long Island's shores and her dogs and will also be missed by her extended family and surviving friends. Visiting hours: Monday, February 17, 4-8pm at Fairchild Sons, Manhasset 516-627-2000. Mass Celebration: Tuesday, February 18, 12:30pm at St. Mary's, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be to St. Francis Hospital 516-562-6000 or Hospice Care Network, Woodbury, NY.

BRUSSEL--Bernice K.,95, died Friday. Beloved wife of the late Harrison. Loving mother of Anne Brooks and the late John Brussel. Also caring aunt to Betty (Ed) Shamas and Jane (David) Beam. Special thanks to her devoted caregivers Miriam Antoine and Gladys Matagaro. Service will be on Sunday February 16 at 1:30pm at Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains. Contributions in her memory will be appreciated by White Plains Hospital, Kol Ami's Fund for the Needy or Hospice of Westchester.

LEHRMAN--Nat. Nat Lehrman, 84, former associate publisher of Playboy magazine and president of the company's publishing division, died February 11, 2014, after struggling with Parkinson's disease for several years. He was instrumental in the writing of Hugh Hefner's Playboy Philosophy and he was a creator of the Playboy Foundation, which devoted itself to civil rights, women's rights and other social issues. He was the husband of Kazuko Miyajima Lehrman, whom he met while stationed in her native city of Nara, Japan, during the Korean War. She predeceased him. He was born in Brooklyn and was a graduate of Brooklyn College. During his years with Playboy, he lived in Chicago, where he was an active and avid tennis player. He loved opera and all music, especially classical and folk, and he was an accomplished guitar player. In retirement, he lived in Sarasota, FL. Intelligent, warm and witty, he was an exceptionally generous, kind and decent man. All who knew him, were charmed by him and became his devoted friends. His children, Cynthia Hochswender of Salisbury, CT, and Jerome and Makiko Lehrman of Irvine, CA; his grandchildren, Daniel Lehrman of Ann Arbor, MI, and Katharine Hochswender of Salisbury; and his companion, Jean Hadden, of Sarasota, will miss him but know that his death was a release from the disease that limited the independence that was so much a part of who he was. A memorial service will be held in Chicago at a later date. Memories, stories and messages for the family can be sent to: nat-lehrman. forevermissed.com

MURRAY--Paul Brady, of New Canaan, CT died on February 14, 2014 at his home. Mr. Murray was born in Brooklyn, NY, October 2, 1923 to the late Thomas and Marie Brady Murray. Paul Murray served as Lieutenant in the navy during WWII. After being discharged he married Anne McVoy of Chicago, IL in November 1946. He graduated from Fordham Law School and subsequently entered the family business, Murray Manufacturing. Later in his career he became President of the East New York Savings Bank following which he served in the same capacity with M&T Bank from which he retired. He was a member of the Order of Malta and the Knights of the Holy Sepulchre. He was also a member of Woodway Country Club, Ekwanok Country Club in Manchester, Vermont, and University Club in New York. In addition to his wife, Anne, Paul is survived by eight daughters and three sons, three brothers and one sister. Paul also leaves twenty-three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. The family will receive friends at Hoyt Funeral Home, New Canaan on Tuesday, February 18, from 57pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Wednesday, February 19, at 10:30am at St. Thomas More Church, Darien, CT. Interment will take place at a later date in Manchester, VT. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Paul's memory can be made to Crudem Foundation, PO Box 804, Ludlow, MA 01056.

CRAPSEY--Marcus Trowbridge, 92, died December 20, 2013. A University of Michigan alumnus, Marc worked for the UN in Thailand and South America. He later worked for IBM in New York and Paris. He is survived by Gay Bailey; children Marcus, Ana Maria and Malinee; Glyn Polson; and their families. Donations may be made to the unfoundation.org or unicefusa.org

FLEMING--Harold S. Diplomat, author and humanitarian, Hal Fleming died on February 4 in Great Falls, Virginia. A loyal friend to many, and loving husband of Arlene, father of Laura, Douglass, Craig and Harold Gordon, and grandfather of Max, Hal was born on April 21, 1931 in New Haven, Connecticut, the son of Harold S. and Edith Wormley Fleming. He graduated from Mount Hermon School, from Brown University and earned an M.A. in English Literature from Columbia University. Hal pursued many interests and talents enthusiastically throughout his life. From West Indian heritage, he developed a passion for all things British: literature, history, culture and sport. He built models, including an extensive 1940s era circus, remodeled houses, excelled at cooking and gardening. A prolific writer, his published works include several short stories and poems and two novels: The Brides' Fair, an intriguing story set in Morocco; and Once Upon A Storm, a Civil Rights era mystery. Hal's distinguished career in diplomacy and international development began at the U.S. Peace Corps (1966 72) where he directed public affairs and recruiting and was country director in Cote D'Ivoire, West Africa. As Executive Director of the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in the mid-1970s, he accomplished major management reforms. At the U.S. Agency for International Development (1978 83) as Mission Director in Morocco he introduced family planning and women's programs and participated in establishing an institute for renewable energy. As counselor for development at the U.S. Mission to the U.N. (1983 86) he negotiated U.S. positions on economic development and environmental protection, then at UNICEF (1986 92) he oversaw new child survival initiatives and helped launch major humanitarian assistance programs. From 1994 - 97, at the U.S. Department of State, as Deputy Assistant Secretary for International Organizations, he was in charge of policy and management of U.S. support to 80 U.N. and other international agencies and the creation of Relief Web, an Internet-based information management system for disaster response. He received numerous awards and throughout his career was appreciated as a kind and generous mentor. A memorial gathering is scheduled for April 27th at 4pm, in DACOR Bacon House, Washington, D.C. Contributions honoring Hal may be made to the U.S. Committee for UNICEF.
CEASAR--Sid. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear cousin Sid Ceasar, the greatest comedian of his time. Dr. Alex Greenberg, Dr. Bruce Greenberg, Mr. Jesse Greenberg and Families

GATCHELL--Marjorie, 81, died on Saturday in Hanover, NH, after a short illness. She was a longtime resident of Cambridge, MA, and a beloved member of the faculty of the Shady Hill School, where she nurtured many future teachers. She was survived by her sister, Elizabeth Bouton of Hilton Head, who died two days after Marjorie, by seven nieces and nephews, and by scores of devoted friends. She was predeceased by her sister Winifred Martin and brother William Montgomery Gatchell. Additional information is available by visiting www.rickerfuneralhome.com

HAGGERTY--Dr. Rita. The Child Mind Institute mourns the loss of our dear friend and colleague Dr. Rita Haggerty. Her legacy will live on in the outstanding cadre of pediatric neuropsychologists she trained and in the thousands of children whose lives she changed for the better. Harold S. Koplewicz, MD President Brooke Garber Neidich Chair

JORDON--Sydelle Gulkin, died peacefully February 8 at age 96 surrounded by her loving family. The most amazing mother of Lucie and Steve Kass, Dorothy Jordon and David Ferber and David and Madelyn Jordon, loving aunt of Carol Wolfe Breen, incredible grandmother of Glenn and Amber Schneider, Corey and Shari Schneider, Jordon Ferber and Alexius Diana, Haley and Greg Kraut, Jenny and Zach Messner and Shelby Jordon, and the greatest great-grandmother to Cooper, Riley, Jaxon, Jacob, Charlie and Isabella Schneider and Dillon and Charlie Kraut. She was predeceased by her husband, Charles Jordon, and two grandsons, Eric Schneider and Russell Ferber. She was the matriarch of our family: wise and gentle, kind and loving, supportive and so unbelievably smart. Special thanks to her caregivers, Jackie Stewart and Dorothy Pauling, who took such good care of her in recent years. Graveside services 1pm at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Queens, February 11. Donations in her memory to FJC/The Russell Ferber Foundation, 520 Eighth Ave., NY, NY 10018.

MIRRER--Gerald P.,MD. The Trustees and Staff of the New-York Historical Society express sincere condolences to our esteemed President and CEO Louise Mirrer and her family on the passing of her father, Gerald P. Mirrer, MD, who practiced internal medicine for forty-one years in Little Neck and North Shore Hospital, Manhasset. Pam B. Schafler, Chair of the Board Rick Reiss, Vice Chair Roger Hertog, Chair of the Executive Committee

MOND--Otto, 81, passed away on February 13, 2014. He was born in NYC on September 4, 1932, the youngest of three children. He graduated from Yeshiva University with a BA in Math, Hunter with a MA in Education, and NYU with a MS in Applied Math. He served in the US Army from 1956-58 specializing in computers, then worked for 35 years as a system analyst for IBM. He was an avid marathon runner competing in over 300 races including 40 marathons, of which 18 were consecutive NYC Marathons. The New York Times featured him in 2012 as "The 80 Year Old Marathon Man." Otto was a strong supporter of the Jewish community. He loved to participate in synagogue services and encouraged his family to follow in his footsteps. He was a loving husband to his wife, Gladys, and was featured on ABC's "Secrets to a Successful Marriage." He was a loving father to four children, a proud grandfather to 10 grandchildren, and a beloved brother to his two siblings. We will miss him dearly.

MIRRER--Gerald P.,MD, age 91. NYU Medical School '46. Surrounded by his beloved wife of 66 years, Mildred and children Brooks, Janet Terry, and Louise. Father-in-law of Kristine, Doug Terry and David Halle. Devoted grandfather to William, Meredith, Britt (Ben), Philip (Emily), Carla and Malcolm. Great-grandfather to Thomas. Practiced internal medicine for forty-one years in Little Neck and North Shore Hospital, Manhasset. Funeral private. Family requests that those wishing to make memorial donations direct them to the DiMenna Children's History Museum at the New-York Historical Society.

HOFFMAN--Deborah. The Aspen Music Festival and School grieves the loss of Deborah Hoffman. Deborah came to Aspen as a fellowship student in 1985 and became one of the great harpists of her time and a beloved member of our faculty. She was a radiant person, a brilliant musician and a wonderful teacher and mentor. We extend our condolences to her family, and husband and stepchildren, Roger, David and Rachel Nierenberg. From the faculty and staff of the Aspen Music Festival and School. Robert Spano, Music Director Alan Fletcher, President & CEO

JERESKI--Bernard. Beloved father of Laura, Elisabeth, Robert and Richard. Loving partner of Audrie. Adored grandfather of Madeleine, Daniel, Sophie and Rose. Funeral Service Monday, 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LEAVY--H. James, of Westport, CT, died peacefully on February 10, 2014, at the age of 83. Born on May 29, 1930, in New York, NY, James was the son of entrepreneur Samuel Leavy and social columnist Lena L. Leavy, and brother to predeceased Gerald Leavy, who passed away in 2012. Too young to enlist during WWII but greatly motivated to serve his country, James accelerated his studies by graduating from the Milton Academy one year early and matriculated to George Washington University. Upon graduation, James quickly enlisted in the United States Marine Corps, eventually rising to the rank of Lieutenant. James was stationed and fought in Korea during the first years of the Korean War and was later stationed in Tokyo and Hawaii. He was a proud Veteran who always extolled the greatness of America and its promise of freedom and democracy around the world. Upon returning to the United States, James began a successful career in the fashion industry serving in executive positions, first at Stern Brothers where he met a beautiful retail buyer, Emilia Anne Zemo, who went on to be his wife of nearly 60 years. James later worked at Colonial Corporation of the Gulf and Western Corp., and later in his career, at Mast Industries in Brookline, MA, where he was the Executive Vice President of Asian Operations. James was a loving husband, son, brother, father, and grandfather. He is survived by his wife Emilia Anne, five children Donald Leavy, Dana Langham, Daniel Leavy, Douglas Lowell, and David Leavy, and nine healthy and happy grandchildren Emily, Wesley, Jeremy, Caitlin, Megan, Christopher, Edward, Gavin and Gardiner. James was a voracious reader whose passions included history, politics, national security, international travel, horse racing, and his favorite New York Times Sunday crossword puzzle. James had a passion for Winston Churchill, whom he greatly admired for his mastery of emotive language, and was always handy with an appropriate Churchill quote for whatever the moment required. He was known to family, friends and colleagues for his sharp wit, booming voice, superior vocabulary, and cultured intellect. He will be greatly missed.

MUSE--Martha Twitchell. The board and staff of the Tinker Foundation Incorporated mourn the passing of its former Chairman and President, Martha T. Muse. She died on Sunday, February 9th, in Stuart, Florida after a brief illness. Martha was born in Dallas, Texas in 1926, the daughter of John Blackburn Muse and Kathryn Poole Burbank, but lived in New York City for most of her life. She maintained residences in New York City, Connecticut and Florida. Her principal interests focused on Latin America, but she contributed substantially to educational, corporate and non-profit areas. Martha was a founding director of the Tinker Foundation. She served as its president for 27 years and its chairman for 33 years, retiring in 2008. It was under her direction that the Foundation became a leading funder of Latin American-related activities providing support for educational, environmental, security, economic, legal and governance issues. Martha received her undergraduate degree from Barnard College in 1948 and a master's degree in political science from Columbia University in 1955. In 1981 she received an honorary doctorate from Georgetown University. She was the first woman elected as a trustee to Columbia University and was among the first women named to the Board of the New York Stock Exchange and the Council on Foreign Relations. She served on numerous corporate boards including The Bank of New York, May Department Stores, Sterling Drug Inc., ASARCO, ACF Industries and Associated Dry Goods. Her non-profit boards included the Americas Society, the Spanish Institute, and the Luso-American Development Foundation. For her many contributions to the field of Latin American relations she received numerous awards: Orden del Sol del Peru, Order of Bernardo O'Higgins (Chile), Order de Mayo al Merito (Argentina); Ordem Nacional do Cruzeiro do Sul (Brazil), and awards from the Spanish Institute and the Americas Society. She was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, the Colony Club, the Huguenot Society and the National Society of Colonial Dames. One of her final directives to the Tinker Foundation was incorporating Antarctica-related subjects under its funding mandate. Her support of Antarctica was recognized in 2009 by the establishment of the Muse Prize for Science and Policy in Antarctica, an award for mid-career Antarctic scientists and policy makers. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the late spring. Letters of inquiry and condolence may be sent to the Tinker Foundation, 55 E. 59th St., New York, NY 10022.

CHARAP--Bertram. Beloved husband of the late Elaine. Cherished companion of Natalie Krantz. Father of Mitchell, Peter and Arthur. Grandfather of Alexander, Rebecca, Joshua, Samuel, Joseph, Adrian and Andrew. Services at 11:30am Sunday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave.

FEKULA--Walter P.,passed away on February 7, 2014. Beloved husband of Beatrice, devoted father to Natalia, stepfather to Lisa and Christopher, grandfather to Eleanor and Beatrice. Born in New York City on May 25, 1936, Walter earned a Bachelor's degree from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania, then served in the United States Marine Corps before beginning a distinguished 40-year career on Wall Street. He retired as Manager of the Credit and Market Risk Department at CS First Boston. He was President and CEO of the Russian Children's Welfare Society since 2000, and served on Boards of several other foundations. Insightful, kind and generous, you brought much happiness to those around you. You will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held on February 20th at 11:00am at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street, New York City. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made in Walter's name to the Russian Children's Welfare Society, 16 West 32nd Street, #

MASTERSON--James F.,III, died February 11th, at age 58. Predeceased by his father, he is mourned deeply by his remaining family, including his mother Patricia, his sister Nancy, his brother Richard and his nephew Jamie and niece Rachel. He was a graduate of the Riverday Country Day School. Subsequently, through an accident, he was blinded and suffered brain injury. He contunued his education, earning a BS from Union College and finishing almost the entire graduate program at the Chicago School of Professional Psychology before his illness overcame him. He was always very special and will forever be remembered and loved.

CLARK--Margaret, age 97. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Clark; cherished mother of Edward and Jonathan. Adored grandmother of Matthew and Gregory, and her great-grandchildren Nathan, Mia and Norah. Margaret Clark was a wise, charming, beautiful and witty friend, and a loving beacon of light to her family. Although the times in which she lived limited the full expression of her talents as a female writer and musician, she yet accomplished a great deal in her brave quest for self-realization. Her superb mezzo-soprano voice was cherished by Congregation Beth Elohim, and by the Brooklyn Philharmonic Chorus under a variety of noted conductors. In her later years, Margaret became a docent with the Brooklyn Museum of Art, conducting guided tours through the entire Impressionist Gallery of the Museum. Hers were the gifts of love, beauty, compassion, wit and a deep knowledge and love for music and art. May the innate radiance of her soul combine with the Supernal Light of G-d, to shine forth for all Eternity. From her loving family

DeVITO MILIO--Estelle, MD, 93, died peacefully, on February 10, 2014 in Baltimore, MD. She is survived by three daughters from her marriage to the late A. Roger Milio: Dr. Lorraine (Rudy) Milio Marshall, of Columbia, MD; Diane (Tom) Milio Cocozza of Staten Island, NY; and Christine Milio of Wilton, CT, as well as five step-grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Estelle was a lifelong New Yorker, attending opera and Broadway shows regularly from a young age and determined to study medicine from childhood. She graduated from Barnard College in 1941 and NYU School of Medicine in 1944. She trained in Internal Medicine and Pediatrics, practicing Pediatrics for 12 years. She then trained in Child Psychiatry, retiring at age 84, having trained many residents and Child Psychiatry fellows along the way. She maintained an affiliation with NYU School of Medicine throughout her career and was a past-president of the Society of Bellevue Alumni. She was a seasoned world traveler and always loved adventure, near and far. She will be remembered as a devout Catholic, for her love of her daughters, her extended family and friends, and her dedication to medicine, especially all her child patients and her colleagues. Viewing will be at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, New York, NY 10010 on Sunday, February 16 from 6-9pm and on Monday, February 17 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass is at Epiphany Roman Catholic Church, 375 Second Avenue, New York, NY 10010 at 11am on Tuesday, February 18, followed by interment at Willowbrook Cemetery in Westport, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the NYU Child Study Center.

KRONISH--Sidney, on February 13th at the age of 101. Formerly of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved Son of Samuel and Ethel Kronish, Sibling of Ruth, Ben, Louis and Frieda, Grateful husband of Mildred Back Kronish. Proud father of Alec and grandfather of Louis. He received his BA and MA from NYU and his PhD. From the New School in NYC. Served as an Academic Economist; formerly chairperson of the Division of Social Science at Fairleigh Dickinson University and Executive Director of the New Jersey Council on Economic Education at Montclair State University. Past President of the Fairleigh Dickinson Chapter of the American Association of University Professors. Author of several books and many professional articles. Service Tuesday at 1:30pm at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ 07601.

BERNSTEIN--Hon. Aaron D.,"Cappy", died on February 9, at age 87. A graduate of West Point, Judge Bernstein served active duty in Korea. He graduated from Columbia Law School, and became a judge in 1975, serving with distinction on the Supreme Court until his retirement in 2002. He will be greatly missed by his loving wife, Florence; his children and grandchildren; and his many friends and colleagues.

BARTON--Hana Jane, teacher, professor, author and art educator of Bethesda, Maryland passed away on January 27, 2014. Jane taught in the Montgomery County, Maryland school system for over 20 years and was instrumental in establishing its Gifted and Talented program. After retiring in 1986, she served as an Adjunct professor of Education at George Washington University. She volunteered at NIH, served on the board of Suburban Hospital, coordinated volunteers at the Montgomery County Thrift Shop to benefit Planned Parenthood, and was a docent at the National Gallery, where she helped develop the "Art around the Corner" program for Washington, DC school children. Jane loved the Delaware shore, the National Gallery rotunda, her sons and daughters-in-law and her beloved grandchildren. Born in Tabor, Czechoslovakia on May 29, 1924, she wrote of her journey to the United States as a young woman in "With a Nugget in My Shoe" and "Collages". She married Frederick Hubert Barton on January 23, 1944 in Washington, DC. and they raised three sons in Old Greenwich, CT. She is predeceased by her husband Fred and her son Peter. She is survived by her second husband Irwin Aisenberg, her sons John and Tom, her daughters-in-laws Tina and Laura, and her grandchildren Fred, Kate, Jeffrey, Emily, Nicholas and Christopher. The Barton family will gather privately to celebrate Jane's life in Old Greenwich, CT.

BOGERT--Linda, 63 of Deerfield Beach, FL, passed away on February 12, 2014. Loving mother of Melissa, dear sister of Ned (Christine) Bogert and fiance of Jim. Funeral services to be held Sunday Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel. 954-427-6500. Please visit our guest register book www.levitt-weinstein.com
BRANDT--Dorothy C. Died February 5, 2014. Owner, Maybrant Boutique Inc. of Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. Beloved aunt of Jessica, Roberta and David Marshall. We will always miss you.

BELKIN WHITEHEAD--Hattie. Famed fashion retailer Hattie Belkin Whitehead, formally of Bloomfield Hills, Michigan and Palm Beach Florida died on February 8, 2014 in Manhattan. She was 74 years old. Hattie is survived by her two daughters, Elizabeth Belkin and Amanda Fiverson, her son-in-law Peter Fiverson, her granddaughters, Sloane and Nicki Fiverson, all of Short Hills, New Jersey. She is also survived by her ex-husband Gareth Whitehead of Las Vegas and so many wonderful friends and colleagues. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to be sent to Columbia New York Presbyterian Hospital in memory of Hattie Whitehead.

BONNARD--Robert Andrew. Actor/ Director/ Playwright died January 23, 2014, age 87, after long illness. Born Robert Videbeck, December 6, 1926 in Elk Horn, Iowa, son of Rev. and Mrs. Christian Videbeck. Won Obie 1967 for Distinguished Performance in Ionesco's "The Chairs." Show Business Award for direction of "Candaules, Commissioner" by Daniel Gerould 1970 with Chelsea Theater Center, NY. Graduated American Academy of Dramatic Arts, 1949, taught State University of Iowa 1959-1962 and at University of Arkansas 1965-1966. Wrote several plays including "They Saw The Whole Zoo", "My Friend Weissman Is Back", "A Passion for Apollo, "The Harrowing", and "Van Gogh's Ear", performed around the country and abroad. Was Member of the Players Club, NY for many years. Last fully staged performance 1998 with Pirates Playhouse, Sanibel Island, Florida, as Caesar in Shaw's "Androcles And The Lion". Death was due to continued failing health after removal of cancerous right vocal cord 2001. He is survived by his brother, William Videbeck, of Brooklyn."

LEAVY--H. James, of Westport, CT, died peacefully on February 10, 2014, at the age of 83. Born on May 29, 1930, in New York, NY, James was the son of entrepreneur Samuel Leavy and social columnist Lena L. Leavy, and brother to predeceased Gerald Leavy, who passed away in 2012. Too young to enlist during WWII but greatly motivated to serve his country, James accelerated his studies by graduating from the Milton Academy one year early and matriculated to George Washington University. Upon graduation, James quickly enlisted in the United States Marine Corps, eventually rising to the rank of Lieutenant. James was stationed and fought in Korea during the first years of the Korean War and was later stationed in Tokyo and Hawaii. He was a proud Veteran who always extolled the greatness of America and its promise of freedom and democracy around the world. Upon returning to the United States, James began a successful career in the fashion industry serving in executive positions, first at Stern Brothers where he met a beautiful retail buyer, Emilia Anne Zemo, who went on to be his wife of nearly 60 years. James later worked at Colonial Corporation of the Gulf and Western Corp., and later in his career, at Mast Industries in Brookline, MA, where he was the Executive Vice President of Asian Operations. James was a loving husband, son, brother, father, and grandfather. He is survived by his wife Emilia Anne, five children Donald Leavy, Dana Langham, Daniel Leavy, Douglas Lowell, and David Leavy, and nine healthy and happy grandchildren Emily, Wesley, Jeremy, Caitlin, Megan, Christopher, Edward, Gavin and Gardiner. James was a voracious reader whose passions included history, politics, national security, international travel, horse racing, and his favorite New York Times Sunday crossword puzzle. James had a passion for Winston Churchill, whom he greatly admired for his mastery of emotive language, and was always handy with an appropriate Churchill quote for whatever the moment required. He was known to family, friends and colleagues for his sharp wit, booming voice, superior vocabulary, and cultured intellect. He will be greatly missed.

KLIEGMAN--Dora "Dutchy", died peacefully in her sleep Thursday, February 13, in Sarasota, FL at age 105. She is survived by daughters Mickie Kaye, Judith Stanton; grandchildren Jonathan Kaye, Juli Oberdorf, Craig Stanton; five great-grandchildren. A true life force, affectionately called 'Nana' by many.

MANTEL--Howard N.,died unexpectedly on February 6, 2014. He was born June 4, 1930 to Dr. Samuel Lewis and Lillian Stigbigel Mantel. Raised in Brooklyn, he attended Brooklyn College (1951) and Columbia University Law School (1956). Law school was interrupted by service in the army where, among other assignments, he worked in the White House as a stenographer. He served as Director of Government Programs, Corporate Secretary and General Counsel for the Institute of Public Administration (1960 to 1993). From 1972 to 1975, he directed the Urban Analysis Center at CUNY. One of the highlights of his career was drafting the constitution for the Northern Mariana Islands. He was admitted to practice in the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands, the US District Court, the Northern Mariana Islands, and the US Supreme Court (1960). He was a member of the Board of the Professional Examination Service, NYC (1972-1989). Board member of the Non-profit Coordinating Community (1984-1988). Member of the Bar of the City of New York and the American Society of Public Administration, president of New York Chapter (1970). His interests included Japanese wood block and other prints. At the time of his death, he was on the Board of the Print Club of New York and previously served on the Board of the Japenese Art Society of America. He was previously married to Suzanne B. Vircik. Howard N. Mantel will be sorely missed by his wife Anita Mantel, son John Marshall, daughter-in-law Jean, and adoring grandchildren Lillian and Chester. Howard leaves behind his brother Kenneth Mantel (Linda), sisters Linda Rose (Herbert) and Gail Zacot (Yves), niece Ellen and nephew Neal. Donations in Howard's honor to be directed to the Brooklyn Museum.

GELLMAN--Stephen G.,The partners, associates and personnel of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz mourn with sorrow the passing of their colleague and friend, Stephen G. Gellman. Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz

Glickman--Barbara Ziet. Passed away on February 16, 2014. A graduate of Finch College, Bradford College, and the Kew Forest School, she taught in the New York City public school system for over 30 years, frequently at P.S. 6. She was married for over 50 years to her soul mate, Richard and was a devoted mother and grandmother. Recipient of the Jessica Cosgrave Award, she was active in the Finch Alumnae Assoc. She was a board member of the Women's Auxiliary at Temple Emanu-El and a gifted and enthusiastic speaker who lectured at Mt Sinai Hospital. She is survived by her children Andrew and Suzanne, daughter-in-law Julie Cohen, grandson Eli Glickman, and her sister Sondra Percy. Services Wednesday, February 19, 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St. Donations in her memory may be made to the Barbara Glickman Fund at the Temple Emanu-El Religious School.

RECHELBACHER--Horst,The Lauder family, The Estee Lauder Companies and Aveda are deeply saddened by the loss of Horst Rechelbacher, founder of Aveda, the pioneering and visionary prestige hair care brand he created in 1978. Our heartfelt condolences go to his family and many friends. Horst Rechelbacher was a trailblazer in the world of beauty and beyond. In 1978, he created Aveda with the ambition of developing prestige beauty products that would care for professionals, their guests and the environment through the power of pure flower and plant essences. Thanks to Horst's passion and vision, Aveda became a lifestyle and a global movement. He brought a caring high-touch experience to the salon industry, and was a pioneer of environmental responsibility. We are proud that Aveda joined the Estee Lauder Companies family in 1997, and are honored to nurture the incredible brand that Horst created. He will be greatly missed by so many for whom he was, and will continue to be, an inspiration. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus William P. Lauder, Executive Chairman Fabrizio Freda, President and CEO Dominique Conseil, Global President, Aveda

GELLMAN--Stephen G.,56, passed away on February 15, 2014, surrounded by his loving family. Beloved husband of Wendy Rosenthal Gellman, loving and devoted father to Lindsay and Alexa. Cherished son of Florence and the late Jerome Gellman, son-in-law of Joseph and Elinor Rosenthal, brother of Elyse (William) Greenbaum and Kenneth (Melissa) Gellman, brother-in-law of Jonathan Rosenthal, and devoted uncle. Brilliant attorney and caring friend who lived his life with humility, grace, and consideration for everyone he touched. A partner of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. Graduate of Haverford College and Stanford Law School, where he was a member of the Law Review and the Board of Visitors. Passionate athlete. His kindness and generosity made the world a better place. Our hearts are broken. He will be forever missed. Funeral service Tuesday, February 18th, 11am, at Temple Emanu-El, 65th Street at 5th Ave., New York City.

O'NEILL--Grover, Jr. The O'Neill family deeply regrets and mourns the passing of beloved Grover O'Neill, Jr. on February 14, 2014 at the age of 91. Grover, known to his friends as Bill, was a graduate of St. Mark's School, class of 1940, and a graduate of Harvard College, class of 1944. He served in the United States Army, Field Artillery from 1943-46 and was a First Lieutenant. Mr. O'Neill was a successful businessman for more than half a century. He joined Meriwether Capital as a Vice President in 1982 and remained active through 2013. During the 1970s, he had been president of two investment advisory organizations, Piedmont Advisory Corporation and Lexington Management Corporation. Before these, his positions included Managing Partner of Wood Walker & Company and General Partner in charge of the Advisory and Research department at Fahnestock & Company. He was a Trustee of St. Barnabas Hospital from 1960 through 2012, and Chairman of its Board from 1991 to 1997; a member of the Council of the Episcopal Diocese of New York from 1967 to 1971; a Trustee of St. Luke's Hospital from 1970 to 1976; and the Director of the Arthur Emerton Orvis Foundation, Inc. since 1968, and its President from 1990 until 2012. Bill is survived by his loving family: wife Elizabeth; daughter Carol O'Neill (Carey Battersby); son Tim O'Neill (Donna); stepchildren Melinda Mackay (Richard Essebag), Michael Mackay (Meggan) and grandchildren William O'Neill, Eliza Sommerville (Gavin), Kate Tuthill (Andrew), James Wendell (Meredith Weinberg), Zoe Mackay, and Hannah Mackay, and two great-grandchildren, Marilyn and Cormac Sommerville. A memorial service will be held in the spring.

STEVENS--Joseph C.,a prominent experimental psychologist and longtime member of the Yale University faculty, died unexpectedly but peacefully on February 7, 2014, at his home in New Haven, CT. He was 84. Dr. Stevens was widely known for his work investigating human sensory perception using principles of psychophysics. Psychophysics refers to methods for quantifying what a person can perceive through the senses, such as the smallest noticeable concentration of an odor or the physical intensity of a sound perceived to be louder than another. Dr. Stevens was born on February 28, 1929 in Grand Rapids, MI, and graduated from Calvin College in Grand Rapids with an A.B. in Biology in 1951. He began his graduate studies at Michigan State University, earning an M.A. in psychology in 1953, and continued them at Harvard University, where he worked under the supervision of S.S. Stevens (not a relation), a founder of modern psychophysics. He received a Ph.D. from Harvard in 1957, and then continued at Harvard as an instructor and assistant professor of psychology until 1966, when he joined the John B. Pierce Laboratory, an independent research institute in New Haven affiliated with Yale University. Dr. Stevens was appointed as fellow at the Pierce Laboratory and as research associate (later, senior research scientist) and lecturer in psychology at Yale. At the Pierce Laboratory, he established its psychology-psychophysics group, which expanded under his leadership to six faculty scientists plus numerous supporting scientists, staff and students. The group quickly became recognized as a world-class center for research on human sensory processes, publishing, over a period of three decades, more than 500 articles, books, and other scientific and scholarly works. Notable among Dr. Stevens's many scientific findings was evidence of how aging blunts sensory perception, especially in touch, taste, and smell. Dr. Stevens found, for example, that many elderly individuals cannot detect the odor-warning agent added to natural gas. For his work on aging in smell and taste, Dr. Stevens received a special Merit Award Grant from the National Institute on Aging of the National Institutes of Health. In addition to these scientific activities, Dr. Stevens taught and mentored scores of students at Yale. Dr. Stevens led an active life in New Haven surrounded by many friends and coworkers. Shortly after joining the faculty at Yale, he became a fellow of its Jonathan Edwards College, where for two decades he lived as a resident fellow. He is remembered for his loyalty to the college and for reaching out to its undergraduate students and counseling them. He was also a devout member of Christ Church, New Haven, and enjoyed the Yale Repertory Theater, the Yale Cabaret, good restaurants, classical music and Shakespeare's plays. An avid bike rider who also enjoyed hiking and skiing, he nevertheless donated considerable time to many causes, actively helping others. He was also devoted to his large extended family. He was one of six siblings, who included the late Joan Stevens VanderPloeg, Esther Stevens Wisse and Henry Ghysels Stevens. He is survived by two sisters, Miriam Stevens Loomis of East Lansing, MI, and Judith Stevens Hooker, and her husband, Robert L. Hooker, of East Grand Rapids MI, as well as fifteen nieces and nephews and 35 great-nieces and nephews. They, as well as his colleagues and friends, will miss his warmth, his kindness and his generosity of spirit. Memorial Services will be held at Christ Church (Episcopal) in New Haven on April 5 at 11:00am and in Grand Rapids at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Community Foundation of Greater New Haven or Calvin College.

DORFMAN--Sid, Celebrated sports writer Sid Dorfman, whose career covering New Jersey high school sports spanned 79 years and made him an enduring fixture in the states sports community, died Saturday at his home. He was 94. Dorfman was only 15 when he went to work as a high school sports correspondent for the Morning Ledger, predecessor to The Star-Ledger. Three years later, in 1938, at the behest of The Star-Ledger, he took over an independent bureau in Newark that was providing the newspaper with coverage of local sports and news. He would run it for the next 76 years. Today, that bureau, Dorf Feature Service, continues to service The Star-Ledger, its sister regional New Jersey newspapers, and its digital property, NJ.com, with what has long been regarded as the most comprehensive high school sports coverage in the country. In addition to chronicling the accomplishments of student-athletes and coaches, Dorfman wrote a general sports column for The Star-Ledger and won numerous writing awards. In 1998, he was inducted into the New Jersey Sports Hall of Fame. Early in his career, while also running Dorf Feature Service, he was a makeup editor and sat on the sports copy desk at The Star-Ledger. He also covered boxing and became the newspaper's first golf writer. As a general sports columnist, he wrote frequently on local and national amateur and professional sports. He retired as a columnist only several months ago due to declining health. Dorfman influenced generations of journalists who started their careers at Dorf Feature Service. The bureau's versatile coverage also included New Jersey college sports, town news, education, harness and thoroughbred racing, amateur and professional golf and tennis, New Jersey society, and obituaries. In the 1970s, he successfully campaigned for a high school football playoff system that would identify sectional state champions on the field of play, replacing ranking systems that declared champions on the basis of mathematical formulas. He also pushed for a realignment of high school sports conferences to promote a more fair and demographically balanced competitive environment. Led by Dorfman, The Star-Ledger was the first newspaper in the metropolitan area to provide comprehensive coverage of girls' high school sports. He also introduced Top 20 team rankings and All-State honor teams to the coverage. Dorfman, a former president of the New Jersey Sports Writers Association and a recipient of its Distinguished Service Award, was inducted into the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association Hall of Fame in 1999. The NJSIAA isstate's governing body of high school sports. Surviving are his wife, Marianne; his daughter, Rhoda; his son, Gary, and his wife, Marianne Dorfman; his son, Joseph; his grandson, Scott, and his wife, Elana Dorfman; and grandchildren, Jessica Dorfman and Lael Dorfman. Sid was also predeceased by his grandson, Jason. Services will be held Tuesday at 1pm at Temple Beth AhmYisrael, 60 Temple Drive, Springfield, NJ. Services are by BernheimApterKreitzman Funeral Chapel, Livingston, NJ.

DWYER--Frances Turecamo, 85, of Manhasset, NY, passed peacefully at home on February 14, 2014 surrounded by her loving family. She was predeceased by her husband of 49 years, Matthew P. Dwyer, Sr. They were married in 1952. Born in Brooklyn and raised mostly on Long Island, she was the youngest child of Bartholdi and Marie (D'Albora) Turecamo, who both emigrated from Italy as children. Fran graduated with honors from Georgian Court College (New Jersey) in 1950. She raised her five children in Bay Shore, Manhasset, and Westhampton Beach. Fran was a beloved volunteer at St. Francis Hospital for 39 years. A devout Roman Catholic, Fran was perseverant, inspirational, and spirited. A true "Greatest Generation" mom, she cherished her children, Matthew, Jr. (Meg), James, Marie Adams, Frances Skeris (Russ), Catherine Ruddy (Mark), and adored her seven grandchildren, Jake and Molly Dwyer; Cate Brinch (Adam); Tyler Adams; Carl and Heidi Skeris; and Christopher Ruddy. She loved Long Island's shores and her dogs and will also be missed by her extended family and surviving friends. Visiting hours: Monday, February 17, 4-8pm at Fairchild Sons, Manhasset 516-627-2000. Mass Celebration: Tuesday, February 18, 12:30pm at St. Mary's, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be to St. Francis Hospital 516-562-6000 or Hospice Care Network, Woodbury, NY.

While she will be greatly missed, her charm, generosity, and kindness will live on in the hearts of her family and friends. Kate is survived by her husband, Leonard; sons Lionel (Jill) and Lowell (Sarah); grandson William; and beloved sister, Margaret Hitchman. A service will be held Friday, February 21 at 10:30am at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89 Street, New York, NY 10128. In lieu of flowers, we ask that you donate to a charity of your choice.

ZECKENDORF--William Jr.,84, died on February 12, 2014 in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Born in Manhattan on October 31, 1929, William Zeckendorf transformed the skyline of New York City and pioneered in changing the urban landscape of the city from Union Square to the Upper West Side. It is with deep love and admiration that we honor the life of our father and celebrate him as our devoted mentor. His brilliance in defining the future for neglected and decaying urban neighborhoods is legendary. When the Upper West Side was far distant from what it is today, William Zeckendorf built The Columbia at West 96th Street and Broadway, a development that undeniably helped to spur a West Side residential renaissance that continues today. He also built some of New York City's finest luxury developments including the Park Belvedere, Vanderbilt and Central Park Place. In midtown, William Zeckendorf built the elegant Four Seasons Hotel, and 4 Columbus Circle, a commercial building that stood alone, long before the successful destination that Columbus Circle has become. Downtown, Union Square could hardly be seen as the vibrant area that it is now. Zeckendorf Towers, envisioned by William Zeckendorf in the 1980's, led the way for the thriving 21st Century commercial and residential neighborhood that Union Square is today. The flourishing Eighth Avenue corridor is due in large measure to what William Zeckendorf saw and accomplished in his development of Worldwide Plaza, well before others followed with new developments now lining the Avenue. Worldwide Plaza was perhaps New York City's first genuine modern mixed use development combining corporate office headquarters with residential, cultural and theater facilities along with a mid-block public plaza. Other major projects included the Ronald Reagan Office Building in Washington, D.C. He was a man of great taste and culture, having served for over 50 years as an esteemed member of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin. His passion for the arts and education leave a lasting legacy from New York to Santa Fe. His quarter century of service to Long Island University preceded his deep commitment to philanthropy in his role as Founding Director of the Lensic Performing Arts Center in Santa Fe and his passionate support of The Santa Fe Opera, the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, Christus St. Vincent Hospital and the College of Santa Fe. William Zeckendorf contributed his great vision to the City of New York and its residents, who benefit enormously every day from his lifetime of achievements. He is survived by his wife, Nancy, his sister Susan Zeckendorf Nicholson, his sons Arthur Zeckendorf and William Lie Zeckendorf and two grandchildren. We are forever thankful and grateful for the wonderful lesson your life has been for us. A memorial service will be held in New York City on March 5th, and on March 29th in Sante Fe, New Mexico. Donations in his memory may be made to the Lensic Performing Arts Center, 211 West San Francisco Street, Santa Fe, New Mexico 87501. Arthur Zeckendorf William Lie Zeckendorf

O'NEILL--Grover, Jr. The O'Neill family deeply regrets and mourns the passing of beloved Grover O'Neill, Jr. on February 14, 2014 at the age of 91. Grover, known to his friends as Bill, was a graduate of St. Mark's School, Class of 1940, and a graduate of Harvard College, Class of 1944. He served in the United States Army, Field Artillery from 1943-46 and was a First Lieutenant. Mr. O'Neill was a successful businessman for more than half a century. He joined Meriwether Capital as a Vice President in 1982 and remained active through 2013. During the 1970s, he had been president of two investment advisory organizations, Piedmont Advisory Corporation and Lexington Management Corporation. Before these, his positions included Managing Partner of Wood Walker & Company and General Partner in charge of the Advisory and Research department at Fahnestock & Company. He was a Trustee of St. Barnabas Hospital from 1960 through 2012, and Chairman of its Board from 1991 to 1997; a member of the Council of the Episcopal Diocese of New York from 1967 to 1971; a Trustee of St. Luke's Hospital from 1970 to 1976; and the Director of the Arthur Emerton Orvis Foundation, Inc. since 1968, and its President from 1990 until 2012. Predeceased by his first wife Kathryn, Bill is survived by his loving family: wife Elizabeth; daughter Carol O'Neill (Carey Battersby); son Tim O'Neill (Donna); stepchildren Melinda Mackay (Richard Essebag), Michael Mackay (Meggan) and grandchildren William O'Neill, Eliza Sommerville (Gavin), Kate Tuthill (Andrew), James Wendell (Meredith Weinberg), Zoe Mackay, and Hannah Mackay, and two great-grandchildren, Marilyn and Cormac Sommerville and his sister Catharine Heyes, brother George O'Neill (Abby) and eight nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held in the spring.

RECHELBACHER--Horst,The Lauder family, The Estee Lauder Companies and Aveda are deeply saddened by the loss of Horst Rechelbacher, founder of Aveda, the pioneering and visionary prestige hair care brand he created in 1978. Our heartfelt condolences go to his family and many friends. Horst Rechelbacher was a trailblazer in the world of beauty and beyond. In 1978, he created Aveda with the ambition of developing prestige beauty products that would care for professionals, their guests and the environment through the power of pure flower and plant essences. Thanks to Horst's passion and vision, Aveda became a lifestyle and a global movement. He brought a caring high-touch experience to the salon industry, and was a pioneer of environmental responsibility. We are proud that Aveda joined the Estee Lauder Companies family in 1997, and are honored to nurture the incredible brand that Horst created. He will be greatly missed by so many for whom he was, and will continue to be, an inspiration. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus William P. Lauder, Executive Chairman Fabrizio Freda, President and CEO Dominique Conseil, Global President, Aveda

LOWY--Sylvia. Born Sidi Rosenberg in Valea Viseului, Romania, Sylvia was a Holocaust survivor dedicated to preserving her family's memory. After coming to the United States in 1950, Sylvia and her husband Simon built their lives in the Bronx. A devoted mother, sister, aunt, and grandmother, Sylvia was a friend to all who knew her and was adored by everyone who crossed her path. Sylvia died as she lived, surrounded by the conversation of visiting family and friends. Sylvia is survived by her husband Simon, son William, daughter-in-law Reva, grandchildren Jenna, Adina, and Matthew, and brother Eugene Rosenberg. May her memory be a blessing.

DORFMAN--Sid, Celebrated sports writer Sid Dorfman, whose career covering New Jersey high school sports spanned 79 years and made him an enduring fixture in the states sports community, died Saturday at his home. He was 94. Dorfman was only 15 when he went to work as a high school sports correspondent for the Morning Ledger, predecessor to The Star-Ledger. Three years later, in 1938, at the behest of The Star-Ledger, he took over an independent bureau in Newark that was providing the newspaper with coverage of local sports and news. He would run it for the next 76 years. Today, that bureau, Dorf Feature Service, continues to service The Star-Ledger, its sister regional New Jersey newspapers, and its digital property, NJ.com, with what has long been regarded as the most comprehensive high school sports coverage in the country. In addition to chronicling the accomplishments of student-athletes and coaches, Dorfman wrote a general sports column for The Star-Ledger and won numerous writing awards. In 1998, he was inducted into the New Jersey Sports Hall of Fame. Early in his career, while also running Dorf Feature Service, he was a makeup editor and sat on the sports copy desk at The Star-Ledger. He also covered boxing and became the newspaper's first golf writer. As a general sports columnist, he wrote frequently on local and national amateur and professional sports. He retired as a columnist only several months ago due to declining health. Dorfman influenced generations of journalists who started their careers at Dorf Feature Service. The bureau's versatile coverage also included New Jersey college sports, town news, education, harness and thoroughbred racing, amateur and professional golf and tennis, New Jersey society, and obituaries. In the 1970s, he successfully campaigned for a high school football playoff system that would identify sectional state champions on the field of play, replacing ranking systems that declared champions on the basis of mathematical formulas. He also pushed for a realignment of high school sports conferences to promote a more fair and demographically balanced competitive environment. Led by Dorfman, The Star-Ledger was the first newspaper in the metropolitan area to provide comprehensive coverage of girls' high school sports. He also introduced Top 20 team rankings and All-State honor teams to the coverage. Dorfman, a former president of the New Jersey Sports Writers Association and a recipient of its Distinguished Service Award, was inducted into the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association Hall of Fame in 1999. The NJSIAA isstate's governing body of high school sports. Surviving are his wife, Marianne; his daughter, Rhoda; his son, Gary, and his wife, Marianne Dorfman; his son, Joseph; his grandson, Scott, and his wife, Elana Dorfman; and grandchildren, Jessica Dorfman and Lael Dorfman. Sid was also predeceased by his grandson, Jason. Services will be held Tuesday at 1pm at Temple Beth AhmYisrael, 60 Temple Drive, Springfield, NJ. Services are by BernheimApterKreitzman Funeral Chapel, Livingston, NJ.

Pina Bausch’s Tanztheater Wuppertal took its “1980” back to the Sadler’s Wells in London after 32 years.
The St. Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra, which Yuri Temirkanov has led since 1988, played at Carnegie Hall last week.

Sabina Sciubba of Brazilian Girls has released her solo debut album, “Toujours,” and Ben Chasny and Donovan Quinn, as New Bums, have done “Voices in a Rented Room.”

A Russian male has a 1-in-4 chance of dying before he turns 55 years old, compared with a 1-in-11 chance for American men. Blame the vodka and cigarettes.
A gas cloud that has been hurtling toward the center of the Milky Way is expected to collide with a black hole, an exciting experience for astronomers.

MacCOWATT Haskell P.,April 15, 1931February 16, 2014 of Summit, NJ and Edgartown, MA, passed away peacefully on Sunday, February 16, 2014. He was 82. Born April 15, 1931 in Plainfield, NJ. He received an AB from Colgate University and a MS from MIT Sloan School of Management. He began his career at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn (BBDO) as a copywriter and account executive. He later joined CBS Inc. in New York, where he worked for 26 years, including serving as Vice President Investor Relations, Vice President and Treasurer, and retired as Senior Vice President of Administration in 1988. Throughout his life, he was active in a variety of civic, cultural and educational organizations. He was President of the Summit Common Council, Chairman of the Board of the Visual Arts Center of New Jersey, President of the Board of the Reeves Reed Arboretum and a trustee of the Summit Area Public Foundation. He was a Trustee Emeritus of Colgate University. He was President of the Edgartown Reading Room, President and a Trustee Emeritus of the Martha's Vineyard Preservation Trust and a trustee of the Edgartown Yacht Club. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Margaret Gentles MacCowatt, son Thomas H. MacCowatt (Anne L.), daughters Nancy M. Sanford, and Sally M. Black (Josiah M.) and seven grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in Paul's memory may be made to the Martha's Vineyard Preservation Trust or Colgate University.

RAUCCI--Pete. Died peacefully on February 17, 2014 aged 90, after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was a WWII Veteran of the United States Navy, and a stalwart of the Life Saving Service of the City of New York. Possessing imposing physical prowess, he was active in sporting activities with a love for swimming, up to his 80s. He was a man of many talents, including a facility for poetry developed in his 70s. Loved by all, Pete is survived by brothers Louis and Angelo, sons Robert and Richard, and grandchildren Tarek, Omar, Faris, Keith and Jaime.

SCHWARTZ--Barbara Ellen, 70, of Armonk, NY, and New York City, died peacefully on February 17, 2014 in her home in Armonk, with her husband Allen and daughter Lara by her side. Barbara, known to all as "Baba", was born May 19, 1943 to Raymond and Miriam Robinson. Baba and two brothers, Don and Jim, grew up in Mt. Vernon, NY. At sixteen, she met Allen. Following graduation from A.B. Davis High School, she studied business and merchandising at the Fashion Institute of Technology. She subsequently completed Bachelor and Master degrees in business at New York University. Baba taught in New York City intermediate schools and Head Start Programs, and then at Lehman College of CUNY. She embarked on a career in the family real estate business in 1974 as an owner and manager. Wherever Baba went, the party followed. She had a palpable passion for life and was always surrounded by family and friends. Generous in every way, she was a proud and steadfast election volunteer for nearly a generation. Baba was a supporter of Wounded Warriors, the Israeli Defense Forces, the Bruce Museum, and the Hole in the Wall Gang Camps, amongst other causes. A lover of tennis, she cherished her days on the court, and looked forward to the US Open and all other major tennis events. Baba is survived by her husband Allen Schwartz of Armonk, NY, and daughter Lara (Schwartz) D'Agostino, son-in-law Dr. Mark D'Agostino, and grandchildren Tyler and Ariella of Katonah, NY. She is also survived by two brothers, Donald Robinson of Rolling Meadows, IL, and James Robinson of Woodstock, NY, as well as numerous cousins, nieces, nephews, and extended family in New York, Pennsylvania, and California. Baba leaves behind a very large network of friends who have supported and enveloped her and her family beyond all expectations. The love and selflessness extended by friends during Baba's battle with cancer has been truly humbling and is reflective of the love that Baba has shown to others, and the quality of her character. Funeral services will be held Thursday, February 20, 2014, 10am, at Congregation B'Nai Yisrael, 2 Banksville Rd, Armonk, NY. Burial services to follow at Middle Patent Rural Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the American Cancer Society.

Rosenblatt--Sheila Urban Pathways notes with great sorrow the passing of Sheila Rosenblatt, former Board member and longtime supporter of the drive to end homelessness. Sheila was a force of nature, whose intellect was as sharp as her heart was full. Her commitment to a more just society, as well as her love of New York City, will inspire us always. SEDLIS--Alexander, MD, Professor Emeritus of Obstetrics and Gynecology at SUNY Downstate College of Medicine died peacefully at home at the age of 92 on February 17, 2014. Alik, as he was known to his family and friends was married for 71 years to his beloved wife Emilia (Mila) who died in 2012. Alik was born May 17, 1921 in Vilna (now Vilnius) where he entered medical school in 1939. He and Mila were survivors of the Vilna ghetto and after World War II made their way to Rome where they both graduated from medical school in 1949. They arrived in New York City in November 1949. He completed his internship and residency in Obstetrics and Gynecology at Cumberland Hospital, graduated from the New York University School of Medicine postgraduate course for Foreign Medical Graduates, and then became a member the faculty at New York Medical College in the department of Obstetrics and Gynecology. He joined the department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at SUNY Downstate in 1980 as Professor and later as Professor emeritus specializing in the field of Gynecologic Oncology where he was recognized for his development of a staging system for cervical cancer, the Sedlis criteria. Amazingly, Alik continued teaching, writing and reviewing scientific papers, seeing patients and running a clinic until the age of 91. Survived by sons Steven and Daniel, daughters-in-law Melissa and Cynthia, grandchildren Elizabeth and Jeb Singer, Jenny and Ben Homrighausen, Julia and Sam Cooper, and Lucy, sister-in-law, Joanna, niece and nephew, Anya, James and Amy, and great-nephews, Aaron and Jared. Donations in Alik's memory may be made to your favorite charity.

ROSENBLATT--Jay S.,passed away early on the morning of February 16 at the age of 90. Born in the East Bronx on November 18th, Jay was a scientist, a psychoanalyst, and an artist. In a long scientific career that included a 17 year directorship of the Institute of Animal Behavior at Rutgers, Jay received numerous honors and awards. Among the first to study the role of hormones, the brain and experience in the regulation of mothering, Jay laid the groundwork for a field of inquiry, the psychobiology of mammalian maternal behavior. His many students, post-docs, and younger colleagues benefited enormously from his professional and personal guidance, and his influence continues through them and their students. For much of his career Jay also saw patients in his Upper West Side apartment, wishing to maintain a balance between the theoretical and practical aspects of psychology. As a high school student, Jay studied art through the Works Progress Administration. He served in WWII as a camouflage artist, and painting remained important to him throughout his life. Jay was married to Gilda Rosenblatt (nee Rosen) until her death in 1999. He is survived by his second wife, Pat, his children Daniel and Nina, and his grandchildren Olivia and Susannah. A memorial service will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Friday February 21 at 1:30.

Preceded in death by his parents Joseph and Dorothy. Herb was a graduate of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and cum laude from Harvard Law School. After serving as an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, Herb co-founded the law firm now known as Kantor Davidoff Mandelker Twoomey Gallanty & Olnick, P.C. where he practiced until his retirement in December 2013. Herb was an avid tennis player, skier and rollerblader. He was a brilliant, loving and kind man who will live in our hearts and thoughts forever. COHEN--Mickey. We mourn the passing of Mickey Cohen on February 14, 2014. Beloved husband of Shelley. Proud father of Elliot and his wife Debbie. Adoring grandfather of Matthew and Rachel and loving brother of Renee. He fought a long and courageous battle and will be missed.

GREENBERG--Natalie, of NYC passed away suddenly on February 15, 2014 in her home. She is survived by her adoring husband, Len, and two daughters Susan (Steven) Gold and Dr. Rise Kass (Dr. Don Millner) as well as by six beautiful grandchildren, the pride of her life: Hannah (affianced to Benji Jack), Remy, Jake, Matt, Ilana and Stephanie. Natalie was a beloved High School English teacher of vocational students, first at Woodrow Wilson High School, then at August Martin High School and finally at Murray Bergtraum High School and began her career in the elementary grades. Over her career, it is estimated she educated about 5000 New York City school students, instilling in them her love of Shakespeare, poetry and reading. Natalie was an accomplished cook and a brilliant entertainer, who worked her way through Julia Child's famed cookbook long before doing so became part of popular culture and she could tell a bawdy joke with split-second timing, surprising her dinner guests every time. From a childhood tinged with loss and struggle, Natalie honed a unique resiliency and a strong independent streak which informed her outlook on life and provided inspiration to her family and students to be positive and persevere, despite troubles. She lived fully and without a hint of regret about paths not taken, for she had taken every turn she ever desired. Funeral services were held on Tuesday, February 18 at noon in Brooklyn. Tributes may be made to Deborah Hospital Foundation www.deborahfoundation.org, Temple Sinai of Roslyn www.templesinairoslyn.org or to Brooklyn Heights Synagogue www.bhsbrooklyn.org.

GLICKMAN--Bernard, beloved husband of Sondra Robinson Glickman, died on February 9, 2014. Bernard was devoted to his sons, Joseph and Marshall, and their wives, Beth and Margaret. LUNDQUIST--James Harold. 82, of Naples, FL and East Hampton, NY died on February 15, 2014. He is survived by his wife Beverly (nee Williams) of 58 years; his son John and daughter Ann; and four grandchildren: Tecla, Lilja, Jesper and Maximillian. He was born in Chicago, IL on March 24, 1931. After attending Chicago public schools, Lundquist earned his AB from Millikin University and his JD from The John Marshall Law School, after which he was admitted to the Illinois Bar in 1954, in Washington, D.C. in 1960 and in the State of New York in 1961. He qualified to practice before the United States Supreme Court in 1966. Following service in the US Army during the Korean War, he practiced law in Chicago until 1960, when the Family moved to New York. He embarked on a career in international trade and customs law as a Partner in Barnes, Richardson & Colburn, including litigation in the Courts of International Trade; regular appearances before the US Congress; Federal agencies in Washington, D.C.; delegations at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and its successor, the World Trade Organization, in Geneva, Switzerland; and the Common Market Headquarters in Brussels, Belgium. He represented multinational businesses trading from the USA, the European Community, Japan, Korea, and Australia. He retired in 1998 as Senior Partner of Barnes, Richardson & Colburn and then became Counsel to Messrs. Pavia & Harcourt of New York City and Milan, Italy, a position he held until 2006. Throughout these decades he was a legal counselor to YKK Corporation of America and, for twenty-five years, a member of its Board of Directors. He was designated Chevaliere de l'Ordre National du Merite Francais by the President of France, awarded the Order of Chevaliere Ordine al Merito della Repubblic Italia, received the Distinguished Alumnus Award from The John Marshall Law School and earned the Millikin University Merit Award. His community and pro bono professional services were extensive. He was a member of the Nassau County Mental Health Board and Chairman of its Task Force on aging from 1965 to 1970, and a decade-long member of the National Conference of Christians and Jews of New York. He served as Chairman of the American Bar Association Standing Committee on Customs Law and President of the National Customs and International Trade Bar Association. He served two terms as President of the Italy-America Chamber of Commerce and, during the 1980's, he was a Trustee and President of the Historical Society of East Hampton, NY. He also was a member of the Italian American Foundation. For the past thirty-five years he and his wife have been active supporters of Public Broadcasting and the Friends of Channel 13 in New York, and the Leadership Council of WGCU Public Media in Ft. Myers, FL. He served as a member of the Board of the United Methodist Church of Port Washington and, since 2007, was a member of the Naples United Church of Christ. He was a member of Sigma Alpha Epsilon Fraternity Alumni Association of Naples, the Union League Club of New York, the University Club of Washington, D.C., the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club of Long Island, and the Country Club of Naples. Life-long Democrats, he and his wife were members of Collier County Democratic Committee. A family memorial service will be private.

ZECKENDORF--William Jr.,84, died on February 12, 2014 in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Born in Manhattan on October 31, 1929, William Zeckendorf transformed the skyline of New York City and pioneered in changing the urban landscape of the city from Union Square to the Upper West Side. It is with deep love and admiration that we honor the life of our father and celebrate him as our devoted mentor. His brilliance in defining the future for neglected and decaying urban neighborhoods is legendary. When the Upper West Side was far distant from what it is today, William Zeckendorf built The Columbia at West 96th Street and Broadway, a development that undeniably helped to spur a West Side residential renaissance that continues today. He also built some of New York City's finest luxury developments including the Park Belvedere, Vanderbilt and Central Park Place. In midtown, William Zeckendorf built the elegant Four Seasons Hotel, and 4 Columbus Circle, a commercial building that stood alone, long before the successful destination that Columbus Circle has become. Downtown, Union Square could hardly be seen as the vibrant area that it is now. Zeckendorf Towers, envisioned by William Zeckendorf in the 1980's, led the way for the thriving 21st Century commercial and residential neighborhood that Union Square is today. The flourishing Eighth Avenue corridor is due in large measure to what William Zeckendorf saw and accomplished in his development of Worldwide Plaza, well before others followed with new developments now lining the Avenue. Worldwide Plaza was perhaps New York City's first genuine modern mixed use development combining corporate office headquarters with residential, cultural and theater facilities along with a mid-block public plaza. Other major projects included the Ronald Reagan Office Building in Washington, D.C. He was a man of great taste and culture, having served for over 50 years as an esteemed member of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin. His passion for the arts and education leave a lasting legacy from New York to Santa Fe. His quarter century of service to Long Island University preceded his deep commitment to philanthropy in his role as Founding Director of the Lensic Performing Arts Center in Santa Fe and his passionate support of The Santa Fe Opera, the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, Christus St. Vincent Hospital and the College of Santa Fe. William Zeckendorf contributed his great vision to the City of New York and its residents, who benefit enormously every day from his lifetime of achievements. He is survived by his wife, Nancy, his sister Susan Zeckendorf Nicholson, his sons Arthur Zeckendorf and William Lie Zeckendorf and two grandchildren. We are forever thankful and grateful for the wonderful lesson your life has been for us. A memorial service will be held in New York City at 4pm on March 5th. Please call 1-212-508-7273 for details. A memorial service will be held on March 29th in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Donations in his memory may be made to the Lensic Performing Arts Center, 211 West San Francisco Street, Santa Fe, New Mexico 87501. Arthur Zeckendorf William Lie Zeckendorf

McDonell--Neil Edwin, 61, of White Plains, NY, passed away February 15 after a valiant battle with cancer. Born in upstate New York, he earned degrees in English Literature and Philosophy from the University of Michigan; a Ph.D. in Philosophy at Harvard, where he met his future wife, Margaret Moline, Ph.D; and a JD from Columbia. A storied career in international law followed as a senior partner at Dorsey and Whitney's New York office. In addition to being a devoted husband and father of two sons, Adam and Aaron, Neil was also an accomplished poet. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the Homeless & Hungry Fund, www.templeisraelcenter.org

WALDMAN--David. It is with deep sadness that the Board and Staff of Lawyers For Children notes the death of David Waldman, our colleague and mentor who so generously shared his wisdom and his passion for children's rights with us all. He will forever be an inspiration to those who had the great pleasure of his friendship and counsel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his loving family.

KANTOR--Herbert Charles, 83, died on February 18, 2014. He is survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Nancy; his loving children, Patricia (Weldon), Robert (Gail); his adored grandchildren Amanda, Allison, Zachary, Drew, and Emma; his dear sister Marilyn; and his devoted nieces Barbara, Karen, and Lizzy. Preceded in death by his parents Joseph and Dorothy. Herb was a graduate of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and cum laude from Harvard Law School. After serving as an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, Herb co-founded the law firm now known as Kantor Davidoff Mandelker Twoomey Gallanty & Olnick, P.C. where he practiced until his retirement in December 2013. Herb was an avid tennis player, skier and rollerblader. He was a brilliant, loving and kind man who will live in our hearts and thoughts forever. Funeral service Thursday, February 20, 2014, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY.

WIEN--Lois, of Manhattan passed away suddenly in January. Born Lois Rosenthal in Chicago, Illinois, she was the second daughter of Zalman and Lillian Rosenthal. She graduated from New Trier High School, and earned Bachelor's and M.A.T. degrees from Vassar and Harvard, respectively. A lifelong educator, she taught at the University of Chicago's Laboratory School and New York's Lenox School before becoming the head of the English Department at the Nightingale Bamford School in 1973. She taught hundreds of students the impact and importance of language and literature, before retiring from teaching in 2002. Students and colleagues remembered her as a guiding force, a stickler for precision and grammatical exactitude, and an inspiration to expression. She traveled extensively, but remained a quintessential New Yorker and faithful patron of the City's artistic institutions. Her devotion to friends and relatives was unrivaled. Services were private. She was predeceased by her sister, Joan Rosenthal Starrels. She is survived by her nephew, Andrew Starrels, and her niece, Sally A. Starrels, both of California.

Grandfather of Michael, Milagro, Alessandro and Lucy, and Brother of Joan McNulty, Karen Strube (William), and Gail Madden (Don Schuenemann).
