Viewing Wednesday 7-9pm and Thursday 8-9am from Dunn-Givnish of Langhorne 378 So. Bellevue Ave. Mass Thursday 10am Our Lady of Grace Church Penndel, PA. Interment with military honors at Washington Crossing National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers a donation to the Oncology Unit at Rhoads Pavilion, Hospital of the University of PA at uphsgift@upenn.edu please visit www.lifecelebration.com

DUNNE--Arthur J. "Artie", Jr.,age 63, of Middletown, NJ and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, passed away unexpectedly on February 17, 2014. He leaves behind a loving family and a lasting legacy. Arthur was born in Bayside, Queens to Arthur and Peg (nee Shea) Dunne. He graduated from Saint Francis High School in Buffalo, NY and went on to attend Saint Francis College in Brooklyn, NY. Artie was an accomplished swimmer and water polo player who starred on high school, college and the New York Athletic Club teams. After graduating college, he entered the insurance industry where eventually he formed his own company, The Risk Management Planning Group (RMPG). The company was defined by Artie's personality and his sense of integrity. He was an active member of numerous organizations including The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, Knights of the Holy Sepulchre and Camp Sunrise. He will be remembered as always willing to help anyone in need. Arthur is survived by his devoted wife of 40 years, Sheila (nee McPartlin), his sister Toni and her husband Ray Pendergrass, his three loving sons: Liam and his wife Stacey of Cedar Grove, NJ, Peter and his wife Christina of Moorestown, NJ, and Sean of San Francisco, CA. He will be sadly missed by his adoring grandchildren: Jack, Sean, Maggie and Ellie, as well as numerous nieces and nephews and his lifelong friend Peter Leonard. While Arthur left this world too soon, he accomplished much in a short time and leaves behind many good friends and fond memories. He will forever be remembered for his generosity and willingness to help others. He touched so many lives and was such an influential presence for his family. Words cannot express the loss of "Artie Dunne". He was loved by all and will be truly missed. Relatives and friends are invited to his viewing Friday from 12pm to 4pm and 5pm to 8pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, New York, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday at 10am at Church of St. Monica, 413 East 79th Street, New York, NY. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations made in Arthur's name may be made to Catholic Charities, Diocese of Trenton, Attn: Barb Willis, 383 West State Street, P.O. Box 1423, Trenton, NJ 08607 or The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia CATIPIHLER Fund, The CHOP Foundation, Lockbox 1352, PO Box 8500, Philadelphia, PA 19178-1352.

CONSTABLE--Henry Lyttleton and Brooke Young, passed away on February 8, 2014 in Sisters, Oregon. Beloved parents to Cody D. Constable. A memorial service will be held at the Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue, New York City, on February 22 at 1:00pm.

FLYNN--Mary Ann "Marian" 82, of Spring Lake, passed away on Sunday, February 16, 2014, at Jersey Shore University Medical Center, surrounded by her loving family. Mrs. Flynn was born and raised in the Bronx. After marrying, she lived in Old Bridge for twenty-five years before coming to Spring Lake in 1985. Prior to starting her family, Mrs. Flynn worked for Con Edison in New York, and in later years, at Foodtown in Old Bridge. Mrs. Flynn was a member of the Spring Lake Women's Club and a volunteer for the Spring Lake Five Race and Meals on Wheels. She enjoyed playing Mah Jong with her friends in Spring Lake and Avon, and was a lover of Irish music and dance. Above all else, she was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother. Mrs. Flynn was predeceased by her beloved husband, John P. Flynn, in 1994. She is survived by her daughters and their husbands, Theresa and Vincent Nason of Voorhees, NJ, Susan and David Pflug of Swansea, IL, Barbara and Jim Coomber of Morganville, NJ, and Jean and Thomas McNiff of Spring Lake Heights, NJ. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Christopher and Ryan Nason, Courtney and Kevin Pflug, James, Shannan and Kelsey Coomber, and Connor and Maggie McNiff. In addition, she is survived by her siblings, Eileen Barrett, Andrew Hunt, Kathleen Kiernan and Peggy Short, and their families, her brother-in-law, Gerald Flynn and his family, and other relatives and friends. Visitation will take place at O'Brien Funeral Home, 2028 Hwy. 35, Wall, on Thursday, February 20, 2014, from 4-8pm. The funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Catharine's Church, Spring Lake, on Friday, February 21, 2014, at 9am, followed by entombment at St. Catharine's Cemetery, Wall. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mrs. Flynn's memory may be made to the ARC of Monmouth, 1158 Wayside Road, Tinton Falls, NJ 07712, to support the programs in which she enjoyed seeing her granddaughter, Shannan Coomber, participate. For further information or to send condolences, please visit www.obrienfuneralhome.com.

COHEN--Mickey. We mourn the passing of our friend Mickey Cohen. He was always positive, gracious and creative in his life and fight for life. We will miss him sorely. Shirley and Jack Silver and family

KANTOR--Herbert C. 1930-2014. The members and employees of Kantor, Davidoff, Mandelker, Twomey, Gallanty & Olenick, P.C. mourn the passing of our beloved founding partner Herbert C. Kantor on February 18, 2014. Herb Kantor was a counselor of choice for all of his clients, regardless of whether their problems were legal, financial, business related or personal. They relied on his wisdom, vast knowledge of the law, business and finance and his ability to cut to the heart of any problem. As Kantor Davidoff's long term leader, Herb created a culture of legal excellence, client service, financial prudence and selfless devotion to clients and the firm. Prior to retirement, Herb nurtured and guided the firm's next generation of attorneys to assume the mantle of leadership. Our hearts go out to Nancy and his family. We will miss Herb Kantor deeply.

SCHWARZ--Herman, 91, Paul and Cheryl Schwarz, their sons Andrew and Evan Schwarz; Malka Schwarz, Ghita Schwarz, Chuck Goldblum and Tirzah Schwarz and their children Navah, Mia and Malena Goldblum mourn the passing of Herman Schwarz. Beloved father, father-in-law, grandfather, brother-in-law, uncle, and great uncle. Holocaust survivor, fighter, mensch, the best of the best. Funeral services to be held on Thursday, February 20th, 10:30am, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

KREMENEZKY--Margret (Miesegades) 77, of Mamaroneck NY, passed suddenly February 17, 2014. Born in Bremen, Germany, Margret was a force of nature; an avid traveler, lover of life and the arts and completely devoted to her family and friends. Beloved wife of the late John Kremenezky, devoted mother of Susan (Dominick Silvestri), Tina (Robert Smith) and Karen (Andrew Koines) and cherished Omi to Sophie, Alexander, Julia, Erika and Dominika. Funeral services Friday February 21 at 2pm Coxe Graziano, E. Boston Post Rd., (914) 698-5968 followed by reception at the family home in Mamaroneck.

NAGLE--Eleanor K.,101, of New Rochelle, NY on February 12, 2014. Wife of the late Leo X, beloved mother of Timothy, Katharine Buckman and Constance Tighe. Much loved grandmother and aunt. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY between the hours of 5 and 8pm Friday, February 21st.

SCHABERG--Frank J.,MD, died peacefully at his Lake Mohawk, Sparta, NJ home on Tuesday, February 18, 2014. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Brown University and the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, Frank interned at Holy Name Hospital, where he met a nurse, Helen Baenziger, who he felt was the most beautiful woman he had ever met. Helen would become his partner in medicine and together they raised six children. A captain in the Army Medical Corps stationed in Winchester, England, Dr. Schaberg participated in many evacuation rescue missions from France. Following World War II, Frank continued his 50 year private practice of family medicine offering compassionate care to his many patients regardless of their ability to pay, gaining their respect and devotion. A person of insatiable curiosity, Dr. Schaberg refused to give up on his toughest medical cases pursuing every avenue for the accurate diagnosis. His life revolved selflessly around his patients and his family. He took great joy in sharing his love of knowledge, history, literature and poetry with his multi-generational family. Frank was loved dearly and will be missed by all. He is predeceased by his beloved spouse Helen, and grandson, Frank. Surviving Dr. Schaberg are six children: Catherine, Frank, Helen, Nancy, John and Paul, eleven grandchildren; Catherine, Louis, Joan, Adrienne, Madeleine, Marianne, Christopher, Peter, Paula, Kurt, and Emma and eleven great grandchildren; Maximilian, Alexandra, Julian, Tyler, Victoria, Allison, Danielle, Ashleigh, Hannah, Frank, Dinah. Friends and family are invited to a 10am Mass of the Resurrection Thursday, at Saint Kateri Tekakwitha Roman Catholic Church, Sparta, NJ followed by entombment in Newton Cemetery, Newton, NJ. Memorial contributions in Dr. Schaberg's name may be made to the Parkinsons Disease Foundation Gift Processing Center. PO Box 96268 Washington, D.C. 20077. Goble Funeral Home, Sparta is handling services.
GILLERS--Sylvia was born 100 years ago today. We remember and miss her. Debra, Stephen, Barbara, Bob, Heather, Gillian, Florrie

ATHANASSIADES--Theodossios of Princeton, NJ, died suddenly on February 13 at the age of 74. Athanassiades is a former president and chief operating officer of Metropolitan Life Insurance Company (MetLife), served as a member of its board of directors as well as a vice-chairman of the company. Athanassiades joined MetLife in 1961, became an actuary and held various senior level positions during his 35 years of service with the company, including leading the group pension department to record sales from 1983 to 1991. Athanassiades played a pivotal role in MetLife's merger with New England Mutual Life Insurance Company in 1996, a move that enhanced MetLife's position in the individual insurance, estate planning and small business markets. Athanassiades became president of MetLife in April 1994 and was the moving force behind the company's market reaching strategies, including building customer relationships on the basis of service, education and trust. During his tenure as president, Athanassiades also emphasized retirement and savings products and launched a major effort to develop the worksite and small business markets. He is survived by his wife, Elaine, children Karen (spouse Elliot Berger) and Stratos (spouse Sheryl), grandchildren, Theo, Tessa, Chloe, Christos, Alec, sister, Maria Halaris (spouse Costas) and nieces and nephews. His sense of integrity and loyalty were ever present in his actions and are remembered by his family, many friends, and colleagues. A lover of classical music, travel, and good wine, Sakis (as he was known by those who were close to him) was born in Athens, Greece to Mary and Stratos Athanassiades where he graduated from Athens College. He came to the United States on a Fulbright scholarship to attend Princeton University, graduating with a degree in math with the class of 1961. His volunteer work included his role as chairman of the New York Blood Center; chairman of the Alzheimer's Association of New York Memory Walk and as trustee and vice chairman of the Gennadius Library of the American School of Classical studies. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made to the Gennadius Library in Athens, care of the American School of Classical Studies, 6-8 Charlton Street, Princeton, NJ, 08540. A memorial will be held at a later date.

WIDDER--Dorothy, suddenly, on February 19, 2014. Beloved mother of Charles Opolinsky and Jill Siegel. Dear mother-in-law of Allison Ames and Bradley Siegel. Adored grandmother of Casey, Griffin, Jake and Harley. She is also survived by her sister Marjorie. She lived life to the fullest. Her family, friends and New York were her passion. Service: Friday, February 21, 2014, 12 noon, at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

SINGER--Hilda Tradelius, (1911-2014) of New York City passed away at the age of 102 years on February 19th. A celebration of her extraordinary life as a Holocaust survivor will be held on Sunday, February 23rd at 3pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

SLOAN--Frank, passed away on February 19, 2014 at the age of 76. Survived by his husband and companion of 18 years, Kieran Walsh. Beloved son-in-law of Mary Walsh. Loving brother-in-law of Shane, Anne and David. Uncle of Andrew, William and Lauren. Survived by his cousin Trudy and many loving friends. Frank was a native of Tarentum, PA. In 1959 he graduated from Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania with a B.A. in English. Frank moved to New York City in the early sixties and quickly established himself in the publishing world. Specializing in children's nonfiction, he would work in this industry for over forty years. Frank was a board member of the SCBWI and the distinguished author of notable books such as Titanic and Bismarck. In addition, he had a lifelong passion for opera and a great love of dogs, especially Teddy. Frank enriched every life he touched and will be greatly missed.

WIEN--Lois. The Nightingale-Bamford School mourns the passing of Lois Wien, beloved English teacher from 1973-2002. In addition to the respect and admiration she earned from her students, Mrs. Wien also garnered the highest praise from her colleagues. A celebration of her life will be held on Thursday, May 15, at 6:30pm at Nightingale-Bamford. Friends and family have chosen to honor her memory with gifts to the Nightingale-Bamford Scholarship Fund, 20 East 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128.

KREMENEZKY--Margret (Miesegades) 77, of Mamaroneck NY, passed suddenly February 17, 2014. Born in Bremen, Germany, Margret was a force of nature; an avid traveler, lover of life and the arts and completely devoted to her family and friends. Beloved wife of the late John Kremenezky, devoted mother of Susan (Dominick Silvestri), Tina (Robert Smith) and Karen (Andrew Koines) and cherished Omi to Sophie, Alexander, Julia, Erika and Dominika. Funeral services Friday February 21 at 2pm Coxe Graziano, E. Boston Post Rd., (914) 698-5968 followed by reception at the family home in Mamaroneck.

MENKEL--Gary, 92, of Floral Park, NY. Beloved father of Robert and Carrie. Predeceased by loving wife of 65 years, Margot, father-in-law of Robert Meadow and Maureen O'Hara, grandfather of Jacqueline and Nicole and companion of Eva Englander. Engineer, designer, painter, music lover, and maker and fixer of everything, refugee from German Holocaust, you are now at rest. We love you and will miss you always.

KLAUSNER--Saul, beloved husband of the late Claire Klausner, devoted father of Ronald, Loren and Jeffrey and their spouses Andrea, Thomas and Tammy, cherished grandfather of Kate, Abigail, Joanna, David, Ryan, Matthew, Henry, Theodore and Anna, loving brother of Thelma and her husband Gil Menter. Mechanical Engineer, World Traveler and Boy Scout Commissioner. Services 1pm, Sunday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York City. Contributions preferred to The Boy Scouts of America.

DRACHMAN--Harvey, passed away peacefully on February 19, 2014. He was 89 years old. Harvey was the loving husband of Suzanne (Applebaum) for 56 years and is survived by his cherished daughter Debbie, his devoted sister Diane and son-in-law Craig. His beloved late son Mark and late brother Stanley predeceased him. Harvey served in the United States Air Force in the Pacific during World War II. He spent his career starting in 1953 as a member of the New York Stock Exchange. He was an avid golfer, bridge and backgammon player, and an avid New York Giants fan. He lived his life with warmth, generosity, and integrity which made him a privilege to know. Funeral service to be held on Sunday, February 23rd at 11:30am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel located at 630 Amsterdam (at 92nd St.). Donations may be made to: Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation.
PASCARIO--Leila. An amazing lady. She lived life to the fullest. Our condolences to her husband Ben, Corinne and James. She will be missed and remembered forever. Majid and Ladan Fateh

BLOEDE--Merle Huie. Mickey died February 18th, 2014 in Dallas, TX after a remarkably courageous six year struggle with cancer. She was born in Lohn, TX, on May 4th, 1921, a town founded by her great-grandfather in the 1890s. She was the daughter of Hulon William Huie and Anna (Lohn) Huie. She graduated from Lohn High School in 1938. Despite her academic achievements she was unable to continue her education due to the effects of the Great Depression. She was very proud of her work in management at the Office of Censorship during the war. After the war she married a young 8th Air Force Bombardier, named Vic Bloede, on March 11, 1945. Shortly thereafter they started their life together in New York, where Vic began his remarkable career in advertising, ably aided by Mickey. Her insight into people, personalities, and business helped propel Vic to the very top of the advertising world where he retired as chairman of Benton & Bowles, one of the largest international agencies at that time. He always said he couldn't have done it without her. Outside of advertising Mickey had a wide variety of interests including significant philanthropic pursuits and charitable activities. Her achievements included the founding of North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, and service on the executive board of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center Society, NYC, and work with American Cancer Society, among many others. In the social realm she served as President of the North Shore Southern Society. Also, Mickey was a member of a number of clubs: Sands Point (NY) Bath & Tennis, Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, Flower Hill Garden, Delray Dunes (FL) Golf and Country, and The Ocean Club of Florida. She was a member of the Community Reformed Church, Manhasset, NY, First Presbyterian Church, Delray Beach, FL, and later Highland Park Presbyterian Church, Dallas, TX. Throughout Mickey's life her intellect, wide ranging curiosity, keen wit, and fondness for a good debate were her hallmarks. It is worth noting because of her self-taught business acumen, her stock broker often consulted her. Mickey joked that he should be paying her. But beyond all her experiences and accomplishments clearly the most important thing in her life was the love of her family, by whom she will be dearly missed. Mickey was preceded in death by her husband of fifty four years, Victor G. Bloede. Survived by her three children, Dee Anna Smith Willis, Victor G. Bloede IV, and Susan Lohn Quaid, and grandchildren Elizabeth Murphy, Amy Arata, Lindsay Carneal, Alexandra Quaid, Victor G. Bloede V, Forrest Bloede, Laura Bloede, sister- in-law Rama Huie, a dozen grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews. Memorial service February 24th, 4pm at Highland Park Presbyterian Church, Dallas.

DUNNE--Arthur J. "Artie", Jr.,age 63, of Middletown, NJ and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, passed away unexpectedly on February 17, 2014. He leaves behind a loving family and a lasting legacy. Arthur was born in Bayside, Queens to Arthur and Peg (nee Shea) Dunne. He graduated from Saint Francis High School in Buffalo, NY and went on to attend Saint Francis College in Brooklyn, NY. Artie was an accomplished swimmer and water polo player who starred on high school, college and the New York Athletic Club teams. After graduating college, he entered the insurance industry where eventually he formed his own company, The Risk Management Planning Group (RMPG). The company was defined by Artie's personality and his sense of integrity. He was an active member of numerous organizations including The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, Knights of the Holy Sepulchre and Camp Sunrise. He will be remembered as always willing to help anyone in need. Arthur is survived by his devoted wife of 40 years, Sheila (nee McPartlin), his sister Toni and her husband Ray Pendergrass, his three loving sons: Liam and his wife Stacey of Cedar Grove, NJ, Peter and his wife Christina of Moorestown, NJ, and Sean of San Francisco, CA. He will be sadly missed by his adoring grandchildren: Jack, Sean, Maggie and Ellie, as well as numerous nieces and nephews and his lifelong friend Peter Leonard. While Arthur left this world too soon, he accomplished much in a short time and leaves behind many good friends and fond memories. He will forever be remembered for his generosity and willingness to help others. He touched so many lives and was such an influential presence for his family. Words cannot express the loss of "Artie Dunne". He was loved by all and will be truly missed. Relatives and friends are invited to his viewing Friday from 12pm to 4pm and 5pm to 8pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, New York, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday at 10am at Church of St. Monica, 413 East 79th Street, New York, NY. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations made in Arthur's name may be made to Catholic Charities, Diocese of Trenton, Attn: Barb Willis, 383 West State Street, P.O. Box 1423, Trenton, NJ 08607 or The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia CATIPIHLER Fund, The CHOP Foundation, Lockbox 1352, PO Box 8500, Philadelphia, PA 19178-1352.

HENSON--John Paul, died suddenly February 14, 2014 at the Kingston City Hospital, Kingston, New York. Born April 25, 1965 he is the son of the late Jane Nebel Henson and Jim Henson. A master in three dimensional spatial design, and active board member in The Jim Henson Company, Henson was an accomplished puppeteer and made numerous appearances in television and feature films. At the time of his death, John Henson had owned and extensively developed many properties in Saugerties. In 1996, Henson met his future wife, and the love of his life, Gyongyi Katona. Their daughter Katrina was born in 1999 and daughter Sydney was born in 2003. John was a loving, playful and dedicated father, and was very involved in all aspects of his girls lives. John leave behind his beloved family; Gyongyi, Katrina and Sydney Henson. His brother Brian and his wife, Mia Sara Henson, sisters Lisa Henson and husband Dave Pressler, Cheryl Henson and husband Ed Finn, and Heather Henson. John's family commented, "John had the deepest soul of any man alive; sensitive, artistic and extremely compassionate". There was no limit to his love. Private services were held. All donations can be made to Museum of the Moving Image, Astoria, New York. movingimage.us/johnhenson

Rosenblatt--Sheila Urban Pathways notes with great sorrow the passing of Sheila Rosenblatt, former Board member and longtime supporter of the drive to end homelessness. Sheila was a force of nature, whose intellect was as sharp as her heart was full. Her commitment to a more just society, as well as her love of New York City, will inspire us always. We extend condolences to her children, extended family and legions of friends and admirers. She will be missed.

HOLCOMB--Joan Hamilton, a longtime resident of Lloyd Harbor and Huntington, NY, died in hospice February 9, 2014 at 83, after a protracted battle with cancer and a stroke in late January. Born in New York City, she grew up there and in Syracuse, and was a 1952 graduate of Syracuse University. During the 1950's and 1960's, she was director of public relations for the Rochester Community Chest. Later, she was chairman of the Columbia County Council on the Arts. After moving to Long Island in 1977, she served as president and board member of the Visiting Nurse Service & Hospice of Suffolk, at a time when the service was expanding and developing plans for a hospice. She was a long-serving board member of Huntington's Heckscher Museum of Art and the St. Johnlands Nursing Center. A loving daughter, wife, mother and grandmother, she will be greatly missed by her many relatives and friends. She is survived by her husband of 53 years, Charles R. Holcomb, a former journalist; three daughters, Kristin Holcomb (MIchael Sharp) of Brooklyn, Alexandra Holcomb Bird (Andrew Bird) of Sydney, Australia, and Margaret Schubauer (James Schubauer II) of Lloyd Harbor, and eight grandchildren: Fiona Sharp, Nicholas, Samantha and Olivia Bird, and Katharine, Elizabeth, Julia and James Schubauer. A celebration of her life is planned for June. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service & Hospice of Suffolk, 505 Main St., Northport, NY 11768.
KANTOR--Herbert. TLC family and friends mourn the loss of Herbert Kantor whose guidance and dedication was immeasurable. Our sincere condolences to Nancy and family.

BALDWIN--David M.,85, of Vero Beach, Florida and Short Hills, New Jersey, died peacefully at his Florida home on February 16, 2014. David will be remembered as a caring gentleman, a loving husband and father, a hugely accomplished New York real estate investor and a champion in athletics, philanthropy and community enrichment. David was born in East Orange, New Jersey in 1928, and was raised in South Orange, New Jersey. The memorable summers of his early years were at the Baldwin family compound at Northampton Shores of Southampton Township. He graduated from the Pingry School in 1947 before attending William and Mary College and graduating in 1951 from Lehigh University with a Bachelor of Science degree in business administration. David served his country in the counterintelligence unit of the army and in 1954 became a real estate broker with the former Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc. In 1964, at the age of 35, he became President and Chief Executive of the company, the youngest chief executive officer of a major national real estate company. He negotiated the sale of the Noyes Company, together with Brown, Harris and Stevens to Mr. Harry Helmsley. This vital partnership lead to responsibility with Mr. Helmsley for many notable properties in New York City and across the country. Among the many awards that recognized his personal accomplishments: in 1964 The Real Estate Board of New York's "Young Man of the Year Award"; in 1966 its "Most Ingenious Deal in Manhattan" award, and in 1977 "Man of the Year" award from the Realty Foundation of New York. David exclusively represented many major corporations for their headquarters and staffing space. In 1994 following the winding down of the Helmsley portfolio, the David M. Baldwin Realty Company, Inc., was formed to specialize in the management of real estate in downtown Manhattan. David served on numerous real estate boards and foundations including the Real Estate Board of New York where he was governor and director and the Realty Foundation of New York. He was also the former Chairman and President of the Public Development Corporation of New York City. Throughout David's career, he instinctively sought to share his personal prosperity with many institutions and worthy initiatives in education, health care and the arts as a trustee and philanthropist. He was a founding member of the board of the Henry Stifel Spinal Cord Injury Foundation and ultimately a Vice-Chair of the Christopher and Dana Reeve Foundation; at Lehigh, he enabled the renovation of The Taylor Gym and created an endowed scholarship fund; at the Pingry School, his generosity helped enable a new campus and he commissioned a monumental bronze replica of Dr. John Pingry; he served as a longstanding Chair of the Strang Cancer Prevention Center in New York and was a member of the board of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center; he also served as Vice Chairman of The Riverside Theatre in Vero Beach and he generously supported Overlook Medical Center in Summit, New Jersey, the Indian River Medical Center in Vero Beach, Florida and The Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey, among other charities. David Baldwin was an accomplished athlete. At Pingry he was an all-star fullback and state ranked track star. Golf, however, was his keenest talent. He was a co-captain of the golf team at Lehigh and in 1954, he won the New Jersey State Open Championship and was runner-up in the National Lefthanders Golf Championship. He twice qualified for the U.S. Amateur and was also Club Champion at Baltusrol, Rock Spring and Essex County in New Jersey. In 2000, he was included in the "Team of the Century" by the New Jersey Star Ledger. He was a longstanding member of the United States Senior Golf Association. Club memberships included: in New Jersey Baltusrol Golf Club, where he was President, and The Short Hills Club; in Florida The John's Island Club, The Red Stick Golf Club and The Windsor Club in Vero Beach; and in New York Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, National Golf Links Club of America, The Meadow Club, The Bathing Corporation of Southampton, The University Club, and Doubles. Magic was David's fascination since early childhood. He assembled one of the most prominent personal collections of magic apparatus in the world. As a member of the International Brotherhood of Magicians, David published biographies of the Great Raymond and of Del-Ray-America's Foremost Magician. He enabled the creation of a new headquarters for The Magic Circle in London, among the most exclusive clubs in the world. In 1977, David commissioned a bronze figure of David Deviant that has become a coveted award for distinguished magicians around the world. In 2006 as an Honorary Lifetime Member he was awarded the Magic Circle's Silver Wand for outstanding service. As a devoted husband and father, he is survived by his loving family which include his wife of thirty-seven years, Barbara M. Baldwin; three sons, David Jr. of Basking Ridge, New Jersey; Alfred of Port Orange, Florida; William of Sag Harbor, New York; two stepchildren, Martin "Fritz" Stein III of Landing, New Jersey, Kimberly Paige Fleming of Aspen, Colorado; three grandchildren Liam Fleming, Alexander and Paulina Stein and a twin brother Theodore Baldwin of Summit, New Jersey. David was pre-deceased by his youngest son Ted and a brother, Cyril. Contributions as a memorial may be made in David's name to The Pingry School, 131 Martinsville Road, Basking Ridge, New Jersey 07920; Lehigh University, 27 Memorial Drive West, Bethlehem, Pennsylvania 18015; or The Riverside Theatre, 3250 Riverside Park Drive, Vero Beach, Florida 32963. A Celebration of Life Service will be held at Community Church of Vero Beach on February 28, 2014 at 11:00am. A reception will follow at the John's Island Golf Club. Services are under the direction of Strunk Funeral Home Vero Beach, Florida. An online guestbook is available at www.strunkfuneralhome.com.

BURGOON--Caroline Carleton, passed away on Saturday, February 15, 2014, in San Jose, CA, at 78. Born and raised as the daughter of United Church of Christ Missionaries in the Middle East, Caroline was educated at Oberlin College, and lived and worked throughout the United States, Latin America and the Middle East. She was for more than 52 years the loving wife of David Warner Burgoon, and raised their four children with deep devotion. She is survived by her husband, David; her four children, David Alford, Kathy, Brian and Ian; and her six grandchildren. She is and will be missed by the many whose lives she touched.
MOTTEL--Syeus, 83, died in his home on the Upper West Side. May 10, 1930-January 25, 2014. I was a Doer & You should always be one too

FELDMAN--Tiffani Bea. What an incredible aunt to Chloe you would be. Miss you so. Mom, Dad, Kerrin and Grandmother

BALDWN--David. The Officers and Directors of the Realty Foundation of New York are deeply saddened at the passing of David. A long standing member of our Board, David was steadfast in his belief of our goals and held tight to his commitment to us. A highly respected real estate professional-mentored many-guiding with a gentle hand. A true gentleman, kind, generous, caring and most of all-true to those around him. We send our heartfelt condolences to family, friends and all those who were fortunate to have known David. May you rest in peace, dear David. H. Dale Hemmerdinger, Chairman Jeffrey R. Gural, President

LA VINE--Mary Virginia Dailey, age 96, beloved wife of the late Kenneth N. La Vine, passed away quietly on February 13, 2014 in Vero Beach, FL. Mrs. La Vine was the only daughter of the late Vincent and Corrine McCoy Dailey of Brockport, NY. Mrs. La Vine was raised in Rochester and graduated from Manhattanville College. The La Vines raised their family in Forest Hills, NY, where Mrs. La Vine served as President of the Long Island Chapter of The Visiting Nurse Association, as President of The Women's Club of Forest Hills and as a member of The Garden Club of Forest Hills. In addition to her husband, her daughter, Carol A. Coogan and her two brothers, Vincent and William Dailey, predeceased her. She is survived by her son, Kenneth N. La Vine Jr. and his wife, Angel; her daughter Linda J. Johnson and her husband, John; her son-in-law, James M. Coogan; five grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at 10:30am on Monday, February 24th at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th St., NY, NY. Memorial donations may be made to the Residents Fund at Indian River Estates, 2250 Indian Creek Blvd. West, Vero Beach, FL 32966.

BLOEDE--Merle Huie. Mickey died February 18th, 2014 in Dallas, TX after a remarkably courageous six year struggle with cancer. She was born in Lohn, TX, on May 4th, 1921, a town founded by her great-grandfather in the 1890s. She was the daughter of Hulon William Huie and Anna (Lohn) Huie. She graduated from Lohn High School in 1938. Despite her academic achievements she was unable to continue her education due to the effects of the Great Depression. She was very proud of her work in management at the Office of Censorship during the war. After the war she married a young 8th Air Force Bombardier, named Vic Bloede, on March 11, 1945. Shortly thereafter they started their life together in New York, where Vic began his remarkable career in advertising, ably aided by Mickey. Her insight into people, personalities, and business helped propel Vic to the very top of the advertising world where he retired as chairman of Benton & Bowles, one of the largest international agencies at that time. He always said he couldn't have done it without her. Outside of advertising Mickey had a wide variety of interests including significant philanthropic pursuits and charitable activities. Her achievements included the founding of North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, and service on the executive board of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center Society, NYC, and work with American Cancer Society, among many others. In the social realm she served as President of the North Shore Southern Society. Also, Mickey was a member of a number of clubs: Sands Point (NY) Bath & Tennis, Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, Flower Hill Garden, Delray Dunes (FL) Golf and Country, and The Ocean Club of Florida. She was a member of the Community Reformed Church, Manhasset, NY, First Presbyterian Church, Delray Beach, FL, and later Highland Park Presbyterian Church, Dallas, TX. Throughout Mickey's life her intellect, wide ranging curiosity, keen wit, and fondness for a good debate were her hallmarks. It is worth noting because of her self-taught business acumen, her stock broker often consulted her. Mickey joked that he should be paying her. But beyond all her experiences and accomplishments clearly the most important thing in her life was the love of her family, by whom she will be dearly missed. Mickey was preceded in death by her husband of fifty four years, Victor G. Bloede. Survived by her three children, Dee Anna Smith Willis, Victor G. Bloede IV (Nancy), and Susan Lohn Quaid, and grandchildren Elizabeth Murphy, Amy Arata, Lindsay Carneal, Alexandra Quaid, Victor G. Bloede V, Forrest Bloede, Laura Bloede, sister-in-law Rama Huie, a dozen grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews. Memorial service February 24th, 4pm at Highland Park Presbyterian Church, Dallas.

BRENNER--Howard. Of Newton, MA, age 84, February 17, 2014. Born in the Bronx, NY, March 16, 1929. Professor Emeritus of Chemical Engineering at MIT who led an extraordinary 60-year academic career. Dedicated scholar and prolific author who received numerous honors and awards recognizing his profound contributions to the field of fluid dynamics, including election to the National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering. Loving husband of Lisa Glucksman. Beloved father of Leslie (Stephen) Lipschultz, Joyce (John) Hagen-Brenner and Suzanne Brenner (John Opferkuch), his children with wife, Lorraine Brenner. Cherished grandfather of Margo, Alex, Daniel, Julia, Kiera, Max and Miles. Brother of Renee Gould. A memorial service will be held at MIT in the fall. Gifts may be directed to the Howard Brenner Memorial Fund at MIT. Checks may be sent to: MIT ASO, c/o Teri Quill, 8-328, 77 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge MA 02139.

CORIN-GOODMAN- FEINSTEIN--Arline. Arline, 87, passed away from lymphoma. She was the student body President of Hunter College at the time of the first United Nations meeting which was held at Hunter College. She was a voracious reader and world traveler. She taught at Cordoza High School for many years. She is survived by her son, Ira Goodman MD (Wende), daughter Ellen Corin, stepson David Corin (Rhonda), Grandchildren Nathaniel Goodman and Nicole Corin, and sister Helen Rubin (Alan). Funeral Services will be held at Schwartz Brothers Chapel 114-03 Queens Blvd (at 76th Rd) Forest Hills, NY Sunday February 23, 2014 at 1pm.
RABINOWITZ--Lora. 7/19- 2/22/11. Remembering you and Dad (Joe), your smile and happy times. Ellyn & Richard.

HIRSCHHORN--Susan, We mourn the passing of Susan Hirschhorn, 68, on February 10, 2014. Beloved mother to Jason Hirschhorn and Jody and Jacques Stambouli. Proud grandma of Lily, Robbie and Amelie. Loving sister, aunt, cousin and friend. She meant a lot to many, and everything to a special few. She will be forever in our hearts.

KOPET--Howard. The family of Howard (Skip) Kopet of Hewlett, Long Island regretfully announce his passing on Tuesday evening, February 18th, from Parkinson's Disease with complications. He is mourned by his children Stacy Heimlich and Dana Kopet, from his beloved first wife Muriel Lurie Kopet. He is also mourned by his beloved wife of 39 years, Sandra Bomze Kopet and her children Ellen, Stephen and Jean. He leaves a sister, Seena Dundes and his dearly loved grandchildren Mariel Heimlich, Hannah and Zachary Kopet, Anna and Stella Westher, Matthew and Michael Ressler. He will be missed by all who knew him and remembered with much love. A funeral service will be held, Sunday, February 23rd at 2:30pm at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, to honor his memory.

BRIGHT--Cruger Lane, 94, passed away Sunday, February 16, 2014, at his home in La Habra Heights, California. He was born December 26, 1919, in Kansas, to William A. Bright and Ethel G (Eyster) Bright. He attended Kansas State, attaining a Bachelor of Science degree before joining the Marine Corps in February 1942. He had a distinguished 26 year career as an aviator, serving in the Pacific in World War II. He also served in Korea and Vietnam. He retired in 1968 as a full Colonel, having served as the commanding officer of Marine Corp Air Facility (Santa Ana). He then attended UCLA law school, graduating in 1971. He practiced law for 19 years, retiring from State Compensation Insurance Fund in 1980. He is survived by his life partner of 44 years, Margarita P. McCoy; sons Jeff Bright of Los Osos, CA, Joshua Bright, and daughter-in-law Mary Paterson-Bright of Castro Valley, CA; and grandson Cameron Bright of Oakland, CA. Services will be private. He had a long and happy life in the hilltop home he loved. He will be missed.

DRABKIN--Steven Wayne. 10/19/1961 - 2/23/1981. Time has not dimmed the memory of his gentle spirit or lessened the heartache of his loss.

WIEN--Lois. The Nightingale-Bamford School mourns the passing of Lois Wien, beloved English teacher from 1973-2002. In addition to the respect and admiration she earned from her students, Mrs. Wien also garnered the highest praise from her colleagues. A celebration of her life will be held on Thursday, May 15, at 6:30pm at Nightingale-Bamford. Friends and family have chosen to honor her memory with gifts to the Nightingale-Bamford Scholarship Fund, 20 East 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128.

WARSAGER--Helen. She left us on February 19 just one week past her 98th birthday. Devoted wife of the late Sam, Beloved mother of Carol (Bruce) and the late Richard. Treasured grandma of Remy. Predeceased by her parents, Hyman and Annie Grubstein and brothers (Milton and Elliott). Sister-in-law, cousin and special aunt. Oh, she was so dearly loved. Smiles can hide the sadness, Tears can be wiped away, But the heartache of losing you will never go away.
WIDDER--Dorothy, You will be in our hearts forever. We will remember your beauty and your spirit. Dorothy and Elizabeth

UTLEYGarrick. The board and staff of Public Radio International mourn the loss of our long time trustee Garrick Utley, who inspired us by his commitment to international reporting. The world has lost one of its keenest observers. We offer our deepest sympathy to his family.

UTLEY--Garrick. The Council on Foreign Relations (CFR) mourns the passing of Garrick Utley, CFR Board member, 1993-2003. As a member for 33 years, we thank him for his longstanding commitment and dedication to CFR, in particular for his years chairing the Meetings and Foreign Affairs committees. The staff and board of CFR offer heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Carla A. Hills, Co-Chair Robert E. Rubin, Co-Chair Richard N. Haass, President

ZEELANDER--Norbert J.,died suddenly while on vacation in the British Virgin Islands on Sunday, February 16. He was 75 years old. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Susan (Haness), whom he met at Queens College in 1959, and by his children, Jeffrey and his wife Maureen Welsh and their sons Zachary and Joshua; by Elliot and his wife Lisa and their children Zoe and Jacob; by Julie and her husband Erik Lederman and their children Bella and Oliver. He served in the United States Army Reserves and graduated from Brooklyn Law School. He started his career in the fledgling computer industry, and developed companies in the computer hardware and communications industries. In 1991 he started Mathers Associates, an Investment Partnership with offices in Ambler, PA and Los Angeles, CA. Norbert was born in Antwerp, Belgium on February 24, 1938, to Ann and Theo Zeelander. The family, together with Theo's parents, fled the German invasion May 10, 1940, staying one step ahead of the Nazis and eventually staying in the south of France. His sister Rosine Fields (now deceased) was born in Toulouse, 1941. A year later the family was able to get into Jamaica, and then to Curacao, where they lived until the War ended. They then tried to enter the United States but were not allowed to stay, and they returned to Belgium for two years. In 1948 they immigrated to the U.S. where a second sister, Estelle Heimann, was later born. Norbert was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He loved his nieces and nephews and their children and he enjoyed watching his extended family grow. Norbert was a caring and moral person. Funeral services are being coordinated by Boyd-Horrox Funeral Home in Norristown, PA and will be held at Tiferet Bet Israel, Blue Bell, PA. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice in Norbert's memory.

WEINDLING--Steven, passed away unexpectedly at the age of 59. He will be greatly missed by his sister Suzanne, brother-in-law Steven, niece Alexis and extended family. Graveside service to be held at Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Ave, Paramus, NJ, at 11:30am on Sunday, February 23rd.
LONG--Ruth Stoddard, M.D. February 23, 1999 Unforgettable

UTLEY--Garrick. The German Academic Exchange Service Alumni Association is deeply saddened by the passing of Garrick Utley, a longstanding honorary member of our board. Garrick was a steadfast supporter of international exchange programs. A true gentleman, he exemplified the highest standards of television journalism. We miss his intelligence, humor, and engagement. Manfred Philipp, President, Mechthild Schmidt, Vice President
KAYE--Robbie, 1/16/76-2/23/96. You may be gone from our lives, but you'll never be gone from our hearts. Love, Mom, Dad and Andy

ZECKENDORF--William Jr.,Bill was indeed a "Master Builder" with vision and confidence. Every project he created ensured physical transformations that went far beyond brick and mortar. He was determined that neighborhoods would be enriched and opportunities made expansive. That conviction and energy were the ingredients which created the greatest changes. He was blessed with his beloved wife, Nancy, and his sons, Arthur and William, who made him very proud and now carry on his legacy of tasteful elegance. Myra and Frank Weiser

LA VINE--Mary Virginia Dailey, age 96, beloved wife of the late Kenneth N. La Vine, passed away quietly on February 13, 2014 in Vero Beach, FL. Mrs. La Vine was the only daughter of the late Vincent and Corrine McCoy Dailey of Brockport, NY. Mrs. La Vine was raised in Rochester and graduated from Manhattanville College. The La Vines raised their family in Forest Hills, NY, where Mrs. La Vine served as President of the Long Island Chapter of The Visiting Nurse Association, as President of The Women's Club of Forest Hills and as a member of The Garden Club of Forest Hills. In addition to her husband, her daughter, Carol A. Coogan and her two brothers, Vincent and William Dailey, predeceased her. She is survived by her son, Kenneth N. La Vine Jr. and his wife, Angel; her daughter Linda J. Johnson and her husband, John; her son-in-law, James M. Coogan; five grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at 10:30am on Monday, February 24th at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th St., NY, NY. Memorial donations may be made to the Residents Fund at Indian River Estates, 2250 Indian Creek Blvd. West, Vero Beach, FL 32966.

MENKEL--Gary, 92, of Floral Park, NY. Beloved father of Robert and Carrie. Predeceased by loving wife of 65 years, Margot, father-in-law of Robert Meadow and Maureen O'Hara, grandfather of Jacqueline and Nicole and companion of Eva Englander. Engineer, designer, painter, music lover, and maker and fixer of everything, refugee from German Holocaust, you are now at rest. We love you and will miss you always.

SCHWARZ--Herman, 91, Paul and Cheryl Schwarz, their sons Andrew and Evan Schwarz; Malka Schwarz, Ghita Schwarz, Chuck Goldblum and Tirzah Schwarz and their children Navah, Mia and Malena Goldblum mourn the passing of Herman Schwarz. Beloved father, father-in-law, grandfather, brother-in-law, uncle, and great uncle. Holocaust survivor, fighter, mensch, the best of the best. Funeral services were held on Thursday, February 20th.

TUZZA--Joseph, died at 105 years of age in Great Barrington, MA. Born in Messina, Sicily to Flavia and Carmelo Tuzza, he came to the United States as a young child where his family settled in Brooklyn. After graduating from Boys High School and New York University, he began a fulfilling career in the New York City school system that lasted over thirty-five years. In 1974, he retired from his position as an Assistant Principal of Forest Hills High School. He and his late wife Mary, also an educator, lived in Manhasset for forty-seven years. In his later years, Joseph maintained his vitality and sharp mind, which amazed everyone he met including those with whom he played bridge just weeks before his passing. He is survived by his daughter Barbara Palumbo, grandsons Matthew and Marc, granddaughters-in-law Sarah and Wendy-lin, great-grandsons Lucas and Alexander, a sister Rose, and a brother Thomas. He was loved and respected by all who knew him.

SU--Zian. Zian Su, passed away in Bedminster, New Jersey on the morning of February 20, 2014. Mr. Zian Su was born into a prominent family on November 2, 1925 in Wuhan, China. His father, Pei Kun Su, graduated from Waseda University in Japan and among his many accomplishments, founded one of the first and most important military schools in China in the early 1900s. Mr. Su graduated from Huazhong University and majored in Chemistry in the 1940s. From 1960 until his retirement in 1990, he was a department head and held the highest position as a research professor at the Chinese Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products. Additionally, Mr. Su was appointed as Secretary General of the Chinese Society of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Forest Products, served on a number of boards of national organizations in chemical industries, and was elected as a member of the Chinese Political Consultation Committee of Jiangsu province. Beyond his professional successes, Mr. Su had an affinity for many crafts including photography. While greatly recognized for his academic and professional accomplishments, Mr. Su will be remembered first-and-foremost as a caring gentleman with an incredibly infectious smile, warm heart, and gracious attitude. He lit up every room he walked into, and all who had the privilege of knowing Mr. Su can attest to his fine character. His life will be forever celebrated, and his presence forever missed. On October 18, 2011, Mr. Su and his wife, Shuxian Zhou, moved from Nanjing, China to the United States to be with their family. Besides his wife, he is survived by his two children, Xiaozhou and Xiaoping; his five granddaughters, Maria, Michelle and Monica Su, and Caroline and Catherine Zhu; his son in-law, Song Zhu; his daughter-in-law, Beilin Xiao; and his two older sisters, Bonan and Zhonghui Su. Mr. Su will rest at a mausoleum in Somerset Hills Memorial Park in Basking Ridge, New Jersey.

LERMOND--Lucia, of New York City, died on February 15. Her brilliant mind and gracious spirit will be sorely missed. A Queens College graduate, Lucia earned a Ph.D. from Columbia University. Her dissertation, "The Form of Man: Human Essence in Spinoza's Ethic," was published in 1997. Lucia returned to Queens College to teach philosophy, religion, and feminist theory. Her enthusiasms-for rembetika music, Minoan civilization, champagne-were wonderfully intense, as was her passion for favorite places. Lucia is survived by her sister, Jessica M. Lermond; her uncle Leonard M. Schwartz; her longtime friend Rodica Diaconescu-Blumenfeld; and a circle of intimate friends. Donations may be made to the American Friends Service Committee, at afsc.org.

PRAGER-DRESCHER--Alice H.,83, died on February 12, 2014, former Chairman of SESAC Inc., one of three U.S. Performing Rights Organizations. Born on August 2, 1930, in New York City, NY, Alice was the only child of the founder of SESAC, Mr. Paul Heinecke and his wife Ruth. Born at the same time as SESAC was founded, she was exposed to the music industry from a very early age. She was trained by her parents to assume the top command at SESAC. Following her graduation from college in 1951, (holding a BA degree in radio and television from Russell Sage College, Troy, New York, and completed graduate work at New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration), she worked in virtually all departments of SESAC and traveled extensively throughout the country and the world, calling on television and radio stations and representatives abroad. As a young woman, she travelled in post-war Europe and Israel to assist artists who had been displaced and whose artists' rights were in question. Within SESAC, Alice moved from administration and sales, vice president and managing director, president, and was elevated to the post of Chairman in April, 1978. In 1964, Alice and her late husband, George L. Drescher, founded The Personal Touch, a nationally recognized product promotion firm. Throughout her entire life, Alice was extremely active and was a member or served on boards of numerous organizations such as the International Radio and Television Society, the American Institute of Management, the American Women in Radio and Television, the International Association of Women in Radio and Television the Advertising Women of New York, Broadcast Pioneers, Women's Forum, the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, and was a lifetime member of both the Country Music Association and the Gospel Music Association. She was made an honorary citizen of the States of Tennessee and Florida and was named an honorary Kentucky Colonel. She was the founder of the Duke Ellington Cancer Center, which established a cancer screening center for performing artists at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital's Center for the Performing Arts in New York City. She spent time in her homes in Manhattan, Westhampton Beach, Key West, and Positano. In Key West she was on the board of directors of the Key West Art and Historical Society and the Waterfront Theater. Alice was listed in the National Register of Prominent Americans and International Notables, Who's Who of American Women, Who's Who in the East, Who's Who in Business and Commerce, Foremost Women in Communications, and innumerable music industry trade references. She died a resident of Florida surrounded by loved ones. She will be remembered as an extraordinary woman who was active and devoted to broadcast, advertising, and music sectors. She will be remembered by many and greatly missed by all who knew her.

ROSSBACH--Jay H.,Jr., died peacefully in his sleep on February 15, 2014 at his home in Palm Beach. He was the son of Jay H. Rossbach and Sophie H. Gimbel. He was the stepson of Adam L. Gimbel. He is survived by his beloved wife of 43 years Linda Johnson Rossbach and loving children Jay Adam Rossbach and Elizabeth R. Schumacher (Peter) and three grandchildren. He retired from Saks Fifth Avenue after 30 years as a Senior Vice President. After moving to Palm Beach in 1983 he became very active in many charities. He became Chairman of the Palm Beach Chapter of the Red Cross. Services and Interment were held in Palm Beach.
