KLAUSNER--Saul, beloved husband of the late Claire Klausner, devoted father of Ronald, Loren and Jeffrey and their spouses Andrea, Thomas and Tammy, cherished grandfather of Kate, Abigail, Joanna, David, Ryan, Matthew, Henry, Theodore and Anna, loving brother of Thelma and her husband Gil Menter. Mechanical Engineer, World Traveler and Boy Scout Commissioner. Services 1pm, Sunday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York City. Contributions preferred to The Boy Scouts of America.

KATZ--Eleanor Meyerhoff. The Board, faculty and Staff of ClalThe National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership extend deepest condolences to our esteemed past Chairman Thomas O. Katz and the entire Katz family on the passing of Eleanor Meyerhoff Katz. She was a true Eym b'Israel, mother of the people of Israel, beloved wife of the late Herb Katz, mother grandmother and wife. An extraordinary woman, who exemplified wisdom, integrity, generosity and gratitude. Her indomitable spirit and leadership of key Jewish institutions both nationally and locally leave an enduring legacy. She was a dedicated and enthusiastic supporter of Clal from its inception. May her memory be a blessing and may her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Debra Tuchman, Chairman Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Rabbi Brad Hirschfield, President

MARKS--Raymond H.,91, of Delray Beach, FL, died peacefully on February 15. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Anne, daughters Victoria (Dan), Andrea (Lindsey) and son, Michael (Joyce) grandchildren, Michael, Jr., Brittany, Milo, Emmett and Sasha. He graduated from North Carolina State University as a chemical engineer and was elected to the Tau Beta Pi engineering honor society. He served as a lieutenant in the American Army of Occupation in Naples, Italy, after the war in Europe was over. Raymond worked for the Monsanto Chemical Company for ten years, then joined Tenneco, Inc. and became president of their Plastics Division. He later became president of Tenneco Chemicals. He spent the last two years of his career as Chairman of Tenneco Europe, based in London. Funeral services were held on February 19 at the Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel in Delray Beach, FL. Donations in his memory made to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

McDonell--Neil Edwin, 61, of White Plains, NY, passed away February 15 after a valiant battle with cancer. Born in upstate New York, he earned degrees in English Literature and Philosophy from the University of Michigan; a Ph.D. in Philosophy at Harvard, where he met his future wife, Margaret Moline, Ph.D; and a JD from Columbia. A storied career in international law followed as a senior partner at Dorsey and Whitney's New York office. In addition to being a devoted husband and father of two sons, Adam and Aaron, Neil was also an accomplished poet. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the Homeless & Hungry Fund, www.templeisraelcenter.org

Rosenblatt--Sheila Urban Pathways notes with great sorrow the passing of Sheila Rosenblatt, former Board member and longtime supporter of the drive to end homelessness. Sheila was a force of nature, whose intellect was as sharp as her heart was full. Her commitment to a more just society, as well as her love of New York City, will inspire us always. We extend condolences to her children, extended family and legions of friends and admirers. She will be missed.

KWOK--Jean Gee-Hing, 81, of New York City passed away peacefully on February 5th, at the home she had shared with her late husband, Arnold Bergier. Jean was a devoted and loving wife to Arnold whom she married in 1970. They had an adventure-filled and happy life, shared a sense of the absurd, and could make any occasion full of fun. Jean also cared for her mother living in San Francisco, CA, where she spent most of her time when away from New York. She was a culinary enthusiast and a world traveler. Jean shared laughter with her family and friends who knew her for her hearty and jovial disposition. She graduated from Mills College in Oakland, CA, worked as a computer programmer in the 1960s and 1970s, and later in life taught Tai Chi in her downtown New York loft and at the Lee Strasberg Theater and Film Institute. A well-respected Tai Chi Master with a loyal following until her retirement in 1997, she maintained close relationships with her students. Jean is survived by her mother, May Kwok, brother, John Kwok; her step-children Thomas Bergier, Wendy Ashley, and Barbara Bergier; six step-grandchildren, and nine step- great-grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made in Jean's name to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. A memorial service will be held in New York in May.

MITCHELL--Tittica Roberts. A memorial service celebrating the life of Tittica "Tica" Roberts Mitchell, age 74, of Columbus, Ohio will be held at 11am on Friday, March 21, at the Newark Chapel of Henderson-Van Atta-Stickle Funeral & Cremation Service. "Tica" was born December 10, 1939 and passed away Wednesday, February 19, 2014 in Newark, Ohio. Please visit www.hendersonvanatta.com to view a memorial and to leave a message of condolence for the Mitchell family.

ROSENBLATT--Jay S.,passed away early on the morning of February 16 at the age of 90. Born in the East Bronx on November 18th, Jay was a scientist, a psychoanalyst, and an artist. In a long scientific career that included a 17 year directorship of the Institute of Animal Behavior at Rutgers, Jay received numerous honors and awards. Among the first to study the role of hormones, the brain and experience in the regulation of mothering, Jay laid the groundwork for a field of inquiry, the psychobiology of mammalian maternal behavior. His many students, post-docs, and younger colleagues benefited enormously from his professional and personal guidance, and his influence continues through them and their students. For much of his career Jay also saw patients in his Upper West Side apartment, wishing to maintain a balance between the theoretical and practical aspects of psychology. As a high school student, Jay studied art through the Works Progress Administration. He served in WWII as a camouflage artist, and painting remained important to him throughout his life. Jay was married to Gilda Rosenblatt (nee Rosen) until her death in 1999. He is survived by his second wife, Pat, his children Daniel and Nina, and his grandchildren Olivia and Susannah. A memorial service will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Friday February 21 at 1:30.

McKEE--Dr. John Braxton. The Western New England Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the death of our beloved colleague and friend Dr. John Braxton McKee on February 3, 2014. His outstanding teaching skills, warmth and generosity of spirit will be deeply missed. Carole Goldberg, Pres., WNEPS Sybil Houlding, Pres., WNEIP

LOW--Robert Allen, former New York City Council member and mayoral candidate, died in San Francisco on January 3, 2014 at the age of 94. Bob Low was born in Scarsdale, NY on June 6, 1919 and raised in New York City. He and his siblings, Stuart and Doris, were the children of Clarence Low, former Treasurer of the Democratic State Committee, and Madeleine Low (nee Mayer), daughter of Levy Mayer, one of America's most distinguished lawyers of the early twentieth century and co-founder of the global law firm Mayer Brown LLP. Bob attended Collegiate School and Choate. He was the youngest tennis player ever to compete in a National Tournament at the age of nine, as a teenager won numerous titles and captained the men's varsity tennis team at Stanford University. The day after his graduation from Stanford in 1941, Bob entered the US Navy and served in the Pacific during World War II. He became one of the youngest Lieutenant Commanders ever and won nine battle stars during his service, fighting at Iwo Jima, Midway and Okinawa. After the war, Bob moved to Washington, D.C. where he worked at the Saturday Review Magazine and graduated from George Washington University Law School. Public service was deeply ingrained in Bob and guided his professional life. He served in the State Department and worked for Senators Herbert Lehman and Henry "Scoop" Jackson (a lifelong friend and mentor), handling congressional relations. In 1952 he met Frances Delia Levison, one of the first female reporters for Time-Life Magazine, and they were married for 60 years until her death in 2012. Bob would often say that she was "the most remarkable woman I ever knew". In 1954 the couple moved back to New York City where Bob was appointed assistant to Mayor Robert Wagner. In 1961, Bob was elected to the New York City Council where he served two terms, representing the "Silk Stockings" District of Manhattan's Upper East Side, East Harlem and Yorkville--a true cross section of upper, lower and middle income families. He co-authored one of the first anti-pollution laws in the United States. Bob was subsequently featured in a New York Times article entitled "Pollution's Nemesis", detailing his critical role in the fight for clean air, which eventually led to the federal Clean Air Act. Bob was also chairman of New York City's Buildings Committee oversaw the first major revision of the building code controlling construction in almost seventy years. Bob disguised himself as a struggling writer and moved into a slum in East Harlem for a week to experience first-hand the living conditions. On another occasion, he moonlighted as a taxi driver to understand their challenges and advocated for higher wages. He studied Spanish in order to communicate and connect with the growing Puerto Rican population. In 1969 he entered the New York City race for mayor and president of city council and, although the campaigns were unsuccessful, he proved to be a progressive and political maverick. In the 1970's Bob was appointed Regional Administrator for the Environmental Protection Administration and then Regional Representative for the U.S. Department of Energy, overseeing the growth and development of the New York City water system, and policing air pollution laws, waste water and nuclear waste in the region. In 1980, Bob returned to civilian life and a small private law practice. Bob and Frances pursued their passion for people, food and wine, founding "Le Cercle de Gastronomes", a precursor to contemporary "pop-up" restaurants, at their house in Dutchess County, where Bob served French haute-cuisine paired with fine wines. He was a food critic and an editor for the French restaurant guidebook "Gault et Millau". In 2002, he and Frances moved to San Francisco to be with their sons and grandchildren. Bob is survived by his brother, Stuart, as well as his sons, Allen and Roger, six grandchildren, and several nieces and nephews. "The Low Family asks that donations be made to The East Harlem School, an organization close to the Family's heart that serves low income students in New York City." A gathering of friends and family to celebrate Bob's life will be held at a later date.

MacCOWATT Haskell P.,April 15, 1931February 16, 2014 of Summit, NJ and Edgartown, MA, passed away peacefully on Sunday, February 16, 2014. He was 82. Born April 15, 1931 in Plainfield, NJ. He received an AB from Colgate University and a MS from MIT Sloan School of Management. He began his career at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn (BBDO) as a copywriter and account executive. He later joined CBS Inc. in New York, where he worked for 26 years, including serving as Vice President Investor Relations, Vice President and Treasurer, and retired as Senior Vice President of Administration in 1988. Throughout his life, he was active in a variety of civic, cultural and educational organizations. He was President of the Summit Common Council, Chairman of the Board of the Visual Arts Center of New Jersey, President of the Board of the Reeves Reed Arboretum and a trustee of the Summit Area Public Foundation. He was a Trustee Emeritus of Colgate University. He was President of the Edgartown Reading Room, President and a Trustee Emeritus of the Martha's Vineyard Preservation Trust and a trustee of the Edgartown Yacht Club. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Margaret Gentles MacCowatt, son Thomas H. MacCowatt (Anne L.), daughters Nancy M. Sanford, and Sally M. Black (Josiah M.) and seven grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in Paul's memory may be made to the Martha's Vineyard Preservation Trust or Colgate University.

PIEPER--William J.,MD, 84, of Chicago, died peacefully of natural causes at his home Thursday. He was born on October 21, 1929, on the South side of Chicago. Dr. Pieper graduated from St. Ignatius High School, and received his B.A. and M.D from The University of Illinois. He married Martha Heineman and they lived in Chicago and shared vacations on Martha's Vineyard, and Eagle, WI. Dr. William Pieper was a medical doctor and psychoanalyst who co-founded, co-authored and co-developed Intrapsychic Humanism, Addicted to Unhappiness, Smart Love, and the Smart Love Clinic and the Natalie G. Heineman Smart Love Preschool, with his wife and partner, Dr. Martha Heineman Pieper. Dr. William Pieper was a passionate advocate for children, and had an immediate rapport and empathy with young people. His honesty and willingness to see children as individuals made children adore and trust him. He was truly interested in what they had to say. He was a committed and caring clinician who loved his work. His favorite hobbies were riding horses with his wife and reading philosophy. Dr. Pieper was a loving husband, father, and grandfather, filled with enormous generosity and humanity. Dr. Pieper is survived by his wife, Dr. Martha Heineman Pieper; five children and stepchildren, Joseph Pieper, married to Janet, of Chicago, Victoria Heineman-Pieper of St Charles, Jessica Heineman-Pieper, married to Param Srikantia, of Cleveland, OH, Thalia Field, married to Jamie Jewett, of Providence, RI, and Johanna Heineman-Pieper, of Chicago; and five grandchildren, Colin, Hayley, Nola, Gershon, and Benjamin. The family will announce a memorial service. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Smart Love Family Services: www.smartlovefamily.org

REICHBACH--Micael. The Board of 330 Third Avenue is deeply saddened by the passing of its Board Member Micael Reichbach. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and friends. Rest In Peace Micael.

SHALAN--Dr. Leslie Joel, of Pittsfield, MA, formerly of Closter, NJ, died peacefully on February 19 after a long illness with family members by his bedside. He was 81 years old. He is survived by his beloved wife of 57 years, Arline, his three devoted sons, Glenn, Jeff (Chedia Ayari), and Gary (Paula), his three cherished grandchildren, Gail, Luke, and Eli, and his dear brother, Donald. Les practiced internal medicine in Englewood, NJ for 43 years before retiring in 2007. In concurrence with his long expressed wish, his body was donated to a medical school. A private memorial service will be held for the family. Donations can be made to either Englewood Hospital or the Berkshire Humane Society in Pittsfield, MA.

DRACHMAN--Harvey, passed away peacefully on February 19, 2014. He was 89 years old. Harvey was the loving husband of Suzanne (Applebaum) for 56 years and is survived by his cherished daughter Debbie, his devoted sister Diane and son-in-law Craig. His beloved late son Mark and late brother Stanley predeceased him. Harvey served in the United States Air Force in the Pacific during World War II. He spent his career starting in 1953 as a member of the New York Stock Exchange. He was an avid golfer, bridge and backgammon player, and an avid New York Giants fan. He lived his life with warmth, generosity, and integrity which made him a privilege to know. Funeral service to be held on Sunday, February 23rd at 11:30am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel located at 630 Amsterdam (at 92nd St.). Donations may be made to: Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation.

BALDWN--David. The Officers and Directors of the Realty Foundation of New York are deeply saddened at the passing of David. A long standing member of our Board, David was steadfast in his belief of our goals and held tight to his commitment to us. A highly respected real estate professional-mentored many-guiding with a gentle hand. A true gentleman, kind, generous, caring and most of all-true to those around him. We send our heartfelt condolences to family, friends and all those who were fortunate to have known David. May you rest in peace, dear David. H. Dale Hemmerdinger, Chairman Jeffrey R. Gural, President

HOLCOMB--Joan Hamilton, a longtime resident of Lloyd Harbor and Huntington, NY, died in hospice February 9, 2014 at 83, after a protracted battle with cancer and a stroke in late January. Born in New York City, she grew up there and in Syracuse, and was a 1952 graduate of Syracuse University. During the 1950's and 1960's, she was director of public relations for the Rochester Community Chest. Later, she was chairman of the Columbia County Council on the Arts. After moving to Long Island in 1977, she served as president and board member of the Visiting Nurse Service & Hospice of Suffolk, at a time when the service was expanding and developing plans for a hospice. She was a long-serving board member of Huntington's Heckscher Museum of Art and the St. Johnlands Nursing Center. A loving daughter, wife, mother and grandmother, she will be greatly missed by her many relatives and friends. She is survived by her husband of 53 years, Charles R. Holcomb, a former journalist; three daughters, Kristin Holcomb (MIchael Sharp) of Brooklyn, Alexandra Holcomb Bird (Andrew Bird) of Sydney, Australia, and Margaret Schubauer (James Schubauer II) of Lloyd Harbor, and eight grandchildren: Fiona Sharp, Nicholas, Samantha and Olivia Bird, and Katharine, Elizabeth, Julia and James Schubauer. A celebration of her life is planned for June. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service & Hospice of Suffolk, 505 Main St., Northport, NY 11768.

GELLMAN--Stephen G.,The partners, associates and personnel of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz mourn with sorrow the passing of their colleague and friend, Stephen G. Gellman. Steve was a brilliant lawyer, trusted advisor, and cherished partner. His commitment to excellence and to our firm and his warmth and generosity of spirit will be missed tremendously. We extend our sympathies and prayers to his loving and devoted wife, Wendy, to his daughters Lindsay and Alexa, who were his everlasting pride and joy, and to his mother, sister, brother and extended family. Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz

BALDWIN--David M.,85, of Vero Beach, Florida and Short Hills, New Jersey, died peacefully at his Florida home on February 16, 2014. David will be remembered as a caring gentleman, a loving husband and father, a hugely accomplished New York real estate investor and a champion in athletics, philanthropy and community enrichment. David was born in East Orange, New Jersey in 1928, and was raised in South Orange, New Jersey. The memorable summers of his early years were at the Baldwin family compound at Northampton Shores of Southampton Township. He graduated from the Pingry School in 1947 before attending William and Mary College and graduating in 1951 from Lehigh University with a Bachelor of Science degree in business administration. David served his country in the counterintelligence unit of the army and in 1954 became a real estate broker with the former Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc. In 1964, at the age of 35, he became President and Chief Executive of the company, the youngest chief executive officer of a major national real estate company. He negotiated the sale of the Noyes Company, together with Brown, Harris and Stevens to Mr. Harry Helmsley. This vital partnership lead to responsibility with Mr. Helmsley for many notable properties in New York City and across the country. Among the many awards that recognized his personal accomplishments: in 1964 The Real Estate Board of New York's "Young Man of the Year Award"; in 1966 its "Most Ingenious Deal in Manhattan" award, and in 1977 "Man of the Year" award from the Realty Foundation of New York. David exclusively represented many major corporations for their headquarters and staffing space. In 1994 following the winding down of the Helmsley portfolio, the David M. Baldwin Realty Company, Inc., was formed to specialize in the management of real estate in downtown Manhattan. David served on numerous real estate boards and foundations including the Real Estate Board of New York where he was governor and director and the Realty Foundation of New York. He was also the former Chairman and President of the Public Development Corporation of New York City. Throughout David's career, he instinctively sought to share his personal prosperity with many institutions and worthy initiatives in education, health care and the arts as a trustee and philanthropist. He was a founding member of the board of the Henry Stifel Spinal Cord Injury Foundation and ultimately a Vice-Chair of the Christopher and Dana Reeve Foundation; at Lehigh, he enabled the renovation of The Taylor Gym and created an endowed scholarship fund; at the Pingry School, his generosity helped enable a new campus and he commissioned a monumental bronze replica of Dr. John Pingry; he served as a longstanding Chair of the Strang Cancer Prevention Center in New York and was a member of the board of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center; he also served as Vice Chairman of The Riverside Theatre in Vero Beach and he generously supported Overlook Medical Center in Summit, New Jersey, the Indian River Medical Center in Vero Beach, Florida and The Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey, among other charities. David Baldwin was an accomplished athlete. At Pingry he was an all-star fullback and state ranked track star. Golf, however, was his keenest talent. He was a co-captain of the golf team at Lehigh and in 1954, he won the New Jersey State Open Championship and was runner-up in the National Lefthanders Golf Championship. He twice qualified for the U.S. Amateur and was also Club Champion at Baltusrol, Rock Spring and Essex County in New Jersey. In 2000, he was included in the "Team of the Century" by the New Jersey Star Ledger. He was a longstanding member of the United States Senior Golf Association. Club memberships included: in New Jersey Baltusrol Golf Club, where he was President, and The Short Hills Club; in Florida The John's Island Club, The Red Stick Golf Club and The Windsor Club in Vero Beach; and in New York Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, National Golf Links Club of America, The Meadow Club, The Bathing Corporation of Southampton, The University Club, and Doubles. Magic was David's fascination since early childhood. He assembled one of the most prominent personal collections of magic apparatus in the world. As a member of the International Brotherhood of Magicians, David published biographies of the Great Raymond and of Del-Ray-America's Foremost Magician. He enabled the creation of a new headquarters for The Magic Circle in London, among the most exclusive clubs in the world. In 1977, David commissioned a bronze figure of David Deviant that has become a coveted award for distinguished magicians around the world. In 2006 as an Honorary Lifetime Member he was awarded the Magic Circle's Silver Wand for outstanding service. As a devoted husband and father, he is survived by his loving family which include his wife of thirty-seven years, Barbara M. Baldwin; three sons, David Jr. of Basking Ridge, New Jersey; Alfred of Port Orange, Florida; William of Sag Harbor, New York; two stepchildren, Martin "Fritz" Stein III of Landing, New Jersey, Kimberly Paige Fleming of Aspen, Colorado; three grandchildren Liam Fleming, Alexander and Paulina Stein and a twin brother Theodore Baldwin of Summit, New Jersey. David was pre-deceased by his youngest son Ted and a brother, Cyril. Contributions as a memorial may be made in David's name to The Pingry School, 131 Martinsville Road, Basking Ridge, New Jersey 07920; Lehigh University, 27 Memorial Drive West, Bethlehem, Pennsylvania 18015; or The Riverside Theatre, 3250 Riverside Park Drive, Vero Beach, Florida 32963. A Celebration of Life Service will be held at Community Church of Vero Beach on February 28, 2014 at 11:00am. A reception will follow at the John's Island Golf Club. Services are under the direction of Strunk Funeral Home Vero Beach, Florida. An online guestbook is available at www.strunkfuneralhome.com.

GELDER--Zoe, age 95, of Atlanta and formerly of Merrick, Long Island, Manhattan and Pompano Beach, Florida passed away peacefully on February 19, 2014. She was born in Brooklyn, New York on June 18, 1918, the daughter of Henrietta and Irving Rosen. Zoe grew up in Brooklyn. She later met and married her beloved husband Gene Gelder and raised her family in Merrick, Long Island. She was a devoted wife and mother and a true friend to all who knew her. She was predeceased by her husband Gene Gelder and her brother Leonard Rosen. Zoe is survived by her son Roger Gelder and his wife Corky of Atlanta, sister-in-law Frieda Rosen of Brooklyn, NY; granddaughter Jennifer Gelder of Atlanta; grandson Josh Gelder and his wife Karen of New York; great-grandchildren Jake and Alex Newberg and Jack and Mia Gelder. Other survivors include niece Ilene Rosen. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to The William Breman Jewish Home, Temple Sinai or Weinstein Hospice all located in Atlanta.

BRENNER--Howard. Of Newton, MA, age 84, February 17, 2014. Born in the Bronx, NY, March 16, 1929. Professor Emeritus of Chemical Engineering at MIT who led an extraordinary 60-year academic career. Dedicated scholar and prolific author who received numerous honors and awards recognizing his profound contributions to the field of fluid dynamics, including election to the National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering. Loving husband of Lisa Glucksman. Beloved father of Leslie (Stephen) Lipschultz, Joyce (John) Hagen-Brenner and Suzanne Brenner (John Opferkuch), his children with wife, Lorraine Brenner. Cherished grandfather of Margo, Alex, Daniel, Julia, Kiera, Max and Miles. Brother of Renee Gould. A memorial service will be held at MIT in the fall. Gifts may be directed to the Howard Brenner Memorial Fund at MIT. Checks may be sent to: MIT ASO, c/o Teri Quill, 8-328, 77 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge MA 02139.

BURGOON--Caroline Carleton, passed away on Saturday, February 15, 2014, in San Jose, CA, at 78. Born and raised as the daughter of United Church of Christ Missionaries in the Middle East, Caroline was educated at Oberlin College, and lived and worked throughout the United States, Latin America and the Middle East. She was for more than 52 years the loving wife of David Warner Burgoon, and raised their four children with deep devotion. She is survived by her husband, David; her four children, David Alford, Kathy, Brian and Ian; and her six grandchildren. She is and will be missed by the many whose lives she touched.

GEORGE--Genevieve D. 83, of Endwell, NY, died February 2 at her home. Born in Woodlawn, NY to Anthony F. and Florence Wiegers she was predeceased by her husband, Richard F. George, her brother Anthony F. (Bud) Wiegers, Jr., and her grandson, Samuel Lincoln George. Genevieve is survived by her children Laura George Hess -Bantam, CT, Alan Lawrence George and his wife, Caie -Reno, NV and Austin Leet George and his companion Hunter Hillers of Manlius, NY. She is also survived by her brother and sister-in-law, George and Elizabeth (Betsy) Wiegers of Vail, CO, her sister and brother-in-law, Marilyn and Louis Thomas of Canandaigua, NY, and five grandchildren who lovingly called her "GG." Genevieve was appointed by several New York State Governors and proudly served many years as a member of the New York State Board of Visitors Region III, and spent her lifetime volunteering in many organizations in Binghamton, NY, Clayton, NY and Sanibel Island, FL. Please visit: www.ParsonsFuneral.com to offer your condolences.

FRIED--Peggy Anne Ellis, age 88, died February 8, 2014 at the Lillian Booth Actors Home in Englewood, NJ. Born LaBlanche Pafford Metz in Sandersville, GA, she was the daughter of Ethleen Sarepta Pafford Metz and Alvin C. Metz. She was the wife of the late Walter Fried. A resident of New York City, Peggy was a Broadway actress, chanteuse, radio personality, television producer and President of Pafford Productions. She was in show business from the time she was three years old. Interment took place at the family plot in Palmetto Cemetery, Brunswick, GA. If desired, contributions may be made to the Actors Fund.

BELLIN--Eugene Lloyd M.D. passed away in his sleep on February 9, 2014 at the age of 83 of chronic and debilitating illness. He was a graduate of Yale University, University of Utah Medical School, and Maimonides Medical Center. He faithfully served his country as a Physician Captain in the United States Air Force. He then went on to practice internal medicine in the Bronx, and was known as a tireless and sometimes unpaid doctor, whose devotion to his craft and patients outweighed other considerations. He fearlessly championed the underprivileged which included working after his retirement with the Innocence Project at Cardozo Law School and feeding the homeless at the Bowery Mission. He was a devoted father, grandfather, and brother. He leaves behind three children, Stephanie, Jonathan and Jennifer, his brother Evan, and seven grandchildren. He will be missed.

CEDERBAUM--Selma, age 86. Beloved wife of 67 years of Harold Cederbaum. Selma was deeply loved by her children, Donna and Arthur Salus, Judi and Sam Ross and Ken and Sandy Cederbaum as well as her adoring grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

HIRSCHHORN--Susan, We mourn the passing of Susan Hirschhorn, 68, on February 10, 2014. Beloved mother to Jason Hirschhorn and Jody and Jacques Stambouli. Proud grandma of Lily, Robbie and Amelie. Loving sister, aunt, cousin and friend. She meant a lot to many, and everything to a special few. She will be forever in our hearts.

BLOOMBERG--Betty Jane, 87, died on February 5, 2014, in her home on the Upper East Side, surrounded by loving family and friends. Born April 28, 1926, in Brooklyn, NY. Adoring daughter to the late Sol E. Bloomberg and the late Sara Leifert Bloomberg. Devoted sister to the late Leonard J. Blayer and caring aunt to the late Seth P. Blayer. Treasured aunt to Zoe Blayer Gray and her husband Lou Gray, and cherished great-aunt to their sons Max and Nick. Loyal employee to the late industrialist and attorney Francis Levien, and manager of Levien Associates after his death. Her employment with the Leviens spanned an astonishing 70 years, with Betty only retiring due to illness mere weeks before her death. In addition to supporting medical research and several charities, Betty enjoyed knitting and for many years routinely donated her handmade baby blankets to local hospitals. She was optimistic, elegant, fun-loving, humorous, energetic, generous, adorable, and one-of-a-kind. Our loss is monumental. The family wishes to extend their gratitude to SeniorBridge and to Calvary Hospice for their support in her final days. Funeral service Tuesday, February 25 at 10am, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st St., New York City.

Hirsch--Jack 93 years young. Loved by all, is survived by his beloved girlfriend Shirley Sandridge, sister Hortense, children; Jo Leslie, Danny, Barry and Lee, 5 beautiful grandchildren and 2 great grandchildren. A WWII Veteran, inventor of the A.I.C. Wet Smoke Scrubber used in incinerators to clean thousands of tons of soot and ash from NYC air. Funeral 2/21, Shalom Memorial, 1pm Smithtown. NY
DRACHMAN--Harvey. A kind, wonderful friend who we will sorely miss. Marianne & Harvey Bernstein

DITTMER--Frances. The entire Drawing Center family, past and present, mourns the sudden tragic death of our esteemed former Board Member Frances Ronshausen Dittmer. Frannie had a rare combination of superior intellect, a great eye for art and incisive opinions about the role of the Visual Arts in our society coupled with infectious enthusiasm and tremendous joie de vivre. She was always generous with her support and provided wise council and valuable encouragement to three successive Directors and to her fellow board members. The Drawing Center remembers with pride, and will always be grateful for, her contributions. Our profound sympathy goes to her family. Frances Beatty Adler, Jane Dresner Sadaka, Eric Rudin, Board Co-Chairs. Brett Littman, Exec. Director

KATZ--Eleanor Meyerhoff. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are deeply saddened by the passing of Ellie Katz, beloved wife of Herbert D. Katz (zl), past national president of AFHU. Ellie was cherished by her children, Tom, Sally, Danny, Walter Katz and Laura Cutler. She and Herb were visionary philanthropists, humanitarians and advocates for Israel and the Jewish community. Through the Joseph & Harvey Meyerhoff Family Charitable Funds, the Meyerhoff and Katz families have increased knowledge, provided educational opportunity and perpetuated Jewish heritage. Hebrew University Benefactors, Ellie and Herb created scholarships and fellowships, and advanced the work of The Truman Research Institute for the Advancement of Peace. Their legacy of goodness will sustain future generations. We extend our condolences to the Katz and Meyerhoff families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President American Friends of The Hebrew University Michael S. Kurtz, Chairman Daniel I. Schlessinger, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

BARRETT--Katherine E.Travis, on Friday, February 14, 2014. Beloved wife of Damien and mother of Casey and Maggie of Fairfield, NJ, and beloved daughter of Marilyn Travis of New York City, Katie, 39, died peacefully, having battled her cancer with brilliant ferocity. Memorial service Sunday, March 16, 1:30pm, Community Church of New York, Unitarian Universalist, 40 E. 35 St., New York.

BLOEDE--Merle Huie. Mickey died February 18th, 2014 in Dallas, TX after a remarkably courageous six year struggle with cancer. She was born in Lohn, TX, on May 4th, 1921, a town founded by her great-grandfather in the 1890s. She was the daughter of Hulon William Huie and Anna (Lohn) Huie. She graduated from Lohn High School in 1938. Despite her academic achievements she was unable to continue her education due to the effects of the Great Depression. She was very proud of her work in management at the Office of Censorship during the war. After the war she married a young 8th Air Force Bombardier, named Vic Bloede, on March 11, 1945. Shortly thereafter they started their life together in New York, where Vic began his remarkable career in advertising, ably aided by Mickey. Her insight into people, personalities, and business helped propel Vic to the very top of the advertising world where he retired as chairman of Benton & Bowles, one of the largest international agencies at that time. He always said he couldn't have done it without her. Outside of advertising Mickey had a wide variety of interests including significant philanthropic pursuits and charitable activities. Her achievements included the founding of North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, and service on the executive board of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center Society, NYC, and work with American Cancer Society, among many others. In the social realm she served as President of the North Shore Southern Society. Also, Mickey was a member of a number of clubs: Sands Point (NY) Bath & Tennis, Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, Flower Hill Garden, Delray Dunes (FL) Golf and Country, and The Ocean Club of Florida. She was a member of the Community Reformed Church, Manhasset, NY, First Presbyterian Church, Delray Beach, FL, and later Highland Park Presbyterian Church, Dallas, TX. Throughout Mickey's life her intellect, wide ranging curiosity, keen wit, and fondness for a good debate were her hallmarks. It is worth noting because of her self-taught business acumen, her stock broker often consulted her. Mickey joked that he should be paying her. But beyond all her experiences and accomplishments clearly the most important thing in her life was the love of her family, by whom she will be dearly missed. Mickey was preceded in death by her husband of fifty four years, Victor G. Bloede. Survived by her three children, Dee Anna Smith Willis, Victor G. Bloede IV (Nancy), and Susan Lohn Quaid, and grandchildren Elizabeth Murphy, Amy Arata, Lindsay Carneal, Alexandra Quaid, Victor G. Bloede V, Forrest Bloede, Laura Bloede, sister-in-law Rama Huie, a dozen grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews. Memorial service February 24th, 4pm at Highland Park Presbyterian Church, Dallas.

The bride owns a catering company in New Jersey; the groom works in New York at an investment banking firm.
The bride is a lifestyle and interiors writer; the groom is a photographer.
The bride is the morning traffic anchor for NY1; the groom is the senior media correspondent for CNN.

Mr. Lump is the director of branded content in the media group at Condé Nast Publications; Mr. Runnette is a vice president who oversees the development and production of videos on the web for a television production company.
The bride is a physician assistant at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center; the groom sells advertising for a sports website.
The bride and groom, both lawyers, are married in Atlanta.
The bride is an executive at a hedge fund; the groom is a founding partner in a law firm.
The bride is a book editor; the groom is a media adviser.
The bride is a lawyer; the groom is a recruiter for an executive search firm.
The bride works for a television show; the groom is an investment banker.

The bride is a graduate of Princeton, where she continues to study, and the groom graduated from Yale.
The couple met at Penn, where they are now studying for medical degrees.
Although some officials were not amused, many Neapolitans welcomed a new campaign to track down owners who do not pick up after their dogs by using the animals’ DNA samples.
Coach Jim Boeheim was ejected from a regular-season game for the first time in his 38-year career for arguing an offensive foul call with his team trailing Duke by 2 late in the game.
The Bobcats used an 18-3 run in the fourth quarter to break open a tight game and snap Memphis’s four-game win streak.
“Downton Abbey” fans who watch Houston PBS don’t have to leave Edwardian England after each episode ends; they can keep the mood going with Ernie Manouse’s “Manor of Speaking.”

Because Texas declined to expand Medicaid eligibility for poor adults, thousands of people, especially in the state’s impoverished colonias, are finding it almost impossible to obtain health insurance.
As the demonstrations continued to grow, Secretary of State John Kerry strengthened his criticism of the Venezuelan government’s response to the protesters.
Discussing real problems is tricky, so many candidates skip talk of boring business in favor of topics that resonate: President Obama, border security, prayer in schools.
Environmental groups are suing industries for excess pollution directly, rather than relying on the government to take action, as some say agencies have been slow to enforce laws.
Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
A university lecturer who was shot to death had made several trips east to the capital to take part in antigovernment protests, a friend said.
Anna Nordqvist shot a five-under-par 67 at the L.P.G.A. Thailand in Chonburi for a four-stroke lead over top-ranked Inbee Park (67) and Michelle Wie (69).
Venus Williams won her 45th career WTA title Saturday with a 6-3, 6-0 victory over Alize Cornet of France in the Dubai Championships in the United Arab Emirates.
The family of a Russian boxer who was critically injured during a Madison Square Garden fight filed court papers in New York preparing to sue.
The Heat’s LeBron James planned to be fitted for a mask to protect his broken nose, saying his availability Sunday against the Chicago Bulls would be a game-time decision.
Ernie Els reached the semifinals of the Match Play Championship by getting past Jordan Spieth, 20, in Marana, Ariz.
Princeton University’s “A” squad was only the second team to ever win the Amateur Team East championship two years in a row, and the last time that happened was in the mid-1970s.
The Los Angeles Dodgers announced that they had signed the Cuban shortstop Erisbel Arruebarrena to a five-year contract.
Jaime Garcia will return to St. Louis on Sunday to have doctors examine his surgically repaired throwing shoulder, making it unlikely he will be ready for the start of the season.
The running back Ray Rice was charged with simple assault and is accused of knocking out his fiancée, Janay Palmer, last weekend in Atlantic City.
He started as a hairdresser making organic hair-care products with herbs and other plants, eventually beginning the company that made natural cosmetics popular in the United States.
American military officials insisted an annual exercise, called Iron Fist, had nothing to do with a dispute over islands, but this year, the Japanese team came packing.
Detroit can learn from New Orleans, where a fix that appeared rational to some was thrown aside for a way forward that has been messier but politically more palatable.

PIERSON--Harry Edwin, 94, passed away Saturday, February 22, 2014, at his home in Manhasset, NY. He was born September 23, 1919, in Philadelphia, to Harry and Mildred Pierson and raised in Allentown, PA. He attended Temple University, where he met his wife, graduating in 1941 prior to entering the United States Army. During World War II, he served as a field artillery officer in the Pacific theatre earning a Bronze Star for his actions in the Philippines. After his discharge from the army, he attended New York University Law School. Graduating in 1949, he had a successful career focusing on commercial real estate, working as an attorney for New York Life Insurance Company, and as an executive of Pacific Coast Properties, W.T. Grant, and W.R. Grace & Co. He is survived by his adoring family including his wife of 70 years, Mae Florence (Lange) Pierson; daughters Ellen Marlin and Elizabeth Casalino; son-in-law James Casalino; grandson Timothy Marlin and his wife Sara; and nephew James Pelzer and his wife Ellen. Funeral services will be at 10am on Tuesday, February 25 at Saint Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Manhasset, NY. His wit, wisdom, and loving heart will be dearly missed.

WALLACH--Stephen H.,of West Orange, NJ, and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, 88, passed away on February 22 in Florida. He was a loyal friend to all those he knew, a terrific grandpa and a wonderful example of character to many. Steve was a loving companion to Barbara Freid Gottesman for the past 26 years, and with her he inherited a large family that he made his own. Of Steve, many said, simply, he was a gentle man and a gentleman. Steve, devoted son of the late Selma and Morton Wallach, was born in Orange, NJ, and attended Orange High School. He enlisted in the United States Navy in 1943, serving in the Atlantic, and was discharged as a Lieutenant (junior grade) in 1946. He graduated from Muhlenberg College after World War II. Steve spent nearly 40 years working for the US Shoe Corporation, where he was an executive in the sales department and is known for having mentored many young executives. He retired in 1991. Steve was a lifelong sports fan, particularly of the football Giants, and he was the most avid golfer. He is survived by his longtime companion Barbara, her three children, their spouses and eight grandchildren; a sister, Fran Weil, and a nephew, Bert Weil; and several great-nieces and a great-nephew. A funeral service will be held Tuesday at 10am at Menorah Chapels, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Wounded Warrior Project at woundedwarriorproject.org.
PERRONE--Frances. April 5, 1923 - February 24, 2013 Dear mom, we missyou. Love, Caroline & Andrew Philip & Anthony
SCHWARTZ--Barry, We forever cherish the memories of our beloved friend and extend our deepest sympathies to Elaine and family. Brenda and Barry Serper

Marion and Jerry Sussman Daniel and Maria Sussman Peter Sussman Asher and Leo Sussman Oren Rosenbaum

UTLEY--Garrick, The members of the Advisory Board of SUNY Global/Levin Institute mourn the passing of Garrick Utley, our founding president and the guiding intellect for the Institute in focusing SUNY's involvement in the challenge of globalization for New York State. Garrick led the Institute from its inception in 2003 in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack, and gave it substance through educational, research and outreach programs in the economic development and human resource sectors. He conceptualized and led a state-wide study of the impact of globalization on the State published in 2011 as "New York and the World". Garrick's effective leadership, the respect with which he was held throughout the world, his broad range of knowledge and his enthusiasm, energy and edication to excellence will be missed by his colleagues at SUNY and, in particular, by the Advisory Board. Garrick's family informs us that a notice of the time and place of a memorial service will be placed in the New York Times in the coming weeks. Matthew Nimetz, Chair Paul Tagliabue, Former Chair SUNY Global/Levin Institute

ZEELANDER--Norbert J.,died suddenly while on vacation in the British Virgin Islands on Sunday, February 16. He was 75 years old. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Susan (Haness), whom he met at Queens College in 1959, and by his children, Jeffrey and his wife Maureen Welsh and their sons Zachary and Joshua; by Elliot and his wife Lisa and their children Zoe and Jacob; by Julie and her husband Erik Lederman and their children Bella and Oliver. He served in the United States Army Reserves and graduated from Brooklyn Law School. He started his career in the fledgling computer industry, and developed companies in the computer hardware and communications industries. In 1991 he started Mathers Associates, an Investment Partnership with offices in Ambler, PA and Los Angeles, CA. Norbert was born in Antwerp, Belgium on February 24, 1938, to Ann and Theo Zeelander. The family, together with Theo's parents, fled the German invasion May 10, 1940, staying one step ahead of the Nazis and eventually staying in the south of France. His sister Rosine Fields (now deceased) was born in Toulouse, 1941. A year later the family was able to get into Jamaica, and then to Curacao, where they lived until the War ended. They then tried to enter the United States but were not allowed to stay, and they returned to Belgium for two years. In 1948 they immigrated to the U.S. where a second sister, Estelle Heimann, was later born. Norbert was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He loved his nieces and nephews and their children and he enjoyed watching his extended family grow. Norbert was a caring and moral person. Funeral services are being coordinated by Boyd-Horrox Funeral Home in Norristown, PA and will be held at Tiferet Bet Israel, Blue Bell, PA. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice in Norbert's memory.

UTLEYGarrick. The board and staff of Public Radio International mourn the loss of our long time trustee Garrick Utley, who inspired us by his commitment to international reporting. The world has lost one of its keenest observers. We offer our deepest sympathy to his family.

UTLEY--Garrick. The German Academic Exchange Service Alumni Association is deeply saddened by the passing of Garrick Utley, a longstanding honorary member of our board. Garrick was a steadfast supporter of international exchange programs. A true gentleman, he exemplified the highest standards of television journalism. We miss his intelligence, humor, and engagement. Manfred Philipp, President, Mechthild Schmidt, Vice President

PIEPER--William J.,MD, 84, of Chicago, died peacefully of natural causes at his home Thursday. He was born on October 21, 1929, on the South side of Chicago. Dr. Pieper graduated from St. Ignatius High School, and received his B.A. and M.D from The University of Illinois. He married Martha Heineman and they lived in Chicago and shared vacations on Martha's Vineyard, and Eagle, WI. Dr. William Pieper was a medical doctor and psychoanalyst who co-founded, co-authored and co-developed Intrapsychic Humanism, Addicted to Unhappiness, Smart Love, and the Smart Love Clinic and the Natalie G. Heineman Smart Love Preschool, with his wife and partner, Dr. Martha Heineman Pieper. Dr. William Pieper was a passionate advocate for children, and had an immediate rapport and empathy with young people. His honesty and willingness to see children as individuals made children adore and trust him. He was truly interested in what they had to say. He was a committed and caring clinician who loved his work. His favorite hobbies were riding horses with his wife and reading philosophy. Dr. Pieper was a loving husband, father, and grandfather, filled with enormous generosity and humanity. Dr. Pieper is survived by his wife, Dr. Martha Heineman Pieper; five children and stepchildren, Joseph Pieper, married to Janet, of Chicago, Victoria Heineman-Pieper of St Charles, Jessica Heineman-Pieper, married to Param Srikantia, of Cleveland, OH, Thalia Field, married to Jamie Jewett, of Providence, RI, and Johanna Heineman-Pieper, of Chicago; and five grandchildren, Colin, Hayley, Nola, Gershon, and Benjamin. The family will announce a memorial service. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Smart Love Family Services: www.smartlovefamily.org

LEE--Jane Love, cherished and devoted wife of George Lee, passed away peacefully at her home Thursday, February 20th, 2014 at age 86. She is survived by her adoring son James Love Lee and daughter-in-law Cynthia Rosenbloom Lee; beloved brothers Matthew Love and Robert Love; and her beloved nieces and nephews: Wendy Love Barnard; Steve Love and wife Jeanie; Victoria Love and husband Greg Rowan; Bill Love and wife Elizabeth; and Gregory Love. She is also survived by her cherished grand-nieces and grand-nephews: Alessandra Love Simons; Lance Love Barnard; Sam Love Yusim; Chase Love; Phoebe Love Yusim; Caroline Love; Amelia Jane Love; and Natalie Love. She was predeceased by her treasured parents, Minerva Rosetsky Love and Joseph Love, dear brother Stanley Love and much-loved nephew Brett Love. Jane radiated a loving kindness, understanding and generosity of spirit that touched and inspired all those who formed the tapestry of her life. Sophisticated and elegant, beautiful and humorous, she was a giver: a devoted wife and mother; a wise matriarch to her family; and above all a true friend who met life's challenges with amazing courage, grace and style. We will all miss her greatly and will continue to carry her in our hearts and spirits forever. A private family burial service will be held Wednesday, February 26th, 2014. Memorial donations can be made to Visiting Nurse Service of New York (VNSNY) Hospice and Palliative Care (1250 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, Ny 10001, Attn: Stephanie Street).

BALDWIN--David. The Board of Directors and staff of the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation express great sadness at the loss of former board member, David M. Baldwin, who passed away on February 16, 2014. As one of the founding leaders of the American Paralysis Association (APA), which eventually transformed into the Reeve Foundation, David dedicated his intellect and passion to ignite the APA's mission of redefining the reality of paralysis. He was a dear friend of APA chairman, Hank Stifel, who conceived a vision of a collaborative movement between scientists and researchers to debunk the dogma that the spinal cord, once injured, couldn't be repaired. David was instrumental in the transition of the APA to the Reeve Foundation, and was a key board member from the group's inception in 1982 to 2008. Over the years, the Baldwin family donated close to a million dollars to safeguard the growth of the Reeve Foundation's research programs. David's legacy of generosity and compassion, will serve as a guiding force for the Reeve Foundation to carry forward. Our thoughts are with David's wife, Barbara, and the entire Baldwin family.

KATZ--Eleanor Meyerhoff. The Herbert D. Katz Center for Advanced Judaic Studies at the University of Pennsylvania is deeply saddened by the death of Ellie Katz, wife of the late Herbert D. Katz. Ellie was a warm and generous friend, mother, and wife, and was an inspiration to all who knew her. She and Herb were visionary philanthropists, who have been vital to the creation and promotion of Jewish learning at Penn and around the world. They have created chairs and lecture series, supported academic publications, and been founding catalysts in the creation of the Katz Center, a world leader in Judaic scholarship. Ellie and Herb's son, Thomas O. Katz, currently serves as Board Chairman of the Center. Our sincere condolences to the extended family. David Ruderman, Joseph Meyerhoff Professor of Modern Jewish History and Ella Darivoff Director of the Herbert D. Katz Center for Advanced Judaic Studies, University of Pennsylvania.

GREENMAN--Charles. Beloved husband, father, friend, attorney and advisor dies at 66. Charles Preston Greenman, a commercial litigator at the law firm of Troutman Sanders LLP, where he was a partner and defended numerous class actions relating to a wide variety of consumer and securities issues, died on Saturday, February 22, 2014, at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. He was respected both in and out of the courtroom as a force to be reckoned with. He served as Assistant Commissioner of the Department of Consumer Affairs for the City of New York and Consumer Advocate for the City--charting new ground for aggressively protecting consumers' rights. Much beloved husband of Jane, father of Margot, Jaclyn and Danielle, proud grandfather of Seymour (Simi), father in-law of Caio and son-in-law of Isabelle, as well as adored brother, friend, uncle, and godfather, Charles was larger than life. Charles was a graduate of Albion College in Michigan where he played college football, Boston University, where he earned a master's degree in history and New York University School of Law, from which he graduated with honors. He served as Chairman of the Robinson-Patman Act Subcommittee of the New York State Bar Association and Chairman of the Committee on Consumer Affairs of the New York County Lawyers' Association. In addition, he taught Consumer Law at NYU School of Law for more than a dozen years and wrote numerous articles on consumer law issues for the New York Law Journal and similar publications. His outsized physique, spirit and uncanny intelligence made people cling to him, looking for protection and guidance in a perilous and sometimes uncontrollable world, a responsibility naturally bestowed upon him that he embraced and enjoyed. Charles loved to travel, play tennis, bicycle, and to be doted upon by his adoring wife and daughters, who will miss him more than he could have ever imagined. We are better human beings today for knowing Charles and being part of his life. He made his home a welcome haven to all comers--friends, family and all their friends and children--all of whom came to him to seek advice and companionship. His giant personality was contagious and inspiring. He made his mark on the world and leaves a gap that can never be filled. Funeral services will be held on Monday, February 24, 2014 at 11:45am at Riverside Chapel in New York City, and the family will be receiving guests at home from Monday early evening until Friday, February 28, 2014.

GREENMAN--Charles P. The partners, associates and staff of Troutman Sanders mourn with great sorrow the sudden and unexpected passing of our partner, colleague and friend, Charles P. Greenman. Charles was a brilliant lawyer, trusted advisor and cherished friend. He was highly respected by his clients, friends and colleagues for his creative advocacy in litigation matters, as well as for his exceptionally thoughtful advice on business and real estate transactions. All of us who were privileged to work with Charlie will miss him tremendously. We extend our deepest sympathies and our prayers to his wife, Jane and to his daughters, Margot (Caio), Jaclyn and Danielle and his new grandson, who were his pride and joy, and to his brothers, Mark and James and his extended family.

DITTMER--Frances. The entire Drawing Center family, past and present, mourns the sudden tragic death of our esteemed former Board Member Frances Ronshausen Dittmer. Frannie had a rare combination of superior intellect, a great eye for art and incisive opinions about the role of the Visual Arts in our society coupled with infectious enthusiasm and tremendous joie de vivre. She was always generous with her support and provided wise council and valuable encouragement to three successive Directors and to her fellow board members. The Drawing Center remembers with pride, and will always be grateful for, her contributions. Our profound sympathy goes to her family. Frances Beatty Adler, Jane Dresner Sadaka, Eric Rudin, Board Co-Chairs. Brett Littman, Exec. Director

BLOOMBERG--Betty Jane, 87, died on February 5, 2014, in her home on the Upper East Side, surrounded by loving family and friends. Born April 28, 1926, in Brooklyn, NY. Adoring daughter to the late Sol E. Bloomberg and the late Sara Leifert Bloomberg. Devoted sister to the late Leonard J. Blayer and caring aunt to the late Seth P. Blayer. Treasured aunt to Zoe Blayer Gray and her husband Lou Gray, and cherished great-aunt to their sons Max and Nick. Loyal employee to the late industrialist and attorney Francis Levien, and manager of Levien Associates after his death. Her employment with the Leviens spanned an astonishing 70 years, with Betty only retiring due to illness mere weeks before her death. In addition to supporting medical research and several charities, Betty enjoyed knitting and for many years routinely donated her handmade baby blankets to local hospitals. She was optimistic, elegant, fun-loving, humorous, energetic, generous, adorable, and one-of-a-kind. Our loss is monumental. The family wishes to extend their gratitude to SeniorBridge and to Calvary Hospice for their support in her final days. Funeral service Tuesday, February 25 at 10am, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st St., New York City.
Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 24, 2014.
Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and “Cabaret” co-director Rob Marshall talk about bringing the Tony-winning musical back to Broadway.
Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actors Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall.
Part 2: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall each recall how they first encountered “Cabaret” in their lives and careers.
Part 3: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall discuss why the show was groundbreaking when it first premiered and why it continues to be important.
Part 4: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall talk about how the 1972 film of “Cabaret” transformed the production.
Part 5: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams discuss their “Cabaret” characters and the difference between musical and non-musical theater.
Part 6: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall explore their collaborative process.
Part 7: Alan Cumming describes what it’s like to work simultaneously on “Cabaret” and “The Good Wife.”
Part 8: Michelle Williams talks about how her daughter influences her career choices; the director Rob Marshall reflects on what Broadway has lost.
Part 9: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall discuss the historical context and relevance of the show’s story and setting.
Part 10: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams reveal what their “Cabaret” roles share in common with other parts they’ve played.
Part 11: The director Rob Marshall talks about the important role John Kander and Fred Ebb played in his career; Alan Cumming describes meeting Joel Grey, who originated the Emcee role.
Part 12: The director Rob Marshall reflects on returning to theater after working exclusively in film for 15 years.
Part 13: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams talk about what draws them to the roles they choose.
Part 14: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall explain their rehearsal process.
Part 15: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall describe how they make decisions about future projects.
