WOOL--Charlotte. Sisterhood of Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our beloved past President and Trustee, Charlotte Wool. Sincere sympathy is extended to her devoted daughters, Poppy and Iris, and the entire family.

WOOL--Charlotte Schlesinger, died peacefully at home on Sunday, February 23rd, shortly before her 94th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Herbert, mother of Iris and Howard Perry and Poppy and Ronny Wurtzburger, grandmother of Marcie and Scott Blackman, Larry and Susan Usilaner, Michelle and Jack DeCicco, Stefanie Perry, Mindy and Steven Shulman, Howard and Lisa Neuthaler, Bonnie and Seth Harris, Richard and Jennifer Wurtzburger, great-grandmother of Alex, Eric, Jacob, Harrison, Zachary, Jared, Harrison, Evelyn, Matthew, Josh, Nicole, Ryan and Gavin, sister of the late Ruth and Harold, and beloved aunt. A 1940 graduate of NYU, for 47 years she stood behind and beside her husband as he built his business and then became a founder and leader of charitable institutions. She served as a volunteer for over sixty years, first at her children's schools and most notably at the Park East Synagogue and Day School. She taught three generations how to be a caring child, spouse, parent, grandparent and friend, a responsible member of the community and an honorable person. She will be loved and missed by all. Funeral services will be held at Park East Synagogue on Tuesday, February 25th at 11:30am. Donations in her memory may be made to Charlotte & Herbert Wool Scholarship Fund at Park East Synagogue.

TOWBIN--Albert S.,87, of New York City, died peacefully on February 23, 2014 at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home. Beloved husband of Nancy, devoted father of Melissa Joan, loving brother of Irene S. Haupt, uncle of Mason Haupt and Marcia Tazbin, great-uncle of Meredith, Kendall, and Davis Haupt and Daniel and Emily Tazbin, and great friend to many. Albert was in a family furniture business for 40 years. He served as a first lieutenant in World War II and was stationed in Okinawa. He was a golfer of sixty years, a private plane pilot, a poker player, and an avid sports enthusiast. He served on the Board of Directors of his coop for 19 years. Funeral Services will be held on Tuesday, February 25, at 11:00am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan, NY. Donations can be made to Lincoln Square Synagogue at 180 Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY 10023.

UTLEY--Garrick, The members of the Advisory Board of SUNY Global/Levin Institute mourn the passing of Garrick Utley, our founding president and the guiding intellect for the Institute in focusing SUNY's involvement in the challenge of globalization for New York State. Garrick led the Institute from its inception in 2003 in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack, and gave it substance through educational, research and outreach programs in the economic development and human resource sectors. He conceptualized and led a state-wide study of the impact of globalization on the State published in 2011 as "New York and the World". Garrick's effective leadership, the respect with which he was held throughout the world, his broad range of knowledge and his enthusiasm, energy and edication to excellence will be missed by his colleagues at SUNY and, in particular, by the Advisory Board. Garrick's family informs us that a notice of the time and place of a memorial service will be placed in the New York Times in the coming weeks. Matthew Nimetz, Chair Paul Tagliabue, Former Chair SUNY Global/Levin Institute
DECAMP--Paul William. 2/25/2004 Ten years ago we lost our dear father. Love from Susan, Mary, Ann Paul, John, Karen, Joe and Jim

WOLPIN--Gerald. 1918-2014 Lake Worth, FL/Great Neck, NY; Ret. Navy Air Corps Lt. Commander, CCNY 1937, MA Columbia 1938, Pensacola and MIT. Ret. VP Alexander's Dept. Stores. Survived by wife Miriam, brother Arnold, sister Frankie Ross, daughters Bonnie Arbesfeld (husband Mel), Carole Bass, grandchildren Dr Stephanie Katz, Jeffrey Katz (wife Suzanne), Rachel Bass, great-grandson Jason Katz.

WOOL--Charlotte. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our dedicated leader and Sisterhood Trustee, Charlotte Wool, who together with her late husband, Treasurer Herbert Wool, were generous benefactors of every aspect of congregational life. The Wool Lecture Hall is one of their legacies. Sincere condolences to their children, Poppy (Vice President Ronny) Wurtzburger, Iris (Howard) Perry, grandchildren Larry (Susan), Marcie (Scott), Michelle (Jack), Stefanie, Mindy (Steven), Howard (Lisa) parents of our day school, Bonnie (Seth), Richard (Jennifer). Funeral services, Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street, Tuesday, February 25, 11:30am. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

WOOL--Charlotte. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School mourns the death of Charlotte Wool, who with her beloved husband, Treasurer Herbert Wool, of blessed memory, were founders and builders of our Day School and established the Herbert Wool Scholarship Fund for the advancement of Jewish education. Our heartfelt sympathy to their children Poppy (Vice President Ronny) Wurtzburger, Iris (Howard) Perry, grandchildren Howard (Lisa) Neuthaler - parents of our day school, who continue to emulate their parents' ways from generation to generation. Condolences to the entire family.

REIFF--Sidney, age 95, passed away peacefully in California on February 22. He leaves behind the love of his life, his wife of 68 years Renee, and three adoring children, Isabel (Lee), Kenneth (Angela), and Russell (Anna) and grandchildren, Sam, Faye, Matthew, Elizabeth, Sophia, and Alexis. Sidney is also survived and fondly remembered by nephews, nieces, friends, classmates, and colleagues. A loving and involved father, Sidney will be remembered for his intelligence, integrity, steadfastness, humor, and engagement in all aspects of life. The first member of his family born in the U.S., Sidney was born in 1918 in Brooklyn, NY to Israel and Yetta Reiff. He graduated from NYU Washington Square ('38) and Medical School ('42). He was a lifelong proud alumnus, attending reunions regularly, as recently as 2012, and proudly wore his NYU hat until the last days of his life. He served in the U.S. Army Medical Corps in the Pacific during WWII. He practiced internal medicine in New York City and was on the staff of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. Fulfilling a dream from his WWII return into San Francisco Bay, in 1971 he moved to Los Angeles where he practiced medicine at Kaiser Permanente until his retirement in 1993. Post retirement he volunteered at the Venice Family Clinic. We will love and miss him always. Services 12 noon, Sunday, March 2 at Hillside Mortuary, Los Angeles 800-576-1994. Contributions in lieu of flowers can be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center.

COHEN--Maxine, 75, of Boynton Beach, FL, passed away peacefully on February 22, surrounded by loved ones. Although Maxine lived up and down the east coast, she never forgot her Brooklyn roots. She was married for 28 years to the late Howard Cohen of Bronx, NY. Maxine is survived by loving children, grandchildren, family, friends, and her life partner.

GREENMAN--Charles P. The partners, associates and staff of Troutman Sanders mourn with great sorrow the sudden and unexpected passing of our partner, colleague and friend, Charles P. Greenman. Charles was a brilliant lawyer, trusted advisor and cherished friend. He was highly respected by his clients, friends and colleagues for his creative advocacy in litigation matters, as well as for his exceptionally thoughtful advice on business and real estate transactions. All of us who were privileged to work with Charlie will miss him tremendously. We extend our deepest sympathies and our prayers to his wife, Jane and to his daughters, Margot (Caio), Jaclyn and Danielle and his new grandson, who were his pride and joy, and to his brothers, Mark and James and his extended family.

EHRENKRANZ--Joseph H. The Yeshiva University family is deeply saddened by the passing of Rabbi Joseph H. Ehrenkranz, an internationally renowned alumnus of the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) who was Rabbi Emeritus after serving with distinction as the Rabbi of Congregation Agudath Sholom in Stamford, CT 1948 until 1992, building it from a membership of 150 to become the largest Orthodox synagogue in New England. In 1992 he was a Co-Founder and became the Executive Director of the Center for Christian Jewish Understanding at Sacred Heart University where he conducted conferences to encourage interreligious understanding and organized study trips for Bishops and Rabbis to Auschwitz and the Vatican and seminars for clergy students. He received the Nostra Aetate Award for his work for a world at peace by the Center for Christian Jewish Understanding. At Yeshiva University's Wurzweiler School of Social Work the Carl and Dorothy Bennett Chair in Pastoral Counseling was established in 1982, in "tribute to Rabbi Joseph H. Ehrenkranz" and there is a scholarship in his name at RIETS. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Sandra and his children, Doris (and Pinhas) Friedenberg, Laura Ehrenkranz and Brian Ullman, Bart (and Cindy) Ehrenkranz and Bina (and Hillel) Fendel. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

DAVIDSON--Janice Helene.Passed away February 22, 2014. Jan was born and raised in the Bronx. She was a pioneer in the garment industry while settling in Hong Kong in the early 1960's where she resided with her children for over 20 years. Jan was the loving mother to Daryl Simon (Irwin), Geoffrey Goldberg (Debra) and Taran Morgan. Adoring grandmother of Nicolette, Trevor, Garett, Lucas, Alec and Griffin. Her fun loving spirit will be dearly missed by the many lives she touched. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Alzheimer's Association-New York City Chapter.

LEE--Jane Love. Cherished and devoted wife of George Lee, passed away peacefully at her home Thursday, February 20th, 2014 at age 86. She is survived by her adoring son James Love Lee and daughter-in-law Cynthia Rosenbloom Lee; beloved brothers Matthew Love and Robert Love; and her beloved nieces and nephews: Wendy Love Barnard; Steve Love and wife Jeanie; Victoria Love and husband Greg Rowan; Bill Love and wife Elizabeth; and Gregory Love. She is also survived by her cherished grand-nieces and grand-nephews: Alessandra Love Simons; Lance Love Barnard; Sam Love Yusim; Chase Love; Phoebe Love Yusim; Caroline Love; Amelia Jane Love; and Natalie Love. She was predeceased by her treasured parents, Minerva Rosetsky Love and Joseph Love, dear brother Stanley Love and much-loved nephew Brett Love. Jane radiated a loving kindness, understanding and generosity of spirit that touched and inspired all those who formed the tapestry of her life. Sophisticated and elegant, beautiful and humorous, she was a giver: a devoted wife and mother; a wise matriarch to her family; and above all a true friend who met life's challenges with amazing courage, grace and style. We will all miss her greatly and will continue to carry her in our hearts and spirits forever. A private family burial service will be held Wednesday, February 26th, 2014. Memorial donations can be made to Visiting Nurse Service of New York (VNSNY) Hospice and Palliative Care (1250 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, Ny 10001, Attn: Stephanie Street).

SCHWARTZ--Barry, left us February 22, 2014. He was a dear part of the Sussman family. He was a fun loving and truly gentle man's man who loved his entire family and took the most wonderful care of our grandchildren. We will remember Barry and treasure all our wonderful fun times together. Our deepest condolences to Elaine and Daniel Schwartz and Jodi Sussman. Marion and Jerry Sussman Daniel and Maria Sussman Peter Sussman Asher and Leo Sussman Oren Rosenbaum

DITTMER--Frances. The entire Drawing Center family, past and present, mourns the sudden tragic death of our esteemed former Board Member Frances Ronshausen Dittmer. Frannie had a rare combination of superior intellect, a great eye for art and incisive opinions about the role of the Visual Arts in our society coupled with infectious enthusiasm and tremendous joie de vivre. She was always generous with her support and provided wise council and valuable encouragement to three successive Directors and to her fellow board members. The Drawing Center remembers with pride, and will always be grateful for, her contributions. Our profound sympathy goes to her family. Frances Beatty Adler, Jane Dresner Sadaka, Eric Rudin, Board Co-Chairs. Brett Littman, Exec. Director

PIERSON--Harry Edwin, 94, passed away Saturday, February 22, 2014, at his home in Manhasset, NY. He was born September 23, 1919, in Philadelphia, to Harry and Mildred Pierson and raised in Allentown, PA. He attended Temple University, where he met his wife, graduating in 1941 prior to entering the United States Army. During World War II, he served as a field artillery officer in the Pacific theatre earning a Bronze Star for his actions in the Philippines. After his discharge from the army, he attended New York University Law School. Graduating in 1949, he had a successful career focusing on commercial real estate, working as an attorney for New York Life Insurance Company, and as an executive of Pacific Coast Properties, W.T. Grant, and W.R. Grace & Co. He is survived by his adoring family including his wife of 70 years, Mae Florence (Lange) Pierson; daughters Ellen Marlin and Elizabeth Casalino; son-in-law James Casalino; grandson Timothy Marlin and his wife Sara; and nephew James Pelzer and his wife Ellen. Funeral services will be at 10am on Tuesday, February 25 at Saint Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Manhasset, NY. His wit, wisdom, and loving heart will be dearly missed.

PINTO--Alyse Diane, age 52, of Demarest, New Jersey, passed away on Sunday (February 23, 2014) at her home after an eight-year courageous battle with Appendix Cancer. She was the beloved wife of Ron Pinto. Mother of Brett, Brandon, and Brittany Pinto. Precious Daughter of Robert and Lenore Nass. Sister to Sherri Leonard and Mark Nass. Alyse was the darling Aunt of Matthew Leonard, Nicole Leonard, Kelsey Nass, and Tara Nass. Alyse also left behind her brother-in-law, Barry Leonard, and sister-in-law, Jill Nass. Alyse was born on April 19, 1961 and raised in Oceanside, NY. Alyse graduated 1983 from the University of Maryland with a BS in Textile Management. Alyse was the consummate person, the total package. She loved to entertain and cook for her family and friends. Her family was her life; nothing brought her more joy. She loved each of them from the bottom of her heart. Alyse loved decorating, she loved creating something from nothing. At the time of her passing, Alyse was an Interior Director at Alyse Pinto Interiors, Inc. Alyse will be sorely missed. Her physical beauty could only be surpassed by her inner beauty. Services will be held at Temple Sinai, 1 Engle St., Tenafly, NJ, February 26, 12:30pm.

SCHWARTZ--Barry Frederick, the former President of Doe-Spun, Chairman of the Lawrence Village Park Commission, and President of the Bristol Plaza (200/210 East 65th Street) died on Saturday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York City. He was 74 years old. Mr. Schwartz was a visionary leader in the children's apparel industry. Doe-Spun's licensed children's clothing brands included Nautica, Diane von Furstenberg, Colorforms, Absorba, Barney the Dinosaur, Budgie the Helicopter, Thomas the Tank Engine, and Might Morphin Power Rangers. His longstanding support of Jewish communities around the world earned him the United Jewish Appeal's Children's Apparel Division Man of the Year. His work for disadvantaged children around the world culminated in his becoming a founding member of the board of K.I.D.S. (Kids in Distressed Situations). He was an ardent support of the Joel Finkelstein Cancer Foundation among many additional philanthropic activities. Mr. Schwartz was a former "all star" quarterback who was recruited to play collegiate football both by Southern Illinois University and by Georgia Tech. Mr. Schwartz is survived by his wife, Elaine, and children Jodi and Andrew Sussman, and Daniel Schwartz, grandchildren Ben and Carly Sussman, and sister Roberta Schwartz. Donations in Mr. Schwartz's honor may be sent to the Jewish Communal Fund/Barry F. Schwartz Memorial Fund (575 Madison Avenue, Suite 703, New York, NY 10022).

MUTCHNIK--Rebecca W.,106 1/2, died on February 22nd. Beloved wife of the late Max Mutchnik, mother of Marilyn Mutchnik and Laurie Mutchnik Maurer (Stanley Maurer), grandmother of Rachel Maurer and Marian Maurer (Costa Varsos), great-grandmother of Sotirios Max Varsos. Graduated from CCNY with honors in 1929 and widowed young, she held many responsible positions. Throughout her life, she was there to help anyone in need and did volunteer work into her 100's. Rebecca, an inspiration for aging independently and gracefully, will be greatly missed and always remembered.

SCHWARTZ--Barry. The Board of Directors of the 200-210 East 65th Street Condominium mourns the passing of our beloved friend, neighbor, and long-serving president, Barry Schwartz. Barry was one of the first owners in the building, joined the original Board in 1989, and became President of the Board shortly thereafter. He was a dedicated president who will forever be remembered and appreciated for his leadership, friendship, and acts of kindness. We extend our most heart-felt condolences and sympathies to his wife, Elaine and all of his family, friends and neighbors.

BALDWIN--David M. Benenson Capital Partners mourns the loss of our long time partner and friend. His business judgment, civic responsibility and support of charitable institutions, including the Realty Foundation will be missed. Our heartfelt condolences go out to the entire Baldwin family. Bruce W. Benenson Frederick C. Benenson Lawrence B. Benenson Richard A. Kessler James E. Stifel

ROLIH--Dr. Ilario Hilary, suddenly on February 16, 2014, age 82, of Oyster Bay, NY, formerly of Laurel Hollow, NY. Beloved husband of Zorka. Loving father of Hilary (Anne), and Peter (Jeanne). Cherished grandfather of Caitlin, Andrew, Alexa, Victoria, and Caroline. Dear brother of Dolores Smith, Gianna Gerlitz (Guido). Visiting Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South St., Oyster Bay, NY, Thursday and Friday 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Patrick Roman Catholic Church, Huntington, NY on Saturday at 9:30am. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery. oysterbayfuneralhome.com

SCHWARTZ--Marvin S.,died at his home in Goshen, Connecticut on Wednesday, February 19th. He was 91. He is survived by his wife of sixty-six years, Joyce S. Schwartz, and by his children Daniel Schwartz and Pamela Pier. His eldest child John B. Schwartz died at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Also surviving him are his four grandchildren, David and Morgan Schwartz and Aisha and Arianna Pier. He served in the Army Signal Corps in the Second World War. Then, after graduating from the University of Pennsylvania Law School in 1949, he clerked for Judge Herbert F. Goodrich of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit and for Justice Harold Burton of the United States Supreme Court. Marvin practiced law at the firm of Sullivan & Cromwell throughout his career, first as an associate and then, from 1960 through 1992, as a partner of the firm. Although he was a litigator and counselor to clients in many fields, he was best known as a preeminent securities lawyer, advising clients and litigating some of the most complex and important securities law issues of the day. He tried cases around the country and before various regulators and argued appeals in many courts including the U.S. Supreme Court. He was a member of the Board of Overseers of the University of Pennsylvania Law School and a Fellow (and member of the Board of Regents) of the American College of Trial Lawyers. At Sullivan & Cromwell, Marvin is remembered not only as a brilliant leader of the bar, but a wonderful colleague, devoted to the firm and its lawyers, and as a mentor to generations of litigators who are grateful for his guidance and generosity. Funeral services are private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the University of Pennsylvania Law School.

MURASE--Yoshiye, passed away February 22, 2014. She was beloved wife of Jiro and mother to Miwa and Satoru and grandmother to three lovely grandsons. She started her professional career after Parsons School of Design working for Vogue. Lifelong she was an active artist and teacher most recently in the art of Mataro Japanese doll creations. She was also a tireless volunteer and contributor to community organizations including the Japan Society, Nippon Club, Nichibei Fujinkai, JAANY and many others. Services private. Memorial service to be scheduled in future. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to the Japan Society Yoshiye Murase Fund www.japansociety.org

BAR--Senta, on February 24, 2014. Devoted mother of Denise and Gregory. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Nehama, Ari, Daniel, Natalie and Steven. Loving great-grandmother of Gabrielle, Emma, Eliyashu, Aubrey, Nolan, Elizabeth, Isabella, Julian, and Sima. Dear sister of Hannelore Hecht. Services Wednesday, 11:15am, "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

MARKS--Ina. Passed away on February 21, 2014 in Los Angeles, California. She lived in White Plains, New York from the late 1950's to 2006. She was born to Pauline and Louis Fogel on October 16, 1914 in Rozan, Poland. After coming to the US she lived in New York City till the mid-1950's when she and her family lived in California for a few years. Ina was married to Maxwell Marks from 1938 to 1995, when Maxwell passed away. Ina had two siblings, Morris Fogel (deceased) and Faye Diamond, living in Florida. Ina and Maxwell had two children, Elinor (Mark) Gordon of Los Angeles, and Michael (Judy) Marks of Tucson, Arizona. She loved each of her seven grandchildren, Joshua and Amanda (Joshua's wife) and Emily and Matthew Marks, and Adam and Tinna (Adam's wife) and Arielle Gordon. She also was crazy about her two great-grandchildren, Noah and Molly, by Joshua and Amanda. Ina also loved Ana Recinos, her caregiver who gave Ina great companionship and comfort and to whom Ina's family is most grateful. Ina was a Registered Nurse, and during WWII was a 1st Lieutenant in the Army Nursing Corps, serving in England and France and Germany. After the war she worked as a nurse at St. Vincent's Hospital and elsewhere. She also attended and received a BA from Manhattanville College. Ina was a painter, a sculptor, a poet, a docent at the Neuberger Museum, a bridge player, a good friend, and much more. A Memorial Service will be held for her at the Congregation Kol Ami Chapel in the Woods in White Plains, NY, at 12:00pm on February 26, 2014.
China has recently increased its pursuit of territorial claims in nearby seas, leading to tense exchanges with neighboring countries. A map of some of the most notable disputes.
Part 14: Wes Anderson, director of “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” talks about what happens to the lovingly created props in his movies after a shoot is over.

Part 8: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” reveal the best thing about working on a Wes Anderson film, and talk about working with the newcomer actor Tony Revolori.
Part 12: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” explain why they don’t think it’s good to rehearse too much when making a film.
Part 10: Wes Anderson, director of “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” discusses the filmmakers who influenced him the most on this film, and talks about why there are so many train scenes in the movie.
Part 7: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” talk about the film’s impressive cast, and discuss Wes Anderson’s ability to attract star actors, even for bit parts.
Part 6: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” describe what it was like working together for the first time.
Part 5: Wes Anderson, director of “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” explains why the majority of the film was shot in the old square “Academy ratio” format.

Part 3: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” talk about how the film deals with real history via a story set in a fake country.

Fur, fabrics and fancy dominated the runways during the Italian fashion week.
Voters in Switzerland have chosen to put a stop to mass immigration. The result sent shock waves across Europe.
Joe Begos’s horror movie “Almost Human” should not be confused with the Fox television drama of the same name.
The former president spoke at a fund-raiser in Louisville for Alison Lundergan Grimes, a Democratic Senate candidate.
Racial tension at United States colleges. Also on the Minute, The National Enquirer settles a libel suit surrounding an actor's death and Disney launches a new movie app.
The president said two new manufacturing institutes would be located in Chicago and Detroit in an effort to create high-quality jobs.
To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.
The actress sings “Nowadays” from the Kander and Ebb musical “Chicago,” on Broadway at the Ambassador Theater. She is appearing in the show through March 9.
Alison Chung followed her lifelong love of solving mysteries to found a forensic technology firm.
Paris
Paris
Julia Moskin shows how to master the art of making sweet, tender scones with a firm crust and a soft, crumbly texture.
The Oscar-nominated composers Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez say that in some part, inspiration for the songs they wrote for “Frozen” came from Prospect Park.
Ukrainians explored the compound of their ousted president, Viktor F. Yanukovych. Also on the Minute, swelling protests in Venezuela and a look at mussels that pose threats in the United States.
TNT, the television network, offered Manhattan motorists $1.98-per-gallon gasoline to promote the show.
In Milan’s Navigli District, locals embrace vintage clothing and bright colors.
Also on the Minute, new evidence that global warming is the main cause of retreating glaciers and some of the most memorable scenes from Harold Ramis.
Suzy Menkes speaks with Antonio Marras about the importance of his Sardinian roots and his new collection inspired by howling wolves.
Television highlights.
A study suggests that camels are the major source of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, a viral disease that has sickened 182 people and killed 79 of them since it was first detected in 2012.
The prominent Bitcoin exchange was said to be on the verge of total collapse following a major theft, even as another company announced plans for a high-profile virtual currency market.
A new study about police stop-and-frisk encounters in Newark found that one quarter of police stops ended in an arrest or a summons, about twice as often as they do in New York City.
Many movie fans would barely recognize Harold Ramis, who died Monday at 69, but as much as anyone, Mr. Ramis invented modern film comedy.
Just in time for this next round of shows, the inimitable Irish cookbook author and food writer Trish Deseine shares her list of must-hit pâtisseries.
The Christie administration appears poised to let a company, Soil Safe, dump millions of tons of petroleum-contaminated soils on a site which lies directly west of Staten Island and the Arthur Kill.
Jamal Crawford hit seven 3-point shots on his way to 24 points, and the visiting Los Angeles Clippers beat the New Orleans Pelicans, 123-110.
Two days after Mexican marines arrested the drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, questions are being asked about whether he will be tried in Mexico or in the United States.
China will not recognize the United States’ appointment of a special coordinator for Tibetan issues, saying that it opposed any foreign intervention in its internal affairs.
The United Nations’ human rights chief called for an independent international inquiry into possible war crimes committed during Sri Lanka’s civil war.
After indictments, resignations and independent-mindedness of one kind or another, vote-counting in the New York State Senate has become more like a calculus problem.
Some residents and businessmen, many of whom have provided support to so-called self-defense forces, are now worried those groups will turn on them.
Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim will not be disciplined for going onto the court on Saturday to protest a charging call in the Orange’s 66-60 loss at Duke.
Fourth-ranked Syracuse blew most of a 12-point lead in the last 8 minutes but used a final defensive stop to squeeze past host Maryland and end a two-game losing streak.
Kristine Lilly, a two-time World Cup champion and winner of two Olympic gold medals, led the inductees to the United States National Soccer Hall of Fame.
Michael Shaw, a Metro-North conductor, apologized to commuters for mistakenly instructing them to wait for a train that ended up being canceled on Friday.
Mong La, Myanmar, draws Chinese over the border to gamble, as well as buy ivory and other animal parts, despite official disapproval of the casinos in China.
Washington Wizards forward Nene will be sidelined for six weeks with a sprained medial collateral ligament in his left knee.
In a coordinated action against the government, residents of Caracas and other cities have taken to the streets to protest a litany of problems that have long troubled the country.
Corrections appearing in print on February 25, 2014.

On Monday, inquiries by those eager to buy a Nets jersey with Jason Collins’s name started to multiply. On Tuesday, Collins jerseys will go on sale at the N.B.A.’s retail shop in Manhattan and online.
Daniel A. D’Aniello gave $20 million to the American Enterprise Institute, which is aiming to increase its staff and expand its conservative mission.
Accused of mass murder, Viktor F. Yanukovych has disappeared, along with a handful of loyalists and perhaps his girlfriend.
The New York City Council heard testimony Monday on Mayor Bill de Blasio’s ambitious pedestrian safety plan, known as Vision Zero, which is based on the idea that all traffic deaths are preventable.

Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday finally fielded inquiries about his motorcade’s caught-on-camera violations of traffic laws — but he could not resist offering reporters some pointed criticism of his own.
Rafael Montero, who will start the Mets’ first exhibition game Friday, has earned praise for his excellent mechanics.
While George W. Bush was inspired by Ukraine’s 2004 revolution, Barack Obama has approached the unrest of 2014 with a more clinical detachment aimed at avoiding instability.
Some of the N.H.L.’s top scorers were among the players who left Sochi in far worse shape than when they arrived.
The new director of the M.L.B. players union said that “the page has been turned” on Alex Rodriguez’s short-lived lawsuit that implicated the union and a respected former director.
The Yankees are hoping Masahiro Tanaka, who they signed for $155 million, can match the results of Yu Darvish, who has starred in two seasons in Texas.
Israel has struck Syria at least three times in the past year, according to United States officials, to prevent sophisticated weapons from reaching Hezbollah amid the chaos of Syria’s war.
While Miami’s Richie Incognito has been the leading figure in a bullying scandal, two offensive linemen, John Jerry and Mike Pouncey, served as henchmen, a report found.
“Kung Fu,” the new play about Bruce Lee by David Henry Hwang, never achieves the fluid grace in its dialogue and dramaturgy that it does in its action sequences.
Racial tensions are playing out in new ways on college campuses nationwide, like the University of Michigan, which has seen a sharp decline in black undergraduate enrollment.
Quotation of the day for Tuesday, February 25, 2014.
Europe, the United States and Russia can play a role in preventing war in a deeply divided country.
Mayor Mark Sokolich met last week with the federal prosecutors investigating the closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge in September, his lawyer said on Monday.
Alex Salmond, Scotland’s first minister, who supports independence, and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, who does not, also differ on the future of oil and gas reserves in the North Sea.
A veto-worthy Arizona bill would authorize ill-treatment of gay people in the name of religion.
The United States and Mexico share a responsibility for the tragedy that spawned criminals like Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the world’s most elusive drug lord.
The next chapter in an insurance marketplace’s success story: offering technology and services to other states.

SWINK--Beydn Gabriel. Age 10, of Fort Benning, GA, died February 22, 2014 at Children Health Care of Atlanta Scottish Rite, Atlanta, Georgia after a courageous battle with leukemia. He was born May 9, 2003 in Lincoln County, NC a son of Meghan Anne Daniels (Sgt. Kevin Daniels) of Fort Benning, GA Sfc. Joshua Alan Swink (Annie Neal) of Fort Drum, NY. Beydn was a 5th grader at Wilson Elementary, Fort Benning, GA. He enjoyed soccer, karate, tae kwon do, and was an avid reader and always wanted to go to New York City. Survivors in addition to his parents are four brothers, two sisters, numerous other relatives. A memorial service will be held at Carpenter's Funeral and Cremation Services on Wednesday, February 26, 2014 at 7:00pm with Rev. Ken Gibson officiating. The family will receive friends from 5:00-6:45pm at the funeral home prior to the service. The burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made in memory of Beydn Swink, to Scottish Rite PICU, 1001 Johnson Ferry Road NE, Atlanta, GA. 30342. Condolences may be made to carpentersfunerhome.net

Marion and Jerry Sussman Daniel and Maria Sussman Peter Sussman Asher and Leo Sussman Oren Rosenbaum

McQUILLAN--William L.,Jr., age 76, passed away on February 23rd in Shadyside Hospital in Pittsburgh, PA with his family by his side. Beloved brother of Nancy Bolanis, loving uncle of George and Michael Bolanis. Bill was a longtime resident of Manhattan, NY. A graduate of Shady Side Academy and Amherst College, Bill enlisted in the United States Army and afterward obtained his MBA from The Wharton School. He spent his whole financial career as a portfolio manager for Manufacturers Hanover Trust. There will be a family service at a later date. Services by John A. Freyvogel Sons, Inc., Pittsburgh, PA.

Above all, Ilene adored her late husband, Gary, children, Amy (Michael Meillarec), Bryan (Theresa) Reiss, and Marc Reiss, and grandchildren, Mackenzie and Kylie Reiss and T.J. Meillarec. SCHWARTZ--Barry Frederick, the former President of Doe-Spun, Chairman of the Lawrence Village Park Commission, and President of the Bristol Plaza (200/210 East 65th Street) died on Saturday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York City. He was 74 years old. Mr. Schwartz was a visionary leader in the children's apparel industry. Doe-Spun's licensed children's clothing brands included Nautica, Diane von Furstenberg, Colorforms, Absorba, Barney the Dinosaur, Budgie the Helicopter, Thomas the Tank Engine, and Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. His longstanding support of Jewish communities around the world earned him the United Jewish Appeal's Children's Apparel Division Man of the Year. His work for disadvantaged children around the world culminated in his becoming a founding member of the board of K.I.D.S. (Kids in Distressed Situations). He was an ardent supporter of the Joel Finkelstein Cancer Foundation among many additional philanthropic activities. Mr. Schwartz was a former "all star" quarterback who was recruited to play collegiate football both by Southern Illinois University and by Georgia Tech. Mr. Schwartz is survived by his wife, Elaine, and children Jodi and Andrew Sussman, and Daniel Schwartz, grandchildren Ben and Carly Sussman, and sister Roberta Schwartz. Donations in Mr. Schwartz's honor may be sent to the Jewish Communal Fund/Barry F. Schwartz Memorial Fund (575 Madison Avenue, Suite 703, New York, NY 10022).

SCHWARTZ--Barry Frederick, age 74, passed away on Saturday, February 22, 2014. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our husband, father and grandfather. Words cannot fully express our sense of deep loss, profound grief, or how much he is missed by his family and friends. We are extremely grateful for the very special bond we shared and consider it a blessing to have had his guidance, wisdom and love. He touched so many people's lives with his compassionate generosity, magnanimous heart and larger than life personality. He had an exemplary career in the children's clothing industry and was a leader in all of the communities in which he lived. Enjoyed spending time with family and friends in Lawrence, Long Island, Manhattan, and in Boca Raton, Florida. Devoted husband to Elaine, loving father to Jodi (Andrew) and Daniel (Csongor), adoring grandfather to Benjamin, Carly, and loving brother to Roberta. We love you and will miss you deeply each and every day.
BAUMAN--Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague, died on February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC

MARTINI--Marion Mann, 85, of Chapel Hill, NC and New York City died on February 17, 2014 at home in Chapel Hill. She was born in New York City, daughter of Thomas Dixon Mann and Elsa Olga Muller. After graduating from Rhodes High School, Marion worked for Standard Oil (now Exxon) for 12 years, attending classes at New York University, the Baruch School of Business and the Practicing Law Institute. In her 30s, she earned a State Department scholarship to the University of Sao Paulo, to finish her bachelor's degree at NYU. In Sao Paulo, she was taught by Fernando Cardoso, who later became the president of Brazil. The life-changing trip led to a marriage, daughter, and a lifetime love of all things Brazilian-music, culture, friends and business. Marion worked for BANESPA for 18 years. She received the Brasilio Machado Neto award from the Brazilian-American Chamber of Commerce for her "very significant efforts and contribution on behalf of commerce and human betterment," and a commendation from the New York State Governor's office for her action on HMOs. She was active in the New York University Club, was an officer and board member for the Dames of the Loyal Legion, New York State, past historian and patriotic officer for the Sons and Daughters of Union Veterans of the Civil War, past historian for the American Association of University Women, past member of the boards of the World Ship Society and the American Association for University Women. Life did not slow on retirement to Chapel Hill, where she toured the South, designed tours for Parks and Recreation, and volunteered for the UNC Volunteer Income Tax Assistance program and as a translator for UNC hospitals. She was a devotee of history, bowling, opera, ballet and the symphony, and was a political and philosophical thinker. She is survived by a brother, Richard Mann, of Portland OR, and daughter, Marinna Martini of Falmouth, MA. Memorial donations may be made to The League of Women Voters or to UNC Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center.

McCORMICK--John Michael, 85, died peacefully on February 19, 2014, at his home in Princeton, NJ, after a sudden illness. To all those who knew him, he was a source of joy, wit and inspiration. He will be sadly missed. Graduate of the City University of New York, he was President of Thatcher Glass Manufacturing Company. Survived by his wife, Julia Losa McCormick, two sons John Lawrence and his wife, Miko, and Paul and his wife, Dorothee, three grandchildren, Jocelyn Lloyd and her husband, David, Terrence McCormick and Charles McCormick and one great-granddaughter, Sophie Lloyd. Private service was held at Washington Crossing National Cemetery on February 26, 2014.

MURASE--Yoshiye, passed away February 22, 2014. She was beloved wife of Jiro and mother to Miwa and Satoru and grandmother to three lovely grandsons. She started her professional career after Parsons School of Design working for Vogue. Lifelong she was an active artist and teacher most recently in the art of Mataro Japanese doll creations. She was also a tireless volunteer and contributor to community organizations including the Japan Society, Nippon Club, Nichibei Fujinkai, JAANY and many others. Services private. Memorial service to be scheduled in future. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to the Japan Society Yoshiye Murase Fund www.japansociety.org

KEEGAN--Albert F. Jr. MD, died Sunday morning at the age of 87 following a long and hard-fought battle with inclusion body myositis. Born to Albert F. Keegan and Veronica Keegan on August 13, 1926, Keegan enlisted in the U.S. Navy in 1944 and served in the Medical Corps. He graduated from Columbia University in 1949 and received his MD from the State University of New York's College of Medicine in 1953. He was married in 1954 to Margaret S. Telesco. The Keegans lived near the water in Port Washington, NY, until their recent move to Bryn Mawr, PA. Dr. Keegan was the longtime Director of Radiology at New York University/Bellevue Hospital and also a member and president of its Medical Board. He served as Professor of Clinical Radiology at NYU School of Medicine and as Director of the Radiology Resident Training Program for NYU/Bellevue, and was made Professor Emeritus at NYU. He was a Diplomat of the American Board of Radiology and Nuclear Medicine and a fellow in the American College of Radiology. Even in retirement, Dr. Keegan remained active as Co-Chairman of the New York County Health Services Review Organization/MedReview, which grew under his guidance from a small organization to one of the largest and most prominent of its kind in the nation. Colleagues recall his keen insight and wise counsel, always accompanied by a soft tone and warm smile. Dr. Keegan's passions were his family, music and medicine. He loved the water and enjoyed sailing and skiing. He was above all intellectually curious and a true Renaissance man. Dr. Keegan is survived by his wife Margaret; their three children and their spouses, Christopher and Debbie Keegan, Cara and John Fry and Matthew and Orsolya Keegan; and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, Dr. Keegan's family encourages donations in his memory be sent to the Department of Radiology, c/o Office of Development, NYU Langone Medical Center, One Park Ave Floor 17, New York, NY 10016 or made online.

Fredric C. Apter, President Bryna Sweedler, Secretary

HIRSCH--Elisabeth, PhD, nee Schiff, wife of the late Julius E. Hirsch died on February 24, 2014 in White Plains, NY at the age of 95. Born in Hungary on June 14, 1918, Dr. Hirsch immigrated to the United States via England after WWII. While living in London she was a student of Anna Freud where she began her life-long interest in early childhood education and child development. She earned higher degrees at the New School for Social Research and New York University. Her career in New York included teaching preschool at The Little Red Schoolhouse, followed by an appointment as professor of Early Childhood Education at the City College of New York. She retired from CCNY at the age of 70 but continued teaching as Professor Emeritus until she was 80. Dr. Hirsch is best known as the author of "The Block Book." She is survived by two daughters Susan and Naomi and a sister Martha Talmi living in Israel. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Clear View School, 480 Albany Post Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510. Funeral service will be held at 1pm Thursday, February 27th at the Gutterman and Musicaant Jewish Funeral Directors, Hackensack, NJ. guttermanandmusicant.com

GREENMAN--Charles P. The board and staff of NYC Outward Bound Schools are deeply saddened by the passing of Charles P. Greenman--loving husband of our longtime board member Jane Greenman. We extend our deepest sympathies to Jane, daughters Margot, Jaclyn and Danielle, and the entire extended family.

GELDER--Zoe, age 95, of Atlanta and formerly of Merrick, Long Island, Manhattan and Pompano Beach, Florida passed away peacefully on February 19, 2014. She was born in Brooklyn, New York on June 18, 1918, the daughter of Henrietta and Irving Rosen. Zoe grew up in Brooklyn. She later met and married her beloved husband Gene Gelder and raised her family in Merrick, Long Island. She was a devoted wife and mother and a true friend to all who knew her. She was predeceased by her husband Gene Gelder and her brother Leonard Rosen. Zoe is survived by her son Roger Gelder and his wife Corky of Atlanta, sister-in-law Frieda Rosen of Brooklyn, NY; granddaughter Jennifer Gelder of Atlanta; grandson Josh Gelder and his wife Karen of New York; great-grandchildren Jake and Alex Newberg and Jack and Mia Gelder. Other survivors include niece Ilene Rosen. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to The William Breman Jewish Home, Temple Sinai or Weinstein Hospice all located in Atlanta.

FISCHER--Harris. Most incredible and funny husband, father, and grandfather died at the age of 91 years young, on February 24th in Manhattan. He is survived by the love of his life, his wife of 62 years, Nancy, who was his travel, drinking, golfing and dining buddy. He is also survived by his adoring daughter Ellen, his phenomenal son-in-law Sam, his son David, and his idolized grandchildren Josh (girlfriend Lise) and Matt. He will be incredibly missed by so many more. Graveside service will be private. Please feel free to make a donation to your favorite charity in Harris's name.

MORAN--Joseph W.,BS, MAAA, FSA, BSI, ASH. Joe Moran, Actuary, "Sherlockian", 86, died February 18, 2014, Mamaroneck, NY. Born November 22, 1927 in Cleveland, OH, to Charles F. and Mary (Gans) Moran, graduated Yale in 1949, Phi Beta Kappa. New York Life Insurance Co. 1949-1992. He is survived by his brother, Richard T. Moran, of Wyoming, OH; his step-mother, Eliner Moran, of Cape Coral, FL; three children, Douglas (Laura) of Denver, CO, Kathleen of Minneapolis, MN, Clifford of Ridgefield, CT; and four grandchildren: Sarah Moran, Dennis Moran, Erica Moran, and Lisa Moran. He was a member of the Baker Street Irregulars and the Adventuresses of Sherlock Holmes. Memorial Service Saturday, March 1, 2014, 11:00am at Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church, 60 Forest Park Avenue, Larchmont, NY. Reception to follow in the church hall. Donations to the Larchmont Avenue Church's "Faith in our Future" Centennial Fund, (www.lacny.org), or the Beacon Society (www.beaconsociety.com). More information at http://jjffh.com/book-of-memories/1808445/Moran-Joseph/obituary.php
COSTELLO--Edward L. Feb. 27, 1914 - Feb. 27, 2014. A family man, he loved each one of us the best. We miss him every day and remember him on his 100th birthday today.

EBERSTADT--Walter A. The Frick Collection mourns the passing of Walter A. Eberstadt, a long-time benefactor of the Collection. At his death a Trustee Emeritus, Walter served on the Board of Trustees for ten years. His support was exceedingly generous, and his largess touched every aspect of this institution. Walter was instrumental in leading the success of our exhibitions program and of the Autumn Dinner, and his work on the board included service on the executive, audit, development, investment, and nominating committees. Walter truly exemplified leadership, generosity, and selflessness, and he was a dear and close friend of the Collection and of many people here. All of us at the Frick will greatly miss Walter's gentle spirit. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Vera, their sons George and Michael, and his entire family. Margot C. Bogert, Chairman Ian Wardropper, Director

AUBRY--Marcel Aboudaram Age 93, on February 15, 2014 in New York joining his beloved wife Blossom in eternal peace and love. Devoted father of Philippe and Michel, daughter-in-law Doreen, and grandfather of Nicholas, he was born in Marseille, and grew up in Paris and Normandy. Marcel first came to the United States as a student at Carleton College in 1937, but returned to France at the onset of WWII. He served as a pilot in the French Air Force, flying light bombers with the allies before returning to the United States in 1948, and settling in New York City. He entered the commodities trading industry in 1953, eventually founding his own firm in 1961, Marcel Aubry & Co., Inc., which endures to this day. He was a long time member of The Cocoa Merchants Association of America, and the Green Coffee Association of New York City. His memory remains in our hearts for his love, kindness, generosity and devotion to his family. Memorial Service will be private.

BRODER--Carley, age 63, on February 25, encircled by loved ones, from lung disease. Originally from Rumson, NJ, Carley was a devoted Upper West Sider, living near Lincoln Center to feed her love of all things ballet. A gifted communicator, Carley championed justice and equality. A cherished daughter of the late Gloria Waldman Appel and Marvin and Lois Broder, and sister to Michael (Rita Rubin), Betsy (David Wentworth) and the late Chip (Celeste Hoppey-Broder). She also leaves her beloved siblings from the Stern and Appel families, adored nieces and nephews, and devoted friends. Contributions in her honor can be made to Project Plie, American Ballet Theater, 890 Broadway, NY, NY, 10003. Memorial service at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday, March 2 at 2pm.

REISS--Ilene, 69, of Franklin Lakes, NJ, died suddenly February 23, 2014 at her home. Owner of a successful travel-agency business, she enjoyed working and traveling. Above all, Ilene adored her late husband, Gary, children, Amy (Michael Meillarec), Bryan (Theresa) Reiss, and Marc Reiss, and grandchildren, Mackenzie and Kylie Reiss and T.J. Meillarec. Forever in our hearts, always in our memories. Donations can be made in honor of Gary Reiss. Make checks payable to Dr. Manish Shah Weill-Cornell Medical Center/G.I. Oncology Research, 1305 York Avenue, 12th Floor, New York, NY 10021. Funeral services will be 9:00am, Thursday, February 27, 2014 at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ, 201-843-9090.

Van de BERGHE--Joan O'Keefe, of Fairfield, CT, wife of the late Richard L. Van de Berghe, MD died Sunday, February 23, 2014. Funeral Mass Saturday, March 1, 2014 11am, St. Pius X Church, Fairfield, CT. Friends may call Friday 5-8pm at the Spear-Miller Funeral Home, 39 South Benson Rd., Fairfield, CT. To read the complete obituary go to: SpearMillerFueralHome.com

FALCONE--Richard Aurelio, 95, died peacefully of cancer on Tuesday, February 25, 2014 in his beloved Greenwich Village home. The devoted and enchanting husband of Mimi Sheraton for 58 delicious years, he loved and was beloved by his son Marc and daughter-in-law Caitlin Halligan and shared a special bond with his adored granddaughter, Anna, the greatest wonder his bright blue eyes ever gazed upon. The youngest of three siblings (all deceased), he was born in the Arthur Avenue section of the Bronx on April 12, 1918, to Giovannina and Francesco Falcone, immigrants from Puglia and Abruzzo who instilled a lasting love of the Italian language, opera, wine and all things pasta. A graduate of St. Martin of Tours and De Witt Clinton High School, Dick was a Morse Code radio operator during World War Il, landed at Gold Beach, spent 45 days in a foxhole during the Bulge and was in one of the first reconnaissance tanks to cross the Remagen Bridge before serving in a United States Army cultural exchange office in Paris where he was befriended by Gertrude Stein as one of her Gl's. A long-time executive at Gimbels where he began as a stockboy, he later was president of Garcia Ski and Tennis, the first to import Rossignol skis. As president of Cafco, NY, he represented Puiforcat silver and other fine French and Italian tableware. He retired to join Mimi in her work that was their pleasure, eating their way around the world and having many wonderful parties at home that were his pride. In addition to music, art, and walking New York City, he remained loyal to the Yankees and the Jets. Vigorous and fastidious, he was a wonderful dancer, a skilled and speedy driver, and a dedicated community activist. A hero for his time as celebrated by Lermontov, darling Richard will be missed forever by all who loved and enjoyed him. Death did not take him too young - only too young. Services to be held 11:30am on Friday, February 28th. Visitation at 10am at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel,) 1076 Madison Ave. New York, NY.
CAREY--Dennis J.,Jr. Jan. 5, 1918 - Feb. 25, 2013 Miss you. Love you. Think of you always. Clare and Your Family

FISCHER--Harris. Most incredible and funny husband, father, and grandfather died at the age of 91 years young, on February 24th in Manhattan. He is survived by the love of his life, his wife of 62 years, Nancy, who was his travel, drinking, golfing and dining buddy. He is also survived by his adoring daughter Ellen, his phenomenal son-in-law Sam, his son David, and his idolized grandchildren Josh (girlfriend Lise) and Matt. He will be incredibly missed by so many more. Graveside service will be private. Please feel free to make a donation to your favorite charity in Harris's name.

FALCONE--Richard Aurelio, 95, died peacefully of cancer on Tuesday, February 25, 2014 in his beloved Greenwich Village home. The devoted and enchanting husband of Mimi Sheraton for 58 delicious years, he loved and was beloved by his son Marc and daughter-in-law Caitlin Halligan and shared a special bond with his adored granddaughter, Anna, the greatest wonder his bright blue eyes ever gazed upon. The youngest of three siblings (all deceased), he was born in the Arthur Avenue section of the Bronx on April 12, 1918, to Giovannina and Francesco Falcone, immigrants from Puglia and Abruzzo who instilled a lasting love of the Italian language, opera, wine and all things pasta. A graduate of St. Martin of Tours and DeWitt Clinton High School, Dick was a Morse Code radio operator during World War Il, landed at Gold Beach, spent 45 days in a foxhole during the Bulge and was in one of the first reconnaissance tanks to cross the Remagen Bridge before serving in a United States Army cultural exchange office in Paris where he was befriended by Gertrude Stein as one of her Gl's. A long-time executive at Gimbels where he began as a stockboy, he later was president of Garcia Ski and Tennis, the first to import Rossignol skis. As president of Cafco, NY, he represented Puiforcat silver and other fine French and Italian tableware. He retired to join Mimi in her work that was their pleasure, eating their way around the world and having many wonderful parties at home that were his pride. In addition to music, art, and walking New York City, he remained loyal to the Yankees and the Jets. Vigorous and fastidious, he was a wonderful dancer, a skilled and speedy driver, and a dedicated community activist. A hero for his time as celebrated by Lermontov, darling Richard will be missed forever by all who loved and enjoyed him. Death did not take him too soon - only too young. Services to be held 11:30am on Friday, February 28th. Visitation at 10am at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel,) 1076 Madison Ave. New York, NY.

BAHNA--Ralph. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of our friend and supporter, Ralph Bahna. All of us at Columbia are deeply grateful for his vision and generosity, and what they have meant to the work in our Division of Cardiology. We offer our condolences to his wife, Dorothy; his children, Lauren, Deborah and Adam; his grandchildren, and the extended Bahna family. Allan Schwartz, MD Chief, Division of Cardiology Vice Chair, Department of Medicine Columbia University Medical Center

BRODER--Carley, age 63, on February 25, encircled by loved ones, from lung disease. Originally from Rumson, NJ, Carley was a devoted Upper West Sider, living near Lincoln Center to feed her love of all things ballet. A gifted communicator, Carley championed justice and equality. A cherished daughter of the late Gloria Waldman Appel and Marvin and Lois Broder, and sister to Michael (Rita Rubin), Betsy (David Wentworth) and the late Chip (Celeste Hoppey-Broder). She also leaves her beloved siblings from the Stern and Appel families, adored nieces and nephews, and devoted friends. Contributions in her honor can be made to Project Plie, American Ballet Theater, 890 Broadway, NY, NY, 10003. Memorial service at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday, March 2 at 2pm.

EBERSTADT--Walter A. The New School mourns the loss of Walter A. Eberstadt, life trustee of The New School. A survivor of the darkest moments of the 20th Century, he displayed a lifelong commitment to education, free discourse, and artistic expression. His commitment to philanthropy and public service will continue to inspire us, and live on in the many programs he generously supported at The New School. We extend deepest condolences to his wife Vera, and his children. David E. Van Zandt, President of The New School and Joe Gromek, Chair of the Board of Trustees of The New School

PARGH--Harriet Turim, born September 28, 1916, died peacefully on February 25, 2014 at her home in North Shore Towers, Floral Park, NY. Harriet grew up in Far Rockaway and left Hunter College to work during the Depression, rising to Vice President Sales in a dynamic 50 year career at Packaging Systems Corp. She was a world traveler who was active in Hadassah, volunteered at Long Island Jewish Hospital, and never turned down a card game. She is survived by her daughter Edith, son Jonathan, and grandchildren Rachel Yohay, David Yohay, David Pargh, and William Pargh. She joins her beloved husband David (died 1974) in Mt Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, LI.

PARKER--Diane. We mourn the loss of Diane Parker, beloved wife of Mel Parker and devoted mother of Emily and David. Diane was a career educator and an inspiring teacher to generations of students, working for 30 years at P.S. 8 in Brooklyn and 10 years as an adjunct professor at Brooklyn College. Contributions in Diane's memory may be made to the Early Childhood Center of Congregation Beth Elohim in Brooklyn.

AUBRY--Marcel Aboudaram Age 93, on February 15, 2014 in New York joining his beloved wife Blossom in eternal peace and love. Devoted father of Philippe and Michel, daughter-in-law Doreen, and grandfather of Nicholas, he was born in Marseille, and grew up in Paris and Normandy. Marcel first came to the United States as a student at Carleton College in 1937, but returned to France at the onset of WWII. He served as a pilot in the French Air Force, flying light bombers with the allies before returning to the United States in 1948, and settling in New York City. He entered the commodities trading industry in 1953, eventually founding his own firm in 1961, Marcel Aubry & Co., Inc., which endures to this day. He was a long time member of The Cocoa Merchants Association of America, and the Green Coffee Association of New York City. His memory remains in our hearts for his love, kindness, generosity and devotion to his family. Memorial Service will be private.

VASSALLO--Edward F. Today, my baby cousin Ed Vassallo breathed his last in this world. He fought as a samurai warrior against the leukemia that returned last year, after a wonderful year in remission. I could go on and on about his humor, his heart, his sense of justice and desire for all mankind to be treated equally, his daily missions and video postings from the Rockaways after Hurricane Sandy, his stint on The Sopranos, his membership with the LAByrinth Theater Company, his deep love of all New York sports teams.... an actor, an inspiration to all who met him and worked with him, he will be missed by his friends around the world, and mostly his family. My heart goes out to his wife Chen, his dad John Vassallo, his brother John Vassallo, his dear sister Elena Vassallo Crossman, his mom Carol Vassallo Soderholm, and all the nieces and nephews who deeply adored him. These were my closet cousins growing - up we have wonderful memories.... I will miss you very much Eddie Freddie.... xoxo see you on the other side. Lee Robin

de BARY--Victoria, of Greenwich, CT, passed away peacefully at her home on Wednesday, February 19, 2014 after a brave struggle with brain cancer. The beloved wife of Paul de Bary and mother of Edward (Ned) de Bary of Boston and John de Bary of New York City, she is also survived by her brother, Robert Stiepock and his wife Virginia, of Wakefield, RI. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 6th, 2014 at 2:00pm at the Belle Haven Club in Greenwich, CT.

JACOBS--Jean Becker, passed away on February 27, 2014, in New York City at the age of 96. Jean was a loving and devoted mother and grandmother to her children, Lois Safian, Jill Franklin, Gary Jacobs, and Randy Jacobs, her 11 grandchildren, her 16 great-grandchildren, and their spouses and companions. Jean was born in New York to Herman Becker, a theatre owner, and Hattie Timberg Weinstein, a vaudeville performer. She was married to physician Lewis Jacobs for more than 60 years. The couple lived in Manhattan, Mt. Vernon and Chappaqua, NY and Lauderhill, FL. While in Mt Vernon, Jean founded the Westchester League for Cardiac Children, helped her husband manage his pediatric practice and Cross County Hospital, coordinated research on brain development and co-authored several articles. She was an excellent gardener, cook, "needle pointer" and amateur poet. Jean loved the theatre and treasured her family. We would like to thank Angela Taylor for all her support. A memorial service will be held at 2pm, February 28th, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, on Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to American Jewish World Service (AJWS.org). The family will be receiving guests at the home of Lois Safian, on February 28th from 3:30pm 6pm and on March 1st from 5:30 to 8:30pm. The immediate family can be reached via email at Jeanjacobs1917@gmail.com

VASSALLO--Edward F.,45, of New York City passed away February 25, 2014 after a long and courageous battle with leukemia. Ed was an actor and producer, and a Board Member of the Labyrinth Theater Company. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Chen He, his parents John and Carol (Soderholm), his step-parents Lynne Vassallo and Paul Soderholm, his brother John and sister Elena Crossman and their spouses Kate and Kenneth, his niece Olivia, his nephews Conrad, John Angelo and Lucas, and countless friends and colleagues. Funeral services will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church, 325 Park Avenue at 51st Street, Tuesday, March 4, 2014 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in Ed's name to organizations that were very close to his heart: The 52nd Street Project (http://www.52project.org), LAByrinth Theater Company (http://labtheater.org) and the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (http://www.lls.org).

BAHNA--Ralph. New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourns the passing of Ralph Bahna, a remarkably creative, innovative and generous friend of our institution. With his wife, Dorothy, Mr. Bahna provided invaluable support and guidance to the Hospital and to our cardiac programs. He and Dorothy created the Bahna Fund for Electrophysiology, which supports the effort to develop improved and innovative treatment for cardiac patients. He also served on the steering committee that spearheaded the creation and construction of the Vivian and Seymour Milstein Family Heart Center. We extend our deepest condolences to Dorothy and his children, Lauren, Deborah, and Adam, and his entire family. Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO, NY-Presbyterian Hospital

LOW--Robert Allen, former New York City Council member and mayoral candidate, died in San Francisco on January 3, 2014 at the age of 94. Bob Low was born in Scarsdale, NY on June 6, 1919 and raised in New York City. He and his siblings, Stuart and Doris, were the children of Clarence Low, former Treasurer of the Democratic State Committee, and Madeleine Low (nee Mayer), daughter of Levy Mayer, one of America's most distinguished lawyers of the early twentieth century and co-founder of the global law firm Mayer Brown LLP. Bob attended Collegiate School and Choate. He was the youngest tennis player ever to compete in a National Tournament at the age of nine, as a teenager won numerous titles and captained the men's varsity tennis team at Stanford University. The day after his graduation from Stanford in 1941, Bob entered the US Navy and served in the Pacific during World War II. He became one of the youngest Lieutenant Commanders ever and won nine battle stars during his service, fighting at Iwo Jima, Midway and Okinawa. After the war, Bob moved to Washington, D.C. where he worked at the Saturday Review Magazine and graduated from George Washington University Law School. Public service was deeply ingrained in Bob and guided his professional life. He served in the State Department and worked for Senators Herbert Lehman and Henry "Scoop" Jackson (a lifelong friend and mentor), handling congressional relations. In 1952 he met Frances Delia Levison, one of the first female reporters for Time-Life Magazine, and they were married for 60 years until her death in 2012. Bob would often say that she was "the most remarkable woman I ever knew". In 1954 the couple moved back to New York City where Bob was appointed assistant to Mayor Robert Wagner. In 1961, Bob was elected to the New York City Council where he served two terms, representing the "Silk Stockings" District of Manhattan's Upper East Side, East Harlem and Yorkville--a true cross section of upper, lower and middle income families. He co-authored one of the first anti-pollution laws in the United States. Bob was subsequently featured in a New York Times article entitled "Pollution's Nemesis", detailing his critical role in the fight for clean air, which eventually led to the federal Clean Air Act. Bob was also chairman of New York City's Buildings Committee oversaw the first major revision of the building code controlling construction in almost seventy years. Bob disguised himself as a struggling writer and moved into a slum in East Harlem for a week to experience first-hand the living conditions. On another occasion, he moonlighted as a taxi driver to understand their challenges and advocated for higher wages. He studied Spanish in order to communicate and connect with the growing Puerto Rican population. In 1969 he entered the New York City race for mayor and president of city council and, although the campaigns were unsuccessful, he proved to be a progressive and political maverick. In the 1970's Bob was appointed Regional Administrator for the Environmental Protection Administration and then Regional Representative for the U.S. Department of Energy, overseeing the growth and development of the New York City water system, and policing air pollution laws, waste water and nuclear waste in the region. In 1980, Bob returned to civilian life and a small private law practice. Bob and Frances pursued their passion for people, food and wine, founding "Le Cercle de Gastronomes", a precursor to contemporary "pop-up" restaurants, at their house in Dutchess County, where Bob served French haute-cuisine paired with fine wines. He was a food critic and an editor for the French restaurant guidebook "Gault et Millau". In 2002, he and Frances moved to San Francisco to be with their sons and grandchildren. Bob is survived by his brother, Stuart, as well as his sons, Allen and Roger, six grandchildren, and several nieces and nephews. "The Low Family asks that donations be made to The East Harlem School, an organization close to the Family's heart that serves low income students in New York City." A gathering of friends and family to celebrate Bob's life will be held at a later date.

RICKERT--Ruth A.,age 96, died February 24, 2014. Beloved wife of Edwin Rickert, mother of Jean, Wendy and Allen. Grandmother of Michael, Henry and Thomas. Born in Norfolk, VA, January 3, 1918, Daughter of Junius and Grace Fulcher. Ruth graduated from Sullins College, the Maryland Institute of Art and Teachers College at John Hopkins. She taught high school art in Maryland. She was a leader in Scouting, the PTA, and an active member of the United Church of Rockville Centre, NY. Her art was exhibited and she published several books on family genealogy. She was related to preachers, farmers, revolutionary and civil war veterans but her most sentimental heritage was of the generations of Cape Hatteras lighthouse keepers. She kept a light in her heart for everyone. She is survived by her children Jean and Allen. Donations may be made in Ruth's name to the charity of your choice.

BAHNA--Ralph M. 71, of Stamford, CT passed away peacefully surrounded by family on February 24, 2014. A global leader and entrepreneur in the travel industry, Ralph launched major innovations and businesses in hotels, ocean cruising and airline travel. He was the founder of the Club Quarters hotel chain; original investor and Chairman of Priceline.com; Chairman of Cunard Lines, Ltd.; and senior executive of Trans World Airlines. In both his business and private life, Ralph combined integrity and modesty with constant drive and passionate commitment to public service and the public good. Soft-spoken, with a gentle manner and an unfailingly cheerful sense of humor, Ralph commanded attention, respect and loyalty through the clarity, forcefulness and originality of his thinking and leadership. His business philosophy emphasized "problem definition," which he said must always precede successful problem solutions. Born 1942 in Grand Rapids, Michigan, Ralph received a BA from the University of Michigan '64, and MBA from UC Berkeley '66. At TWA he invented the idea of business class service ("Ambassador Service"), as well as curbside check-in. Credited with turning around the troubled airline, The New York Times acclaimed him a "marketing genius" while still in his twenties. At age 30, Ralph became the president of Cunard Lines. There he reinvented luxury cruise travel in the age of airline competition. He recast the company's flagship, the QE2, as a vacation destination by itself with the first-ever spas and computer centers on an ocean liner. Instead of competing with airlines, he partnered with them to offer Atlantic crossings via sea for one leg of the voyage and via supersonic Concorde flights for the return. Cunard became the world's largest buyer of supersonic airline seats. Cunard made luxury cruises accessible to middle-class consumers, quadrupling sales. Ralph became the first U.S.-born Chairman and CEO of Cunard Lines from 1980 to 1989. In 1990 Travel Trade Magazine named him "Cruise Industry Leader of the Decade". In the '90s Ralph created Club Quarters, a global chain of full service hotels for business travelers in major city centers. Club Quarters serves many Fortune 500 and FTSE 100 companies as members of this private organization. The chain's prime city-center locations include Rockefeller Center and the World Trade Center in NYC; Chicago River at Michigan Ave.; Embarcadero Center in San Francisco; Washington, DC (one block from the White House); and Trafalgar Square, London. Ralph was a pre-IPO investor in Priceline, the revolutionary, name-your-own-price web platform. He helped lead Priceline from its 1998 launch to an historic $1 billion in sales in 18 months. A board member, he became non-executive Chairman from 2004 until 2013. During his tenure, Priceline expanded worldwide, joined the S&P 500 and became the #

VASSALLO--Edward F. Today, my baby cousin Ed Vassallo breathed his last in this world. He fought as a samurai warrior against the leukemia that returned last year, after a wonderful year in remission. I could go on and on about his humor, his heart, his sense of justice and desire for all mankind to be treated equally, his daily missions and video postings from the Rockaways after Hurricane Sandy, his stint on The Sopranos, his membership with the LAByrinth Theater Company, his deep love of all New York sports teams.... an actor, an inspiration to all who met him and worked with him, he will be missed by his friends around the world, and mostly his family. My heart goes out to his wife Chen, his dad John Vassallo, his brother John Vassallo, his dear sister Elena Vassallo Crossman, his mom Carol Vassallo Soderholm, and all the nieces and nephews who deeply adored him. These were my closet cousins growing - up we have wonderful memories.... I will miss you very much Eddie Freddie.... xoxo see you on the other side. Lee Robin
