VASSALLO--Edward F.,45, of New York City passed away February 25, 2014 after a long and courageous battle with leukemia. Ed was an actor and producer, and a Board Member of the Labyrinth Theater Company. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Chen He, his parents John and Carol (Soderholm), his step-parents Lynne Vassallo and Paul Soderholm, his brother John and sister Elena Crossman and their spouses Kate and Kenneth, his niece Olivia, his nephews Conrad, John Angelo and Lucas, and countless friends and colleagues. Funeral services will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church, 325 Park Avenue at 51st Street, Tuesday, March 4, 2014 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in Ed's name to organizations that were very close to his heart: The 52nd Street Project (http://www.52project.org), LAByrinth Theater Company (http://labtheater.org) and the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (http://www.lls.org).

VASSALLO--Eddie. We are saddened to learn of Eddie's passing. He was taken way too soon. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to our dear friends, the entire Vassallo family. Charlotte & Roger, Beth & Peter, Marc & Ellen and Eric

EBERSTADT--Walter. Died February 26, 2014 at home. Born July 15, 1921 in Frankfurt, Germany, Walter Eberstadt moved with his family to England in 1936 to escape Nazi persecution and was educated at Oxford University. In WWII, he was first interned, then released to the Pioneer Corps for domestic service. When "enemy aliens" were allowed to join fighting units, he transferred to the Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry and fought in Normandy where he was wounded in August of 1944. He was posted back to Germany at the beginning of the reconstruction, having risen to the rank of major, in charge of "Radio Hamburg," and then spent three years in London writing for the Economist. In 1951 he immigrated to the United States, where he began a highly successful career in investment banking, first at Lehman Brothers and later at Lazard Freres, becoming a partner there in 1970. He was an innovator in the field of closed-end mutual funds, establishing a number of successful international investment partnerships. Walter married Vera von Kuffner in 1964, and had two sons, Michael and George. He was a loving grandfather to Max, Zoe, Esme, and Maya and adored his daughters-in-law, Nina Beattie and Cynthia Young. His sister, Bridget, who married his Oxford friend James Collier and passed away in 2013, remained in England with his parents, and his two nieces Caroline and Lucy and their families live there. Walter served as a Trustee of the New School University for 39 years where he was instrumental in preserving the legacy of the University in Exile and was awarded an Honorary Doctorate in 1996. As President of the Northside Center for Child Development, Board Member of the American Council on Germany, Chairman of the Martha's Vineyard Preservation Trust, Board Member of the St. Bernard's School, and Chairman of the Advisory Board of the World Policy Institute, Walter guided great institutions with wisdom and acumen. He had an elegant way about him, and delicate matters benefited from his respectful and diplomatic approach. During his last 10 years, The Frick Collection, where he served as a Trustee, becoming Vice Chair of the Board, was his great passion. He supported many exhibitions and scholarly endeavors at both the museum and the library, and he constantly enlarged the circle of supporters of the Frick through his sheer enthusiasm and love of the institution. In his many international business and volunteer activities, Walter built bridges between his three countries of citizenship, and he was honored with both an OBE from England and the Order of Merit from Germany. Walter had a keen intellect and wide range of interests in literature, music, and art. He authored "Whence We Came, Where We Went" (2002), a book tracing the history of his remarkable family back to its origins in Germany. He had a special passion for sailing, centered in Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard, where he and his family spent happy summers for nearly fifty years. He was always open to new things. He was at home everywhere, and exuded charm and a profound love of and pride in his family. Everyone who came into his world was touched by his generosity of spirit and love of life. His many friends will miss his conversational wit, kindness, and resilient spirit. Contributions in Walter's memory may be made to the Frick Collection frick.org/support/annual--fund and the New School www.newschool.edu/eberstadt There will be an open memorial service on Monday, March 3 at 11am at the Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street.

GENOVA--John M.,age 59, of Jersey City, NJ and Southampton, NY and formally of Drexel Hill, PA on February 26, 2014. Son of the late Stephanie M. and John C. Genova. Beloved partner of Graham Seymour; brother of Rosemary(John) Byrne and Joyce (Joseph) Dominick. Uncle of Dennis, Kevin and Matthew Byrne and Lauren Dominick. Great Uncle of Connor, Samantha and Abigail Byrne. Graduate of Monsignor Bonner High School, Scranton University, NYU, Fordham Law. Most recently with the law firm of White & Case (New York). In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Cancer Society are being accepted.

EBERSTADT--Walter A. Lazard mourns the passing of Walter Eberstadt, our partner and cherished friend for four decades. He was one of our best: worldly, erudite, accomplished, and fully dedicated to his clients. He bridged cultures in international finance and enriched the lives of those he touched. He lived a remarkable life: born in Germany; fighting for the British in World War II; and moving to the U.S. where he would pioneer the field of international investing, while cultivating deep and broad passions for history, the arts, and global affairs. In retirement he remained a vibrant presence at Lazard and in society, serving not-for-profit organizations in the arts, education and public policy. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Vera, and his sons, George and Michael.

FALCONE--Richard A. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of Richard A. Falcone, beloved father of our friend and partner, Marc Falcone. We express our deepest sympathies to Marc, Caitlin and to all other members of the family.

BERNSTEIN--Arnold. The Board of Trustees, faculty, administration, students, and alumni of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies mourn the passing of Arnold Bernstein, PhD. In 1972, he and other psychoanalysts founded CMPS in order to train people in the theory and technique of modern psychoanalysis. In his capacity as founder, faculty, analyst, supervisor, and Board member, he touched the lives of an incalculable number of people. It is fitting to note that he passed away while dressing to go to his office to his first analysand of the day. His intellect was vast but not more so than his humanity. He was the epitome of a truly therapeutic personality. The pain of losing him is eased in knowing that his compassion and contributions to the field will carry forward.

VASSALLO--Ed. Our valiant friend, Ed Vassallo, is gone. Commitment. Joy. Pranks. Love of life. Bright laughter. Eyes that grew large with enthusiasm over the smallest detail he believed would move our theater company forward - keep it together. Ed's great love of theater, strength of spirit and his special talent as an actor is known to many. We are deeply saddened by his loss. For Labyrinth Theater Company, Ed brought spirit, labor, and loving embrace. As an actor, he lit up our stage. As an educator, he inspired literally hundreds of the next generation of theater artists. As a producer of our marathon festivals, he made the impossible possible. He was committed to the success of not only our theater but to the history, the craft, and the brilliance of the American theater. We say goodbye with our sense of great loss and profound love. Ed Vassallo was elected by his fellow Company members to serve on our Board of Directors. He was and will always be a Company Member of Labyrinth Theater Company.

ZECKENDORF--William Jr.,84, died on February 12, 2014 in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Born in Manhattan on October 31, 1929, William Zeckendorf transformed the skyline of New York City and pioneered in changing the urban landscape of the city from Union Square to the Upper West Side. It is with deep love and admiration that we honor the life of our father and celebrate him as our devoted mentor. His brilliance in defining the future for neglected and decaying urban neighborhoods is legendary. When the Upper West Side was far distant from what it is today, William Zeckendorf built The Columbia at West 96th Street and Broadway, a development that undeniably helped to spur a West Side residential renaissance that continues today. He also built some of New York City's finest luxury developments including the Park Belvedere, Vanderbilt and Central Park Place. In midtown, William Zeckendorf built the elegant Four Seasons Hotel, and 4 Columbus Circle, a commercial building that stood alone, long before the successful destination that Columbus Circle has become. Downtown, Union Square could hardly be seen as the vibrant area that it is now. Zeckendorf Towers, envisioned by William Zeckendorf in the 1980's, led the way for the thriving 21st Century commercial and residential neighborhood that Union Square is today. The flourishing Eighth Avenue corridor is due in large measure to what William Zeckendorf saw and accomplished in his development of Worldwide Plaza, well before others followed with new developments now lining the Avenue. Worldwide Plaza was perhaps New York City's first genuine modern mixed use development combining corporate office headquarters with residential, cultural and theater facilities along with a mid-block public plaza. Other major projects included the Ronald Reagan Office Building in Washington, D.C. He was a man of great taste and culture, having served for over 50 years as an esteemed member of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin. His passion for the arts and education leave a lasting legacy from New York to Santa Fe. His quarter century of service to Long Island University preceded his deep commitment to philanthropy in his role as Founding Director of the Lensic Performing Arts Center in Santa Fe and his passionate support of The Santa Fe Opera, the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, Christus St. Vincent Hospital and the College of Santa Fe. William Zeckendorf contributed his great vision to the City of New York and its residents, who benefit enormously every day from his lifetime of achievements. He is survived by his wife, Nancy, his sister Susan Zeckendorf Nicholson, his sons Arthur Zeckendorf and William Lie Zeckendorf and two grandchildren. We are forever thankful and grateful for the wonderful lesson your life has been for us. A memorial service will be held in New York City at 4pm on March 5th. Please call 1-212-508-7273 for details. A memorial service will be held on March 29th in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Donations in his memory may be made to the Lensic Performing Arts Center, 211 West San Francisco Street, Santa Fe, New Mexico 87501. Arthur Zeckendorf William Lie Zeckendorf

VANDENBERG--Kent D. On Saturday, February 22, 2014, Kent Douglas Vandenberg, of Solebury, Bucks County, PA, a husband, a father, a brother, a friend, a musician, a spiritual guide, a business man, an engineer and most of all a teacher of life died peacefully at home after courageously fighting gastric cancer. Kent is survived by his loving wife of 23 years, Stephanie Vandenberg; his three amazing children, Eric Maxwell, Nicholas Ryan and Claire Lois of Solebury, PA; his brother Raymond Vandenberg (Margaret) of Pelham Manor, NY and several nephews and nieces. Born in Bristol, PA on June 22, 1955, Kent earned a BS Engineering degree Summa Cum Laude from Northeastern University and a Masters Degree in Electrical Engineering/Semiconductors from University of Vermont. Over the years, Kent led a successful sales and marketing career with IBM, Toshiba, Samsung and several Silicon Valley start-ups. Funeral Services were held on Saturday, March 1, 2014 at Trinity Episcopal Church, 6587 Upper York Road, Solebury, PA. GREENMAN--Charles. Beloved husband, father, friend, attorney and advisor dies at 66. Charles Preston Greenman, a commercial litigator at the law firm of Troutman Sanders LLP, where he was a partner and defended numerous class actions relating to a wide variety of consumer and securities issues, died on Saturday, February 22, 2014, at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. He was respected both in and out of the courtroom as a force to be reckoned with. He served as Assistant Commissioner of the Department of Consumer Affairs for the City of New York and Consumer Advocate for the City--charting new ground for aggressively protecting consumers' rights. Much beloved husband of Jane, father of Margot, Jaclyn and Danielle, proud grandfather of Seymour (Simi), father in-law of Caio and son-in-law of Isabelle, as well as adored brother, friend, uncle, and godfather, Charles was larger than life. Charles was a graduate of Albion College in Michigan where he played college football, Boston University, where he earned a master's degree in history and New York University School of Law, from which he graduated with honors. He served as Chairman of the Robinson-Patman Act Subcommittee of the New York State Bar Association and Chairman of the Committee on Consumer Affairs of the New York County Lawyers' Association. In addition, he taught Consumer Law at NYU School of Law for more than a dozen years and wrote numerous articles on consumer law issues for the New York Law Journal and similar publications. His outsized physique, spirit and uncanny intelligence made people cling to him, looking for protection and guidance in a perilous and sometimes uncontrollable world, a responsibility naturally bestowed upon him that he embraced and enjoyed. Charles loved to travel, play tennis, bicycle, and to be doted upon by his adoring wife and daughters, who will miss him more than he could have ever imagined. We are better human beings today for knowing Charles and being part of his life. He made his home a welcome haven to all comers--friends, family and all their friends and children--all of whom came to him to seek advice and companionship. His giant personality was contagious and inspiring. He made his mark on the world and leaves a gap that can never be filled. Funeral services will be held on Monday, February 24, 2014 at 11:45am at Riverside Chapel in New York City, and the family will be receiving guests at home from Monday early evening until Friday, February 28, 2014.

GREENING--Robert C.,passed away February 24, 2014 at the age of 78, in San Francisco, CA of Multiple Systems Atrophy. Bob is survived by his loving wife of thirty two years, Serena Kokjer Greening; children Michelle Schmitt (Henry), Robert Jr. (Renee), Michael (Teresa), Patrick, Kelly Kopatsis (Anthony); and grandchildren Eric and Alex Schmitt, Rory and Claire Greening, Lauren, Natalie and Erin Greening, Jack and Grace Greening, Katie and Tony Kopatsis. He is also survived by his sister Dolores Greening; cousins Karen, Mary and Jim Longe (Marcy) and well as other cousins. Bob was born in Ionia, Michigan, the third of five children to Ambrose and Mary Kathryn Greening. His brothers Frederick, John and Philip are deceased. He graduated from St. Stephen High School in Port Huron, Michigan, attended Sacred Heart Seminary and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from Wayne State University both in Detroit. Upon graduation Bob married Elizabeth Roche, to whom he was married for twenty years, and worked for the J. L. Hudson Company, the major Michigan department store, where during the course of twenty years he held several merchandising and store management positions. In 1977 Bob was hired by Emporium Capwell, a division of Carter Hawley Hale Stores, Inc., with whom he held key merchandising positions for ten years before relocating to The Broadway, the CHH division in Los Angeles, where he held senior store management positions. In 1990 Bob started Alliance Stores Inc. and, in partnership with his son Michael, rapidly expanded its Designer Brands Accessories stores in factory outlet shopping centers throughout the country. Upon selling the company in 1996 to a costume jewelry manufacturer, Bob went to work for Enchante Accessories, Inc. a New York based producer of bath and body products for the retail industry where he worked in sales until his retirement in August 2010. At that time Bob secured his real estate license and assisted his wife, Serena, in her mortgage broker business. SIMONS--Mary. We mourn the passing of Mary Simons, 82, of New York City, Mill River Massachusetts, and Orvieto, Italy. Her life ended peacefully and with dignity, on February 19th, surrounded by her family. She had battled Leukemia for 20 years. Born in Arlington, Massachusetts. She was a 1953 graduate of Wellesley College. Mary went on to have an accomplished career as an award winning journalist, foreign correspondent and editor at Interiors, Look, and Life magazines. She was also the first female Senior Editor of The New York Times Sunday Magazine and Editor in Chief of Food & Wine Magazine. Her work focused on the arts and other cultural areas. In addition to her homes in New York City and Massachusetts, Mary lived for many years with her family in Europe and Asia. After retirement, she continued to pursue her love for travel, gardening and the arts. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Walter, her two daughters, Alexandra Houston and Hilary Simons, and six grandchildren. Mary was a person of great strength and generosity. We will remember her intellectual prowess, culinary skills, and her love of aesthetic beauty. She was deeply engaged in life; she wanted to experience and share it all. We will miss forever her presence in our lives. Donations in Mary's memory can be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center, and the Special Olympics.

SOKEL--Walter H, 96, one of the last of the generation of Jewish intellectual refugees from Europe that so enriched American cultural life, died February 21st at his residence in San Francisco. Cherished father, beloved friend and lifelong scholar, he possessed a charming, vital and generous spirit as well as a driving intellect. Walter Sokel was born in Vienna, Austria in December, 1917. He fled soon after the Nazi Anschluss of Austria in 1938, and arrived in New York at the age of 21. On the basis of a letter of recommendation from the revered German author Thomas Mann, he received a scholarship from Rutgers University, and went on to become a prominent professor and scholar who bridged cultural boundaries, explaining the best of German and German-Jewish culture to an American audience. In a career spanning almost 50 years, Professor Sokel was connected to many top US, German and Austrian universities. He spent the last 20 years of his teaching career at the University of Virginia as Commonwealth Professor in the German and English Departments. Known for his work on 20th century European literature, German intellectual history, Expressionism, and in particular Kafka, two of Professor Sokel's books published in 1964 and 1966 were the first to put Kafka into his proper place as a giant of European literature. Among other honors, Professor Sokel was the recipient in 1998 of the Austrian Cross of Honor for Science and Art. He was preceded in death by his wife of 41 years, Jacqueline P. Sokel, and is survived by his daughter, Shari Sokel, her partner Mark Strek, and granddaughter, Hannah as well as many friends and former colleagues. A celebratory memorial service will be held April 6th in San Francisco (503) 475-4274.

KRAUS--Shirley D. Professor Emeritus in Pharmacology, Long Island University, Arnold & Marie Schwartz School of Health Sciences (formerly Brooklyn College of Pharmacy) died in New York City at age 94. Dr. Kraus was born December 24, 1919 in New York City to Michael and Hannah Dushkind. She attended Hunter College BA ('40), Cornell University MA ('43) and the University of Illinois, Champaign-Urbana, where she was granted a Ph.D. in Physiology in 1946. Entering a scientific and academic world where few women colleagues existed, Dr. Kraus held positions at Harlem Hospital, New York University College of Dentistry and Howard University Medical School before accepting a position at Brooklyn College of Pharmacy in 1957 where she remained for 25 years actively conducting research and teaching physiology and pharmacology. She inspired many of her best students, affectionately known as "Shirley's Boys" who went on to graduate schools, making their own important contributions to scientific research in pharmacology and medicine. Her "Boys" established an endowment fund bearing her name in 1996 to support undergraduate research. Dr. Kraus has written dozens of articles and received research grants funded by the National Institute of Health and National Science Foundation. She wrote Physiological and Biochemical Foundations of Therapeutics. Her accomplishments gained recognition in Who's Who in: American Education; the World of Women; American Women; the East; and American Jewry. She also appeared in American Men & Women of Science and Jews in the World of Science. She married Jerome Kraus in 1946. They have two children, Dr. Teri J. Schwartz (Raymond), C. Gordon Kraus-Friedberg (Nurit Kraus-Friedberg), seven grandchildren (Rachel Schwartz, Michael Schwartz, Daniel Schwartz, Dr. Chana Kraus-Friedberg, Yeshaya Kraus, Kaila Iserovich and Nechemia Kraus-Friedberg) and seven great-grandchildren.

PARKER--Diane. We mourn the loss of Diane Parker, beloved wife of Mel Parker and devoted mother of Emily and David. Diane was a career educator and an inspiring teacher to generations of students, working for 30 years at P.S. 8 in Brooklyn and 10 years as an adjunct professor at Brooklyn College. LIDELL--John (Jean-Claude), on February 28, 2014 at 73 years of age. Loving cousin of Huguette Bornstein, Valerie Green, Eliane Malfi and family, Robert Rossano and family. Services Tuesday, 11:30am at "The Riverside" West 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

REIFF--Sidney, age 95, passed away peacefully in California on February 22. He leaves behind the love of his life, his wife of 68 years Renee, and three adoring children, Isabel (Lee), Kenneth (Angela), and Russell (Anna) and grandchildren, Sam, Faye, Matthew, Elizabeth, Sophia, and Alexis. Sidney is also survived and fondly remembered by nephews, nieces, friends, classmates, and colleagues. A loving and involved father, Sidney will be remembered for his intelligence, integrity, steadfastness, humor, and engagement in all aspects of life. The first member of his family born in the U.S., Sidney was born in 1918 in Brooklyn, NY to Israel and Yetta Reiff. He graduated from NYU Washington Square ('38) and Medical School ('42). He was a lifelong proud alumnus, attending reunions regularly, as recently as 2012, and proudly wore his NYU hat until the last days of his life. He served in the U.S. Army Medical Corps in the Pacific during WWII. He practiced internal medicine in New York City and was on the staff of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. Fulfilling a dream from his WWII return into San Francisco Bay, in 1971 he moved to Los Angeles where he practiced medicine at Kaiser Permanente until his retirement in 1993. Post retirement he volunteered at the Venice Family Clinic. We will love and miss him always. Services 12 noon, Sunday, March 2 at Hillside Mortuary, Los Angeles 800-576-1994. Contributions in lieu of flowers can be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center.

In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Cathedral High School, 350 East 56th Street, New York, NY 10022.

HARWAY--Norman I.,died peacefully on February 24, 2014, at the age of 88. Resident of Milwaukee, WI; formerly of Wilmette, IL; Pittsburgh, PA; Mashpee, MA; Rochester, NY; and New York, NY. He was predeceased in 2010 by his beloved wife of 59 years, Vivian T. Harway. Devoted father of Maura Harway (Richard Mark) and Judith Harway (Daniel Armstrong), and grandfather of Alice Mark, Sylvie Armstrong, Keith Armstrong and Hannah Mark. Norman's parents, the late Joseph and Hannah Harway, raised their son in Manhattan during the Great Depression. Norman attended New York's public schools including Townsend Harris High School and the City College of New York. After army service in World War II (in both the European and Pacific theaters), Norman earned a doctorate in Psychology from the University of Rochester in 1952. It was in that program that he met Vivian: they married in 1951 and were the only two to earn degrees in their cohort. Norman had a long and distinguished career in the field of clinical psychology, including service on the faculties of the University of Rochester and at the University of Pittsburgh (where he was department chair), and, while on sabbatical, the University of South Australia. An avid photographer, his remarkable pictures of landscapes, flora and fauna decorated his home. In retirement, he and Vivian traveled the world, and delighted in their grandchildren's accomplishments at home. A private family memorial has been held. In lieu of flowers, gifts in Norman's memory may be made to the Norman and Vivian Harway Scholarship Fund at the Milwaukee Institute of Art and Design, 273 East Erie Street, Milwaukee, WI 53202 (Attn: Vivian Rothschild).

STEVENS--Lydia Beebe Hastings, 95, of Guilford, Conn., died peacefully at her home, February 25, 2014. She lived a life of service to family and community, always expressing appreciation for the opportunities life presented. A role model for four generations she was an avid gardener, sailor, birdwatcher, world traveler, lifelong community activist and committed environmentalist. She lived fully with dignity, humor, integrity and compassion. Born August 2, 1918 in Highland Park, Illinois to Rolland Thomas Rankin Hastings III and Ruth Shotwell Beebe, she attended Elm Place School then Roycemore School. She graduated from Vassar College in 1939 and continued as an active Vassar alumna for many decades. She married George Cooke Stevens (Yale '36) of Wallingford, Conn. in 1940. They lived in New Haven, and Mineola, N.Y. then moved to Greenwich, Conn. in 1949 where they raised their six children. Lydia Stevens devoted over half a century of her life to the people and institutions of Greenwich. She served as president of the YWCA board and chaired its building committee, which oversaw the construction of its new building that opened in 1970. She was chairman of the Greenwich Commission on Aging, first president of the Greenwich Housing Coalition, consultant to the Carver Center of the Bethel A.M.E. Church, trustee of the Greenwich Public Library and of the United Way where she served as vice president of planning and chairman of the planning council. She was first winner of the YWCA's President's Award and was Greenwich Council of Churches and Synagogues Lay Person of the Year. She was trustee of the League of Women Voters, Connecticut League of Conservation Voters, Save the Sound and the Fairfield County Fund. She served as consultant to the International Executive Service Corps. A devout Episcopalian, she worked in many capacities as a lay leader at Christ Church, Greenwich and served as its first female senior warden starting in 1981. She worked on projects for the Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut and was affiliated with the Alban Institute of Washington, D.C. Following her husband's death in 1977 she served as president of the Greenwich Broadcasting Corporation, parent company of WGCH where he had been president. She was twice elected, as a Republican, to represent the 151st district in the Connecticut General Assembly in 1988 and 1990. She continued to work on local issues in Greenwich after retiring from the legislature. In 2002 she moved full time to Guilford, Conn. to the home she and her husband designed with architect Fred Vogt in the 1970s. Predeceased by brother Rolland Thomas Rankin Hastings, Jr. in 1996 and sister Jean Hastings Ayres in 2011, she is survived by children, Lydia Stevens Gustin, N.Y., N.Y.; Priscilla (Michael) Goldfarb, Garrison N.Y.; Frederick (Ramelle) Stevens, Chapel Hill, N.C..; Elizabeth Stevens (Norman MacLeod), Woodstock, Vt.; George Stevens, Willow Creek, Calif.; Ruth Stevens (Thomas M. Stellard), East Grand Rapids, Mich.; 15 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. A celebration of Lydia's life is planned for May 3, 2014, 11:00am, Christ Episcopal Church, Greenwich, Conn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Episcopal Relief and Development, P.O. Box 7058, Merrifield, VA 22116-7058 or www.episcopalrelief.org.

MANNY--James C.,of Harpswell, Maine died February 26. Jim was born in New York City on March 21, 1933. He was a graduate of the Buckley School, St. Paul's School, Yale University and Harvard Business School. Before retiring to Maine in 1993 he lived in New Canaan, CT for 20 years. He was president of Composition Systems Inc. in White Plains. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club, Huguenot Society and Mystic Seaport. He leaves his wife of 59 years, Abigail, six children, Alison Doucette (Tom) of Stow, MA, Walter Manny (Amy) of Peterborough, NH, Alix Manny (Charles Cook) of Norwich, VT, Timothy Manny (Serena) of Barrington, RI, Abigail Newport (Jason) of Norwalk, CT and Ailsa Fox (Jason) of New York City. He also leaves 15 grandchildren. Donations in his memory may be made to the Horizons Student Enrichment Program, c/o New Canaan Country School, P.O. Box 997, New Canaan, CT 06840 or to the charity of one's choice.

BERNSTEIN--Arnold. The Board of Trustees, faculty, administration, students, and alumni of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies mourn the passing of Arnold Bernstein, PhD. In 1972, he and other psychoanalysts founded CMPS in order to train people in the theory and technique of modern psychoanalysis. In his capacity as founder, faculty, analyst, supervisor, and Board member, he touched the lives of an incalculable number of people. It is fitting to note that he passed away while dressing to go to his office to his first analysand of the day. His intellect was vast but not more so than his humanity. He was the epitome of a truly therapeutic personality. The pain of losing him is eased in knowing that his compassion and contributions to the field will carry forward.
BLAKE--Carol Tobin. Devoted friend, force of nature, held forever dear in the hearts of countless friends.

ALLISON--Anthony Clifford, passed away on February 20, 2014 at 88 at his aerie overlooking San Francisco Bay in Belmont, California. Born and raised in Africa, Tony studied medicine at Oxford, and dedicated his life to medical research. He is best known for demonstrating that humans carrying the sickle cell trait are resistant to Plasmodium falciparum malaria (1953), representing the first recognized example of Darwinian selection in humans. At Syntex in Palo Alto, CA, in collaboration with his second wife Elsie and many other scientists, he developed his concept of a novel immunosuppressive drug. The successful development of CellCept has dramatically improved the long-term survival of patients with transplanted organs, and autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus. CellCept became one of Roche's blockbuster drugs. He covered many fields of research, and published more than 400 papers in peer reviewed journals. Many were citation classics. He is survived by his second wife and professional partner Elsie Eugui, his two sons in the UK (from his first marriage to Helen Green), Miles and Joseph Mark, a half sister, Colleen, and half brother Roy in South Africa, and numerous nieces, nephews, cousins, and friends in different countries. An avid reader with an extraordinary memory, Tony was passionate about nature, including deep-sea fishing, hiking, bird-watching, classical music and wine tasting, all of which he shared with Elsie and imparted to his sons. Tony will be sorely missed, and remembered by friends, collaborators, and family for his boundless intellectual energy, creativity, many contributions to science, work ethic, and his human qualities. A celebration of his life will be held on April 13. Time and location will be found at www.crippenflynn.com or through Elsie at emeugui05@yahoo.com. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, Sierra Club, or any charity desired.

ALPERN--Sherry, 73, Died suddenly on February 24, 2014. Born in Chicago on October 8, 1940, she died in Brooklyn. A zestful lover of fine music, food and conversation, Sherry was also a fierce and inspiring advocate for the environment and for peace. She leaves her husband, Robert Alpern, her daughter, Susan Clapp, her granddaughter, Hannah, her son-in-law, Brian Clapp, and her sister, Natalie Lee. Sherry was a leader in the environmental movement, an early champion of recycling in New York City and executive director of the Environmental Action Coalition. After her daughter, Susan, married into a farming family she became active in New York Farms! She worked for the New York State Department of Agriculture & Markets. In support for peace in Israel-Palestine, she was involved in the Dialogue Project and was co-chair of J Street/New York. Sherry was a vice-president of Konheim & Ketcham, an environmental consulting firm. She worked for the NYC Department of Sanitation and the Health Systems Agency. It was as a member of the Citizens Advisory Committee on Wastewater Management that she met her husband Robert, who was the chair. Sherry was deeply committed to the arts: as an actress at the University of Michigan; in her later years as a collage-ist, and always as a lover of beautiful music. All can share in her website, sherryalpern.blogspot.com. Donations in Sherry's memory can be made to the Humane Society of the United States (http://action.humanesociety.org/goto/sherryalpern) and to J Street (https://act. jstreet.org/donate/sherry --alpern/). A Memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 6, at 12:30pm at Congregation Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn. (718)768-3814.

BAHNA--Ralph M. 71, of Stamford, CT passed away peacefully surrounded by family on February 24, 2014. A global leader and entrepreneur in the travel industry, Ralph launched major innovations and businesses in hotels, ocean cruising and airline travel. He was the founder of the Club Quarters hotel chain; original investor and Chairman of Priceline.com; Chairman of Cunard Lines, Ltd.; and senior executive of Trans World Airlines. In both his business and private life, Ralph combined integrity and modesty with constant drive and passionate commitment to public service and the public good. Soft-spoken, with a gentle manner and an unfailingly cheerful sense of humor, Ralph commanded attention, respect and loyalty through the clarity, forcefulness and originality of his thinking and leadership. His business philosophy emphasized "problem definition," which he said must always precede successful problem solutions. Born 1942 in Grand Rapids, Michigan, Ralph received a BA from the University of Michigan '64, and MBA from UC Berkeley '66. At TWA he invented the idea of business class service ("Ambassador Service"), as well as curbside check-in. Credited with turning around the troubled airline, The New York Times acclaimed him a "marketing genius" while still in his twenties. At age 30, Ralph became the president of Cunard Lines. There he reinvented luxury cruise travel in the age of airline competition. He recast the company's flagship, the QE2, as a vacation destination by itself with the first-ever spas and computer centers on an ocean liner. Instead of competing with airlines, he partnered with them to offer Atlantic crossings via sea for one leg of the voyage and via supersonic Concorde flights for the return. Cunard became the world's largest buyer of supersonic airline seats. Cunard made luxury cruises accessible to middle-class consumers, quadrupling sales. Ralph became the first U.S.-born Chairman and CEO of Cunard Lines from 1980 to 1989. In 1990 Travel Trade Magazine named him "Cruise Industry Leader of the Decade". In the '90s Ralph created Club Quarters, a global chain of full service hotels for business travelers in major city centers. Club Quarters serves many Fortune 500 and FTSE 100 companies as members of this private organization. The chain's prime city-center locations include Rockefeller Center and the World Trade Center in NYC; Chicago River at Michigan Ave.; Embarcadero Center in San Francisco; Washington, DC (one block from the White House); and Trafalgar Square, London. Ralph was a pre-IPO investor in Priceline, the revolutionary, name-your-own-price web platform. He helped lead Priceline from its 1998 launch to an historic $1 billion in sales in 18 months. A board member, he became non-executive Chairman from 2004 until 2013. During his tenure, Priceline expanded worldwide, joined the S&P 500 and became the #

FELLEMAN--Carroll A. Passed away on February 27, 2014. He was professor emeritus at Brooklyn College and a clinical psychologist in Baldwin, Long Island for forty years. Dr. Carroll Felleman received a Purple Heart for his service in the Battle of the Bulge in WWII. Deeply mourned by his wife of 66 years, Muriel Felleman and children: Laura (Jacob) Fattal, Daniel and Fred Felleman, his five loving grandchildren of whom he was tremendously proud, and his newest joy great-grandchild, Isaiah.

BECKER--Jerome David, died peacefully in his home and surrounded by his family on Friday, February 28th. Born in 1928, Jerome was a lifelong New Yorker with a vast knowledge of the city. He was a teacher and supervisor committed to the development of students and fellow teachers alike. A loving, generous father and a devoted husband, Jerome took great pride in the secular and Jewish education he provided for his sons and rigorously supported the work of their mother, his late wife Evelyn, a committed educator and activist. With an active love of jazz he shared with his family, Jerome was a person of great taste who exhibited the rare combination of exceptional knowledge and discernment with the complete absence of snobbery. He was at home in nature and treasured time on the ocean. Jerome had a special ability to connect with family, friends and strangers alike. Because he read widely, he had an exceptional life of the mind. Because he cared passionately, he had an exceptional heart. He was always willing to share both. He is survived by his sons, Lawrence and Charles, his sister Elise and her children Fred and Joanne, his daughter-in-law Beth, and three granddaughters, Marlena, Cecilia, and Dahlia
BLAYNEY--Molly. We mourn the loss of our dear Molly. Service March 10, 4pm Epiphany Church, 1393 York Ave, NYC. Gifts to Epiphany Homeless Program welcome.

de BARY--Victoria, of Greenwich, CT, passed away peacefully at her home on Wednesday, February 19, 2014 after a brave struggle with brain cancer. The beloved wife of Paul de Bary and mother of Edward (Ned) de Bary of Boston and John de Bary of New York City, she is also survived by her brother, Robert Stiepock and his wife Virginia, of Wakefield, RI. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 6th, 2014 at 2:00pm at the Belle Haven Club in Greenwich, CT.
ELLIS--Elliot F. We note with deep sadness the passing of our beloved cousin, Elliot F. Ellis, MD. Maxine & Richard Margolis Andrea & M. John Germain

AUBRY--Marcel Aboudaram Age 93, on February 15, 2014 in New York joining his beloved wife Blossom in eternal peace and love. Devoted father of Philippe and Michel, daughter-in-law Doreen, and grandfather of Nicholas, he was born in Marseille, and grew up in Paris and Normandy. Marcel first came to the United States as a student at Carleton College in 1937, but returned to France at the onset of WWII. He served as a pilot in the French Air Force, flying light bombers with the allies before returning to the United States in 1948, and settling in New York City. He entered the commodities trading industry in 1953, eventually founding his own firm in 1961, Marcel Aubry & Co., Inc., which endures to this day. He was a long time member of The Cocoa Merchants Association of America, and the Green Coffee Association of New York City. His memory remains in our hearts for his love, kindness, generosity and devotion to his family. Memorial Service will be private.

EBERSTADT--Walter. Died February 26, 2014 at home. Born July 15, 1921 in Frankfurt, Germany, Walter Eberstadt moved with his family to England in 1936 to escape Nazi persecution and was educated at Oxford University. In WWII, he was first interned, then released to the Pioneer Corps for domestic service. When "enemy aliens" were allowed to join fighting units, he transferred to the Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry and fought in Normandy where he was wounded in August of 1944. He was posted back to Germany at the beginning of the reconstruction, having risen to the rank of major, in charge of "Radio Hamburg," and then spent three years in London writing for the Economist. In 1951 he immigrated to the United States, where he began a highly successful career in investment banking, first at Lehman Brothers and later at Lazard Freres, becoming a partner there in 1970. He was an innovator in the field of closed-end mutual funds, establishing a number of successful international investment partnerships. Walter married Vera von Kuffner in 1964, and had two sons, Michael and George. He was a loving grandfather to Max, Zoe, Esme, and Maya and adored his daughters-in-law, Nina Beattie and Cynthia Young. His sister, Bridget, who married his Oxford friend James Collier and passed away in 2012, remained in England with his parents, and his two nieces Caroline and Lucy and their families live there. Walter served as a Trustee of the New School University for 39 years where he was instrumental in preserving the legacy of the University in Exile and was awarded an Honorary Doctorate in 1996. As President of the Northside Center for Child Development, Board Member of the American Council on Germany, Chairman of the Martha's Vineyard Preservation Trust, Board Member of the St. Bernard's School, and Chairman of the Advisory Board of the World Policy Institute, Walter guided great institutions with wisdom and acumen. He had an elegant way about him, and delicate matters benefited from his respectful and diplomatic approach. During his last 10 years, The Frick Collection, where he served as a Trustee, becoming Vice Chair of the Board, was his great passion. He supported many exhibitions and scholarly endeavors at both the museum and the library, and he constantly enlarged the circle of supporters of the Frick through his sheer enthusiasm and love of the institution. In his many international business and volunteer activities, Walter built bridges between his three countries of citizenship, and he was honored with both an OBE from England and the Order of Merit from Germany. Walter had a keen intellect and wide range of interests in literature, music, and art. He authored "Whence We Came, Where We Went" (2002), a book tracing the history of his remarkable family back to its origins in Germany. He had a special passion for sailing, centered in Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard, where he and his family spent happy summers for nearly fifty years. He was always open to new things. He was at home everywhere, and exuded charm and a profound love of and pride in his family. Everyone who came into his world was touched by his generosity of spirit and love of life. His many friends will miss his conversational wit, kindness, and resilient spirit. Contributions in Walter's memory may be made to the Frick Collection frick.org/support/annual--fund and the New School www.newschool.edu/eberstadt There will be an open memorial service on Monday, March 3 at 11am at the Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street.

FALCONE--Richard A. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of Richard A. Falcone, beloved father of our friend and partner, Marc Falcone. We express our deepest sympathies to Marc, Caitlin and to all other members of the family.

BLAKE--Carol Tobin, age 79, died February 27, 2014, joining her beloved husband Edmund J. Blake, Jr. in eternal peace and love. Originally from Boston, Massachusetts, Carol was a devoted New Yorker and loved being an active member of the Upper West Side community. Cherished daughter of the late Maurice and Helen Tobin, devoted sister of Helen Maixner and Maurice Tobin and beloved aunt to Ted, Maurice, Alexandra, Marise and Gabriella. She was a former board member of the MOMA, volunteered at the local Soup Kitchen, and was a devoted parishioner at the Blessed Sacrament Church. Carol loved to draw and paint, garden on her terrace, cook fabulous meals and host wonderful dinner parties. She was a loyal, compassionate friend to everyone that had the fortune of knowing her. She will truly be missed. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Madison Square Boys and Girls Club. Funeral Mass will be held 10:30am on Monday, March 3rd at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 West 71st St., NY, N.Y.

COHEN--Marion Cleveland. Granddaughter of former President Grover Cleveland, died on February 21 at age 87. Marion was the daughter of Francis Grover Cleveland and Alice Pardee Erdman who founded The Barnstormers Theatre in Tamworth, New Hampshire in 1931. She attended Friends Seminary in New York, Smith College and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. She entered the travel business in New York and in 1968 she married Fred Cohen and settled in Rome. The couple moved to Baltimore in 1973 where Marion was an active volunteer and supporter for Planned Parenthood, The Baltimore Zoo, The Smith College Book Sale and Animal Rescue. In 2008, Marion moved to Tamworth. A memorial service is planned for summer. Donations in her memory may be sent to The Barnstormers Theatre, PO Box 434, Tamworth, NH 03886.

EHRLICH--Peter Richard, of Bedford, NY, aged 83, husband of Selby Newell Brown, brother of David Ehrlich of Washington, DC, father of Peter R. Ehrlich, Jr. of Miami, James N. Ehrlich of Atlanta, Timothy H. Ehrlich of Miami Beach and John N.B. Ehrlich of Canada, grandfather of Samuel H. Ehrlich, Katherine A. Ehrlich, Josie Ehrlich and Peter Ehrlich.

CHANG--Robert, on February 27, 2014. Beloved husband of Emily and father of Spencer, Aubrey and Bobby died. Owner of Robert Chang Productions in NYC and California for many years. A memorial service will be held at 2pm, Saturday, March 8th at So. Salem Presbyterian Church, 111 Spring St., So. Salem, NY.

EBERSTADT--Walter A. Lazard mourns the passing of Walter Eberstadt, our partner and cherished friend for four decades. He was one of our best: worldly, erudite, accomplished, and fully dedicated to his clients. He bridged cultures in international finance and enriched the lives of those he touched. He lived a remarkable life: born in Germany; fighting for the British in World War II; and moving to the U.S. where he would pioneer the field of international investing, while cultivating deep and broad passions for history, the arts, and global affairs. In retirement he remained a vibrant presence at Lazard and in society, serving not-for-profit organizations in the arts, education and public policy. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Vera, and his sons, George and Michael.

ALPERN--Sherry, 73, Died suddenly on February 24, 2014. Born in Chicago on October 8, 1940, she died in Brooklyn. A zestful lover of fine music, food and conversation, Sherry was also a fierce and inspiring advocate for the environment and for peace. She leaves her husband, Robert Alpern, her daughter, Susan Clapp, her granddaughter, Hannah, her son-in-law, Brian Clapp, and her sister, Natalie Lee. Sherry was a leader in the environmental movement, an early champion of recycling in New York City and executive director of the Environmental Action Coalition. After her daughter, Susan, married into a farming family she became active in New York Farms! She worked for the New York State Department of Agriculture & Markets. In support for peace in Israel-Palestine, she was involved in the Dialogue Project and was co-chair of J Street/New York. Sherry was a vice-president of Konheim & Ketcham, an environmental consulting firm. She worked for the NYC Department of Sanitation and the Health Systems Agency. It was as a member of the Citizens Advisory Committee on Wastewater Management that she met her husband Robert, who was the chair. Sherry was deeply committed to the arts: as an actress at the University of Michigan; in her later years as a collage-ist, and always as a lover of beautiful music. All can share in her website, sherryalpern.blogspot.com. Donations in Sherry's memory can be made to the Humane Society of the United States (http://action.humanesociety.org/goto/sherryalpern) and to J Street (https://act. jstreet.org/donate/sherry --alpern/). A Memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 6, at 12:30pm at Congregation Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn. (718)768-3814.

EASTON--Thomas Lind, of Williamsburg, VA died March 1, 2014. Tom was born in Detroit on March 31, 1927. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Judith Ann Isenberg Easton; their son James Lind Easton and daughter-in-law Martha Pollard Easton, also of Williamsburg; grandchildren William Bernard Easton of New York, Susan Lind Easton and Mary Pollard Easton; and nephew Jeffrey Lind Easton and wife Pegah and daughter August of New York. Tom and Judy began married life in Roselle, NJ before moving to West Newton, MA where they lived for 33 years. Tom's professional life included work for Foster Grant and Trina, Inc., of Fall River, MA and New York, from which he retired as chairman and chief executive officer in 1991. Tom was proudest of co-founding with Judy in 1994 The Berkshire Institute for Lifetime Learning, now Osher Lifelong Learning Institute. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Tom's memory to Hospice House and Support Care of Williamsburg, 4445 Powhatan Parkway, Williamsburg, VA, 23188.

NISLEY--Janessa C.,age 69, died peacefully at her home in Hudson, NY on February 27, 2014. Her husband Professor Jay Carlisle was at her side. Janessa was an honors graduate of Vasser College and Fordham Law School. She argued hundreds of appeals as Chief of the Special Litigation Bureau for The New York City offices of Housing Preservation and Development. She was a Past President of the Brooklyn Chapter Civil Liberties Union and a Director for 20 years of the South Brooklyn Legal Services Corp. She is survived by her husband and step-daughter Marie Carlisle, brothers Robert Martin and Jack Nisley, sister Rebecca Nisley and several nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

STEVENS--Lydia Beebe Hastings, 95, of Guilford, Conn., died peacefully at her home, February 25, 2014. She lived a life of service to family and community, always expressing appreciation for the opportunities life presented. A role model for four generations she was an avid gardener, sailor, birdwatcher, world traveler, lifelong community activist and committed environmentalist. She lived fully with dignity, humor, integrity and compassion. Born August 2, 1918 in Highland Park, Illinois to Rolland Thomas Rankin Hastings III and Ruth Shotwell Beebe, she attended Elm Place School then Roycemore School. She graduated from Vassar College in 1939 and continued as an active Vassar alumna for many decades. She married George Cooke Stevens (Yale '36) of Wallingford, Conn. in 1940. They lived in New Haven, and Mineola, N.Y. then moved to Greenwich, Conn. in 1949 where they raised their six children. Lydia Stevens devoted over half a century of her life to the people and institutions of Greenwich. She served as president of the YWCA board and chaired its building committee, which oversaw the construction of its new building that opened in 1970. She was chairman of the Greenwich Commission on Aging, first president of the Greenwich Housing Coalition, consultant to the Carver Center of the Bethel A.M.E. Church, trustee of the Greenwich Public Library and of the United Way where she served as vice president of planning and chairman of the planning council. She was first winner of the YWCA's President's Award and was Greenwich Council of Churches and Synagogues Lay Person of the Year. She was trustee of the League of Women Voters, Connecticut League of Conservation Voters, Save the Sound and the Fairfield County Fund. She served as consultant to the International Executive Service Corps. A devout Episcopalian, she worked in many capacities as a lay leader at Christ Church, Greenwich and served as its first female senior warden starting in 1981. She worked on projects for the Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut and was affiliated with the Alban Institute of Washington, D.C. Following her husband's death in 1977 she served as president of the Greenwich Broadcasting Corporation, parent company of WGCH where he had been president. She was twice elected, as a Republican, to represent the 151st district in the Connecticut General Assembly in 1988 and 1990. She continued to work on local issues in Greenwich after retiring from the legislature. In 2002 she moved full time to Guilford, Conn. to the home she and her husband designed with architect Fred Vogt in the 1970s. Predeceased by brother Rolland Thomas Rankin Hastings, Jr. in 1996 and sister Jean Hastings Ayres in 2011, she is survived by children, Lydia Stevens Gustin, N.Y., N.Y.; Priscilla (Michael) Goldfarb, Garrison N.Y.; Frederick (Ramelle) Stevens, Chapel Hill, N.C..; Elizabeth Stevens (Norman MacLeod), Woodstock, Vt.; George Stevens, Willow Creek, Calif.; Ruth Stevens (Thomas M. Stellard), East Grand Rapids, Mich.; 15 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. A celebration of Lydia's life is planned for May 3, 2014, 11:00am, Christ Episcopal Church, Greenwich, Conn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Episcopal Relief and Development, P.O. Box 7058, Merrifield, VA 22116-7058 or www.episcopalrelief.org.

WOO--Paul King. Dear friend and valued member of our firm for 28 years. His untimely passing is a terrible shock. Paul was a vibrant person, full of ideas and consistently cheerful. GRATE--Jerrol Kenneth, passed away peacefully on March 1, 2014, at New York Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia University Medical Center in New York City. Mr. Grate was born in Washington, D.C. on December 26, 1948 to Anna Hoeffler and the late Robert Hamberg. He was a business owner who attended Boston College. Mr. Grate is survived by his loving wife, E. Denise Perry Grate of New York City, his mother Anna Hoeffler and many other relatives and devoted friends across the nation. The Grate family wishes to express our deep appreciation for all of the assistance, guidance and love shared with us during this time. The wake for Mr. Grate will be held Tuesday, March 4, 2014, 6:00pm to 9:00pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue in Manhattan. The funeral celebration will be held Wednesday, March 5, 2014, 11:00am at Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 Odell Clark Place, also in Manhattan. Mr. Grate was a dedicated patron of the arts and a passionate supporter of The Millennium Dance Company, the Harlem based, nonprofit dance center devoted to providing free classical training for those in need and a feeder school for major professional dance companies around the country since 1994. The Grate family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to The Millennium Dance Company, www.themillenniumdancecompany.com, in memory of Jerrol Kenneth Grate.

ROUSE--Carl A.,died on February 25, 2014 at his home in Princeton, NJ at the age of 87. Born in Youngstown, OH, he studied physics and math at Case Institute of Technology after serving in the Army Specialized Training Reserve. In 1956 he was the first African-American to earn his PhD in physics from Caltech. He worked at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory where he made contributions in atomic, plasma, and computational physics; he also worked at General Atomics for many years. A solar physicist at heart, he developed an alternative model of the sun that has led many astrophysicists to question the standard model. Mr. Rouse is survived by his wife, a son, two daughters, and six grandchildren. Donations in his honor can be sent to the National Society of Black Physicists, The Carl Rouse Fellowship Memorial Funds, 3033 Wilson Boulevard, Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

ROSS--Jesse Simmons, died unexpectedly at his home on January 11, 2014. He was thirty-six years old. A lifelong New Yorker, Jesse was born in Chelsea, raised in Tribeca, and happily returned to the city after graduating from Skidmore College with a degree in business. He centered his professional life around his love of fashion and hip-hop design. We see his unique tee shirts worn all around the city. Jesse was a natural athlete, an expert in tennis, skiing and basketball. As an adult, he developed a passion for mixed martial arts and was preparing to become an instructor in the field. Jesse was handsome and sweet, he had an amazing smile, warmth, natural intelligence and remarkable charm. Jesse's life dramatically changed in 2007 with the birth of his son. Damien, his "mini-me" and "little ninja" instantly became the center of his world and remained the focus until the day Jesse died. Jesse is survived by his adored son Damien Ross; his parents Dr. Bonnie Simmons and Roger Ross; his sister Julie Ross; step-father Bart Wenrich; and grandparents Dorothy Simmons and Itta and Donald Ross. He will also be missed by his aunts, Laurie and Susan Simmons, and uncles Carroll and Jeff; and by his cousins Jenna, Lena, and Grace. Donations in Jesse's memory may be made to the Lutheran Medical Center, Brooklyn, NY at https:// lmcmc.thankyou4caring.org/.

BAHNA--Ralph, You were an extraordinary human being. Brilliant, successful, compassionate, philanthropic, loving and kind. Few people had your qualities, capabilities or ethics. With your "laser vision" and sharp mind, you could get to the heart of any issue. Yet you never put yourself forward or sought recognition for your extraordinary achievements. You were a man who gave of yourself to others. You were an inspired leader. We are all the wiser and better human beings for having known you. We will never forget you. YPO 49er Forum Burtt Ehrlich Jan Endresen Joel Friedman Arthur Goldstein Tod Johnson Andy Kahn Neil Ryan Dan Silver Alan Stuart

PITT--David Emmett. February 19, 1947-February. 24, 2014. "If you're feeling fancy free/come wander through the world with me/and any place we chance to be/ will be a rendezvous. Two for the road/we'll travel down the years/collecting precious memories/selecting souvenirs/and living life the way we please. In summertime the sun will shine/in winter we'll drink summer wine/and any day that you are mine/will be a lovely day. As long as love still wears a smile/I know that we'll be two for the road, and that's a long long while."

STARR--Terry. On Saturday, March 1st, after a 12 year battle with Alzheimer's, my beloved wife, Terry Starr, died at home on our 61st wedding anniversary. Born Therese Frankfort in Brussels, in 1928, she and her parents Jacques and Hillegonda, sister Sophie and brother Simon Jacques fled Belgium after the Nazis bombing of Brussels on May 10th, 1940. Her family were fortunate recipients of a Sousa de Mendez visa which granted them safe passage to the US where they then lived on the upper west side in Manhattan. Terry was a talented still-life painter, an avid tennis player, a gardener and a long time volunteer docent for the Museum of the City of New York. She exhibited her work at The Clothesline in East Hampton. She will be long remembered by her husband, Herbert Starr, daughter Gaia Starr, her son David, his wife Elizabeth Ducat, and brother-in-law, Jerome Starr. May she rest in peace. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave (81st Street), Wednesday 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Terry's name to the Alzheimer's Association.

EVERHARD--Coenraad. Age 83, passed away on February 25, 2014, at his California retirement home after a brief battle with cancer. One of the iconic leaders and characters of the maritime industry during the last half of the 20th century, Conrad, or Connie, as he was known to his many friends in the industry and elsewhere, is survived by Yolanda, his devoted wife of 58 years, and by his three children. Born in 1930 in Holland, he witnessed first-hand the horrors of the Nazi invasion. He came to the US in the 1950s and graduated from Georgetown's School of Foreign Service. He then started his long and distinguished career in the maritime industry, first with United States Lines and then with the Massachusetts Port Authority where he served as Director General for Europe and Africa for eight years in Brussels, Belgium. In 1973, Conrad became CEO of Dart Container Line and OOCL (USA), Inc., a position that he held for more than a decade. In the 1980s, Conrad served as a founder of American Hawaii Cruises. In the 1990s, Conrad served as Chairman of Cho Yang Line (USA), Inc. Conrad retired in 1998. An adamant defender of the US Merchant Marine, Conrad was a much sought-after speaker on maritime subjects for both his knowledge and his humor. Conrad Everhard epitomized a generation of transportation leaders who were deeply concerned about the US Merchant Marine, the necessity of fair play in maritime transportation, the maintenance of stability in management/labor relations in that industry, and the role of the US in international commerce. His leadership and his humor will be sorely missed.

DRISCOLL--Timothy Brien, Esq.,died on March 1st, 2014. Born on January 4th, 1943 in Brooklyn to Timothy Driscoll of Crosshaven, Co. Cork and Mary Driscoll (nee O'Brien) of Dungarvan, Co. Waterford, he graduated from Mt. St. Alphonsus Redemptorist Seminary as President, Student Body, 1965. He served with the 39th Combat Engineers in Chu Lai, Vietnam (1967-68). Upon his return he received a Master's Degree in Sociology from St. John's University. In 1976 Governor Carey appointed him Liaison to Veterans- the first Vietnam Veteran to hold the position. Determined to practice law, he returned to school and graduated from Fordham University Law School in 1984 at the age of 41. A popular lecturer at Brooklyn's NYCTC for forty years, he co-authored An Album (History) of Irish Americans. Tim co-founded the Bay Ridge Branch of the Irish Immigration Reform Movement and the American Committee for Ulster Justice. In 2012 he received the Frank T. Carvill Distinguished Service Award from the County Cork Association. He is survived by his wife, Hilda Lam and her family, his sister Isabelle Murray, brother in law Jim, nieces and nephews Peggy, Barry, Jimmy, Shelley, Shaun, Lynn and grand nephews Kevin, Tim, Calum, and Finn and extended family. Services will be held at M.V.Cosgrove & Son Chapels, 5723-5th Ave on Thursday from 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday at 9:30am at the Basilica of Our Lady of Perpetual Help. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

You were a man who gave of yourself to others. You were an inspired leader. We are all the wiser and better human beings for having known you. We will never forget you. GRATE--Jerrol Kenneth, passed away peacefully on March 1, 2014, at New York Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia University Medical Center in New York City. Mr. Grate was born in Washington, D.C. on December 26, 1948 to Anna Hoeffler and the late Robert Hamberg. He was a business owner who attended Boston College. Mr. Grate is survived by his loving wife, E. Denise Perry Grate of New York City, his mother Anna Hoeffler and many other relatives and devoted friends across the nation. The Grate family wishes to express our deep appreciation for all of the assistance, guidance and love shared with us during this time. The wake for Mr. Grate will be held Tuesday, March 4, 2014, 6:00pm to 9:00pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue in Manhattan. The funeral celebration will be held Wednesday, March 5, 2014, 11:00am at Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 Odell Clark Place, also in Manhattan. Mr. Grate was a dedicated patron of the arts and a passionate supporter of The Millennium Dance Company, the Harlem based, nonprofit dance center devoted to providing free classical training for those in need and a feeder school for major professional dance companies around the country since 1994. The Grate family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to The Millennium Dance Company, www.themillenniumdancecompany.com, in memory of Jerrol Kenneth Grate.

GOLDMAN--Hon. Richard J.,a former Justice on the New York State Supreme Court in Kings County, died peacefully on February 27, 2014, in Brooklyn, New York at the age of 87. Over his lifetime, he dedicated his time and energy to serving in distinguished positions at legal, civic, and military institutions. A graduate of Long Island University and Brooklyn Law School, at the start his legal career, he joined the Corporation Counsel of New York City, working on some of the earliest, pioneering investigative reports on New York's services. He was later elected as a Justice of the New York City Civil Court, and, after years of distinguished service, he was appointed a Justice for the New York State Supreme Court, where he presided over criminal-court cases in Brooklyn for nearly three decades. As a young man prior to World War II, he enlisted in the US Army, and served in military intelligence at some of the most prestigious U.S. military-intelligence centers for over three decades, eventually retiring highly decorated at the rank of Major. He served many years in the US Army Reserves, teaching military intelligence at Fort Meade and the Coronado Naval Base. Later in his life, he served as a Brig. Gen. in the New York State Guard. As a young man in Brooklyn, he worked for his father's brother-in-law, Abe Stark, former Brooklyn Borough President and New York City Council President, starting out in Abe Stark's legendary, New York men's clothing store, recognized widely by its sign in Ebbetts Field ("Hit sign, win suit") and many decades later served on the board of directors for Abe Stark Philanthropies. He also served on the board of directors for the Nephrology Foundation of Brooklyn. He is survived by his beloved wife, Lee, his son, Andrew and his fiancee Tasha Bengoechea, a daughter, Leslie, her husband, Carey and their sons Max and Spencer.

GARTLIR--Bernard. We note with sorrow the passing of our founding partner. For more than 60 years Bernie was a mentor and an inspiration to generations of HGG attorneys. He will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathy to his family. Everyone at Hofheimer Gartlir & Gross, LLP

GARTLIR--Bernard, 96, died peacefully on March 1st, in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Born in Brooklyn, formerly of Great Neck, NY, WWII veteran, practicing attorney for 70 years and a founding partner of Hofheimer Gartlir & Gross, graduate of Cornell University and Yale University Law School. He is survived by his beloved wife of 72 years, Shirley, children Lois and Kenneth, daughter-in-law June, eight nieces and nephews and dear friend Judy Spence. We treasure our memories and feel privileged to have had this spirited man with a kind heart in our lives. A bright light has gone out.

BERGER--Blanche R.,of Miami, FL., beloved wife of the late Dr. Paul F.Berger, mother of Roni Gershon, Dr. Robert "Bobby" Berger, Janice Berger-Landau, mother in law of Dr. Roger M Gershon, Linda Berger and Jeffrey Landau, sister of Sidney Sonenblum and late Carl Sonnett, grandmother of Carl-Adam, Andrew, Jeremy and Caleb. She was a matriarch and great story teller of the family legacy. For info: "Eden memorial" (201)947 3336.

PITT--David Emmett. February 19, 1947-February. 24, 2014. "If you're feeling fancy free/come wander through the world with me/and any place we chance to be/ will be a rendezvous. Two for the road/we'll travel down the years/collecting precious memories/selecting souvenirs/and living life the way we please. In summertime the sun will shine/in winter we'll drink summer wine/and any day that you are mine/will be a lovely day. As long as love still wears a smile/I know that we'll be two for the road, and that's a long long while."

LEE--George. George Lee, passed away in the loving care of his family Sunday, March 2nd, 2014 at age 96, just days following the death of his wife and life-long love Jane Love Lee. He is lovingly remembered by his son James Love Lee and daughter-in-law Cynthia Rosenbloom Lee; son Jeffrey Lee; nieces and nephew: Penny Levin; Dayle Elizabeth Cummings and husband Jack; and Gary Levin and wife Mary Anne; and his grand-nieces and grand-nephews: Cherie Florio; Jimmy Florio; Gina Daze and husband Rock; Mark Cummings and wife Marysol; Nicole Hisler and husband Pram, Michael Levin and wife Dana; and Rick Levin. Mr. Lee was predeceased by parents Anna Racher Levin and John Meyer Levin of New Haven, Connecticut, and brother Ralph Levin and wife Mary. Mr. Lee served as a sergeant in the 12th Air Force during World War II and was called upon to contribute his musical talents to boosting troop morale while serving overseas. He enjoyed a multi-faceted career in the music industry: as featured vocalist and guitarist with the Buddy Morris and Stan Kenton Orchestras; as production, recording, publishing, promotion, and artist discovery/relations executive for his own and other major music labels, including B.M.I., Zodiac, Palette, Decca, Capital, RCA Victor, Warner Brothers/7 Arts/Reprise, Chappell, Polygram, and MCA; as signer and producer of such notable artists as Sammy Davis Jr., Lena Horne, Joan Rivers, Peter Paul & Mary, Arlo Guthrie, Jimi Hendrix, Hall & Oates, B.J. Thomas, Antonio Carlos Jobim, and Morgana King; and as producer of original Broadway cast and film soundtrack recordings. He will be privately interred at his wife's side at Mount Hope Cemetery in Hastings-On-Hudson, New York, on Thursday, March 6th, 2014. Memorial donations can be made to Visiting Nurse Service of New York (VNSNY) Hospice and Palliative Care (1250 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10001, Attn: Stephanie Street).
MARSHALL--Robert Keith. Our pride, our joy, our hero. Mom, Dad, and Oakley

ORTENAU--Trude, born in Vienna, Austria, June 5, 1911, the daughter of Leopold and Margarete Teitelbaum. Her childhood was in Vienna where she and her parents resided at the same address with her Uncle Wilhelm Teitelbaum, Aunt Josephine and her beloved cousin Kurt. Austria and Vienna were the center of their universe. However, World War II changed everything. She and her mother found their way to Palestine while her father took refuge in the Shanghai Colony. They survived and resettled in Munich, however her cousin Kurt chose to take his family to America. Years later Trude would visit Kurt and his family on Long Island every summer. When travel was no longer possible, trips were taken to Munich, most recently for her 100th, 101st and 102nd birthdays. She died on March 1, 2014, with her only surviving relative Peter with her, in what turned out to be her last hours. Her long life was her victory over the tyranny of 1936-1945. With the lens of life upon her we ride on the shoulders of her history. Our love goes with her always as we honor her. Now thanks to the direct efforts of Rabbi Michel Gurkov of Wayne, NJ she will be buried with her mother in the Jewish Cemetery in Munich. May her memory always be a blessing. Debbie, Peter, Andrew, Lindsay, Harrison, Grant and Jordan Till

WISSNER--Aileen Hollander, of Great Neck, Manhattan and Sarasota on March 1, 2014. Her beloved husband, Irwin, died in 1993. She is survived by her sister, Beth Holland, and her daughters, Loren Wissner Greene, Elizabeth Wissner-Gross and Dana Wissner-Levy and their respective husbands Norman, Sigmund and Yosef. Grandchildren and their spouses are Alison and Peter Chillemi, Rebecca Greene, Zach Wissner-Gross, Alex Wissner-Gross, Tim Sullivan, Yael Wissner-Levy, Omer Briller, Talia Wissner-Levy, Ori Wissner-Levy, Netta Wissner-Levy; great-grandchildren Jennifer and Samantha Chillemi. An educational pioneer, Aileen Wissner is fondly remembered by many of the parents and teachers in Great Neck and celebrated by scores of students whom she taught in Great Neck's inter-age class, which she co-founded. Kisco, NY, Timothy Tostanoski (Maureen) of Danbury, CT, Katie Frosinini (Riccardo) of Florence, Italy, Jean Tostanoski (Edward Higham) of Armonk, NY, Nancy Tostanoski (Brian Hogan) of Scarsdale, NY, and Patty Tostanoski of Suffern, NY, her beloved grandchildren (13) and great-grandchildren (three), and her two brothers, Richard W. HABIB--Myron. Loved by many, died on March 3, 2014, age 83. Graveside service 2pm, Thursday, March 6, 2014 at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Myron was delicious and will be sorely missed by his friends and family.

TURKEN--Marvin, 85, died peacefully on March 2nd of Parkinson's Disease after a long courageous battle. Leaves loving wife Rosalyn; children Sheila (Christopher) and son Arthur; grandchildren Diana and Edward. Brother Jerry (Hanna); nieces and nephews Greta, Jason and Joel and Jessica, and other loving family and friends who cared deeply for him. He was a unique, funny and brilliant mensch. PAUL--Jeanne Kahn, 95, of Brooklyn, NY on February 28. Loved by children, Elizabeth Larsen, Andrew, Jay and Jane Paul, and family.

BAUER--Mrs. Carolyn on March 3, 2014. Our beautiful, brilliant, beloved mother Carolyn. Her life was a celebration of everything that is beautiful in the world. A passionate educator, she was an inspiration and an advocate for the hundreds of children whom she taught and whose lives she improved. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend; Carolyn was predeceased by her beloved husband Dr. Stanley Bauer. She is survived by children Katie Karkus and Darryl Seavey; Suzanne Karkus; Ted and Lynn Karkus; and Leslie Karkus; by grandchildren Jason, Brett, Melanie, and Jack and by step children Barbara and Len Gray, Susan and Seth Schwinger and Davida and David Zimble and their children Ben and Annie, Tara, and Eli, Asher, Jacob and Ezra. Service Wednesday, March 5, 2014, 1pm, "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

ALMY--William III. 85, Bronxville, NY, February 27. Adored by Alyce (Bunny) Micolino Almy. Visitation - March 7, 2-4, 6-8. McGrath's (20 Cedar Street, Bronxville). Service: March 8 at 11am, Reformed Church (180 Pondfield Road, Bronxville).

BERGER--Blanche R.,of Miami, FL., beloved wife of the late Dr. Paul F.Berger, mother of Roni Gershon, Dr. Robert "Bobby" Berger, Janice Berger-Landau, mother in law of Dr. Roger M Gershon, Linda Berger and Jeffrey Landau, sister of Sidney Sonenblum and late Carl Sonnett, grandmother of Carl-Adam, Andrew, Jeremy and Caleb. BOWMAN--Ken. Denver artist. Born in 1937, died on February 16, 2014. He was a member of the original "Rhino Horn" new humanism group. His work was shown at Tibor de Nagy Gallery and is in many private and corporate collections. His widow, Connie Bowman, is handling his estate. You may reach her at kcbow@comcast.net.

BRONSTON--Adele S.,on March 3, 2014. She lived her life with humor, courage, conviction and deep love for her family and friends. Public service, education, philanthropy and world travel were among her passions. We love you Mom. Funeral services on Thursday, March 6, 10am at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

EBERSTADT--Walter A. The Board of Directors, staff, families of Northside Center for Child Development mourn the passing of Mr. Eberstadt who was the President of the Board of Directors and served on the board and Council of Advisors for over 40 years. Mr. Eberstadt worked closely with the legendary Drs. Mamie and Kenneth Clark. Walter noted in his book "Where We Came, Where We Went" that to be on Northside's board was a labor of love. Walter knew the devastating consequences of discrimination and devoted himself to Northside's mission of ensuring that children and families have equal opportunities to succeed. We are deeply grateful for his many years of unwavering commitment and generous support. Our deepest condolences to his family. Thelma Dye, Ph.D., CEO, Michael Goldstein, Board Chair, Susan Patricof, Board President.
