Grandchildren and their spouses are Alison and Peter Chillemi, Rebecca Greene, Zach Wissner-Gross, Alex Wissner-Gross, Tim Sullivan, Yael Wissner-Levy, Omer Briller, Talia Wissner-Levy, Ori Wissner-Levy, Netta Wissner-Levy; great-grandchildren Jennifer and Samantha Chillemi. An educational pioneer, Aileen Wissner is fondly remembered by many of the parents and teachers in Great Neck and celebrated by scores of students whom she taught in Great Neck's inter-age class, which she co-founded. She was with her companion, Arthur Nusbaum, in Sarasota at the time of her death. Funeral: 10:30am Wednesday March 5, at Nassau Riverside Chapel 55 N. Station Plaza in Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Anti-Defamation League (adl.org), Emily's List (emilyslist.org), Nature Conservancy (nature.org), Student Conservation Association (thesca.org).
McGUIRE--Muriel Margaret. Happy Birthday Mom. Time can not erase the loss of you. Love, Sissy
MARSHALL--Robert Keith. Our pride, our joy, our hero. Mom, Dad, and Oakley

BERGER--David. The Yeshiva University family mourns the recent passing of David Berger of blessed memory, a highly respected member of the Jewish community who with his beloved wife, Honey Berger, was a Yeshiva University Guardian. They established scholarships in their names for deserving students at Yeshiva College, Stern College for Women and the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. May his cherished wife, Honey, be blessed with renewed strength and vigor and may she and their loved ones find comfort among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

CARSON--Dr. Joan, beloved Professor Emerita of The College of New Rochelle, died on March 4, 2014. A memorial service in her honor will be held at a later date. Donations in her memory can be made to The College of New Rochelle, 29 Castle Place, New Rochelle, NY 10805. www.lloydmaxcy.com

WINOGRAD--Bernard. 63, businessman, United States Treasury Department official and philanthropist, died Saturday, March 1. Mr. Winograd started his career in 1977 as executive assistant to W. Michael Blumenthal during Mr. Blumenthal's term as Secretary of the U.S. Treasury. He then moved on to Bendix Corporation where he held positions as director of Public Affairs and Treasurer. From 1983 to 1992, he was President of Taubman Investment Company, and from 1992 to 1996, Mr. Winograd served as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Taubman Centers. In that position, he was a key architect of Taubman's 1992 initial public offering. The transaction represented the first umbrella partnership real estate investment trust IPO, which set the stage for the dramatic increase in the capitalization of the real estate investment trust industry. Mr. Winograd joined Prudential Financial, Inc., which is headquartered in Newark, NJ, in 1996 as chief executive officer of Prudential Real Estate Investors. In 2000, he was named senior managing director of Prudential Private Investments, then president and chief executive officer of Prudential Investment Management in 2002. Mr. Winograd was appointed executive vice president and chief operating officer of all of Prudential's United States businesses in January 2008. He retired from Prudential on February 11, 2011. At the time, he expressed his desire to focus his energies on the many social issues, philanthropic causes and personal activities to which he was committed. Also, following his retirement, he was named to the Board of Cohen and Steers. Prudential's Chairman and CEO John Strangfeld said: "Bernard's sharp mind and legendary wit will be missed by the many people at Prudential who were privileged to call him a friend and colleague. We will also miss his valued counsel and his unfailing focus and vision. But what I will miss most is his friendship. Bernard's many years of dedicated leadership helped to build Prudential into the financial services company it is today. With his passing we have lost a truly remarkable person." Mr. Winograd held a Bachelor of Arts degree in social sciences from the University of Chicago and was a member of the University of Chicago's Visiting Committee on College and Student Activities. He also served on the board of Local Initiative Support Corporation (LISC), a community development financing organization. Mr. Winograd met his wife, Carol, almost 40 years ago when he was working for the Michigan Democratic Party. Mrs. Winograd was Communications Director of the party at the time. They have two children, Simon and Christina. In addition to his wife and children, Bernard is survived by his brother, Morley Winograd. Funeral services will be held at 3:30pm on Thursday, March 13, at the Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., New York, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or to your religious organization of choice.

McKENZIE--Evelyn Miller, 87, March 5, 2014, of Manhattan, NY. She was born in Great Neck, New York. She married the late Neil Wintringham in 1946 and is survived by four children from that marriage: Nina, Karen, and Drew Wintringham and Jill Wintringham Kennedy. She married the late Arthur McKenzie in 1968 and became the mother of Leslie and Douglas McKenzie and late son Craig McKenzie. She is survived by 15 grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. Evelyn graduated from Cornell University and did post-graduate studies at Keene College, Columbia University, and NYU. She was a respected educational therapist who specialized in the analysis and treatment of learning disabilities. She worked for the Mountainside, NJ public school system and the Gateway School in Manhattan before going into private practice. The Gateway School building was named in her honor in 2001 through a generous donation from the Devlin Family Foundation. Friends may call on Friday, March 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NY with a service being held there on Saturday, March 8 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Gateway School or The Mary Manning Walsh Home.

PITT--David Emmett. February 19, 1947-February. 24, 2014. "If you're feeling fancy free/come wander through the world with me/and any place we chance to be/ will be a rendezvous. Two for the road/we'll travel down the years/collecting precious memories/selecting souvenirs/and living life the way we please. In summertime the sun will shine/in winter we'll drink summer wine/and any day that you are mine/will be a lovely day. As long as love still wears a smile/I know that we'll be two for the road, and that's a long long while."

STANLEY--Robert, a resident of Armonk, NY passed away on March 2nd, 2014 at Northern Westchester Hospital after a brief illness. Born May 4, 1931 to Olga Zylick Stanley and Joseph Stanley in Mt. Vernon, NY, he was brought up in the Russian Orthodox faith of his mother. After graduating from Roosevelt High School in Yonkers, he attended New York University where he was an active member of the Glee Club, Chapel Choir, and AROTC. Throughout college, he was a head lifeguard, competitive swimmer and diver, and an avid skier. From 1953 to 1955 he served as a military police officer in Fort Dix, NJ, and then later as a court interpreter in Wurzburg and Schweinfurt, Germany. Upon his discharge from the military, he attended Columbia University (Teacher's College), where he earned graduate degrees in German, French, Guidance and Secondary School Administration. His first teaching position was in John Adams High School in New York City, and then worked the next nine years teaching French, German, Russian and English at White Plains High School. During this time, he was awarded scholarships to study in Germany, France and Quebec, Canada. In 1960 he was selected to be a group leader taking students to Minden, Germany for the Experiment in International Living. He also served as a part-time swimming and diving coach, as well as the leader of the school ski club. In 1966, he married Doris Dunker of Herford, Germany, after meeting through a mutual friend on her first day in the United States. For the next thirty years he was a full-time guidance counselor at the school, while also working for fifteen years as an adjunct professor of foreign languages at Westchester Community College. Five years of this time, he also taught a course in scientific and conversational German for the Ciby-Geigy Corporation in Ardsley, NY. He was the founder and the president of Stanley Translations, a document translation company, and also wrote and published "Mr. Stanley's Guide to Better Scholarships". After retiring from White Plains High School in 1996, he became a teacher of English to the Foreign Born at the White Plains Adult Education School. He also taught French for two years at the Keio Academy in Purchase, NY. He spent two years researching a book on his family history, including his maternal side dating back to 1785 in the Carpathian Mountains, and his paternal side in Rochdale, England. He also greatly enjoyed classical music. For over twenty years, he was very involved in working with and being an advocate for the autistic and disabled populations. He is survived by his wife Doris, and his two sons, Robert Dirk Stanley, MD, and Marc Thomas Stanley, who is autistic. Private memorial services will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Abbott House, Director of Autistic Services, 110 North Broadway, Irvington, NY 10533 or to: Westchester Association for Retarded Citizens, 265 Saw Mill River Road, Hawthorne, NY 10523.

OZER--Jerome S. Ph.D, of Englewood, NJ, husband of the late Harriet Ozer, survived by sons Joseph and Ira, daughters Carol and Alyzza, grandchildren Max, Samantha, Rebecca, Evan and sweetheart Ann Moscovitz. Jerry was a brilliant and caring man who was loved by everyone who knew him. Funeral Sunday for info "Eden Memorial" (201) 947 3336.

TIGHE--Joseph M. 76 of Darien, CT, died Sunday, March 2. Born June 9, 1937 in Yonkers, NY, Joe raised six children in NY/CT with his wife, Elaine, of 51 years. An Iona College basketball player, Goal Club founder, Hall of Fame inductee and Continental League football player. He held key management positions at RJR Nabisco, Heublein and Guinness. Upon retirement, Joe was a successful entrepreneur in the beverage industry. Winged Foot Golf Club was his home away from home. Joe is survived by his wife Elaine and children Julie Carrabino (Joe), Jill Kelly (Joe), Joe Tighe, Jr (Sabrina), Joy Cummiskey (James), Jayne Jepsen (Christian), Jeana Roche (Kevin) and 20 grandchildren. He cherished family and friends above all and will be forever in our hearts. Services: Gallagher Funeral Home, Greenwich, CT, Thursday March 6th 6-8pm, Friday March 7th 2-4pm and 6-8pm; Mass at the Church of St. Augustine, Larchmont, NY, on Saturday March 8th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Joe Tighe Memorial Basketball Scholarship Fund at Iona College.

MULLARKEY--Michael J. The Electronics Analysts Group thanks God for the friendship of the marvelous investment analyst and modest friend, Michael Mullarkey, no longer with us. He endures in our prayers. Jim Magid, President, EAG

RIKLIN--Bernard. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved longtime member Dr. Bernard Riklin. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest sympathy to his sons Jeff and Matthew, and the entire family. Fredric C. Apter, President Bryna Sweedler, Secretary

LEE--George. George Lee, passed away in the loving care of his family Sunday, March 2nd, 2014 at age 96, just days following the death of his wife and life-long love Jane Love Lee. He is lovingly remembered by his son James Love Lee and daughter-in-law Cynthia Rosenbloom Lee; son Jeffrey Lee; nieces and nephew: Penny Levin; Dayle Elizabeth Cummings and husband Jack; and Gary Levin and wife Mary Anne; and his grand-nieces and grand-nephews: Cherie Florio; Jimmy Florio; Gina Daze and husband Rock; Mark Cummings and wife Marysol; Nicole Hisler and husband Pram, Michael Levin and wife Dana; and Rick Levin. Mr. Lee was predeceased by parents Anna Racher Levin and John Meyer Levin of New Haven, Connecticut, and brother Ralph Levin and wife Mary. Mr. Lee served as a sergeant in the 12th Air Force during World War II and was called upon to contribute his musical talents to boosting troop morale while serving overseas. He enjoyed a multi-faceted career in the music industry: as featured vocalist and guitarist with the Buddy Morris and Stan Kenton Orchestras; as production, recording, publishing, promotion, and artist discovery/relations executive for his own and other major music labels, including B.M.I., Zodiac, Palette, Decca, Capital, RCA Victor, Warner Brothers/7 Arts/Reprise, Chappell, Polygram, and MCA; as signer and producer of such notable artists as Sammy Davis Jr., Lena Horne, Joan Rivers, Peter Paul & Mary, Arlo Guthrie, Jimi Hendrix, Hall & Oates, B.J. Thomas, Antonio Carlos Jobim, and Morgana King; and as producer of original Broadway cast and film soundtrack recordings. He will be privately interred at his wife's side at Mount Hope Cemetery in Hastings-On-Hudson, New York, on Thursday, March 6th, 2014. Memorial donations can be made to Visiting Nurse Service of New York (VNSNY) Hospice and Palliative Care (1250 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10001, Attn: Stephanie Street).

McGORRY--Brian M. Died of a heart attack while sleeping in his home in Brooklyn Heights on February 27, 2014, at age 64. Born into the extended Bayside, Queens McGorry "Clan," Brian was a lifelong resident, builder, and protector of the people, communities and environments of New York City. Above all, Brian was dedicated to the stewardship, nurturing, and selfless caring for his immediate family, his extended family, his friends and neighbors of all walks of life, which were ever expanding. Always the man behind the scenes, turning conflict into resolution and pragmatically knowing and doing what had to be done to make the best outcome for all. He leaves for us all a great hole in the universe. Brian was a dedicated member of the Brooklyn Heights community for decades. He worked to create Brooklyn Bridge Park, both as a neighborhood activist and as a founding member and operating officer of the Brooklyn Bridge Park Conservancy. The park and its success was a continuing source of pride and joy to him. An active member of the Board of Governors of The Brooklyn Heights Association (BHA) for many years, Brian was also a member of the Grace Church School Board. Brian is survived by "his bride" of twenty seven years, Kathy Marshall, his adored sixteen-year-old twin daughters Ella and Kate, his brother Mark, sister-in-law Lana, his sister Lenore (who predeceased him), and his bountiful clan of cherished nieces, nephews, cousins, aunt, and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to debra of America at debra.org. A "Celebration of Brian's Life" will be held Saturday, March 8, 2014.

RIKLIN--Bernard, 92, of Greenwich, CT, died peacefully on March 4th. Devoted husband and golf partner to his loving wife of 66 years Marilyn, who recently predeceased him. Loving mother to Jeff, Matthew and Scott, who predeceased him. Father-in-law to Liz, grandmother to Leah, Eric and Allison. Brother to Stanley and Harold, who predeceased him. Bernard practiced dentistry for over 50 years, and taught dentistry at Columbia for over 25 years. He was a strong advocate for social justice and was the founding President of Rye B'nai Brith. Funeral on March 7th at 12:30pm at Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave, Rye. The family will receive visitors at home on Friday 3-6pm and Saturday 12-3pm. Contributions may be sent to www.COMSYNRYE.org.

BRONSTON--Adele S.,on March 3, 2014. She lived her life with humor, courage, conviction and deep love for her family and friends. Public service, education, philanthropy and world travel were among her passions. We love you Mom. Funeral services on Thursday, March 6, 10am at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

CARR--Joel Louis, died February 27, 2014 in Salem, MA at the age of 86. Born in New York City, he was a graduate of McBurney High School, Williams College, Yale Law School and Harvard Business School. A corporate attorney by profession, he practiced law at Dewey Ballantine, Atlantic Refining, Levitt & Sons, and Patterson, Belknap, Webb and Tyler. Mr. Carr taught law at Hofstra University and later became a Court Examiner for the State Supreme Court in Queens, NY. A resident of Garden City, NY for 47 years, Mr. Carr spent many summers throughout his life on Fire Island and was the Mayor of Saltaire, NY for several terms. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Dorothy, a daughter Kathy, two sons Jay and Brooks, and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Williams College Alumni Fund, 75 Park St, Williamstown, MA 01267.

HEISEL--Marsel Alazraki. Died peacefully at home on March 2, 2014. She was born in Istanbul, Turkey in 1929. She attended Robert College and the Turkish National University, both in Istanbul. She continued her higher education at the Universities of Chicago, and then Wisconsin. She completed her PhD at Rutgers University, where she served as a member of the faculty of the Graduate School of Social Work. She was a dedicated teacher and research scholar. Survivors include Donald, her husband of 58 years; her daughter Sylvia and her son-in-law Scott; and her sister Rasel. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Any contribution in her memory should be to the Central Park Conservancy.

KASKAWITS--May Shlom, passed away on Wednesday, March 5. She was born on February 23, 1928, in Bronx, New York, to Fannie and Nathan Karp. She was a loving wife to Albert Shlom and Irwin Kaskawits, and brother Leonard Karp, who predeceased her. She is survived by her children Donna and Larry Dunkelman, Karen and Vic Hansen, and Howard and Elizabeth Shlom, her adoring grandchildren, David, Josh, Rachel, and their spouses, Seth, Alison, and Evan and great granddaughter, Lacey Brooke. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Kol Ami, Chapel in the Woods, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, N.Y. on Thursday, March 6 at 10:30am. Burial will follow the services at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y.

WEISBURGH--Frankie. The Board of Governors and members of Rockrimmon Country Club are profoundly saddened by the passing of their beloved friend and esteemed member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Lonny Weisburgh and all members of the Weisburgh Family. Robert J. Bluestone, President

ADLER--Bill, 84, February 28. Partner in life and work to Gloria. Loving father of Diane and Bill, grandfather to Karen, Madeleine, Claire, Amanda. Literary agent, book packager, bestselling author. A singular individual, he will be missed. Service at Plaza Jewish, 630 Amsterdam Ave, March 7, 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations to Carl Schurz Conservancy: www.carlschurzparknyc.org

ALMY--William III. 85, Bronxville, NY, February 27. Adored by Alyce (Bunny) Micolino Almy. Visitation - March 7, 2-4, 6-8. McGrath's (20 Cedar Street, Bronxville). Service: March 8 at 11am, Reformed Church (180 Pondfield Road, Bronxville).

ROBERTS--Patte Bogen. Born March 12, 1919, died March 6, 2014. Just shy of her 95th Birthday. Shy would not be an adjective anyone who knew Patte would use to describe her. She loved being the center of attention, telling anyone who would listen her off colored jokes. Patte was a past President of National Council of Jewish Women and board member of Peninsula General Hospital in Far Rockaway, NY. She was a supporter of Hebrew University in Israel. Her beloved husband Harold predeceased her, as well as her brother Irwin Bogen. She will be missed by her children Eric (Jane), Joan (Greg) and Jayne. Her granddaughters Alison (Ted), Amanda (Rob) and Jennifer (David) and six great-grandchildren Zoe, Lexxie, Elias, Layla, Dylan and Blake. Funeral services will be private. Contributions in Patte's memory to the charity of your choice.

McKENZIE--Evelyn Miller. The Gateway Schools community mourns the loss of one of its former teachers, Evelyn Miller McKenzie. Ms. McKenzie dedicated her career to educating children with learning disabilities and inspired a generation of special educators. After several years at Gateway, Ms. McKenzie established a private practice that reflected our schools' desire to truly understand each student as a learner and our confidence in a student's ability to overcome his challenges. In 2002, we recognized Ms. McKenzie by naming our schoolhouse at 236 Second Avenue in her honor and endowing The Evelyn McKenzie Scholarship Fund. A friend and colleague, we will miss Ms. McKenzie. Our deepest condolences go out to her family and friends. Carolyn Salzman Head of School The Gateway School

KELLEY--Marc Watson, Fort McCoy, FL, passed away March 4, 2014 after a long battle with cancer. He was 64 years old. Born in Greenwich, CT. Son of the late Augustus W. Kelley III and Elizabeth (Watson) Kelley. Marc earned his B.S. from Antioch College and his M.S. from Columbia University. In 1979 Marc started the non-profit Corporation Greystone, Inc., the first community-based provider for individuals with autism in New York State. During his 20 years as CEO, Greystone grew to serve over 300 children and adults with autism, traumatic brain injury and other disabilities in New York. He also helped launch the Autism Directory Service, Inc, and served on the Board for five years. Marc was also on the Board of Directors of Watson Industries, in Pittsburgh, PA for 20 years and managing Director of DeNoon and Co, LLC, a commercial real estate venture in Florida. He was a member of the Carriage Association of America, and the St. Petersburg Yacht Club. He is survived by his partner, Dawayne Wade Smith, his sister, Corrine Kelley Wagner; nieces, Helen Wagner and Elizabeth Gilmartin; nephews Drew Wagner and Benjamin Gilmartin and wife, Denise Ng Gilmartin; great-nieces Alexis and Tess Gilmartin, and his brothers-in-law; Robert Wagner and Peter Gilmartin; loyal pets; and many dear friends. Marc is predeceased by his sister, Christina Kelley Gilmartin, Ph.D. Celebration of Life services will be held at the Mount Auburn Story Chapel, 580 Mount Auburn Street, Cambridge, MA www.mountauburn.org on Saturday, March 8 at 11:31am and at The Farm at Lambeth Ground, Ft McCoy, FL on Saturday, March 15th at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to The Greystone Endowment, Inc, 36 Violet Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601. www.greystoneprograms.org or the Humane Society of Marion County, 701 NW 14th Rd, Ocala, FL 34475. On line guest book at: www.brownandhickey.com

TIGHE--Joseph M. 76 of Darien, CT, died Sunday, March 2. Born June 9, 1937 in Yonkers, NY, Joe raised six children in NY/CT with his wife, Elaine, of 51 years. An Iona College basketball player, Goal Club founder, Hall of Fame inductee and Continental League football player. He held key management positions at RJR Nabisco, Heublein and Guinness. Upon retirement, Joe was a successful entrepreneur in the beverage industry. Winged Foot Golf Club was his home away from home. Joe is survived by his wife Elaine and children Julie Carrabino (Joe), Jill Kelly (Joe), Joe Tighe, Jr (Sabrina), Joy Cummiskey (James), Jayne Jepsen (Christian), Jeana Roche (Kevin) and 20 grandchildren. He cherished family and friends above all and will be forever in our hearts. Services: Gallagher Funeral Home, Greenwich, CT, Thursday March 6th 6-8pm, Friday March 7th 2-4pm and 6-8pm; Mass at the Church of St. Augustine, Larchmont, NY, on Saturday March 8th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Joe Tighe Memorial Basketball Scholarship Fund at Iona College.

KRAMER--Myrna Mae, of Plainview, NY died on Thursday, March 6, 2014 at North Shore Hospital in Great Neck, NY. She was 77 years old. She was born on February 14, 1937 in New York, NY. She graduated from Bridgeport University in 1959 and later got a Masters Degree in Education from St. Johns University. She had a 35 year career teaching elementary school in the New York City School districts. She primarily taught in Woodhaven, Queens and specialized in grades 3-4 and focused on reading and writing proficiency. She was loved by students, parents and administrators. Education was her passion and she firmly believed that it was the springboard to future advancement for children of all backgrounds. Myrna was married to Richard Kramer for 32 years before he passed away in 1995. She is survived by her twin sons Robert and Scott Kramer, daughter-in-law Susan Kramer, grandchildren Jack, Kyle, Bailey and Kayla and her brother Ira Klosk, sister-in-law Doris and nieces and nephews, Steven and Rena Klosk, Craig and Tricia Klosk, Gary Klosk, and Craig and Shari Geller. Myrna's true love was her large family which included the children of her nieces and nephews. She combined her love of her grandchildren and learning by participating in inter-generational trips. Myrna was a "people person" and was blessed with many life long friends who survive her including Doris and Mike Flax, Jan and Charlie Honig, Joan and Jerry Kimmelman, Barbara Klein, Janet Kornhauser, Mary Lou and Leonard Kresch, and new relationships that were created in her retirement years in her community with the "funny ladies". Since her retirement in 1999, Myrna has traveled extensively including safari in Africa, Russia, Israel, Vietnam, Europe, the South Pacific, the Galapagos and Machu Picchu. The funeral is being held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 W. 76th Street New York, NY on Friday at 12:00pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Liberty Park Elementary (for- student enrichment). Mailing address Liberty Park Elementary, 6601 Constitution Way, Greenacres, FL 33413.

WEISER--Louis. Died peacefully at age 95 on March 3rd. Anita, his adored wife of 69 years passed away in 2013. A lifelong civil servant and advocate, Louis became an NYPD Patrolman in 1941, retired as Lieutenant in 1965 and served as Deputy Commissioner Department of Investigations. He was President of both NYPD and National Shomrim Societies and The Council of Jewish Organizations in Civil Service. He is survived by his proudest achievements: daughters Bobbi Stanley (Alan) and Ronnie Pinkowitz (David) and grandchildren Jeff Newelt (Erica), Marc Newelt (Stacy), and Jason and Marisa Mendelson. A true people person, his tenacious leadership, ubiquitous helping hand and Borscht Belt humor uplifted many and will never be forgotten.
MINDLIN--Michael. 3/11/23-3/7/04. Gone 10 years; greatly missed and forever loved. Freda

WIGDER--Ben, 94, on March 5, 2014. Holocaust survivor. Longtime owner of the Royale Bakery on West 72nd Street. Also survived by his brother Israel, and several nieces and nephews. Service: Friday, March 7, 2014, 11:15am, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

RIKLIN--Bernard, 92, of Greenwich, CT, died peacefully on March 4th. Devoted husband and golf partner to his loving wife of 66 years Marilyn, who recently predeceased him. Loving mother to Jeff, Matthew and Scott, who predeceased him. Father-in-law to Liz, grandmother to Leah, Eric and Allison. Brother to Stanley and Harold, who predeceased him. Bernard practiced dentistry for over 50 years, and taught dentistry at Columbia for over 25 years. He was a strong advocate for social justice and was the founding President of Rye B'nai Brith. Funeral on March 7th at 12:30pm at Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave, Rye. The family will receive visitors at home on Friday 3-6pm and Saturday 12-3pm. Contributions may be sent to www.COMSYNRYE.org.

BEIL--Sheldon. It is now 6 years since you are gone. You are thought of often by our family and friends, still asking for your pickled herring. I think of you every day and miss hearing you say "Did I tell you today that I love you". Your Loving Wife, Ruthie

O'SULLIVAN--Mary Ellen, 77, of Bronxville, New York passed away peacefully on March 6th, 2014. She is survived by her brother, Jack Baker and his wife Babs, her daughter, Maura O'Sullivan, and her granddaughter, Siobhan D'Angelo. She was born to William and Catherine Baker on April 30th, 1936 in Manhattan. She received a B.A. in English from the College of Mount St. Vincent in 1958 and pursued a master's degree in English at Hunter College. She was very active in her community, volunteering her time to many organizations such as Meals on Wheels and Pregnancy Care Center. Calling hours will be held at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville, on Monday, March 10th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made in her name to The Ursuline School or Pregnancy Care Center.

WINOGRAD--Bernard. The Local Initiatives Support Corp. mourns the death of our respected board member, Bernard Winograd. Since 2008, he offered invaluable service and demonstrated a commitment to the low-income communities that we serve across the country. We extend our sympathy to his family and remain forever grateful both for his wisdom and friendship. Robert Rubin, Chair, LISC Board of Directors Michael Rubinger, CEO and President, LISC

SCHEINER--Irving, 91, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away on Thursday, March 6, 2014. Please visit www.glickfamily funeralhome.com for more information.

KAISH--Luise Clayborn , died in New York City on March 7, 2013. A sculptor of soaring ambition and achievement and a painter of gem-like abstractions, she leaves a remarkable legacy. Luise was among the first women to receive the American Academy in Rome Prize. A Guggenheim Fellow, a recipient of a Louise Comfort Tiffany Grant, she was awarded the Arents Pioneer Medal, her alma mater's highest honor. She received her BFA magnum cum laude and MFA from Syracuse University, where she studied with the renowned sculptor Ivan Mestrovic, and as a graduate student, created her first large commissioned work, The Saltine Warrior, which stands on the campus today. Her work is included in the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the Whitney Museum of American Art; the Smithsonian Institution; the Jewish Museum; the Hood Museum, Dartmouth College; the Rochester Memorial Art Gallery; the National Academy Museum. Among her numerous commissions were the massive bronze "Ark of Revelations" for Temple B'rith Kodesh with architect Pietro Belluschi; "La Lumiere", Continental Grain Co. NYC; "Christ in Glory", Holy Trinity Mission Seminary, MD; "Wall of Martyrs", Temple Beth El, New Rochelle, NY; and the bronze Ark for Temple Beth Shalom, Wilmington, DE. She was Professor Emerita of Columbia University, where she Chaired the Division of Painting and Sculpture. She was the first woman Artist-in-Residence at Dartmouth College, the University of Hiafa, Israel, and the University of Washington, Seattle. She served as guest lecturer, critic, and panelist at numerous institutions and conferences. Luise was a Trustee Emerita of the American Academy in Rome, served on the Augustus-St. Gaudens Memorial, National Park Service, the board of the Sculptors Guild, and the New York City Fine Arts Commission. Luise Kaish lived and worked in New York City. Ever creative, it was her wish that her ashes travel into space. http://celestis.com/memorial/ sunjammer/ kaish.asp
DISICK--Ellis R. Your smile, your humor, your love and guidance are in our hearts forever. Laurie, Grant, Tia, Evan, Ritu and our little boys Noah, Sam, Brody and Ellis

EVERHARD--Coenraad. Age 83, passed away on February 25, 2014, at his California retirement home after a brief battle with cancer. One of the iconic leaders and characters of the maritime industry during the last half of the 20th century, Conrad, or Connie, as he was known to his many friends in the industry and elsewhere, is survived by Yolanda, his devoted wife of 58 years, and by his three children. Born in 1930 in Holland, he witnessed first-hand the horrors of the Nazi invasion. He came to the US in the 1950s and graduated from Georgetown's School of Foreign Service. He then started his long and distinguished career in the maritime industry, first with United States Lines and then with the Massachusetts Port Authority where he served as Director General for Europe and Africa for eight years in Brussels, Belgium. In 1973, Conrad became CEO of Dart Container Line and OOCL (USA), Inc., a position that he held for more than a decade. In the 1980s, Conrad served as a founder of American Hawaii Cruises. In the 1990s, Conrad served as Chairman of Cho Yang Line (USA), Inc. Conrad retired in 1998. An adamant defender of the US Merchant Marine, Conrad was a much sought-after speaker on maritime subjects for both his knowledge and his humor. Conrad Everhard epitomized a generation of transportation leaders who were deeply concerned about the US Merchant Marine, the necessity of fair play in maritime transportation, the maintenance of stability in management/labor relations in that industry, and the role of the US in international commerce. His leadership and his humor will be sorely missed.

HOFFERT--Constance. Died on March 6 in Lantana, FL. Born on December 5, 1920 in Portland, ME to Pauline and Samuel Dorfman, she graduated from Wellesley College in 1942 and married her adoring lifetime mate, Daniel, that same year. He predeceased her in 2010. She is survived by her loving daughter and son-in-law, Rebecca and Peter Rosow. Connie lived a long and full life, was loved by many, and was impressively resilient in times of adversity. A real lady and true beauty, she turned heads until the end. We will miss her greatly. Graveside service at Mount Sinai Cemetery, Portland, ME at 1pm on Sunday, March 9th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County.
EDWARDS--Harold G.,DDS. Beloved New York Orthodontist, Dr. Harold G Edwards, died January 15, 2014 at 64, in Miami. His wife, mother, kids, siblings and employees, wish him eternal peace.

REICE--Sylvie. Beloved wife of the late Albert Reice, mother of Milo, Naomi, Seth, Andrew and Richard, grandmother of David, Jennifer, Rebecca, Max, and Alexandra, died peacefully at her home shortly before her 95th birthday. Noted author, editor, and columnist.

ROBERTS--Patte Bogen. Born March 12, 1919, died March 6, 2014. Just shy of her 95th Birthday. Shy would not be an adjective anyone who knew Patte would use to describe her. She loved being the center of attention, telling anyone who would listen her off colored jokes. Patte was a past President of National Council of Jewish Women and board member of Peninsula General Hospital in Far Rockaway, NY. She was a supporter of Hebrew University in Israel. Her beloved husband Harold predeceased her, as well as her brother Irwin Bogen. She will be missed by her children Eric (Jane), Joan (Greg) and Jayne. Her granddaughters Alison (Ted), Amanda (Rob) and Jennifer (David) and six great-grandchildren Zoe, Lexxie, Elias, Layla, Dylan and Blake. Funeral services will be private. Contributions in Patte's memory to the charity of your choice.

ROHER--Daniel S. Daniel S. Roher, of White Plains, age 88, died March 5 after a period of declining health. Beloved husband of Florence (Rodkinson), with whom he shared 63 years. Devoted father to Deborah of New Bedford, MA, Richard of Chappaqua, and Torin of West Linn, OR. He is also survived by brothers Clarence (Cliff) of Pearl River and Robert (Bob) of the Bronx, daughters-in-law Susan and Lisa, grandchildren David and Natalie, many nieces and nephews, friends and proteges. After graduating from Baruch College in 1946, he worked as advertising manager for Channel Master Corp. in Ellenville, NY, then as campaign manager and administrative assistant to Congressman Joseph Y. Resnick, 1965-69. He then founded Roher Public Relations and served as its president until 1996. Avid traveler, lover of nature, patron of the visual and performing arts, and supporter of Jewish causes and of expanded opportunity for higher education. Services Sunday, 12:30pm at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, to be followed by burial at Old Montefiore Cemetery. Shiva will be observed at his late residence Sunday 6-9pm, Monday and Tuesday 1-4 and 6-9pm. For directions or to send online condolences, visit www.ballarddurand.com. The family requests that donations in his memory be made to the Florence and Daniel S. Roher Scholarship Fund of Baruch College, CUNY, 55 Lexington Avenue, New York 10010.

SHASHA--Violet, on March 3rd, 2014 at 92 years of age. Beloved mother of Vivienne Pero (Richard), Emil Shasha and Virginia Shasha Kaplan (Barry). Loving sister of David Shuker (Batia). Adoring grandmother of Janine Pero Mullen (Paul), Brent Pero (Alana), Blake Kaplan. Great grandmother of Zachary, Ryan and Savannah. She was born in Bagdad, Iraq, spoke multiple languages, traveled the world and lived many joyous years in Scarsdale before retiring to Florida. She was an accomplished pianist and loved the opera. Donations in her name to the American Cancer Society. Services 11:15 Sunday at "The Riverside" w. 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

FARBER--Gerald. March 5, 2014. Beloved husband, father, and grandfather. An Edisonian scientist who used his eclectic talents for the benefit of country, family, and friends. Respected by colleagues at Brookhaven Laboratory and missed by all.

GRINSTEIN--Stanley. November 26, 1927 March 2, 2014. Art patron and social activist, Stanley Grinstein passed away peacefully at home on Sunday, March 2nd surrounded by his family. Stanley not only impacted the art world but every person he encountered. He was deeply invested in politics and social advocacy. He believed in living every moment to the fullest and that life is as much of an adventure as you make of it. He wants to be remembered as someone who inspired others and enjoyed the party of life. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Elyse, three daughters, Ayn Grinstein, Ellen Grinstein Perliter (Chuck), and Nancy Grinstein (Neal Rabin), his sister Corinne Miller, and six grandchildren, Amanda, Alex, Willie, Joe, Tess, and Dia. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to: The Stanley Grinstein Memorial Fund benefiting the Cedars-Sinai Art Program Cedars-Sinai Medical Center 8700 Beverly Boulevard, Suite 2416 Los Angeles, CA 90048 or ACLU Foundation of Southern California 1313 West 8th Street, Los Angeles, CA 90017.

MILLER--Mrs. Iris H. Most beloved wife of Sidney. Adored mother of Vera Miller Aryeh and Lee Miller. Loving mother-in-law of Clara Miller. Cherished grandmother of Jason Aryeh and Olivia Aryeh, Laura Aryeh Murawczyk and Richard Murawczyk, Samantha Miller and Russell Valdez, Justin Miller and Simone Kalinowski, Sophie Miller, and Audrey Miller. Most devoted and thoughtful great-grandmother of Katie Aryeh, Jack Murawczyk, Daniela Murawczyk, Sascha Miller and Bodhi Miller. Bama, you taught us all how to love infinitely. We will always adore you. Services Sunday, March 9 at 11:00am Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison Avenue.

DILEO-KORFF--Virginia Katherine (nee Errera) beloved wife of Joseph Korff, both of Jupiter Florida, passed away peacefully at her home on March 6, 2014 with her family at her side after a three year courageous fight with cancer. She was 65. She was preceded in death by her father Salvatore Errera and her mother Mary Yuhoss Errera, and is survived by her husband, Joseph Korff, sister Phyllis Errera Punk, brother Nicholas Errera, sons Daniel Dileo and Phillip Christopher Dileo, granddaughters Aria Dileo, Olivia Dileo, and Giana Dileo, grandson Giancarlo Dileo, and stepchildren Christopher Korff, Penelope Korff, Jason Korff, Geoffrey Korff, and Mark Korff; many relatives in Sicily including cousin Enzo Errera who she considered her brother, Antonella Errera, Antonino Errera, Guissepe Cavasino, Bice Cerami, and dear friend Mimma Puma, as well as many loving friends in New York, Italy and the Jupiter area. Virginia was born in New York City on July 5, 1948 and attended catholic schools and the New School for Social Research where she became an expert in handwriting analysis. Her practice included forensic analysis and pre-employment screening. She owned the company Character Profiles and was a Certified Forensic Graphologist by the American Board of Forensic Examiners. She authored the book "Exposing Drug Addiction in the Handwriting of Adolescents and Young Adults," and achieved level 5 in Homeland Security where, up to her illness, she was actively involved. She wrote children's books exclusively for her children with the titles "Rob the Slob, Louise's Sneezes, Pat the Rat, Mister Tinkles Tickle, Tom Tom Meets Bullyboots, and Jake the Snake." Virginia loved art and beauty. Her home in Jupiter and her yacht, The Virginia Mia, reflected the Italian Renaissance with commissioned frescoes depicting Greek mythology, Roman Centurions, and Egyptian scenes. Scenes in which, if she didn't like the original historically correct character, she directed the artist to insert one more friendly. Most of the furniture in her home is of her design including a wood sculpted Cleopatra bed for which Virginia holds a patent. Her taste for beauty and her eye for detail and her insistence that work is done precisely challenged the most practiced artisans. She owned the art gallery Le Pitit Musee d'Art in Palm Beach Gardens and commissioned many artists and sculptors. Virginia had a gentleness that was coupled with a Sicilian intensity. Her quick wit meant that there was laughter around her, and her approachable beauty convinced bystanders that they had seen her in a movie, on TV, or somewhere; and many asked for her autograph. Her husband Joseph, family, and friends are saddened beyond words at losing her, and we pray she is with God in heaven finding the peace and comfort the past three years have denied. We know that all is well with her soul, and that the constant prayers for her healing by friends and family during her three year battle will comfort her on her journey. If there were an Olympic Gold Medal for Love, Virginia Dileo-Korff would have won it. Visitation in Virginia's honor will be held on Monday, March 10, from 6pm to 8pm, and a service on Tuesday, March 11, at 10am at Aycock Riverside Funeral and Cremation Center, 1112 Military Trail, Jupiter, FL 33458. Contributions in her memory can be made to Operation Smile at operationsmile.org 1-888-955-5455.

TRAPHAGEN--Ross E.,Jr. Died peacefully in his 91st year at his home in Hobe Sound, FL on Tuesday, March 4th. Born in Newark, NJ, he graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, received a BA from Yale University and his JD from Harvard Law School. Ross served as a Captain in the United States Army, and was awarded a Bronze Star for bravery in World War II. After the War, Mr. Traphagen practiced securities law at Davis Polk and Wardwell in New York City. He joined Goldman, Sachs & Co. in 1966 as an investment banker, and became a Partner in 1968. In 1986, he became a Limited Partner, and soon thereafter founded his own private investment firm, Plough Penny Partners. A strong supporter of educational causes, Ross served as a Trustee of various schools: The Peck School, The Eaglebrook School, Phillips Exeter Academy, Harvard Law School; and Denison University. Passionate about politics in his earlier life, Ross was Founder of Youth for Eisenhower and also served as President of the New York Young Republicans Club. An active philanthropist, he served on the boards of Neighborhood House in Morristown, NJ, Newark Museum, Family Service America, and Morristown Memorial Hospital. He served on the vestry for both St. Bernard's Church in Bernardsville, NJ and Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, FL. Over the years, he served on several corporate boards, including Congoleum Corporation, Bath Iron Works and Pennsylvania Crusher Corporation. Ross is survived by his devoted family including his wife Barbara, his children Edward May, Sara Bennett, Laura Traphagen and Judson Traphagen, and his grandchildren Phillip May and Charlotte Traphagen. Private memorial services will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Ross E. Traphagen Jr. to the Alzheimer's Foundation, 322 Eighth Ave., 7th Floor, New York, NY 10001.
DISICK--Ellis R. Your smile, your humor, your love and guidance are in our hearts forever. Laurie, Grant, Tia, Evan, Ritu and our little boys Noah, Sam, Brody and Ellis
EDWARDS--Harold G.,DDS. Beloved New York Orthodontist, Dr. Harold G Edwards, died January 15, 2014 at 64, in Miami. His wife, mother, kids, siblings and employees, wish him eternal peace.

GLENN--Morton Bernard, MD, age 91 passed away at home with family by his side in West Palm Beach, FL on March 1, 2014. Formerly of New York City, Dr. Glenn was born in New York in 1922, son of Mimi and Harold Glenn. He was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, 1942 and New York University School of Medicine, 1946. He served in the US Naval Medical Corps, 1947-1949. Dr. Glenn was a pioneer in the treatment of obesity. He was a teacher, lecturer, consultant, author and clinician. Fellow of numerous medical societies and past president of the American College of Nutrition. Preceded in death by his wife, Justine Glenn. Beloved brother of Arnold Glenn of North Palm Beach, FL; adored father and father-in-law of Wendy Glenn and Marianne Lowenthal, Valerie Glenn Jorgensen, John Glenn and Nan, Adrienne Harkavy and Jerry, Marcia Stamberg and Arthur. Also survived by his dearly loved grandchildren, Lena, Henry, Allan, Edward, Michael and Erika, Dan and Amy, four great-grandchildren, nieces, grand nieces and nephews. Memorial service at IJ Morris at Star of David Cemetery of the Palm Beaches, 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach, FL. March 9, 9:30am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County or Hospice of Palm Beach.

HOFFERT--Constance. Died on March 6 in Lantana, FL. Born on December 5, 1920 in Portland, ME to Pauline and Samuel Dorfman, she graduated from Wellesley College in 1942 and married her adoring lifetime mate, Daniel, that same year. He predeceased her in 2010. She is survived by her loving daughter and son-in-law, Rebecca and Peter Rosow. Connie lived a long and full life, was loved by many, and was impressively resilient in times of adversity. A real lady and true beauty, she turned heads until the end. We will miss her greatly. Graveside service at Mount Sinai Cemetery, Portland, ME at 1pm on Sunday, March 9th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

LIST--Claire. Peterborough, NH. Claire List, 81, formerly of New York, NY died on March 5, 2014 at Rivermead Lifecare Community in Peterborough surrounded by her loving family. Claire was Born on July 12, 1932 in Rochester, NY, the daughter of Stuart List and Claire (Wrightson) List. Claire is survived by her niece Sarah Greene Wrightson and husband Vince Bell, and her god children and their families, Malcolm and Zola Brown, Peter and Elizabeth Brown, Claire and Peter Kenny, and Sarah and Oliver Carley. She is predeceased by her sister Nancy Lloyd List Greene, and dear friend Elizabeth Alexander Richards. Services are private for family. Jellison Funeral Home and Cremation Services is assisting the family with services. To view an online obituary or leave a condolence please visit: www.jellisonfuneralhome.com

GALE--Daniel Kent, a lifelong resident of Huntington, NY passed away on March 5, 2014. Born December 13, 1917. Chairman, Daniel Gale Sotheby's International Realty, founded in 1922 by his father, Daniel Gale. Widely recognized and respected for ironclad values, integrity and ingenuity. For all his business success, he counted his loving family as his greatest accomplishment. Married 70 years to Jean Wallice (July 27, 1943). At Huntington High School played Varsity football, basketball, track, baseball. A superb bridge player who played with skill and enthusiasm into his 90s. Lifetime member, Rotary International, maintained perfect attendance while professionally active. Member, Huntington Country Club. WWII veteran, stationed at Schofield Barracks (Oahu) during Pearl Harbor attack. Completed "90 Day Wonder" officer training. Earned Captain, served in Panama. In 1955 and 1956 named top sales representative, North America, Travelers Insurance. Assumed leadership of Daniel Gale Agency from his father in the mid-1950s, was early leader in the Long Island Board of Realtors and Multiple Listing Service of Long Island. In 1976, Daniel Gale became affiliated with Sotheby's. Today Daniel Gale Sotheby's is a $2.5 billion dollar organization with nearly 600 sales associates/22 sales offices spanning Long Island. It consistently leads the nation in achieving one of the highest average sales prices in the country. Cherished husband of Jean (nee Wallice). Devoted father of Danny Gale, Stanley C. Gale and Mary Stokkers, grandfather to Kelly Stokkers, Aly Stokkers McKee, Kyle Stokkers, Stanley Gale Jr., Katherine Gale, Jaclyn Gale; great-grandfather to Brinley McKee.
RUBIN--Benjamin A. 9/27/17-3 / 8/ 2010. Always with me. Mae
Munier--Jonathan, passed at home, March 4, in Houston, TX. He was a loving husband to Marie, and caring father of Erin, Todd, and Nathan. He will be missed by all who knew him.

VAN DYNE--Neil W.,77 of Raleigh NC, died Tuesday, March 4 of cancer. Born November 11, 1936 in Brooklyn, NY. Neil was a proud and loving father of two with his beloved wife of 54 years, Philippa (Penny). Neil lived for the love of his wife, placing family above all. Many men and women thought of him as a second dad, others a brother. He was well loved by his friends and compatriots in the publishing & book printing industry. His other great love was cars and long road trips. He could fix anything with a toothpick and Elmer's glue. Neil also volunteered his time for many important causes. He is survived by his wife Penny, daughter Lisa, Son Alexander, and daughter-in-law Angelina. A memorial service will be held at the TPC Wakefield Plantation Country Club in Raleigh, March 16 at 10am. Donations can be made to Hospice of Wake County, 250 Hospice Circle, Raleigh NC 27607.

WEISER--Louis. Died peacefully at age 95 on March 3rd. Anita, his adored wife of 69 years passed away in 2013. A lifelong civil servant and advocate, Louis became an NYPD Patrolman in 1941, retired as Lieutenant in 1965 and served as Deputy Commissioner Department of Investigations. He was President of both NYPD and National Shomrim Societies and The Council of Jewish Organizations in Civil Service. He is survived by his proudest achievements: daughters Bobbi Stanley (Alan) and Ronnie Pinkowitz (David) and grandchildren Jeff Newelt (Erica), Marc Newelt (Stacy), and Jason and Marisa Mendelson. A true people person, his tenacious leadership, ubiquitous helping hand and Borscht Belt humor uplifted many and will never be forgotten.

ZERA--Hortense (Lieberthal), 97, died March 2, 2014 at the Goodman Brown Hospice. She was the center of a loving international circle of family and friends. A beautiful woman of many talents, she loved painting at the Fabrizio Studio and was honored to be part of the early modern dance movement. She was also wholeheartedly committed to issues of social justice. Predeceased by her beloved husband Max, she leaves behind her daughters Helene and Barbara Abramson (Bernard), adored grandchildren Louis and Galia Abramson, and the many kind women who were her caregivers. Donations would be appreciated to the Hortense Zera Fund of Na'amat, 315 W. 70 St, #

WINOGRAD--Bernard. 63, businessman, United States Treasury Department official and philanthropist, died Saturday, March 1. Mr. Winograd started his career in 1977 as executive assistant to W. Michael Blumenthal during Mr. Blumenthal's term as Secretary of the U.S. Treasury. He then moved on to Bendix Corporation where he held positions as director of Public Affairs and Treasurer. From 1983 to 1992, he was President of Taubman Investment Company, and from 1992 to 1996, Mr. Winograd served as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Taubman Centers. In that position, he was a key architect of Taubman's 1992 initial public offering. The transaction represented the first umbrella partnership real estate investment trust IPO, which set the stage for the dramatic increase in the capitalization of the real estate investment trust industry. Mr. Winograd joined Prudential Financial, Inc., which is headquartered in Newark, NJ, in 1996 as chief executive officer of Prudential Real Estate Investors. In 2000, he was named senior managing director of Prudential Private Investments, then president and chief executive officer of Prudential Investment Management in 2002. Mr. Winograd was appointed executive vice president and chief operating officer of all of Prudential's United States businesses in January 2008. He retired from Prudential on February 11, 2011. At the time, he expressed his desire to focus his energies on the many social issues, philanthropic causes and personal activities to which he was committed. Also, following his retirement, he was named to the Board of Cohen and Steers. Prudential's Chairman and CEO John Strangfeld said: "Bernard's sharp mind and legendary wit will be missed by the many people at Prudential who were privileged to call him a friend and colleague. We will also miss his valued counsel and his unfailing focus and vision. But what I will miss most is his friendship. Bernard's many years of dedicated leadership helped to build Prudential into the financial services company it is today. With his passing we have lost a truly remarkable person." Mr. Winograd held a Bachelor of Arts degree in social sciences from the University of Chicago and was a member of the University of Chicago's Visiting Committee on College and Student Activities. He also served on the board of Local Initiative Support Corporation (LISC), a community development financing organization. Mr. Winograd met his wife, Carol, almost 40 years ago when he was working for the Michigan Democratic Party. Mrs. Winograd was Communications Director of the party at the time. They have two children, Simon and Christina. In addition to his wife and children, Bernard is survived by his brother, Morley Winograd. Funeral services will be held at 3:30pm on Thursday, March 13, at the Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., New York, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or to your religious organization of choice.

THOMAS--Dr. Joab. Dr. Joab Thomas, President Emeritus of The University of Alabama and Penn State University and former chancellor of North Carolina State University, died March 3 in Tuscaloosa, Alabama, at age 81. He is survived by his wife, the former Marly Allene Dukes; children: Catherine McGee (Dr. Robert S. McGee, Jr.), Greensboro, NC; David Thomas (Mari Lunde), Cincinnati, OH; Dr. Jennifer Bolton (Timothy J. Bolton), Tuscaloosa; and Frances Thomas Doherty, Athens, GA; and 13 grandchildren: Meredith and Laura McGee; Kieren, Lia and Olivia Thomas; Luke, Marly, Stella and Adam Bolton; Caroline, Emily, Allison and Philip Doherty. He is also survived by his brother Dr. James Thomas, Tuscaloosa, and his sister Lois McGarity, and her husband, the Rev. Owen McGarity, Austin, Texas. An Alabama native, Dr. Thomas was a world-renowned botanist and three-time graduate of Harvard University. He is remembered as a student-centered academic leader and a champion of undergraduate research who spearheaded the growth of world-class honors programs and led numerous highly successful economic development initiatives. In 1961 he joined the UA faculty, where he rose through the administrative ranks over the next 15 years. In 1976 he was named chancellor of NC State; in 1981 returned to Alabama as UA president; in 1990 he became Penn State's president, retiring in 1995. A prolific research scholar and seasoned outdoorsman, Thomas co-authored several books, including Wildflowers of Alabama and Adjoining States. Memorial gifts may be made to the Joab Thomas Scholarship at The University of Alabama, the Joab and Marly Thomas Graduate Fellowship at The Pennsylvania State University, or to The North Carolina State University Foundation.

EPSTEIN--Sally. 5/25/30 -3/10/09. In 1952, you were so right John, Sally was a good athlete and a lot of fun, BUT she was so much more. She was smart, so caring and indeed quite remarkable. Adored and fondly remembered by Alan, her family and many friends.
GREEN--Sylvia. Happy 101st Birthday to my wonderful mother. Your words of wisdom are always with me. I miss you so much. Love, Barbara

KAISH--Luise Clayborn , died in New York City on March 7, 2013. A sculptor of soaring ambition and achievement and a painter of gem-like abstractions, she leaves a remarkable legacy. Luise was among the first women to receive the American Academy in Rome Prize. A Guggenheim Fellow, a recipient of a Louise Comfort Tiffany Grant, she was awarded the Arents Pioneer Medal, her alma mater's highest honor. She received her BFA magnum cum laude and MFA from Syracuse University, where she studied with the renowned sculptor Ivan Mestrovic, and as a graduate student, created her first large commissioned work, The Saltine Warrior, which stands on the campus today. Her work is included in the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the Whitney Museum of American Art; the Smithsonian Institution; the Jewish Museum; the Hood Museum, Dartmouth College; the Rochester Memorial Art Gallery; the National Academy Museum. Among her numerous commissions were the massive bronze "Ark of Revelations" for Temple B'rith Kodesh with architect Pietro Belluschi; "La Lumiere", Continental Grain Co. NYC; "Christ in Glory", Holy Trinity Mission Seminary, MD; "Wall of Martyrs", Temple Beth El, New Rochelle, NY; and the bronze Ark for Temple Beth Shalom, Wilmington, DE. She was Professor Emerita of Columbia University, where she Chaired the Division of Painting and Sculpture. She was the first woman Artist-in-Residence at Dartmouth College, the University of Hiafa, Israel, and the University of Washington, Seattle. She served as guest lecturer, critic, and panelist at numerous institutions and conferences. Luise was a Trustee Emerita of the American Academy in Rome, served on the Augustus-St. Gaudens Memorial, National Park Service, the board of the Sculptors Guild, and the New York City Fine Arts Commission. Luise Kaish lived and worked in New York City. Ever creative, it was her wish that her ashes travel into space. http://celestis.com/memorial/ sunjammer/ kaish.asp

SUKENIK--Richard Nachman. Died in New York March 7, 2014 at the age of 75. Former resident of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Graduate of Cornell (BA) and Harvard (MBA). Former Controller of WR Grace. Predeceased by his parents and brother. Survived by Nancy, his loving wife of 40 years, and many cousins. Life long Yankee fan and enthusiastic devotee of tennis.

TRAPHAGEN--Ross E.,Jr. Died peacefully in his 91st year at his home in Hobe Sound, FL on Tuesday, March 4th. Born in Newark, NJ, he graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, received a BA from Yale University and his JD from Harvard Law School. Ross served as a Captain in the United States Army, and was awarded a Bronze Star for bravery in World War II. After the War, Mr. Traphagen practiced securities law at Davis Polk and Wardwell in New York City. He joined Goldman, Sachs & Co. in 1966 as an investment banker, and became a Partner in 1968. In 1986, he became a Limited Partner, and soon thereafter founded his own private investment firm, Plough Penny Partners. A strong supporter of educational causes, Ross served as a Trustee of various schools: The Peck School, The Eaglebrook School, Phillips Exeter Academy, Harvard Law School; and Denison University. Passionate about politics in his earlier life, Ross was Founder of Youth for Eisenhower and also served as President of the New York Young Republicans Club. An active philanthropist, he served on the boards of Neighborhood House in Morristown, NJ, Newark Museum, Family Service America, and Morristown Memorial Hospital. He served on the vestry for both St. Bernard's Church in Bernardsville, NJ and Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, FL. Over the years, he served on several corporate boards, including Congoleum Corporation, Bath Iron Works and Pennsylvania Crusher Corporation. Ross is survived by his devoted family including his wife Barbara, his children Edward May, Sara Bennett, Laura Traphagen and Judson Traphagen, and his grandchildren Phillip May and Charlotte Traphagen. Private memorial services will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Ross E. Traphagen Jr. to the Alzheimer's Foundation, 322 Eighth Ave., 7th Floor, New York, NY 10001.

UDEM--Stephen A, MD, PhD. Physician, scientist and medical educator, died of lymphoma on January 11, 2014, at his Manhattan home. He was 69. He is survived by his adoring wife of 35 years, psychologist Sharon G. Nathan. Stephen was a highly regarded physician-scientist, internationally recognized by academia and industry for his contributions to virology and vaccinology. Throughout his career he held joint appointments in medical and basic science departments of medical schools, where he was appreciated for his clinical skills, his creativity as a scientist, and his excellence as a teacher. His research was funded by grants from the National Institutes of Health, the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, and the American Cancer Society, among others. Later in his career he focused his efforts on inventing vaccines in the pharmacology industry, in a non-profit organization, and as a consultant to start-up biotech companies. A winner of many honors and awards, Stephen was also an author of over 80 scientific papers and holder of several patents. A more comprehensive list of his accomplishments can be found at StephenUdem.com. As a person he was warm, witty, incisive, empathic, care-taking, generous, brave and fiercely determined, but what was most characteristic was that he was always fully present with everyone he came into contact with. A lifelong New Yorker, Stephen was born at Gotham Hospital in Manhattan on April 4, 1944. He attended New York City schools including the Bronx High School of Science (class of 1960), City College (BS, 1964), and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine (PhD, 1971; MD, 1972). In his 25 years at Einstein, he went from student to full professor. As a participant in the Medical Scientist Training Program, he earned a PhD in Genetics and Cell Biology and an MD. After completing his Residency in Medicine and Fellowship in Infectious Diseases in 1976, he joined the Einstein faculty in the departments of Medicine; Cell Biology; and Microbiology and Immunology. His research focused on the mechanism by which viruses cause persistent infection in the central nervous system. From 1989 to 1994, Stephen was Professor in the Departments of Medicine; Neuroscience; and Microbiology and Medical Genetics at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey (UMDNJ). In his role as Director of the Division of Infectious Diseases, he developed much-needed HIV in-patient and out-patient treatment units at University Hospital in Newark. Joining Wyeth in 1994, Stephen, as Vice-President for Viral Vaccine Research, oversaw the expansion of the company's programs to include vaccines for chronic infectious diseases, hospital-acquired infections, diseases affecting the geriatric population, respiratory syncytial virus, and HIV in addition to continuing Wyeth's work on rota-virus and the influenza vaccine delivered as a nasal spray. In 2006, committed to creating an AIDS vaccine, he joined the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative (IAVI) as Senior Vice-President of Research and Development. He was instrumental in developing a vaccine that IAVI is now evaluating in a clinical trial. In addition to his wife, he is survived by a sister, Edith Osman, a sister- and brother-in-law, Vicki and John Nelson, four nieces and nephews, and eight grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Stephen's parents, Arthur and Judith Udem, Jewish immigrants from Latvia who arrived in the US in 1940, died in 2006. A previous marriage to Linda Donaldson Kirk ended in divorce. A memorial service will be held on May 4th at 2:00 at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street.

O'GORMAN--Ned. We mourn the loss of our colleague and founder, Ned O'Gorman. Above all, we grieve for the children of Harlem who found in him a teacher, father-figure, and friend. At this difficult time we send our condolences to his surviving family and the community on 129th Street of which he was so vital a part. We remain inspired by his fierce determination, exhilarated by his passionate advocacy, and committed to honor his memory through our daily work at the school. The Board and Staff of the Ricardo O'Gorman Library and Garden. 23 West 129th Street, New York, NY 10027

ISAAC--Caridad. The Division of Pediatric Emergency Medicine and the Departments of Emergency Medicine and Pediatrics at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Weill Cornell Medical Center mourn the passing of our dear friend and beloved colleague, Dr. Cary Isaac. Since September 2004, Dr. Isaac has provided compassionate and exceptional care to countless children in the Pediatric Emergency Service. She was a dedicated teacher and mentor to residents and medical students, and a highly respected and loved colleague to physicians, nurses, and all who had the opportunity to work beside her. She will remain in our hearts forever. We extend heartfelt condolences to her husband, Dr. William Boxer, her children Isabella and Benjamin, and her entire family. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering, Breast Cancer Research, c/o Dr. Clifford Hudis.

GLENN--Morton Bernard, MD, age 91 passed away at home with family by his side in West Palm Beach, FL on March 1, 2014. Formerly of New York City, Dr. Glenn was born in New York in 1922, son of Mimi and Harold Glenn. He was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, 1942 and New York University School of Medicine, 1946. He served in the US Naval Medical Corps, 1947-1949. Dr. Glenn was a pioneer in the treatment of obesity. He was a teacher, lecturer, consultant, author and clinician. Fellow of numerous medical societies and past president of the American College of Nutrition. Preceded in death by his wife, Justine Glenn. Beloved brother of Arnold Glenn of North Palm Beach, FL; adored father and father-in-law of Wendy Glenn and Marianne Lowenthal, Valerie Glenn Jorgensen, John Glenn and Nan, Adrienne Harkavy and Jerry, Marcia Stamberg and Arthur. Also survived by his dearly loved grandchildren, Lena, Henry, Allan, Edward, Michael and Erika, Dan and Amy, four great-grandchildren, nieces, grand nieces and nephews. Memorial service at IJ Morris at Star of David Cemetery of the Palm Beaches, 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach, FL. March 9, 9:30am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County or Hospice of Palm Beach.
HOROWITZ--Celia, of Delray Beach, FL. Cherished wife, mother, grandmother, sister and friend died peacefully on March 4, 2014. She brought joy to all who knew her.

KATCHER--Evelyn, age 97, of Forest Hills, New York passed peacefully in her home on March 6, 2014. She was predeceased by her husband Arthur in 2003. She is lovingly remembered by her children Laurie Lindner Meister (Barry), William Katcher, and Alice Leder; her grandchildren Peter, Robert, Christopher, Cameron, David, Elizabeth and her great-grandchildren, Matthew and Adam. She left a huge personal legacy of devotion and respect for the arts, the State of Israel and a variety of intellectual pursuits. She was an avid opera and concert goer and president emeritus of the Medinah Chapter of Hadassah. She earned a Master's Degree in Education after her children had graduated from college. She completed the doublecrostic puzzle in ink every Sunday. She dazzled us with her endless knowledge of so many subjects. She will be missed.

MILLER--Mrs. Iris H. Most beloved wife of Sidney. Adored mother of Vera Miller Aryeh and Lee Miller. Loving mother-in-law of Clara Miller. McGORRY--Brian M. Died of a heart attack while sleeping in his home in Brooklyn Heights on February 27, 2014, at age 64. Born into the extended Bayside, Queens McGorry "Clan," Brian was a lifelong resident, builder, and protector of the people, communities and environments of New York City. Above all, Brian was dedicated to the stewardship, nurturing, and selfless caring for his immediate family, his extended family, his friends and neighbors of all walks of life, which were ever expanding. Always the man behind the scenes, turning conflict into resolution and pragmatically knowing and doing what had to be done to make the best outcome for all. He leaves for us all a great hole in the universe. Brian was a dedicated member of the Brooklyn Heights community for decades. He worked to create Brooklyn Bridge Park, both as a neighborhood activist and as a founding member and operating officer of the Brooklyn Bridge Park Conservancy. The park and its success was a continuing source of pride and joy to him. An active member of the Board of Governors of The Brooklyn Heights Association (BHA) for many years, Brian was also a member of the Grace Church School Board. Brian is survived by "his bride" of twenty seven years, Kathy Marshall, his adored sixteen-year-old twin daughters Ella and Kate, his brother Mark, sister-in-law Lana, his sister Lenore (who predeceased him), and his bountiful clan of cherished nieces, nephews, cousins, aunt, and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to debra of America at debra.org. A "Celebration of Brian's Life" was held yesterday.

O'SULLIVAN--Mary Ellen, 77, of Bronxville, New York passed away peacefully on March 6th, 2014. She is survived by her brother, Jack Baker and his wife Babs, her daughter, Maura O'Sullivan, and her granddaughter, Siobhan D'Angelo. She was born to William and Catherine Baker on April 30th, 1936 in Manhattan. She received a B.A. in English from the College of Mount St. Vincent in 1958 and pursued a master's degree in English at Hunter College. She was very active in her community, volunteering her time to many organizations such as Meals on Wheels and Pregnancy Care Center. Calling hours will be held at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville, on Monday, March 10th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made in her name to The Ursuline School or Pregnancy Care Center.

FLOOD--Rev. Matthew C.,S.J., on March 7, 2014. Loving brother of Msgr. William J. Flood of Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament, Bayside, NY. GALE--Daniel Kent, a lifelong resident of Huntington, NY passed away on March 5, 2014. Born December 13, 1917. Chairman, Daniel Gale Sotheby's International Realty, founded in 1922 by his father, Daniel Gale. Widely recognized and respected for ironclad values, integrity and ingenuity. For all his business success, he counted his loving family as his greatest accomplishment. Married 70 years to Jean Wallice (July 27, 1943). At Huntington High School played Varsity football, basketball, track, baseball. A superb bridge player who played with skill and enthusiasm into his 90s. Lifetime member, Rotary International, maintained perfect attendance while professionally active. Member, Huntington Country Club. WWII veteran, stationed at Schofield Barracks (Oahu) during Pearl Harbor attack. Completed "90 Day Wonder" officer training. Earned Captain, served in Panama. In 1955 and 1956 named top sales representative, North America, Travelers Insurance. Assumed leadership of Daniel Gale Agency from his father in the mid-1950s, was early leader in the Long Island Board of Realtors and Multiple Listing Service of Long Island. In 1976, Daniel Gale became affiliated with Sotheby's. Today Daniel Gale Sotheby's is a $2.5 billion dollar organization with nearly 600 sales associates/22 sales offices spanning Long Island. It consistently leads the nation in achieving one of the highest average sales prices in the country. Cherished husband of Jean (nee Wallice). Devoted father of Danny Gale, Stanley C. Gale and Mary Stokkers, grandfather to Kelly Stokkers, Aly Stokkers McKee, Kyle Stokkers, Stanley Gale Jr., Katherine Gale, Jaclyn Gale; great-grandfather to Brinley McKee.

KOEPPEL--Lillie. 92, beloved wife of David Koeppel (deceased) and Charles Elgart (deceased) died on March 5th in New York City.
