O'NEILL--Grover, Jr. The O'Neill family deeply regrets and mourns the passing of beloved Grover O'Neill, Jr. on February 14, 2014 at the age of 91. Grover, known to his friends as Bill, was a graduate of St. Mark's School, Class of 1940, and a graduate of Harvard College, Class of 1944, where he was a goalie on the Varsity Hockey Team. He served in the United States Army, Field Artillery from 1943-46 and was a First Lieutenant. Mr. O'Neill was a successful businessman for more than half a century. He joined Meriwether Capital in 1982 and remained active through 2013. He was a Trustee of St. Barnabas Hospital from 1960-2012, and Chairman of its Board from 1991-97; and Director of the Arthur Emerton Orvis Foundation, Inc. since 1968, and its President from 1990-2012. Predeceased by his first wife Kathryn, Bill is survived by his loving family: wife Elizabeth; daughter Carol O'Neill (Carey Battersby); son Tim O'Neill (Donna); stepchildren Melinda Mackay (Richard Essebag), Michael Mackay (Meggan) and grandchildren William O'Neill, Eliza Sommerville (Gavin), Kate Tuthill (Andrew), James Wendell (Meredith Weinberg), Zoe Mackay, and Hannah Mackay, and two great-grandchildren, Marilyn and Cormac Sommerville, and his sister Catharine Heyes, brother George O'Neill (Abby) and eight nieces and nephews. The memorial service will be held on Friday, March 21, 2014, 11am at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave. at 71st St, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to St. Mark's School, 25 Marlborough Road, Southborough, MA, 01772, Attn: Dr. John C. Warren; or St. Barnabas Hospital, Finance Dept., 4422 Third Ave., Bronx, NY, 10457, Attn: Todd Gorlewski.

GRINSTEIN--Stanley. November 26, 1927 March 2, 2014. Art patron and social activist, Stanley Grinstein passed away peacefully at home on Sunday, March 2nd surrounded by his family. Stanley not only impacted the art world but every person he encountered. He was deeply invested in politics and social advocacy. He believed in living every moment to the fullest and that life is as much of an adventure as you make of it. He wants to be remembered as someone who inspired others and enjoyed the party of life. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Elyse, three daughters, Ayn Grinstein, Ellen Grinstein Perliter (Chuck), and Nancy Grinstein (Neal Rabin), his sister Corinne Miller, and six grandchildren, Amanda, Alex, Willie, Joe, Tess, and Dia. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to: The Stanley Grinstein Memorial Fund benefiting the Cedars-Sinai Art Program Cedars-Sinai Medical Center 8700 Beverly Boulevard, Suite 2416 Los Angeles, CA 90048 or ACLU Foundation of Southern California 1313 West 8th Street, Los Angeles, CA 90017.

ROHER--Daniel S. Daniel S. Roher, of White Plains, age 88, died March 5 after a period of declining health. Beloved husband of Florence (Rodkinson), with whom he shared 63 years. Devoted father to Deborah of New Bedford, MA, Richard of Chappaqua, and Torin of West Linn, OR. He is also survived by brothers Clarence (Cliff) of Pearl River and Robert (Bob) of the Bronx, daughters-in-law Susan and Lisa, grandchildren David and Natalie, many nieces and nephews, friends and proteges. After graduating from Baruch College in 1946, he worked as advertising manager for Channel Master Corp. in Ellenville, NY, then as campaign manager and administrative assistant to Congressman Joseph Y. Resnick, 1965-69. He then founded Roher Public Relations and served as its president until 1996. Avid traveler, lover of nature, patron of the visual and performing arts, and supporter of Jewish causes and of expanded opportunity for higher education. Services Sunday, 12:30pm at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, to be followed by burial at Old Montefiore Cemetery. Shiva will be observed at his late residence Sunday 6-9pm, Monday and Tuesday 1-4 and 6-9pm. For directions or to send online condolences, visit www.ballarddurand.com. The family requests that donations in his memory be made to the Florence and Daniel S. Roher Scholarship Fund of Baruch College, CUNY, 55 Lexington Avenue, New York 10010.
ROBERTS--Patte Bogen. I met her at my bris, where she held me. I said goodbye to her at Good Sam; and I loved her in between. Stanley and Family

SCHINDEL--Barbara Ann. August 30, 1949-February 28, 2014. Barbara Schindel passed away peacefully after a short illness. She will be missed by people around the world who were touched by her caring ways, generous spirit and ever-active intellect. She had the heart of an explorer and Manhattan fed her insatiable curiosity. She traveled widely, especially by ocean liner, and she savored the pleasure of slow travel in high style with interesting shipmates. She will be laid to rest in Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, surrounded by fascinating fellow passengers. Barbara graduated from the University of Illinois in 1971 and had a long career of public service, advancing to become Chief of Training and Development at IRS. She retired in 2007 with many achievements, awards and admiring colleagues. She then joined the 'Nexters', a circle of cherished retiree friends, who explored what's next together. Ms. Schindel is survived by her parents, Beulah and Arnold, her brother David and sister-in-law Kate Becker, and her devoted nieces Emily and Cassandra. Information about a memorial service and charitable contributions are posted on her Facebook page.

SHAPIRO--Sidney, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by family on March 2, 2014. Survived by wife Eugenia and five children. A renowned expert antique clock restorer and electrical engineer, graduate of NYU, he was project manager for the Genesis of the Litton Inertial Navigation System.

FISHER--Seymour, 89, of Bethlehem, PA, died, Friday, March 7, 2014. A 1946 graduate of Columbia University, Mr. Fisher excelled during a 50 year career, representing Home Life Insurance Co. in Manhattan. He is survived by his wife Ellen, son, Evan and daughters, Myra Saturen and Alice Benash and their families. Funeral Services will be held at noon on Monday, March 10, 2014 at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue at South Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601.

HOYMAN--Scott. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, labor leader. At 93, Scott passed away after a long battle with Alzheimer's. A graduate of Monmouth College, IL, Scott became aware of the labor movement while living in Philadelphia and attending the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. He began working for the Textile Workers Union of America (TWUA) in New England, but spent most of his career as the Southern Regional Director for the TWUA. Later he became head of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union's (ACTWU) textile division. Dedicated to social justice and racial equality, Scott worked tirelessly to organize southern textile plants to help workers achieve higher wages, health insurance and other benefits and to ensure fair labor practices. He was instrumental in unionizing J.P. Stevens, the historic campaign upon which the academy award winning movie "Norma Rae" was based. Scott is survived by his second wife Barbara; son and daughter-in-law Scott Hoyman and Alice Orzechowski; daughter and son-in-law Michele Hoyman and Michael Mackuen; son and partner Neal Grier Hoyman and Joan Hutchison; grandchildren Dr. Courteney Mackuen and Elan Hoyman. His first wife, Dotti, died in 2000. Scott will also be missed by the expansive community of Workers United (successor union to ACTWU). Noel Beasley, President of Workers United, stated: "Scott was a great leader, teacher and friend. His commitment to workers, their families and communities was focused, disciplined and effective." James Andrews, President of the North Carolina AFL-CIO, said: "He was committed to workers and workers' rights and particularly those earning low wages in textile plants in the south. It was a delight to work with Scott, who helped to ground me in organizing skills." Donations in his memory may be made to American Association of University Women Scholarship Fund, or Medical Outreach Clinic: aauw.org/get-involved/ or medicaloutreachclinic.org

KLEIN--Paul L.,89, passed away peacefully on March 6, 2014. He is survived by his wife Francene and his son Conrad. Paul's wit, wisdom and warm heart will be remembered by all who were lucky enough to have crossed his path.

REICE--Sylvie. Beloved wife of the late Albert Reice, mother of Milo, Naomi, Seth, Andrew and Richard, grandmother of David, Jennifer, Rebecca, Max, and Alexandra, died peacefully at her home shortly before her 95th birthday. Noted author, editor, and columnist.
Munier--Jonathan, passed at home, March 4, in Houston, TX. He was a loving husband to Marie, and caring father of Erin, Todd, and Nathan. He will be missed by all who knew him.

SHASHA--Violet, on March 3rd, 2014 at 92 years of age. Beloved mother of Vivienne Pero (Richard), Emil Shasha and Virginia Shasha Kaplan (Barry). Loving sister of David Shuker (Batia). Adoring grandmother of Janine Pero Mullen (Paul), Brent Pero (Alana), Blake Kaplan. Great grandmother of Zachary, Ryan and Savannah. She was born in Baghdad, Iraq, spoke multiple languages, traveled the world and lived many joyous years in Scarsdale before retiring to Florida. She was an accomplished pianist and loved the opera. Donations in her name to the American Cancer Society. Services 11:15 Sunday at "The Riverside" W. 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

CIRILLO--Diana Lee, (October 4, 1963 - February 11, 2014) A woman of intelligence and charm, Diana died of cancer still young at 52, having battled to the very end with all her strength, fearlessness, hope, and wry, often wicked, wit. This loss is incalculable for Diana's family and friends, whom she dearly loved, professional colleagues, whom she deeply respected, Tarrytown community, where she lived happily and contributed proudly, and her Labrador joy, Jake. Diana made her mark as a scholar at Wellesley and Wharton, skilled writer, hard worker, and most gracious host and guest. Diana leaves bereft siblings Joan and Dick, almost-sister Kathy, niece and nephew Amanda and Ben and his family. She is now in the company of her beloved nephew, Ted, and together they are preparing to welcome the rest of us. We will remember how Diana enhanced our lives and every moment we shared with her on April 5 at her home, which reflected her so perfectly.

DIEBOLD--Dr. A. Richard, Jr.,of New York, NY passed away March 1st, 2014 in his longtime home in Tucson, Arizona at age 80. 'Dieb' joins his son, Albert Richard Diebold III; parents, Albert Richard Diebold and Dorothy Orizondo Roosen Diebold; and sister, Diane Diebold Terni. A beloved father and cherished grandfather, Richard is survived by his daughter, Deborah Diebold de Naveja and her husband, Juan Maria Naveja de Anda; grandson, Juan Maria Naveja Diebold and his wife, Belinda Kamm; brother, Dudley George Diebold and his wife, Honoria Hine Diebold; nephews and Nieces. Dr. Diebold led a brilliant academic career as a linguistic anthropologist specializing in comparative and historical Indo-European Studies, theoretical linguistics, psycholinguistics and transcultural psychiatry. His work with Mesoamerican ethnic groups, in particular with the Huave people, proved crucial to the communities' cultural survival. His impressive track as a scholar began at the Buckley School in New York and continued in Connecticut through prep school at Hotchkiss and college and doctoral studies at Yale University. He flourished as a researcher and a Professor at Harvard, Berkeley and Stanford and culminated his career as Professor Emeritus of Anthropology at the University of Arizona. As illustrious an academic as he was, he found a calling as a philanthropist, founding and directing the Salus Mundi Foundation, which focused on funding Indo-European studies, but supported many local causes that were dear to his heart. In his personal life he became a devoted Father to Deborah and a doting Grandfather to JM. A man of a thousand stories, he enjoyed none more than Tolkien's journeys to Middle Earth. He is an example to those who seek to live life true to themselves. The truest gentleman at every turn of his life, his kindness will be missed by those who knew him, his everlasting search for truth and hope by those who did not and his brilliance and wit by those closest to him. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to AILLA are greatly appreciated. Services handled by Adair Funeral Homes, Tucson, Arizona.
EDWARDS--Harold G.,DDS. Beloved New York Orthodontist, Dr. Harold G Edwards, died January 15, 2014 at 64, in Miami. His wife, mother, kids, siblings and employees, wish him eternal peace.

ELLIS--Elliot F.,M.D., 84 years old, died on February 22, 2014. Beloved husband of Dr. Kathleen Conboy-Ellis. Devoted father of Michael (Virginie), John, Andy (Mandy) and Nancy Ellis Noval; Cherished stepfather of Brendan (Rachael) Conboy. Adored "Pa" of Natalia and Andrea Noval, Ryan Ellis, Gabe, Teddy and Calvin Conboy; Caring sister of Carole Ellis. Dr. Ellis is also survived by former wife Jann Ellis, four cousins and dear friend and caregiver, Kati Lorinc. He will be privately interred at a later date to be determined by his family. Memorial donations can be made in his name to The American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology (AAAAI) at www.aaaai.org, an organization he loved and served for many years.

COLE--Elliot H.,81, one of the earliest partners in the Washington, D.C. law firm of Patton Boggs LLP, died peacefully in his sleep on March 6, 2014. Mr. Cole was born July 13, 1932 in Lynn, MA. After graduating from Reading (MA) High School, he attended Emerson College, but after one year transferred to Boston University to major in Communications and graduate in the Class of 1954. After serving in the United States Army, he returned to Boston University to attend the School of Law where he graduated at the top of his class. By that time, he had married Miriam Turran, a recent University of Maine graduate, who supported him and his career and causes enthusiastically during 52 years of marriage until she preceded him in death in 2009. Mr. Cole's success as an attorney for more than 45 years was equaled by his contributions on behalf of the State of Israel and philanthropic support for institutions such as his alma mater, Boston University, and Woodmont Country Club. Mr. Cole enjoyed playing golf, collecting art and fine dining, which he enjoyed as a longtime member of the Washington chapter of the International Food & Wine Society. He is survived by his daughter, Pamela Cole, two sons, Jonathan Cole and Michael Cole, six grandchildren, and sister, Eleanor Katcoff.

EASTON--Thomas Lind, of Williamsburg, VA died March 1, 2014. Tom was born in Detroit on March 31, 1927. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Judith Ann Isenberg Easton; their son James Lind Easton and daughter-in-law Martha Pollard Easton, also of Williamsburg; grandchildren William Bernard Easton of New York, Susan Lind Easton and Mary Pollard Easton; and nephew Jeffrey Lind Easton and wife Pegah and daughter August of New York. Tom and Judy began married life in Roselle, NJ before moving to West Newton, MA where they lived for 33 years. Tom's professional life included work for Foster Grant and Trina, Inc., of Fall River, MA and New York, from which he retired as chairman and chief executive officer in 1991. Tom was proudest of co-founding with Judy in 1994 The Berkshire Institute for Lifetime Learning, now Osher Lifelong Learning Institute. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Tom's memory to Hospice House and Support Care of Williamsburg, 4445 Powhatan Parkway, Williamsburg, VA, 23188.

BEIR--John W. "Jack" 90, of White Plains, formerly of Scarsdale, March 5, 2014. Husband of Ellen Haupt Beir and the late Barbara Katz Beir. Father of Linda Goslin and her husband Chuck of Brewster, Jeffrey Beir and his wife Sarah of Winchester, MA and Stephen Beir and his wife Jewel of Glen Allen, VA. Grandfather of Taylor, Andrew, Cameron, Kelsey, Hannah, Landon and Rachel. Army Veteran WWII. A memorial celebration of Jack's life will be planned for later this summer. For complete obituary and guest book see: mcmahonfuneralhome.com

BERGER--Les, 95, beloved patriarch of a loving family and founder of Cardinal Industries, a world leading manufacturer of board games and puzzles, died on March 6. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Sylvia; son Joel; daughter Bonnie Canner; grandchildren Ilana and Perri Canner and Justin and Carly Berger; and daughter-in-law Jody Berger. A memorial service will be held today, March 9, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel in Forest Hills, followed by interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery in Queens. Les will be dearly missed by his family and his countless friends and colleagues in the toy industry.

CALIENDO--Ralph J.,65, Passed away on March 6, 2014 in Flushing NY. Graduate of NYIT, avid numismatist, author and Past President of the Flushing Coin Club. Beloved son of Rose and Thomas Caliendo Sr. Caring brother of Thomas Jr. and Gerald Caliendo. Dearest uncle of Caitlin, Daniel, Justin and Christian. Visitation to be held on Sunday, March 9, 2014 at Frederick Funeral Home 192-15 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Kevin R.C. Church at 9:45am on Monday, March 10, 2014. Entombment to follow at St. John Cemetery in Middle Village NY.

DAVIS--Samuel Riker Sam Davis, 91, of Plymouth, MA died on February 26, 2014; preceded in death by his first wife, Barbara; survived by his wife of 40 years, Dorothy Davis; his children, Pam (Terry) Schmidt, Riker (Cindi) Davis, Shippen (Rifle) Salas, George (Emily) Davis, Dan (Meg) Warren, Caleb Warren, Katharine Warren, Ethan (Linda) Warren; 13 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. He practiced law and was a partner with Reynolds, Richards, LaVenture, Hadley and Davis in New York. His wisdom, kindness and generosity were an inspiration for his large family and many friends who loved him dearly. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be made to Wildlands Trust, P.O. Box 2282, Duxbury, MA 02331 or Pomfret School, 398 Pomfret St., Pomfret, CT 06258.

ROSEN--Rita,Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the passing of our cherished friend and Benefactor. Together with her beloved late husband, Philip, Rita was a devoted supporter of the College of Medicine for more than 50 years and an esteemed member of the Einstein family. A longtime member of our Women's Division and one of its most ardent supporters, she was a dynamic and inspirational leader. Over the years, she served as the division's president and as an executive vice president, and on the executive committee of its New York chapter's board. In 2005, the Women's Division honored her with its highest accolade, the Lizette H. Sarnoff Award for Volunteer Service. A trained actress and award-winning film producer, Rita contributed her time, passion and creativity to making nearly 20 films for Einstein that would help tell the College of Medicine's story, highlight the importance of medical research and inspire others to become involved. Her documentary about our Children's Evaluation and Rehabilitation Center received a prestigious Clarion award. Rita joined Einstein's Board of Overseers in 1983 and was a vibrant, creative and active member. Along with Philip, she was recognized by the College of Medicine for her extraordinary service with both its Humanitarian and Lifetime Achievement awards, and by Yeshiva University with an honorary doctorate. Tireless champions of Einstein and its mission to improve human health, this remarkable couple used their many talents to help the College of Medicine grow and flourish; our Department of Communications and Public Affairs is named in their honor and has benefited greatly from their support and vision. We will miss Rita's elegant and spirited presence and extend our heartfelt sympathy to Phyllis, Michael, Robert, Richard, Stephanie and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman, EdD, Chair, Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, MD, The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Gordon Earle, Associate Dean, Philip and Rita Rosen Department of Communications and Public Affairs Carol Roaman, President, Women's Division

BAILEY--Agnes T.,passed away on March 7, 2014, surrounded by family in her home in South Kent, CT. Agnes is predeceased by mother, Mary A. McHugh and father, John H. McHugh; brother, John E McHugh; daughter, Mary A Corwin; and husband, Merle D. Bailey. Agnes is lovingly remembered and survived by daughter, Joan A. and James Fleischman; daughter, Noreen C. Granbery and children, Liam, Erin and Enan; daughter, Erin P. Duffy; son, Michael T. and Jill Duffy and children, Patrick and Kelsey and granddaughter, Sinead N. Corwin; son, Curtis T. Bailey and his daughter, Lara; daughter, Robin Lehnert and her sons, Curtis and Dustin; brother, James and Ellen McHugh and children, Noreen E. and Brenden Casey, Regina E. and Richard Kane, Sean E. McHugh and sister-in-law Marie D. McHugh, Maureen and William Pynn, and Kathryn and Nicola Sisto. Agnes will be remembered for her long tenure at the Wall Street firm of Chapdelaine and Co. where she was Corporate Secretary. She will be remembered by everyone whose life she had touched during her stay here on earth as well as for her unending energy, deep conviction of life, generosity of heart and unconditional love for all. A wake will be held at Lillis Funeral Home, 58 Bridge St., New Milford, CT on Monday, March 10th, from 7-9pm and Tuesday, March 11th , from 2-4 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at Sacred Heart Church in Kent, CT on Wednesday, March 12th at 11am. Interment will take place in the spring.

KATCHER--Evelyn, age 97, of Forest Hills, New York passed peacefully in her home on March 6, 2014. She was predeceased by her husband Arthur in 2003. She is lovingly remembered by her children Laurie Lindner Meister (Barry), William Katcher, and Alice Leder; her grandchildren Peter (Helene), Robert, Christopher, Cameron, David, Elizabeth and her great-grandchildren, Matthew and Adam. She left a huge personal legacy of devotion and respect for the arts, the State of Israel and a variety of intellectual pursuits. She was an avid opera and concert goer and president emeritus of the Medinah Chapter of Hadassah. She earned a Master's Degree in Education after her children had graduated from college. She completed the doublecrostic puzzle in ink every Sunday. She dazzled us with her endless knowledge of so many subjects. She will be missed.

GALE--Daniel Kent, a lifelong resident of Huntington, NY passed away on March 5, 2014. Born December 13, 1917. Chairman, Daniel Gale Sotheby's International Realty, founded in 1922 by his father, Daniel Gale. Widely recognized and respected for ironclad values, integrity and ingenuity. For all his business success, he counted his loving family as his greatest accomplishment. Married 70 years to Jean Wallice (July 27, 1943). At Huntington High School played Varsity football, basketball, track, baseball. A superb bridge player who played with skill and enthusiasm into his 90s. Lifetime member, Rotary International, maintained perfect attendance while professionally active. Member, Huntington Country Club. WWII veteran, stationed at Schofield Barracks (Oahu) during Pearl Harbor attack. Completed "90 Day Wonder" officer training. Earned Captain, served in Panama. In 1955 and 1956 named top sales representative, North America, Travelers Insurance. Assumed leadership of Daniel Gale Agency from his father in the mid-1950s, was early leader in the Long Island Board of Realtors and Multiple Listing Service of Long Island. In 1976, Daniel Gale became affiliated with Sotheby's. Today Daniel Gale Sotheby's is a $2.5 billion dollar organization with nearly 600 sales associates/22 sales offices spanning Long Island. It consistently leads the nation in achieving one of the highest average sales prices in the country. Cherished husband of Jean (nee Wallice). Devoted father of Danny Gale, Stanley C. Gale and Mary Stokkers, grandfather to Kelly Stokkers, Aly Stokkers McKee, Kyle Stokkers, Stanley Gale Jr., Katherine Gale, Jaclyn Gale; great-grandfather to Brinley McKee.

SMITH--Marjorie, (Pinsly) (aka Maggie Silver), of Manhattan. Formerly of Boston, East Falmouth and Westfield, Massachusetts. Wife of Robert Glenn Smith. Mother of John Levine of Northampton, MA, Anne Levine of Newton, MA, Marc Levine of Fairfield, CT, and Dr. James Levine of Granby, MA. Stepmother of Leslie Smith of Ridgefield, CT and Lindsey Smith Hill of Newport, RI. Grandmother of Natalie Levine, Samuel Kooris, Lily Levine, Sara Jackson, Jeremy Levine, Evan Smith, Stephen Paolini and Maya Levine. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell- The Funeral Chapel; 1076 Madison Ave (81 St.) New York, NY Wednesday, March 12, 2014 at 3:30pm. In lieu of flowers, a donation could be made to the DANA-FARBER Cancer Institute 450 Brookline Avenue, Boston, MA 02215.

KREUTZER WEBSTER-- Ursula, 90, on March 7, 2014. Beloved wife of the late John Bancroft Webster. Visitation Thursday, March 13, 9:30am-11am. Funeral services 11am-12pm at Frank E Campbell, The Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (81st St), New York, NY. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY.

HOLLOWAY--Frank P.,Jr., 87, died peacefully February 8, 2014. He will be laid to rest with his parents Frank P. Holloway, Sr. and Caroline Ellis and first wife Lecarda Johnson Holloway in Pass Christian, MS on the Gulf Coast where he spent his formative years. He served in the U.S. Navy during WWII as an electronics communications instructor. He graduated from Purdue University with a degree in chemical engineering. In 1948 he joined Carbon Products Division, Union Carbide, Fostoria, OH as project engineer and later the Stellite Division, Indianapolis, IN and Materials Systems Division, Columbia, TN, in management positions. In 1975 he moved to corporate headquarters, New York, NY as President of the Electronics Division. His team received awards including an Oscar for the development of lighting technology that enhanced movie production. Retired in 1986 he divided his time between New York, NY and Hanover, NH pursuing interests in travel, history, theater, carpentry and golf. He was an active board member of AVA Art Center, Lebanon, NH. Frank was a family man with a big heart and a sense of humor. He is survived by his wife of 36 years, Ann Audley Holloway, an artist; daughters Gail Shiel, Jean Holloway Nahum; Ann's daughter Laura Shawn Bolger, son John Sparks; nieces, nephews, 12 grandchildren, three great-grandchildren. He is predeceased by sister Ina Jean Bailey, son-in-law Andrew Shiel.

NURNBERG--Rita. Died March 9, 2014, age 93. A life-long resident of New York City, she was predeceased by her husband of 66 years, Joseph. She is survived by her three children, Ronald (Fran Luckom-Nurnberg), Aileen (Stephen Schreiber) and Leslie (Charles Saber); her six grandchildren: Carolyn (Scott Spungin), Jason Schreiber, Jeff (Alison), Peter, Amanda and Jennifer Saber; the apple of her eye great-granddaughter Lindsay Spungin; and her sister Marcy Rothman. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (90th St) at 11:30am, Tuesday, March 11. Contributions in her memory may be made to: Sisterhood at the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, 475 West 250th St., Riverdale, NY 10475.

COWAN--Roger B.,79, attorney, died March 9, 2014, after a long illness. A private service for immediate family was held March 10. Roger's love and devotion to his wife Barbara; children Michael and Jane; sons-in-law Eduardo Finkielsztejn and Tim Ries; grandson Andrew Ries; brother-in-law Stanley Judd; late parents Augusta and Percy; and brother Marty will always be remembered.
HERSHKOWITZ--Marie. 3/11/54 - 11/21/13. In loving memory of my wonderful daughter, whose death was caused by a glioblastoma brain tumor. Melvin Hershkowitz, M.D.
ROSEN--Rita. Her love of life and inspiration will be missed and never forgotten. Barney Mayrsohn

DOLLINGER--Gisela (Kohn) Born August 30, 1902 in Baden-bei-Wien, Austria, Her family business was destroyed on Kristallnacht and her beloved husband, Bernard, was arrested. Able to free him from prison, they emigrated to China, living in Shanghai's Jewish Ghetto, where she worked with the Joint Distribution Committee (JDC), assisting many refugees from Europe in finding housing, food and clothing. Since 1950, they lived in the E. Village. The matriarch to scores of nieces, nephews, cousins, great-nieces and great-nephews, great-great-nieces and great-great-nephews. She was also a trusted friend to so many people. She lived her life with dignity and with honor. She died peacefully, at 111 years of age, on March 10, after telling family that she had "lived a long, happy life". Her life is an example to all of us.

GITTER--Wolf. Age 97, March 8th in Brockton, MA. Although his early life was turbulent, he died peacefully surrounded by loved ones. He was born in 1916 in a tiny village near the city known as Lemberg, Lvov, or L'viv, then the eastern capital of the Galicia Province of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. He survived both the Nazi invasion of Eastern Europe and a Soviet gulag in Siberia. In 1950 he emigrated to the U.S. with his wife Paula and two young sons. He leaves sons Max (Elisabeth), Martin, and Henry (Elana); grandchildren Emily, Michael, Alexandra, Joy, and Shayna; and two great-grandchildren. Donations may be made to Old Colony Hospice, 1 Credit Union Way, Randolph, MA 02368.

ROSEN--Rita Rita Rosen, of New Rochelle, NY passed away on Saturday, March 8, 2014. She is survived by her loving children Phyllis Hadley and Michael Rosen, her sons-in-law Richard Hadley and Robert Landes, her daughter-in-law Stephanie Rosen and her adoring grandchildren: Brett Raskin, Shaun and Weston Deutschlander, Matthew, Alexandra and Jacqueline Landes, Alec, Kayla and Sierra Rosen. Sadly Rita was predeceased by her daughter Wendy Landes on March 14, 2013 and her beloved husband Philip on January 19, 2014. Born in Pittsburgh, PA. to Anne and Max Pochapin, Rita excelled in the theatre arts. After receiving the Best Actress Award from Great Neck High School, Rita went on to study with Sanford Meisner, Martha Graham and Lee Strassberg at the Neighborhood Playhouse. Upon graduation she was invited by Rabbi Steven Wise to dramatize "Behold The Jew", the plight for a Jewish National Homeland, at The World Jewish Congress. This became the platform for her life of volunteerism. She created "Theatre for a Cause", which presented dramatizations in support of civic, philanthropic and humanitarian causes. Guidance Center, UJA, National Conference of Christians and Jews, Union of American Hebrew Congregations, United Way, New Rochelle Hospital, American Jewish Committee, Family Service of Westchester, Jewish Braille Institute and Temple Israel of New Rochelle, were among the organizations Rita and Philip supported. Highlights: In 1973 Rita and Rabbi Amiel Wohl of Temple Israel, began broadcasting a radio program for High Holy Days and Sabbaths to those who could not physically attend worship services. That program continues, bringing comfort to the homebound of all faiths. Rita and Philip devoted a large portion of their time and energy to The Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Rita used her talents to create over 20 films, telling the college of medicine's story and highlighting the importance of medical research. Rita became a member of the Board of Overseers in 1983. In 2000 Rita received an Honorary Doctorate from Yeshiva University. In 2005 The Women's Division honored her with its highest accolade, The Lizette H. Sarnoff Award for Volunteer Service. Along with Philip, Einstein bestowed upon them their Humanitarian and Lifetime Achievement Awards. Rita fell in love with and married Philip Rosen in 1947. They built their home and raised their family on the shores of the Long Island Sound in New Rochelle, NY where they lived until this day. As important as her volunteerism became, nothing was more important to Rita than her family. The tradition of her holiday dinners with children, grandchildren, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends were legendary, spanning more than three generations. Rita was a strong, loving and fiercely dedicated matriarch. She celebrated life to the fullest, savoring each moment, turning every occasion into something special. She will be greatly missed. Rita was truly "a woman of valor". A memorial celebration of her life will be scheduled in the spring. Donations in memory of Rita should be made to Temple Israel, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, NY 10804 or to "The Wendy Walk" www.wendywalk.com

DOLIN--Ada Wohl. Mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. A woman who cared about what was important in life and has left a wonderful legacy. Loving and devoted, she adored her family and has made all of us proud to be a part of that family. She will be greatly missed. We love you.

O'GORMAN--Ned. The Children's Storefront is deeply saddened by the death of Ned O'Gorman, its founder and long-time Head. In 1966, Ned opened a center for young children in a rundown storefront on Madison Avenue. From this small beginning grew the full elementary school that is today's Storefront. After leaving the Storefront in 1998, Ned opened The Garden, a preschool on 129th Street. Ned believed fiercely in the strength and ability of Harlem's children, and was determined to help them succeed. The Storefront evolved from his vision. He changed the lives of countless students and of many adults whose lives he touched. He will be greatly missed. The Board and Staff of the Children's Storefront

HIRSCHLER--Alice Marion Shindel, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and friend, passed away on March 8th after a long bout with cancer. Born on May 21, 1930 in Berlin, Germany, her family will remember her eternal optimism, unconditional love, and never-ending support. She is survived by her husband of 58 years, Alexander, her children Karen (Edward Dovner), David (Maura Keating) and Dina (Kerry Cochran) and her grandchildren Justin, Kyle, Danielle Cochran and Matthew Hirschler. Alice, who left Germany in 1941, has a standing exhibit at the Jewish Museum in Berlin. She had many passions and pursuits including Hadassah, Mah-Jong, crossword puzzles, travel and reading. She will be missed by all who knew her. Services were held at Gutterman Musciant in Hackensack NJ, on Monday, March 10. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to either Hadassah (Hadassah.org) or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (mskcc.org/giving).

SLIFKA--Alfred A. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of it's esteemed member, Alfred A. "Fred" Slifka, and extends sincere sympathy to his wife, children, grandchildren and other members of his family. William L. Mack, President; Alan Curtis, Secretary
MEIR--Ruth, of Palm Beach, FL, passed away March 8, 2014. Graveside service for family 2:00pm, Wednesday, March 12, 2014, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Gutterman's 1-800-992-9262

ROSEN--Rita. JBI International (the Jewish Braille Institute) mourns the passing of longtime Trustee and Honorary Officer, Rita Rosen. Together with her late husband Phil, she was instrumental in supporting JBI's programs on behalf of blind and visually impaired children and adults. Rita's vibrant leadership, generosity and devotion will remain an inspiration and a blessing. Our thoughts are with Phyllis, Michael and the entire family. Judy E. Tenney, Chairman of the Board Dr. Ellen Isler, President & CEO Israel A. Taub, Vice President & CFO The Board of Trustees and Staff of JBI

WEISS-SCHWARTZ--Sandra. Dr. Sandra Weiss-Schwartz, 78, of Livingston, New Jersey, passed away on Tuesday, March 4, 2014. She was born in Flushing, Queens on May 2nd, 1935 to Pearl and Max Weiss. Dr. Weiss-Schwartz graduated with a bachelor's degree from Queen's College and earned a medical degree from Albert Einstein Medical College; she was a board certified psychiatrist and psychoanalyst. A beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, Dr. Weiss-Schwartz is survived by seven children, 17 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Funeral services and burial were held on Thursday, March 6, 2014. Memorial donations in honor of Sandra may be made to Beit Yaakov Ko Tomar c/o David Dolinger, 422 Montgomery Ave., Highland Park, NJ 08904.

SHARFF--Florence, nee Kaiser, 96, passed away March 5. A Hunter College graduate, she married and gave birth to two children in Brooklyn, before moving to Bergen County, NJ. There, she began a teaching career that lasted almost fifty years in the Park Ridge system and then, at the Huntington Learning Center in Ridgewood. She was a music lover able to play many classical pieces on the piano. Reading nineteenth century literature, particularly the Lake poets, playing bridge, and a walking tour abroad were regular parts of her life. Expression of her athletic abilities began with participation on her high school basketball team, and included tennis and playing golf with an occasional tournament award. Always generous, she contributed to numerous charities including those supporting women, children, nature and Israel. She is survived by her sister, Gloria Ratner, of New York City; her daughter Jill Sharff, of Haverford, PA; and her son David Sharff, of Rockaway, NJ. Donations in her name can be made to Smile Train or Operation Smile.
JOHNSRUD--Judith H.,82, of State College, PA, died Sunday, March 9, 2014. stevenrnefffuneralhome.com

BLUESTEIN--Sanfurd Dr. At 1:00am on March 9, 2014 Dr. Sanfurd Bluestein passed away peacefully surrounded by family at his home in Boca Raton, FL. He was a giant of a man, a good father, a world class physician, star athlete, philanthropist, and guiding spirit to more people than can be counted. He was a force for good everywhere he went. A graduate of Lafayette College, he was one of the first Jews to attend Yale Medical School. He was a pioneer in the field of radioactive isotopes and was the head of Radiology at both Chilton Memorial Hospital and Barnert Hospital in New Jersey and taught interns at Mt. Sinai in New York City. He was a 40 year board member of the NYC Opera and established a scholarship fund in his name at Yale Medical School. He was also a long-time sponsor of the TV program "The Open Mind" hosted by Richard Hefner. He is survived by his son Joel Bluestein of Woodstock, NY and his two granddaughters Jessica Reisman and Jessica Bishop both residing in South Florida. His spirit was indomitable but his body was not. Dad you will be missed. Contributions in his name can be made to the Sanfurd G Bluestein MD 1946 Scholarship. All additions to Doctor Bluestein's scholarship fund should be made to: Office of Development Yale School of Medicine P.O. Box 7611 New Haven, CT 06519-0611.

BERGMAN--Dr. Moe. The first Executive Officer of the Doctoral Program in Speech-Language-Hearing Sciences at the City University of New York, and one of the founders of the field of audiology, died on February 20, 2014 in Herzliya, Israel. He was 97. Upon his retirement from CUNY in 1975, he accepted a comparable position in the Sackler School of Medicine in Tel Aviv, Israel. He is survived by his wife of 75 years, Hannah Goodelman Bergman, of Herzliya, Israel, a son, Jay, of Newington, Connecticut, and a grandson, Aaron, of New York City. Donations in his memory can be made to the Department of Communication Disorders, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, Israel.

Bank--Arthur, MD, Professor Emeritus of Medicine and of Genetics and Development at Columbia University, where he was until his retirement the Director of the Division of Hematology in the Department of Medicine, died in New York City on February 27, 2014. Dr. Bank was an internationally recognized leader and major contributor in the field of hematology research. Over the more than 40 years of his research career as a molecular biologist, he published extensively on the pathophysiology, on the protein and genetic levels, of Cooley's anemia, also known as beta thalassemia; on the mechanisms of human gene regulation; and on human gene therapy. He chaired several international meetings on Cooley's anemia, and served as Vice President for Medical Affairs of the Cooley's Anemia Foundation. He continued his substantial contributions to the Foundation serving on its Medical Advisory Board and Scientific Review Committee. The Foundation remembers him with great warmth, enduring respect, and gratitude for all the advances that he brought forth and his generous concern for each patient. We extend our condolences to his wife Rona, his sons David and Michael, and his three grandchildren.

BLUESTEIN--Dr. Sanfurd. The Wexler family mourns the passing of Dr. Sanfurd Bluestein. He was truly one-of -a-kind, both interesting and interested; generous on so many different levels. Dr B was a mentor and friend to us all and will be missed immensely.
ABRAHAM--Liza. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her family. Louis M. Solomon, Parnas

BROMBERG--Joseph S.,93, of New Rochelle, NY passed away peacefully on March 8, 2014. He was born on July 25, 1920 to the late Ivor and Mollie (November) Bromberg in New York City. A graduate of CCNY, he was a retired manufacturer's representative in the furniture industry. He is survived by his devoted wife, Miriam (Powell); by his loving children, Maddy (James) Posig of Burlington, VT, Amy (Harry) Bromberg Funk of Minneapolis, MN and Richard Bromberg of Yonkers, NY; and his sister, Helen (Leonard) Mendelsohn of Northridge, CA. He is also survived by his six cherished grandchildren, Andrea (Rob) Roley, Benjamin Bromberg, Daniel (Amy Amato) Bromberg, Wyatt Posig, and Sadie and Willie Bromberg Funk. Predeceased by his sister, Thelma Stern. Joe loved life and lived it to the fullest. Funeral Service, Kensico Cemetery Chapel, Valhalla, NY on Tuesday (today) 1:00pm, Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society would be appreciated.

WARDEN--Yvonne. 85, Actress and former dancer. Yvonne Warden, led a distinguished career that spanned over 50 years. She started out as a chorus dancer in the 1940's, then fulfilled her dream to become an actress. She died in her sleep on March 12th, 2013 in Manhattan. She was 85. The cause was emphysema, said her son, James Warden. Her first play was in 1967, "The Trials Of Brother Jero and the Strong Breed". She did a great deal of Off-Broadway, TV, soaps, films including "The Cosby Show" and "Law & Order" to name a few. The most important thing in Yvonne's life was being a great mother to her son, James. Which she was. She was an activist in fighting for positive representation of actors of color on soap operas. Audiences will remember her as "Joanna" in Kool & the Gang's hit music video. Sometime this year a memorial will be held in her honor.

ROSEN--Rita. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Rita Rosen, and extend sincere condolences to her family. James Dreyfus, President

DOLLINGER--Gisela (Kohn) Born August 30, 1902 in Baden-bei-Wien, Austria, Her family business was destroyed on Kristallnacht and her beloved husband, Bernard, was arrested. Able to free him from prison, they emigrated to China, living in Shanghai's Jewish Ghetto, where she worked with the Joint Distribution Committee (JDC), assisting many refugees from Europe in finding housing, food and clothing. Since 1950, they lived in the E. Village. The matriarch to scores of nieces, nephews, cousins, great-nieces and great-nephews, great-great-nieces and great-great-nephews. She was also a trusted friend to so many people. She lived her life with dignity and with honor. She died peacefully, at 111 years of age, on March 10, after telling family that she had "lived a long, happy life". Her life is an example to all of us.

GORDAN--Henry (Hank) S. Passed away on March 5, 2014 in Bethesda East Hospital in Delray, FL. Henry was born in Brooklyn, NY on February 11, 1944, son of Roslyn and Milton Gordan. He was a graduate of Hunter College and received his Master's from City College of New York. He was a life-long employee of Celanese Corporation, retiring in 2005 as Financial Director. Predeceased by his wife Nicole and son David. He is survived by his beloved son Jason of Durango, CO and his loving companion Cacky Bell. He was deeply loved by all of her family and by his many friends scattered throughout the country. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at 11am on May 3, 2014 at the Mt. Kemble Lake Clubhouse, 2 Trails End, Morristown, NJ 07960. Memorial contributions may be made to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation.
ROSEN--Rita. A lifetime of memories. Together with Uncle Phil after only 48 days. Rest in peace Aunt Rita. You will always be in our hearts. Cheryl, Bill, Ian & David

COHEN--Melvin S.,85, passed away on March 10, 2014, surrounded by family at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, NY. Beloved husband of Joan and wonderful father of Laurie and Peter and the late Robert. Devoted grandfather of Molly, Sam and Sophie and adored father-in-law of Renee and cherished son of the late Minnie and George. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Melvin's name to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisade Ave., Riverdale, NY 10471. Attn: Development Office.

ALENSTEIN--Ronald H.,73, passed away at home on March 8, 2014, in Briarcliff Manor, NY. He is survived by his wife Mary Raymond Alenstein, and his children Abby (James) Langehennig of Dix Hills, NY, Alec P. (Helene) Alenstein of Briarcliff Manor, his grandchildren Raymond, Holly, Lyle and Will and his sister Marla (Robert) Michel of Baltimore, MD. He loved the practice of law, beginning his career at Shea & Gould in 1965 and concluding his career in 2014 as a litigating partner at Ingram, Yuzek, Gainen, Carroll and Bertolotti in New York City. He was a fine and honorable gentleman who cherished his family above all else. Visiting hours are at Waterbury & Kelly in Briarcliff Manor, 914-941-1600, on Thursday, March 13, 2-4pm and 6-8pm. Memorial service at Briarcliff Congregational Church, 914-941-4368, 30 South State Rd., Briarcliff Manor, on Friday, March 14 at 11am.

JOHNSRUD--Judith H.,82, of State College, PA, died Sunday, March 9, 2014. stevenrnefffuneralhome.com

ROSEN--Rita Rita Rosen, of New Rochelle, NY passed away on Saturday, March 8, 2014. She is survived by her loving children Phyllis Hadley and Michael Rosen, her sons-in-law Richard Hadley and Robert Landes, her daughter-in-law Stephanie Rosen and her adoring grandchildren: Brett Raskin, Shaun and Weston Deutschlander, Matthew, Alexandra and Jacqueline Landes, Alec, Kayla and Sierra Rosen. Sadly Rita was predeceased by her daughter Wendy Landes on March 14, 2013 and her beloved husband Philip on January 19, 2014. Born in Pittsburgh, PA. to Anne and Max Pochapin, Rita excelled in the theatre arts. After receiving the Best Actress Award from Great Neck High School, Rita went on to study with Sanford Meisner, Martha Graham and Lee Strassberg at the Neighborhood Playhouse. Upon graduation she was invited by Rabbi Steven Wise to dramatize "Behold The Jew", the plight for a Jewish National Homeland, at The World Jewish Congress. This became the platform for her life of volunteerism. She created "Theatre for a Cause", which presented dramatizations in support of civic, philanthropic and humanitarian causes. Guidance Center, UJA, National Conference of Christians and Jews, Union of American Hebrew Congregations, United Way, New Rochelle Hospital, American Jewish Committee, Family Service of Westchester, Jewish Braille Institute and Temple Israel of New Rochelle, were among the organizations Rita and Philip supported. Highlights: In 1973 Rita and Rabbi Amiel Wohl of Temple Israel, began broadcasting a radio program for High Holy Days and Sabbaths to those who could not physically attend worship services. That program continues, bringing comfort to the homebound of all faiths. Rita and Philip devoted a large portion of their time and energy to The Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Rita used her talents to create over 20 films, telling the college of medicine's story and highlighting the importance of medical research. Rita became a member of the Board of Overseers in 1983. In 2000 Rita received an Honorary Doctorate from Yeshiva University. In 2005 The Women's Division honored her with its highest accolade, The Lizette H. Sarnoff Award for Volunteer Service. Along with Philip, Einstein bestowed upon them their Humanitarian and Lifetime Achievement Awards. Rita fell in love with and married Philip Rosen in 1947. They built their home and raised their family on the shores of the Long Island Sound in New Rochelle, NY where they lived until this day. As important as her volunteerism became, nothing was more important to Rita than her family. The tradition of her holiday dinners with children, grandchildren, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends were legendary, spanning more than three generations. Rita was a strong, loving and fiercely dedicated matriarch. She celebrated life to the fullest, savoring each moment, turning every occasion into something special. She will be greatly missed. Rita was truly "a woman of valor". A memorial celebration of her life will be scheduled in the spring. Donations in memory of Rita should be made to Temple Israel, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, NY 10804 or to "The Wendy Walk" www.wendywalk.com

SHAW--Jerome, age 92, born in New York and residing in Fairhope AL, passed away March 7th. He served in the Army Air Force in WWII, fought for civil rights in Alabama in the late 1940s, was an accomplished painter and sculptor, and wrote many novels, short stories, and plays. He worked in real estate, built houses, and was employed by the Department of Community Affairs in New Jersey, where he created the state's first Land Bank program.

WIRTENBERG--Leon, 92, of Boston, MA, March 10, 2014. Adored and beloved husband of the late Patricia Zarrella Wirtenberg, much loved uncle and great-uncle, friend of many. Veteran of World War II, Captain United States Marine Corps, former business owner in Boston. Loved life. and lived it, with zest, with honor, with integrity, a sense of humor and a giving nature. Memorial in honor of his life to be held in Jamaica Plain, MA at a future date, to be announced. Contributions may be given to U.S. Marine Corps Heritage Foundation or U.S. Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation.
O'GORMAN--Ned. Artist, believer, educator, music lover, philosopher, poet, raconteur, reader, traveler, wit, and unfailing as a friend in his affection, devotion, and encouragement.

FRISH--Beatrice, nee Sillman, proud alumna of Hunter College and Maxwell School at Syracuse University. Admired and treasured mother of Martha (Bob) and Anabel (Mark), beloved grandmother of Tori and David. Services Thursday, March 13th at 10am at Parkside Memorial 98-60 Queens Blvd. Interment in Fairfield, CT immediately following. Shiva will be Thursday evening and Friday until 3pm at home.

JORDAN--Ruth Bennett, died on March 8, 2014, peacefully in New York City. Known as Rudy, she was born on September 11, 1924 in Chicago, one of five daughters of James Ewing Bennett and Mary Mable Dwyer. She attended the Girls' Latin School in Chicago and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College with a B.A. in 1946. Rudy served as a volunteer ambulance driver for the Red Cross Motor Corps in Chicago during World War II. She volunteered as a nurse's aide during and after college. A long term member of The Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York, New York, and St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York, Rudy was a person of strong values and a leader in ethics. Rudy studied at Columbia University Teacher's College towards a Master's degree in Teaching and taught English and American History for 10 years at The Lenox School in Manhattan. She subsequently earned her Juris Doctor from New York Law School in 1981, and was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1982 at the age of 57. She worked as an assistant in the Law Department at the New York County Surrogate's Court, and later at a law firm and also volunteered in the field of environmental law. Rudy was a direct descendant of Thomas Soule and Richard Warren of the Mayflower. She was a long term member of the Colony Club, The New York Junior League, the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club and The Colonial Dames of America. She was a champion bridge player, representing the bridge team for the Colony Club for many years. She was interviewed by Dan Rather on CBS 60 Minutes II, and by others on television, on the topic of the Dennis Kozlowski, Tyco International Ltd. trial, in which she was involved. She advocated that as there was not sufficient evidence in the initial trial to establish the defendant's guilt, as she saw it, the presumption of innocence must prevail. Rudy was an optimist and an idealist; a person of great fortitude and original thought. Always supportive of her children and grandchildren, and an extremely warm and devoted mother, she set an example of determination and creative solutions in the face of adversity. Rudy is survived by her two children, Jennifer Jordan McCall and William Winston Jordan, a daughter-in-law, Denise A. Walter, three grandchildren, Caroline Debevoise Clark, Hillary Sage Clark and Samantha Marie Jordan, and by a sister, Joan Bennett Gordon of Glenview, Illinois. A Memorial Service will be held at 10:30am on Saturday, March 15 at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York.

Bank--Arthur, MD, Professor Emeritus of Medicine and of Genetics and Development at Columbia University, where he was until his retirement the Director of the Division of Hematology in the Department of Medicine, died in New York City on February 27, 2014. Dr. Bank was an internationally recognized leader and major contributor in the field of hematology research. Over the more than 40 years of his research career as a molecular biologist, he published extensively on the pathophysiology, on the protein and genetic levels, of Cooley's anemia, also known as beta thalassemia; on the mechanisms of human gene regulation; and on human gene therapy. He chaired several international meetings on Cooley's anemia, and served as Vice President for Medical Affairs of the Cooley's Anemia Foundation. He continued his substantial contributions to the Foundation serving on its Medical Advisory Board and Scientific Review Committee. The Foundation remembers him with great warmth, enduring respect, and gratitude for all the advances that he brought forth and his generous concern for each patient. We extend our condolences to his wife Rona, his sons David and Michael, and his three grandchildren.

SHILLMAN--Irving, of New York City, died peacefully on March 10, 2014, age 92, son of the late Morris and Sarah, immigrants from Lithuania. Predeceased by his wife Florence (Fineblum) in 1971. Survived by his children, Sara and Jay, and their respective spouses, Andrew Feinstein and Ellen, and his grandchildren Rick and Gabbi, Katie, Michael and Erika, Jenny and Michael, Jake, and his great-grandsons Liam and Ryan. He is also survived by his beloved friend Phyllis Barchas. Born and raised in Williamsburg, he was a proud graduate of Stuyvesant High School and NYU. He served for three years in WWII with the 33rd Infantry Division and he was awarded the Bronze Star for Valor. He then joined the family toy business and built it into a widely respected member of the toy industry. He was a Mason, Shriner and a founder and longtime trustee of the Central Queens YM&YWCA. Grandpa Shilly was our familiy's patriarch. We will miss him dearly and he will be in our hearts forever. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, 9:30am at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

WELCH--Ted Houston. Nashville businessman and longtime fundraiser for the Republican Party, passed away Saturday, March 8th in Nashville, TN. He is survived by his loving wife of 30 years, Colleen Conway Welch. Ted had three adoring daughters with Joanne C. Thornton. He is preceded in death by his parents, Hilda Houston, his father, Louis Welch, his sister Patsy Welch Peach, brother Fred Welch and his oldest daughter, Kala Welch MacLeod of Nashville. A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, March 15th at Westminster Presbyterian Church at 2:30pm. After the service, the family will be receiving visitors at the Welch residence. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Vanderbilt University School of Nursing scholarship fund or Nashville Humane Society.

BLUESTEIN--Dr. Sanfurd G. The Mardyks and Levin families want to honor and wish to express both sadness in the passing and celebration in the life of our cherished 93 year old friend. His decades of devotion to others will remain legendary. The goodness in Sandy's passions and purposes will inspire us always and in all ways. We wish his family peace and comfort in the great love that is his legacy.

AGISIM--Blanche Tedlow. With deep sadness we share the news of the passing of our family matriarch, Blanche, who just celebrated her 93rd birthday. Blanche and Phil shared a love story for 71 years of marriage. Predeceased by her sister Ethel, brother Ted. Survived by Philip, sons Leslie (Judith), Elliot (Laura), three great and three grandchildren. Funeral services at Park Avenue Synagogue, Thursday at 11:00am.

ROBBINS--Donald H. Passed away at his home on March 5, 2014, in West Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 96. A fixer of things and people who loved nothing more than to solve problems great and small for his family, and for those who crossed paths with him. He was a man of unlimited strength, determination and will- a character to be reckoned with, never to be circumvented. He was a man of deeply felt beliefs and morals who lived by his own unique principles. A fiercely loyal husband, father and friend, pre-deceased by his wonderful loving wife Barbara in 2003, survived by his sons Richard and James, his sister Norma Heller, grandchildren Jessica, Leslie, Zachary and Lucas, daughters in law Ilene and Nancy, beloved nieces and nephews, lifelong friends Emmanuel Pearlman and Emily Johnson and dear companion Sascha Sorin. The void he leaves is enormous and the stories told about him will forever help to fill it. A graduate of Brooklyn's Poly Preparatory and Bucknell University as well as an Army veteran of WWII, his time in these institutions meant the world to him. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Hospice of Palm Beach County Foundation at www.hpbc.com

SIVE--David, (1922-2014) Sive, Paget & Riesel mourns the passing of our founding partner, David Sive. David was a great friend to his colleagues, an exceptional litigator, and a loving husband, father, and grandfather. As an intellectual and spiritual leader of the modern environmental law movement, he devoted his energies and passion to protecting the environment. Our hearts go out to David's family in this difficult time. A veteran of World War II, David fought in the Battle of the Bulge. After graduating from Columbia Law School in 1948, he emerged as an authority on administrative law. However, his love of the wilderness soon led him into the then-nascent field of environmental law. He quickly became an authority in this new field, and was often referred to as the father of modern environmental law. His sustained success in the courtroom over decades established vitally important precedents for later generations of environmental lawyers. David was one of the first lawyers to bring litigation effectuating the "forever wild" provisions of the New York State Constitution, and litigated a number of cases protecting the environment in his beloved Adirondack and Catskill Mountains. In the 1960's, he played a leading role in the administrative and judicial proceedings that prevented the construction of a power plant on Storm King Mountain along the Hudson River, and helped to establish aesthetics as a recognized environmental value. In subsequent decades David litigated numerous important environmental cases. He prevented the construction of the proposed Hudson River Expressway (a precursor of the ill-fated Westway Project). He challenged up to the U.S. Supreme Court the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's testing of atomic weapons off Alaska's Amchitka Island, and litigated the principal case establishing that the military is subject to the National Environmental Policy Act. In a landmark case decided by the New York Court of Appeals, David established that the preservation of wilderness areas for the benefit of the public serves charitable, educational, and moral purposes and entitles nature preserves to the tax-exempt status that is essential to their survival. David was proud of his role as a teacher, introducing generations of young lawyers to the emerging field of environmental law, both as a member of the adjunct faculty of Columbia and Pace Law Schools, and as the founder of several continuing legal education courses for the Environmental Law Institute and the American Law Institute- American Bar Association. David's lectures and written scholarship, including an environmental column in the National Law Journal and articles in numerous law reviews, helped to shape the field of environmental law. David also played a critical role in the creation of the Environmental Law Institute, the Natural Resources Defense Council, and other prominent national environmental organizations, as well as scores of regional and local entities. His legacy is permanently embedded in innumerable precedent-setting cases. But to those who knew David well and worked with him closely, his gentle way and kind soul will be missed most of all. We will miss David greatly.

JORDAN--Ruth Bennett, died on March 8, 2014, peacefully in New York City. Known as Rudy, she was born on September 11, 1924 in Chicago, one of five daughters of James Ewing Bennett and Mary Mable Dwyer. She attended the Girls' Latin School in Chicago and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College with a B.A. in 1946. Rudy served as a volunteer ambulance driver for the Red Cross Motor Corps in Chicago during World War II. She volunteered as a nurse's aide during and after college. A long term member of The Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York, New York, and St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York, Rudy was a person of strong values and a leader in ethics. Rudy studied at Columbia University Teacher's College towards a Master's degree in Teaching and taught English and American History for 10 years at The Lenox School in Manhattan. She subsequently earned her Juris Doctor from New York Law School in 1981, and was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1982 at the age of 57. She worked as an assistant in the Law Department at the New York County Surrogate's Court, and later at a law firm and also volunteered in the field of environmental law. Rudy was a direct descendant of Thomas Soule and Richard Warren of the Mayflower. She was a long term member of the Colony Club, The New York Junior League, the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club and The Colonial Dames of America. She was a champion bridge player, representing the bridge team for the Colony Club for many years. She was interviewed by Dan Rather on CBS 60 Minutes II, and by others on television, on the topic of the Dennis Kozlowski, Tyco International Ltd. trial, in which she was involved as the sole "hold out" juror against conviction. She advocated that as there was not sufficient evidence in the initial trial to establish the defendant's guilt, as she saw it, the presumption of innocence must prevail. Rudy was an optimist and an idealist; a person of great fortitude and original thought. Always supportive of her children and grandchildren, and an extremely warm and devoted mother, she set an example of determination and creative solutions in the face of adversity. Rudy is survived by her two children, Jennifer Jordan McCall and William Winston Jordan, a daughter-in-law, Denise A. Walter, three grandchildren, Caroline Debevoise Clark, Hillary Sage Clark and Samantha Marie Jordan, and by a sister, Joan Bennett Gordon of Glenview, Illinois. A Memorial Service will be held at 10:30am on Saturday, March 15 at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York.

FELDER--Jerome a/a Doc Pomus Twenty-three years is but a moment: the blink of an eye; the beat of a heart, for we think of you every day that has passed since then. Sharyn, Geoffrey, Raoul and Shirlee

ULLMAN--Richard H.,of Princeton, NJ, died on March 11, 2014. He was 80 years old. He was a distinguished scholar of International Affairs at Princeton University for over 40 years, ultimately as the David K. E. Bruce Professor of International Relations. He began his career at Harvard University and while on a sabbatical from Princeton was the George Eastman Visiting Professor at Oxford University, where he had received his D. Phil. and been a Rhodes Scholar. He educated generations of students and mentored many who guided United States foreign policy for both Democratic and Republican presidents. Through his own service in the administrations of two presidents, his time on The New York Times Editorial Board, his leadership of Foreign Policy Magazine as Director of Studies at the Council of Foreign Relations, and through his many books and articles, Dick made important contributions to the country's pressing foreign policy discussions over many decades. Dick is survived by his beloved wife Gail, two children, two step-children, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a time to be announced over coming weeks.
FINKELSTEIN--Irving. Happy Birthday Dearest Dada. Loved and Remembered Forever and a Day. Cynthia

WALKER--Sally B.,92, of Greenville, DE formerly of New York, NY., died on Monday, March 10, 2014 in her home after a long struggle with Alzheimer's disease. Sal was the daughter of the late Edith Parkhouse Walker and Lambert Roger Walker of Bellerose, NY. She graduated from the Cathedral School of St. Mary's and Finch College. After graduating from Finch, she began her career at Steuben Glass in New York, ultimately retiring as Executive Vice President. Sally was a avid world traveler, tennis player and golfer. She was a member of the Rockaway Hunting Club of Lawrence, NY and a member of the Lawrence Beach Club, Atlantic Beach, NY. Sally was also a member of the Colony Club in New York. She served as the Chairman of the Board of Directors of 116 East 66th Street Corp, the co-op building where she lived before moving to Delaware. She is survived by her devoted brother Lambert R. (Bob) Walker, Jr., nephews Roger and Patrick and her niece Moira. Sally was dearly loved by her family and friends and for her zest of life and adventure. She will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 15, 2014 at 11:00am at the Chapel at Christ Church Christiana Hundred, Greenville, DE. Interment will be private. The family would like to extend their heartfelt thanks and appreciation to the staff of the Stonegates Health Center for their loving care and dedication given to Sally over the past eighteen months. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions in Sally's name to the Alzheimer's Association, 240 N. James St., Suite 100A, Newport, DE 19804. For online condolences please visit chandlerfuneralhome.com

Broad St., Philadelphia, PA 19102.

RUBINOW-FRIEDMAN--Shirley, 88, on February 24, 2014, in Philadelphia. She received a Master's in mathematics at University of Chicago in 1949 and was an avid bridge player. Her first husband, Sol Rubinow, died in 1981, and her second husband, Leonard Friedman, in 1998. Survived by her children, Jerry, Sonya, and Marisa, and three grandchildren, Charlotte, Dorothy, and Olin. Services were held in Westchester on February 27.

KING--Lambert ("Bert"). The entire Montefiore community mourns the loss of our friend and colleague Bert King, MD. Bert held a variety of senior leadership positions at Montefiore, including pioneering the Montefiore Rikers Island Health Service where he set the stage for that program's leadership role in curtailing and treating the HIV-TB epidemic. Bert went on to a fabled role in medical leadership at private and public hospitals where he always championed social justice and access to healthcare. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Sharon and their daughter Martha. Steven M. Safyer, MD President & CEO, Montefiore

MARKOWITZ BROWN--Beth, 63, passed away on March 8, 2014. She spent her entire adult life in New York City. She graduated from the University of Miami and worked in the financial and legal industries in New York. She was the daughter of the late Joseph Markowitz and the late Lenore Adleman. She was the step-daughter of the late, Stanley Adleman. She is survived by her step-mother, Mary Rose Markowitz, her sister and brother-in-law, Judith and Simon Srybnik, her brother and sister-in-law, Joshua and Stacey Markowitz, and her beloved niece Jessica Markowitz. She was a loving sister who cherished her family. Funeral service will be private. Donations can be made to Capital Health Hospital, One Capital Way, Pennington, NJ 08534.

SIVE--David. 1922-2014. A Brooklyn boy who discovered rambling along Catskill and Adirondack trails, David launched the Sierra Club's Atlantic Chapter and nurtured nature conservation evolving to become environmental law. A consummate litigator, he fashioned remedies to protect nature where none yet existed. His senior years he devoted to service as a Professor at Pace Law School but truly he was quietly a teacher to all of us throughout his life. Nicholas A. Robinson

GUTMAN--Walter H.,died on March 13, 2014 in Rye Brook, NY at the age of 93 years old. He was born in Vienna, Austria on February 3, 1921. Former husband of the late Ruth Gutman, father of John and Steven Gutman, brother of Lyla Weiss and Peter Gutman. Survived by grandsons Alex, Sam, Andrew, and Daniel. Walter was president and CEO of Lucky Star Undergarments founded by his father Theodore Guttmann. He was an avid skier until his late 80's and tennis player as a member of Fairview Country Club. Since Ruth was a travel agent, he travelled a great deal, even after her demise and later with Joan G. Toepfer. Walter served in the United States Army as a member of the medical corps. in the European-Mediterranean theater for over four years from 1942 to the end of 1945. Funeral service will be held at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY on Monday March 17th at 9:30am. Interment will follow the service at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY. No flowers, please.

MINTZ--Arlene, on March 13, 2014 of Cherry Hill, NJ. Wife of the late Nathan Mintz. Mother of Perry (Marcie) Mintz and Drs. Randy (Irene) Mintz. Grandmother of Evan, David and Eric. Graveside services are Sunday at 1:30pm at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. The family will return to the home of Perry and Marcie Mintz.

STERN--Dr. E. Mark, passed away peacefully on March 11, 2014. He was born in New York City on December 5, 1929. He was a distinguished clinical humanistic/existential psychologist; a pioneer in graduate level training in pastoral counseling; and author, co-author and editor of many books on the cross-fertilization of humanistic psychology and belief systems. For nearly 50 years, Dr. Stern, a board-certified clinical psychologist, was in private practice in New York City. He was also Professor Emeritus of the Graduate Faculty of Arts and Sciences of Iona College, New Rochelle; Editor Emeritus of the Journal of Pastoral Counseling and of VOICES: The Journal of the American Academy of Psychotherapists; and Founding Editor of the Psychotherapy Patient Monograph Series. Dr. Stern was Professor of Psychology and Philosophy at the Center for Humanistic Studies, Seton Hall University; Visiting Professor, The National Catholic University (Australia); Adjunct Professor of Psychology, Fordham University; and adjunct clinical supervisor, Ferkauf Graduate School of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Psychoanalysis. He was a Fellow of the American Psychological Association and the Association for Psychological Science and a Diplomat in Clinical Psychology of the American Board of Professional Psychology. Dr. Stern was a member of Psi Chi the National Honor Society in Psychology and Phi Delta Kappa, a professional fraternity in education. He served as a member of the Council of Representatives of the American Psychological Association as well as president of two divisions: the Psychology of Religion and Humanistic Psychology. This year he is receiving an award from the American Psychological Association for Lifetime Contributions to Humanistic Psychology. In his semi-retirement he was a member of the Dutchess County Mental Hygiene Commission and a member of the Executive Board of the Dutchess County Democratic Committee. Dr. Stern is survived by his wife Virginia Fraser Stern; children Sarah (Thomas) Crowell, Cailean (Darren) Press, and Cameron (Rebecca) Stern; and six beloved grandchildren. A memorial mass will be held in the chapel at St. Paul the Apostle, 415 W. 59th Street, 11am, Saturday, March 22. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Habitat for Humanity, Oxfam or Amnesty International would be appreciated.
HOWARD--Ellen. With deepest sadness we send our heartfelt sympathy and love to the Howard family for the untimely loss of Ellen. Priscilla and Stuart

HOWARD--Ellen. We will miss your incredible kindness and the softness you possessed. To Harriett, Morty, Marilyn, Steve, Lauren, Josh, Skylar, Regan and Midge, our hearts truly ache for your tremendous loss. We will keep Ellen's memory deep within our hearts. Love, Laurie, Joe, Alyson and Julian.

SWIRSKY--Sheldon, 82, of Cedarhurst, LI. Korean War Veteran, retired parole officer, former Nassau County Parole Commissioner. Survived by his wife of 58 years Linda (nee Wax), sons Michael and Robert (Steven Warner) and sister Irene Wolk. Funeral on Sunday at 11:30am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

O'NEILL--Grover, Jr. The O'Neill family deeply regrets and mourns the passing of beloved Grover O'Neill, Jr. on February 14, 2014 at the age of 91. Grover, known to his friends as Bill, was a graduate of St. Mark's School, Class of 1940, and a graduate of Harvard College, Class of 1944, where he was a goalie on the Varsity Hockey Team. He served in the United States Army, Field Artillery from 1943-46 and was a First Lieutenant. Mr. O'Neill was a successful businessman for more than half a century. He joined Meriwether Capital in 1982 and remained active through 2013. He was a Trustee of St. Barnabas Hospital from 1960-2012, and Chairman of its Board from 1991-97; and Director of the Arthur Emerton Orvis Foundation, Inc. since 1968, and its President from 1990-2012. Predeceased by his first wife Kathryn, Bill is survived by his loving family: wife Elizabeth; daughter Carol O'Neill (Carey Battersby); son Tim O'Neill (Donna); stepchildren Melinda Mackay (Richard Essebag), Michael Mackay (Meggan) and grandchildren William O'Neill, Eliza Sommerville (Gavin), Kate Tuthill (Andrew), James Wendell (Meredith Weinberg), Zoe Mackay, and Hannah Mackay, and two great-grandchildren, Marilyn and Cormac Sommerville, and his sister Catharine Heyes, brother George O'Neill (Abby) and eight nieces and nephews. The memorial service will be held on Friday, March 21, 2014, 11am at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave. at 71st St, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to St. Mark's School, 25 Marlborough Road, Southborough, MA, 01772, Attn: Dr. John C.
