UHL--Christopher. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Christopher Uhl, associated with The New York Times from July 15, 2010 until the present.

HOWARD--Ellen. We mourn the untimely loss of a bright, gentle, caring woman who fought a brave battle with cancer. Our deepest condolences to Morty, Harriett, Steve and Marilyn, Lauren and Josh, Regan and Skylar. Robin, Barry, Jack & Jennifer Rosenberg

JUDGE--Thomas B.,Jr., 83, died on Monday, March 10, at home. For the bulk of his career, Judge managed the AT&T venture capital portfolio for the AT&T Investment Management Corporation. He co-founded the Institutional Limited Partners Association, which has grown to a membership of over one hundred institutions. He had been a frequent speaker at private equity and pension fund conferences and seminars worldwide. He retired from AT&T in 1995, the same year he was inducted into the Private Equity Hall of Fame. He is also an honorary Kauffman Fellow and is designated as a "Venture Capital Great" by the National Venture Capital Association and The Harvard Business School. In his retirement, he continued his work in private equity as a consultant for JPMorgan and others, until very recently. Judge graduated from Pennsylvania State University and earned his MBA at Seton Hall University. He served in the US Army in the 1950s, and as Mayor of the Borough of Little Silver, New Jersey in the early 1970s. Judge is survived by his wife, Barbara, his friend Ellen Catlin, his sisters Jackie Seuffert and Connie Judge, his son Thomas B. Judge III of Shrewsbury, NJ, his daughters Lauren Bartkus and her husband Brian of Bedford, MA, Linda Ferrogine and her husband Jim of Shrewsbury, NJ, and Dana Farabaugh and her husband Jay of Sudbury, MA. He is also survived by his beloved 10 grandchildren, Taylor, Anne, Brooke, Jimmy, Tommy, Kate, Casey, David, Jill and Nick. Donations may be made to the Surf City Volunteer Fire Company & Emergency Medical Services at www.surfcityfire.org.

PHILLIPS--Vikki, of New York passed suddenly on March 11, 2014. Survived by devoted husband Peter Phillips, loving daughters Cheri Phillips and Vanessa Phillips, mother Augusta Scari, brother Dean Scari and sister-in-law Renee Phillips. Graduate of Lehman College (BA), NYU (MBA) and New York Law (JD). Tax director and manager in accounting firm and banking, petroleum, media and retail industries.

GAREY--Ira S.,81, died peacefully on March 10 at Casa de La Luz Hospice in Tucson, AZ. Beloved husband of Carol and devoted father of Joshua and Matthew; he leaves behind three brothers and three sisters and countless family and friends who he loved dearly and felt their love in return. He served honorably as a member of the US Army in Korea - followed by a distinguished career in publishing, which included his role as Publisher of Seventeen Magazine. Ira lived with Carol and their children in Westport, CT for over 30 years - he spent his work days impeccably dressed in Manhattan helping to champion the magazines he represented, while serving as a trusted colleague and mentor. A talented chef and gracious host, he and Carol resided over many dinner parties with family and friends, resulting in fond memories that will be cherished by all those involved. An avid athlete, coach, and devoted fan of the Yankees, Giants, Knicks, and in later years University of Arizona athletics, he was present for many stirring victories (and some agonizing defeats) in the Bronx, Meadowlands and at The Garden. He and Carol moved to Tucson in 2002 to enjoy a lifestyle in line with the relaxing pace of the Southwest. He was truly a great man who impacted many through his passion for life, selfless support of others and ability to find the good in all of us...he is gone, but will never be forgotten. Donations in his honor can be made supporting Multiple Myeloma research at: https://donate.cancer.org/ index.

KING--Dr. Lambert N.,beloved husband of Sharon B. King, devoted father of Martha Whitney King, brother to Dawn King and loyal friend to many, died at home on March 13, 2014. Dr. King, an internist, served as medical director of two prison health care systems: Cermack Hospital in Chicago and the Montefiore Rikers Island Health Services on Rikers Island in New York City. He was an expert on healthcare within the prison system and dedicated his life to improving and reforming that system throughout the United States. Through his work in landmark prison litigation in Illinois, Rhode Island, and Arizona, Dr. King defined and refined the role of the physician serving as appointed federal monitor to improve health care for prisoners. As the medical director successively of Montefiore Hospital and St. Vincent's Hospital, Dr. King protected patients and guided generations of medical students and residents. He established the St. Vincent's AIDS Treatment Center, the largest in New York City, and served on the New York State AIDS Advisory Council. At the time of his death, Dr. King was the director, Department of Medicine, Queens Hospital Center. He leaves a legacy of love in action and an empty space in many lives. He will be sorely missed.

FEIGEN--Robert S.,died peacefully at his home on March 12, 2014. The son of Joseph and Bella Feigen, Bob was a lifelong New Yorker who loved his city. A graduate of Brooklyn Tech, City College, and Brooklyn Law School, Bob served in the United States Army as a Corporal and US Army accountant during the Korean War, and practiced law in New York City for over 50 years. His practice recalled an era of the family lawyer who could solve any problem, and made house calls to loyal clients who depended on his counsel. He worked his entire life, from the age of 12 through retirement as an arbitrator. A great reader, Bob read two-three books a week. We recall a wonderfully kind and caring man who adored his family above all else. Whether travelling the world with Lois, his wife of 56 years and companion in adventure; shopping for food in far away specialty markets; squeezing fresh orange juice every morning for his children; or teaching his grandchildren to jump rope; Bob found the greatest pleasure in the simplest activities. He ran track as a boy and rediscovered his passion in his forties, running two New York City Mara- thons, the first at age 49 and the second after turning 50, each proudly under three and a half hours. Bob was known by all as having the most gorgeous operatic baritone. Always the first on the dance floor, he celebrated every joyful occasion with a song and a dance. Bob Feigen leaves behind his beloved wife, Lois Feigen; his children, Marc Feigen, Valerie Feigen; daughter-in-law, Sheri Feigen; son-in-law, Steven Eisman; five beloved grandchildren; his brother Bernard Feigen; and his "cousins-like-brothers" Irving Breitman and Martin Rosenberg. His family welcomes donations to the Michael J. Fox Parkinson's Foundation, in memory of Robert S. Feigen.

RUIZ--Dr. Oscar Jorge. August 30, 1926 - March, 4 2014. Oscar, a true Humanitarian who helped others in an extraordinary fashion, gently encouraged and supported all those in his life. His family here and those in Cuba seeking a new life in the US, his thousands of patients, and innumerable others came to know his love. A man of simple pleasures, his greatest joy was in being helpful. He will always be loved, remembered, and in our hearts.

BOMZE--Richard. March 11, 2014. Devoted husband of Diane, father of Dana, Jennifer, adored grandfather of Jordan, Avery, Haley and Noah, father-in-law of Scott and David. Former publisher of American Turf Monthly and Sports Reporter. Served two terms as President of the New York Thorougbred Horsemans Association. Owner/breeder of famed Fourstardave and Fourstars Allstar. Services on Sunday, 10am Parkside Memorial Chapel, Rego Park, NY. Donations to Belmont Child Care Association, Elmont, NY.

BAYER--Stephen, of Croton-on-Hudson, NY passed away on March 13 age 71. He lived his life and faced his illness with courage and grace. Beloved husband of Gale, proud father of Kim Bayer Olthoff (John Henry) and Jesse Bayer (Dori Kavanagh), grandfather to Ruby Aselya Bayer and John Stephen Bayer Olthoff, adored uncle and brother-in-law, son of the late Marge and Bryan Bayer. Family man, extraordinarily kind to all, Doo-Wop King and music man, nature boy and ocean lover, expert tickler, superb gardener, special friend to animals and world traveler. After a successful career in the advertising business including Doyle Dane Bernbach and Chiat Day, a mid- life career transition brought him to Phelps Hospice for l7 years where he became Director of Volunteer Services and developed the Complementary Care Program. His life will be celebrated Sunday, March 16 at 2:30pm at Riverside Chapel in Mount Vernon. Donations can be made to the Phelps Hospice Patient Care Fund, 701 N. Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591.

BERNSTEIN--Zachary. We mourn the loss of the beloved son and grandson of Deena and David Bernstein and Lila and Jeffrey Bernstein, our esteemed members, and send heartfelt sympathy to them. Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre

STERN--Dr. E. Mark, passed away peacefully on March 11, 2014. He was born in New York City on December 5, 1929. He was a distinguished clinical humanistic/existential psychologist; a pioneer in graduate level training in pastoral counseling; and author, co-author and editor of many books on the cross-fertilization of humanistic psychology and belief systems. For nearly 50 years, Dr. Stern, a board-certified clinical psychologist, was in private practice in New York City. He was also Professor Emeritus of the Graduate Faculty of Arts and Sciences of Iona College, New Rochelle; Editor Emeritus of the Journal of Pastoral Counseling and of VOICES: The Journal of the American Academy of Psychotherapists; and Founding Editor of the Psychotherapy Patient Monograph Series. Dr. Stern was Professor of Psychology and Philosophy at the Center for Humanistic Studies, Seton Hall University; Visiting Professor, The National Catholic University (Australia); Adjunct Professor of Psychology, Fordham University; and adjunct clinical supervisor, Ferkauf Graduate School of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Psychoanalysis. He was a Fellow of the American Psychological Association and the Association for Psychological Science and a Diplomat in Clinical Psychology of the American Board of Professional Psychology. Dr. Stern was a member of Psi Chi the National Honor Society in Psychology and Phi Delta Kappa, a professional fraternity in education. He served as a member of the Council of Representatives of the American Psychological Association as well as president of two divisions: the Psychology of Religion and Humanistic Psychology. This year he is receiving an award from the American Psychological Association for Lifetime Contributions to Humanistic Psychology. In his semi-retirement he was a member of the Dutchess County Mental Hygiene Commission and a member of the Executive Board of the Dutchess County Democratic Committee. Dr. Stern is survived by his wife Virginia Fraser Stern; children Sarah (Thomas) Crowell, Cailean (Darren) Press, and Cameron (Rebecca) Stern; and six beloved grandchildren. A memorial mass will be held in the chapel at St. Paul the Apostle, 415 W. 59th Street, 11am, Saturday, March 22. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Habitat for Humanity, Oxfam or Amnesty International would be appreciated.
SPINELLI--Michael A. Left us on March 15, 2013 Wonderful son, gentleman, scholar. Loved and missed by all. The Spinelli Family
UNTERMAN--Roslyn Eisen. With love Mom on your 100th Birthday. Your daughter, Judith

WILLIAMSON--Laura Maria DeMyer, passed away peacefully at home in New York City on March 7, 2014. Born March 15, 1954, she was the eldest daughter of the late William F. DeMyer, a career U.S. Foreign Service officer, and Pacita Panganiban DeMyer, of Manila, Philippines. After graduating from Loyola Marymount University in 1974, she joined the U.S. Foreign Service as a consular officer in Tehran, Iran. She returned to graduate school, earning an M.A. from Georgetown University, and embarked upon a career in the financial services industry that included early positions at Irving Trust Company in New York and National Bank of Abu Dhabi in Abu Dhabi, U.A.E. She then joined Citibank, where she spent the bulk of her career before taking senior positions at J.P. Morgan Chase and Deutsche Bank. Laura believed strongly in the importance of education and was a dedicated member of the Advisory Board of the Bellarmine College of Liberal Arts at Loyola Marymount University, as well as a member of the Board of Trustees of the University. She is survived by Steven, her husband of 34 years, her sons Michael and Andrew, her mother Pacita DeMyer, her siblings William DeMyer, J. Paul DeMyer, Clare Marsch, and Marianna DeMyer and their families. A memorial mass will be offered at 2:00pm on Saturday, March 15th, at St. Catherine of Siena Church, 411 East 68th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in memory of Laura DeMyer Williamson to the Bellarmine College Student Scholarship Fund at Loyola Marymount University. Donations may be made to Loyola Marymount University and sent to Alma Vorst, Development Services, Loyola Marymount University, University Hall Suite 2800, Los Angeles, CA 90045-2659.

MARKOWITZ BROWN--Beth, 63, passed away on March 8, 2014. She spent her entire adult life in New York City. She graduated from the University of Miami and worked in the financial and legal industries in New York. She was the daughter of the late Joseph Markowitz and the late Lenore Adleman. She was the step-daughter of the late, Stanley Adleman. She is survived by her step-mother, Mary Rose Markowitz, her sister and brother-in-law, Judith and Simon Srybnik, her brother and sister-in-law, Joshua and Stacey Markowitz, and her beloved niece Jessica Markowitz. She was a loving sister who cherished her family. Funeral service will be private. Donations can be made to Capital Health Hospital, One Capital Way, Pennington, NJ 08534.

DURAZZO--Donatella. The Towbin family mourns the passing of their loving friend, Donatella Durazzo, who left us on March 11, 2014. She leaves her loving daughter, Zoe, and son Christopher, and their children Cecilia, Bettina, Charles and Olivia with whom she shared her devotion to art and her career as Docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where she worked for more than 25 years. Her friends and relatives in England, Italy and France, where she had divided her time for many years, will miss her. A wake will be held at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, New York, NY, on Friday, March 21st from 2:00pm to 5:00pm, and 7:00pm to 9:00pm. A Memorial Funeral Service will be held on Saturday, March 22nd at 10:00am, at St. Joseph's Church Yorkville, 404 East 87th Street, New York, NY.

GARRETT--Robert. With deep sadness we share the death of Robert Garrett on March 12th. He was born on February 27, 1937, in Baltimore, MD, the son of the late Grace and Harrison Garrett. He was a graduate of Gilman School in Baltimore, and then went on to Princeton University and served in the U.S. Army in Germany as a First Lieutenant for three years before attending Harvard Business School. He moved to New York to pursue a long and distinguished career in investment banking and corporate board directorships. At the time of his death, he was a Founding Partner of Media Advisory Partners. He was also serving as a Board Member for the New York Botanical Garden, the Cleveland H. Dodge Foundation, the A. S. Abell Foundation, Board treasurer of the Adirondack Council, Chairman of the Robert Garrett Fund for the Surgical Treatment of Children at Johns Hopkins Hospital, Chairman of the Advisory Council for the Near Eastern Studies Department at Princeton University, and until recently, Chairman of the Board of Penn Virginia Corporation. Hiking and canoeing in his beloved Adirondacks brought him special joy throughout his life. Above all he cherished his wife Jacquie of 48 years, sons Robert and Johnson, daughter-in-law Jennifer and four grandchildren to whom he was their adored "Papa". All who knew him considered him to be a towering figure physically as well as in intellect, achievement, curiosity, and kindness to others. Above all, he was a true gentleman. A memorial service will be held at 4pm on Wednesday, March 26th, at St. James Church, located at 71st and Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made either to NYU Langone Medical Center, Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery or to the New York Botanical Garden.

GARRETT--Robert. The Board of Directors of the Cleveland H. Dodge Foundation mourns the loss of our beloved cousin, colleague and friend. A stalwart member of our board for over 33 years, Rob added thoughtful insight to our work supporting many worthy institutions in New York City and around the world. A commanding presence in every way, each of us will forever celebrate his memory, but his wisdom, friendship and humor will be greatly missed. We are a better organization because of him. Our love and thoughts are with Jacquie, the boys and their families. William Dodge Rueckert, President

MILLER--Robert Jackson III. Miller & Wright Architects mourns the death of Founding Partner, Robert Jackson Miller III. His passion for architecture, contemporary and historic, led to designs of award-winning homes, clubs, churches, schools, and libraries. He studied architecture at the University of Virginia and Princeton. Prior to M&W, he worked for Robert A.M. Stern and was the partner-in-charge of the New York office of Michael Graves & Associates. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Grace, and daughters, Eve, Margot, Lily b., and Poppy, sisters, brother, mother and father.

SIVE--David. The Board and Staff of NRDC mourn the passing of our cherished friend and honorary trustee, David Sive. David, a World War II Veteran, was a founding father of American environmental law and founding member of NRDC's board. He committed his life and career to protecting our air, water, communities and wild places. His passion for justice was only matched by his generosity of spirit. Our deepest sympathies go out to his beloved wife Mary, his children and grandchildren and all of those who have had the honor to call him an ally, mentor, teacher and friend. Daniel R. Tishman, Chairman; Frances G. Beinecke, President; John H. Adams, Founding Director; Peter Lehner, Executive Director
FALICK--Charles. October 21, 1925- March 15, 2012. In memory of my husband Charlie. A special man. Resilient, brave, loved & missed. Evelyn

AUGUSTSON--Clifford, 96, of Emerson, NJ, died on Thursday, March 13, 2014. Before retiring, Cliff was noted for his work as an animator. He was an animator for Terry Toons, Famous Studios and Hanna Barberra. He spent close to five years in the Army Signal Corps during WWII. Clifford is survived by his wife Jacqueline, his son Jean, his daughter-in-law Sharyn and his granddaughter Meghan. He is predeceased by his first wife Millie, and his son Jan. Donations may be made to the environmental organization, Bergen Swan, P.O. Box 217, Westwood, NJ 07675. becker-funeralhome.com
Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 15, 2014.
The conductor Gustavo Dudamel and composer John Adams discuss their collaboration on the oratorio “The Gospel According to the Other Mary.”
Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the conductor Gustavo Dudamel and the composer John Adams.
Part 2: The composer and conductor recall the origins of their collaborative relationship.
Part 3: John Adams explains how classical music can elevate a conventional story to relevance and even timelessness.
Part 4: The composer and conductor talk about how “The Gospel According to the Other Mary” evolved over several performances.
Part 5: The composer and conductor discuss Adams’ tendency to compose music that deliberately offsets the slickness and skill of the musicians performing it.
Part 6: John Adams talks about the vocalists and dancers who perform in the staged version of “The Gospel According to the Other Mary.”
Part 7: The composer and conductor discuss the passage from “Gospel” that incorporates the Primo Levi poem “Passover.”
Part 8: Gustavo Dudamel explains the impact that Venezuela’s “El Sistema” program had on him, and talks about the program’s continuing impact on the world of classical music.
Part 9: John Adams talks about composing for chorus and explains how “The Gospel According to the Other Mary” was influenced by current events.
Part 10: Gustavo Dudamel reflects on the political situation and street protests in Venezuela.
Part 11: John Adams recalls writing the final scene of “The Gospel According to the Other Mary.”

WALDMAN--Edward A. March 13, 2013 One year feels like forever. I miss you so much. Love you always, Your wife Hilda, son Larry and Family

TIME FOR BED, FRED! Written and illustrated by Yasmeen Ismail. 32 pp. Walker/Bloomsbury. $14.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5) 
 
Ismail, a British illustrator with a background in animation, uses bright, beautiful brush strokes of watercolor to convey the manic, tail-wagging, mud-spattering energy that Fred, a furry black mop of a dog, brings to bedtime. Though Fred is the center of attention, Ismail adds just the right amount of decorative intensity to his surroundings: Look out for the cleverly appropriate book titles (“Woof,” “A Shaggy Tale”) that at last persuade this exuberant puppy to settle down for a story.

WALKER--Kenneth Brian. Your tender caress, soft voice, and caring words are missed daily. As you continue to transform our lives, know we miss you but understand the universe moves us all. You changed us for good through your grace. With Love and Gratitude, Your husband David, Family and Friends

STERN--Dr. E. Mark, passed away peacefully on March 11, 2014. He was born in New York City on December 5, 1929. He was a distinguished clinical humanistic/existential psychologist; a pioneer in graduate level training in pastoral counseling; and author, co-author and editor of many books on the cross-fertilization of humanistic psychology and belief systems. For nearly 50 years, Dr. Stern, a board-certified clinical psychologist, was in private practice in New York City. He was also Professor Emeritus of the Graduate Faculty of Arts and Sciences of Iona College, New Rochelle; Editor Emeritus of the Journal of Pastoral Counseling and of VOICES: The Journal of the American Academy of Psychotherapists; and Founding Editor of the Psychotherapy Patient Monograph Series. Dr. Stern was Professor of Psychology and Philosophy at the Center for Humanistic Studies, Seton Hall University; Visiting Professor, The National Catholic University (Australia); Adjunct Professor of Psychology, Fordham University; and adjunct clinical supervisor, Ferkauf Graduate School of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Psychoanalysis. He was a Fellow of the American Psychological Association and the Association for Psychological Science and a Diplomat in Clinical Psychology of the American Board of Professional Psychology. Dr. Stern was a member of Psi Chi the National Honor Society in Psychology and Phi Delta Kappa, a professional fraternity in education. He served as a member of the Council of Representatives of the American Psychological Association as well as president of two divisions: the Psychology of Religion and Humanistic Psychology. This year he is receiving an award from the American Psychological Association for Lifetime Contributions to Humanistic Psychology. In his semi-retirement he was a member of the Dutchess County Mental Hygiene Commission and a member of the Executive Board of the Dutchess County Democratic Committee. Dr. Stern is survived by his wife Virginia Fraser Stern; children Sarah (Thomas) Crowell, Cailean (Darren) Press, and Cameron (Rebecca) Stern; and six beloved grandchildren. A memorial mass will be held in the chapel at St. Paul the Apostle, 415 W. 59th Street, 11am, Saturday, March 22. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Habitat for Humanity, Oxfam or Amnesty International would be appreciated.
Schoenfeld--Mel 57/30 - 3/14/13 "I see you," I said/m. "I am here," you said. You still are. In my heart and mind. Loving you. Missing you. Every day. Your Aud

Tishman, Chairman; Frances G. Beinecke, President; John H. Adams, Founding Director; Peter Lehner, Executive Director

WILLIAMSON--Laura Maria DeMyer, passed away peacefully at home in New York City on March 7, 2014. Born March 15, 1954, she was the eldest daughter of the late William F. DeMyer, a career U.S. Foreign Service officer, and Pacita Panganiban DeMyer, of Manila, Philippines. After graduating from Loyola Marymount University in 1974, she joined the U.S. Foreign Service as a consular officer in Tehran, Iran. She returned to graduate school, earning an M.A. from Georgetown University, and embarked upon a career in the financial services industry that included early positions at Irving Trust Company in New York and National Bank of Abu Dhabi in Abu Dhabi, U.A.E. She then joined Citibank, where she spent the bulk of her career before taking senior positions at J.P. Morgan Chase and Deutsche Bank. Laura believed strongly in the importance of education and was a dedicated member of the Advisory Board of the Bellarmine College of Liberal Arts at Loyola Marymount University, as well as a member of the Board of Trustees of the University. She is survived by Steven, her husband of 34 years, her sons Michael and Andrew, her mother Pacita DeMyer, her siblings William DeMyer, J. Paul DeMyer, Clare Marsch, and Marianna DeMyer and their families. A memorial mass will be offered at 2:00pm on Saturday, March 15th, at St. Catherine of Siena Church, 411 East 68th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in memory of Laura DeMyer Williamson to the Bellarmine College Student Scholarship Fund at Loyola Marymount University. Donations may be made to Loyola Marymount University and sent to Alma Vorst, Development Services, Loyola Marymount University, University Hall Suite 2800, Los Angeles, CA 90045-2659.

ROSENBLOOM--Michael, Beloved husband of Caren for 38 wonderful years. Devoted son of Lillian and Bernard. Loving father of Brooke and Bradford and father-in-law to Jeremy. Cherished Poppy of Luke. Dedicated brother to Denise and Bob. Adored by nephew Marc, nieces Abby and Lauren and their children Jacquelyn, Jeremy and Lexie. Michael was a graduate of Tulane University and had a successful career in Real Estate. His happiest times were when surrounded by family and friends. He will be missed tremendously but will remain in our hearts forever.

ROSEN--Rita Rita Rosen, of New Rochelle, NY passed away on Saturday, March 8, 2014. She is survived by her loving children Phyllis Hadley and Michael Rosen, her sons-in-law Richard Hadley and Robert Landes, her daughter-in-law Stephanie Rosen and her adoring grandchildren: Brett Raskin, Shaun and Weston Deutschlander, Matthew, Alexandra and Jacqueline Landes, Alec, Kayla and Sierra Rosen. Sadly Rita was predeceased by her daughter Wendy Landes on March 14, 2013 and her beloved husband Philip on January 19, 2014. Born in Pittsburgh, PA. to Anne and Max Pochapin, Rita excelled in the theatre arts. After receiving the Best Actress Award from Great Neck High School, Rita went on to study with Sanford Meisner, Martha Graham and Lee Strassberg at the Neighborhood Playhouse. Upon graduation she was invited by Rabbi Steven Wise to dramatize "Behold The Jew", the plight for a Jewish National Homeland, at The World Jewish Congress. This became the platform for her life of volunteerism. She created "Theatre for a Cause", which presented dramatizations in support of civic, philanthropic and humanitarian causes. Guidance Center, UJA, National Conference of Christians and Jews, Union of American Hebrew Congregations, United Way, New Rochelle Hospital, American Jewish Committee, Family Service of Westchester, Jewish Braille Institute and Temple Israel of New Rochelle, were among the organizations Rita and Philip supported. Highlights: In 1973 Rita and Rabbi Amiel Wohl of Temple Israel, began broadcasting a radio program for High Holy Days and Sabbaths to those who could not physically attend worship services. That program continues, bringing comfort to the homebound of all faiths. Rita and Philip devoted a large portion of their time and energy to The Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Rita used her talents to create over 20 films, telling the college of medicine's story and highlighting the importance of medical research. Rita became a member of the Board of Overseers in 1983. In 2000 Rita received an Honorary Doctorate from Yeshiva University. In 2005 The Women's Division honored her with its highest accolade, The Lizette H. Sarnoff Award for Volunteer Service. Along with Philip, Einstein bestowed upon them their Humanitarian and Lifetime Achievement Awards. Rita fell in love with and married Philip Rosen in 1947. They built their home and raised their family on the shores of the Long Island Sound in New Rochelle, NY where they lived until this day. As important as her volunteerism became, nothing was more important to Rita than her family. The tradition of her holiday dinners with children, grandchildren, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends were legendary, spanning more than three generations. Rita was a strong, loving and fiercely dedicated matriarch. She celebrated life to the fullest, savoring each moment, turning every occasion into something special. She will be greatly missed. Rita was truly "a woman of valor". A memorial celebration of her life will be scheduled in the spring. Donations in memory of Rita should be made to Temple Israel, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, NY 10804 or to "The Wendy Walk" www.wendywalk.com

SIEMENS--Mark A.,53, of Bronxville, NY, died Wednesday, March 5, 2014 at his home from natural causes. Mark was born in Boston, MA to Robert W. and Estelle V. Siemens. The youngest of three children, Mark graduated from Wheaton College in 1982, with a BS in Chemistry. After taking his first job in San Antonio, TX, Mark relocated back to Albany, NY and attended Albany Law School from where he graduated in 1991. Mark was employed at Shearman & Sterling, LLP as Associate Council in the Anti-Trust & Litigation departments immediately after his graduation. Later, he moved to Siemens Corporation where he rose to Senior Council with responsibility for M&A activity and counseling on a wide range of matters related to marketing, distribution and strategic alliances. He retired several years ago and married his long-term partner, Matthew J. Crawford, on September 19, 2011. In retirement Mark devoted his time to small business endeavors and social justice matters, particularly in the area of equality. He was a member of the American Bar Association, the New York State Bar Association, and the New York City Bar Association and served as an advisor to several alumni and bar association boards. Admissions include: New York, Massachusetts (retired), Eastern District of New York and Southern District of New York. Preceding Mark in death was his spouse, Matthew, and his mother, Estelle. Survivors include his father, Dr. Robert W. Siemens of Loudonville, NY; sister, Karen E. Messier of Sand Lake, NY, brother, David R. Siemens of Omaha, NE; nieces and nephews, Eric and Cody Messier, Kimberly Ralph, Rebecca Perry and Scott Siemens; and great nieces and nephews, Madison and Harper Perry, Clay Siemens and Caleb Ralph. Memorial service will be Friday, March 21, 2014, 11am at Christ Church Bronxville, 17 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, NY 10708. Relatives and friends are also invited to a light reception at the church immediately following the service. A private interment with family will be conducted separately. Donations may be made to: "Equality and Justice Scholarship Fund", Albany Law School, c/o Development Office, 80 New Scotland Avenue, Albany, NY 12208 or "Lawyer Assistance Program" NYSBA Lawyer Assistance Program, One Elk Street, Albany, NY 12207. (Note: contributions to LAP are not tax-deductible).

FALICK--Charles. October 21, 1925- March 15, 2012. In memory of my husband Charlie. A special man. Resilient, brave, loved & missed. Evelyn

PFAFF--William W.,M.D., died on March 6, 2014. He was married to Patricia Ann Clark Pfaff for 53 years. He was best known for his experience in organ transplantation, performing the first successful kidney transplant in Florida in 1966. He was on the faculty at University of Florida for over 30 years. He was an incredible man who touched the lives of many, and will be greatly missed. Services will be private.

WEATHERLEY--John Swan. In Memory of John Swan Weatherley. April 15, 1951 March 5, 2014, Age 62, passed away peacefully at his home in New Canaan, Connecticut, on March 5, 2014. Formerly a resident of Ridgefield, Connecticut for 23 years, John was a devoted husband, father, and grandfather. Born in 1951 in Greenwich, Connecticut, John is survived by his wife, Susan Weatherley. He leaves his children James Simpson, Jebb Atkinson, Zoe Smith and Noel Miller along with five grandchildren and three sisters. His parents, now deceased, were Jack and Ruth Weatherley of Bridgewater, Connecticut. John graduated Dartmouth College where he received a B.A. Magna Cum Laude with Distinction in Anthropology. A life-long learner, John continued his studies at Princeton University where he attended graduate school and earned a M.S. in Anthropology. John was a Fulbright Scholar and a member of the Phi Beta Kappa Fraternity. His interests included the study of cultures, which led him to France where he attended the Universite Paris Sorbonne and the Ecole des Hautes Etudes. From 1978 to 1989, he was owner of Weatherley Building Company in Princeton, New Jersey. John went on to serve as Managing Owner of Berwick Land Corporation of New York from 1989 to 2006. For more than 40 years, John served as an active member of The Gurdjieff Foundation of New York. Aside from his service to others, friends will remember John's generosity and his spirit for life, and his love of nature and the arts. As a couple, John and Susan enjoyed traveling and spent much of their time in Nantucket, Massachusetts and Rockport, Maine. In celebration of John's life, a memorial service is planned for the spring. Charitable contributions may be made under John's name to: Doctors Without Borders, 333 7th Avenue, 2nd Floor New York, NY 10001-5004; (212) 679-6800 or Coastal Mountains Land Trust, 101 Mt Battie St, Camden, ME 04843 : (207) 236-7091

SMILOWITZ--Herbert. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Herbert Smilowitz, Vice Chairman of the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) who with his beloved wife Marilyn was a Yeshiva University Benefactor. Herbert Smilowitz was a humble giant whose modesty belied the major leadership role he played on behalf of Congregation AABJ&D of West Orange, NJ where he was Chairman of the Board and with his wife dedicated the Beit Midrash. He served as President of the Jewish Education Center of Elizabeth and Chairman of the Boards of the several Jewish day schools in NJ. At Yeshiva University/RIETS he received the Heritage Award in 1987 and then its highest award, the Eitz Chaim Award, in 2002. Together with his son Rabbi Mark Smilowitz of Beit Shemesh, Israel, he received the Inaugural Father/Son Israel America Award in 2008. He was a kind, compassionate, devoted husband and father whose family follows in his noble ways as active leaders in their respective communities. He was an active leader in the New Jersey MetroWest Federation among his other roles to strengthen Jewish life in America and Israel. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Marilyn, his sister, Dr. Rita Newman, and children, Rabbi Mark and Michelle Smilowitz, Gloria and Dr. Bruce Mosenkis, Rachel and Dr. Howard Neiman and fourteen grandchildren and a great- grandchild. May the entire family be comforted among all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

MILLER--Robert Jackson III. Miller & Wright Architects mourns the death of Founding Partner, Robert Jackson Miller III. His passion for architecture, contemporary and historic, led to designs of award-winning homes, clubs, churches, schools, and libraries. He studied architecture at the University of Virginia and Princeton. Prior to M&W, he worked for Robert A.M. Stern and was the partner-in-charge of the New York office of Michael Graves & Associates. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Grace, and daughters, Eve, Margot, Lily b., and Poppy, sisters, brother, mother and father.

PORTER--Shirley Robinson, (nee Plume), 93, of New York City, passed away February 23, 2014. Born September 16th, 1920 in Orange, NJ to William F. Plume and Grace Fairchild Plume, Shirley graduated from the renowned Northfield School for Girls, class of 1939. During WWII, Shirley worked in the Curtis Wright aircraft factory, then served with the Red Cross at Pilgrim State Hospital, treating shell shock victims. Shirley was married to Jack Burner Porter on April 13th, 1950 and three years later their son, William B. Porter was born. Her career achievements include: Assistant to Andrew Cordier, Dean of Columbia University and The School of International Affairs, Executive Secretary to labor mediator Theodore Kheel, and Executive Secretary to the President of The Commonwealth Fund. In the 1990s she worked with pioneering ethnomusicologist and explorer Laura Boulton, and later became President of the Laura Boulton Foundation. She was an active advocate for the Ketcham Inn Foundation. Shirley was predeceased by her sister Elizabeth Riggs but is survived by her son, her brother William F. Plume Jr., seven nieces and nephews, 11 great nieces and nephews and eight great-great-nieces and nephews.

NICOTRA--Frank Joseph, formerly of Pelham Manor, died on March 12, 2014, in Minneapolis, MN. He was 87. Frank was the proud son of Italian immigrants, Giovanni and Sebastiana (Arcidiacono) Nicotra and was born December 16, 1927. He is preceded in death by his wife Ruth Nicotra and his daughter Linda Ann Kinsman. A Veteran of WW II, Frank later received his degree in engineering from City College and an MBA from NYU. His professional career included the Department of the Navy, Turner Construction, CBS, and many productive years at Rockefeller Center. Frank had a wide range of interests including travel, the stock market, opera and loved animals. He was a terrific dancer, a patient chauffeur to his wife and family, and a doting husband, father and grandfather. Frank believed the true measure of a man was the ability to weather adversity, and he faced his challenging last years with dignity and humor. He is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, John and Lisa Nicotra of Minneapolis; his granddaughters, Kimberly and Victoria; and son-in-law Eddie Kinsman of Ridgefield, CT. He will be greatly missed. Visiting hours will be held at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave., Pelham, NY on Tuesday, March 18th between 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The Funeral Mass will be held at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Pelham Manor, NY, 10:30am on Wednesday, Mar-ch 19th with interment to follow at St. Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx. Memorials: Doctors without Borders and North Shore Animal League.

RUIZ--Dr. Oscar Jorge. August 30, 1926 - March, 4 2014. Oscar, a true Humanitarian who helped others in an extraordinary fashion, gently encouraged and supported all those in his life. His family here and those in Cuba seeking a new life in the US, his thousands of patients, and innumerable others came to know his love. A man of simple pleasures, his greatest joy was in being helpful. He will always be loved, remembered, and in our hearts.
BRAUNSTEIN--Irving. March 12, 1969. 45 years. A way back yonder and a long time ago. Very much missed. Always remembered.

ULLMAN--Richard H.,of Princeton, NJ, died on March 11, 2014. He was 80 years old. He was a distinguished scholar of International Affairs at Princeton University for over 40 years, ultimately as the David K. E. Bruce Professor of International Relations. He began his career at Harvard University and while on a sabbatical from Princeton was the George Eastman Visiting Professor at Oxford University, where he had received his D. Phil. and been a Rhodes Scholar. He educated generations of students and mentored many who guided United States foreign policy for both Democratic and Republican presidents. Through his own service in the administrations of two presidents, his time on The New York Times Editorial Board, his leadership of Foreign Policy Magazine as Director of Studies at the Council of Foreign Relations, and through his many books and articles, Dick made important contributions to the country's pressing foreign policy discussions over many decades. Dick is survived by his beloved wife Gail, two children, two step-children, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a time to be announced over coming weeks.

ZABRISKIE--John L.,Jr., died peacefully at home on March 13, 2014 from throat cancer. John was born on June 8, 1939 in Auburn, New York, the descendent of Albrecht Zabriskie who settled in New Amsterdam circa 1660. He was the son of John Zabriskie and Edith Virginia Seldomridge. He was the stepson of Leslie Weed and Adolf Gronningsater. Beloved husband to Adelaide Zabriskie for 40 years, John was known for being a devoted family man who enjoyed spending as much time as possible with his children, Regina Cannon, Marie Layton (Wade), Tina Constable (Rob) and Lance Zabriskie (Adrienne). Over the years, the annual family ski vacations were a great source of pleasure to him particularly as his grandchildren were born and started skiing. He was often seen on the Snowmass trails with his grandchildren, Emma Layton, Spencer Constable, Max Cannon, Mia Layton, Tyler Constable and Zach Zabriskie in tow following his beautiful form and flawless stem christie turns. If not on the ski slopes he could be found with Adelaide on their Colorado ranch with their horses, Fleur and Moneypenny. John was an accomplished business executive in the pharmaceutical and biotechnology industries. He was a graduate of Deerfield Academy and Dartmouth College. He received his PhD in organic chemistry from the University of Rochester. John was Co-Founder and General Partner of Puretech Ventures and Chairman of the Board, Chief Executive Officer and President of NEN Life Science Products, Inc. At NEN, Dr. Zabriskie led the successful turnaround and sale of the company in a transaction that generated a significant return for investors. Prior to joining NEN Life, Dr. Zabriskie was President and Chief Executive Officer of Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. As Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of Upjohn, Dr. Zabriskie led the Upjohn project, which resulted in the $12 billion merger of equals with Pharmacia Corporation. Prior to joining Upjohn in 1994, Dr. Zabriskie spent 27 years at Merck & Co., where he began as a chemist. He held a variety of positions in quality control, manufacturing, marketing, and executive leadership including President of Merck Frosst Canada, Inc., President of Merck Sharp & Dohme, President of Merck Manufacturing Division, and Executive Vice President of Merck and Co., Inc. Dr. Zabriskie served on the Board of Directors of Kellogg Company, Array Biopharma, ARCA Biopharma, and the privately-held PureTech Ventures. In addition to his wife, children and grandchildren, John is survived by his brothers Steve Zabriskie, Stan Zabriskie, Ken Zabriskie, Eric Gronningsater and his sister Randi Stroh. Our lives will be forever enriched by this kind, thoughtful spirit who we all loved so much. A funeral service will be held April 5, 2014 at 2pm at The First Congregational Church, 1128 Pine Street, in Boulder, CO. Interment will follow later for the family in Aurora, NY. Donations may be made to TRU Community Care, www.trucare.org (Boulder Hospice). Please visit www.greenwoodmyersfuneral.com to offer condolences.

RICHARDSON--Marie Balfe, of Fountain Hills, AZ, formerly of Akron, OH and Rye, NY. Died on March 12, she is survived by her husband James, five children and five grandchildren. The family recommends those who wish to make remembrances do so to the Alzheimer's Association.

SIVE--David. 1922-2014. A Brooklyn boy who discovered rambling along Catskill and Adirondack trails, David launched the Sierra Club's Atlantic Chapter and nurtured nature conservation evolving to become environmental law. A consummate litigator, he fashioned remedies to protect nature where none yet existed. His senior years he devoted to service as a Professor at Pace Law School but truly he was quietly a teacher to all of us throughout his life. Nicholas A. Robinson

GOODGOLD--Murray, MD. March 17th. Dearest Dad, It's hard to fathom that its been 18 heartbroken years. You were once here and we had a life and it went by in a flash. You were the back-bone of the family. Nobody loved you more than I did. You died tragically too young. I think about you every day of my life and will forever. Kaddish will now perpetually be recited in Jerusalem for you. Love, Iris

SWIRSKY--Sheldon, 82, of Cedarhurst, LI. Korean War Veteran, retired parole officer, former Nassau County Parole Commissioner. Survived by his wife of 58 years Linda (nee Wax), sons Michael and Robert (Steven Warner) and sister Irene Wolk. Funeral on Sunday at 11:30am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

FEIGEN--Robert S.,died peacefully at his home on March 12, 2014. The son of Joseph and Bella Feigen, Bob was a lifelong New Yorker who loved his city. A graduate of Brooklyn Tech, City College, and Brooklyn Law School, Bob served in the United States Army as a Corporal and US Army accountant during the Korean War, and practiced law in New York City for over 50 years. His practice recalled an era of the family lawyer who could solve any problem, and made house calls to loyal clients who depended on his counsel. He worked his entire life, from the age of 12 through retirement as an arbitrator. A great reader, Bob read two-three books a week. We recall a wonderfully kind and caring man who adored his family above all else. Whether travelling the world with Lois, his wife of 56 years and companion in adventure; shopping for food in far away specialty markets; squeezing fresh orange juice every morning for his children; or teaching his grandchildren to jump rope; Bob found the greatest pleasure in the simplest activities. He ran track as a boy and rediscovered his passion in his forties, running two New York City Mara- thons, the first at age 49 and the second after turning 50, each proudly under three and a half hours. Bob was known by all as having the most gorgeous operatic baritone. Always the first on the dance floor, he celebrated every joyful occasion with a song and a dance. Bob Feigen leaves behind his beloved wife, Lois Feigen; his children, Marc Feigen, Valerie Feigen; daughter-in-law, Sheri Feigen; son-in-law, Steven Eisman; five beloved grandchildren; his brother Bernard Feigen; and his "cousins-like-brothers" Irving Breitman and Martin Rosenberg. His family welcomes donations to the Michael J. Fox Parkinson's Foundation, in memory of Robert S. Feigen.

LEVY--Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Fred. Loving mother of Barbara (Alan) Klieger and Dr. Mark (Sharon) Levy. Devoted grandmother and proud great-grandmother. Former Principal at P.S. 195 in Brooklyn. Services today 12 Noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., (Ave. J). www.shermanschapel.com

EINSIDLER--Frederick Roy. Passed away on March 13, 2014 in Boca Raton, Florida. He is survived by his loving wife of 65 years, Mimi. He was a wonderful father and father-in-law to son Jon (Karen) Einsidler and Amy (Keith) Lewis, and adoring grandfather to Bobby, Laura, Billy, Teddy, Nina and Scott. Fred was born in New York City on June 7, 1925. At an early age, Fred developed a keen interest in a military career. An honor student at Stuyvesant High School, he received his appointment to West Point, where he graduated in 1945. He served as a tank commander during the occupation of Japan. Returning to the States in 1948, he received his Masters of Science degree at the University of Michigan. With the onset of the Korean War, Fred returned to the 1st Cavalry Division serving as an intelligence and reconnaissance platoon leader. His unit was at the Yalu River when the Chinese entered the war and where his subsequent actions earned him the Bronze Star Medal for bravery and a purple heart. Fred ended his military career in 1953 and joined AMF's General Engineering Division as an engineer heading up numerous ordinance projects. Not surprisingly, his energy, enthusiasm and talent led to a number of promotions while at AMF. In 1959, Fred became president of Consultants and Designers, Inc. He managed the company during a period of explosive growth. During Fred's stewardship the company expanded in a variety of businesses until the company was sold to Greyhound Corporation in 1972. Never shying away from a good challenge, Fred was named President and CEO of Butler International. During his 15 year tenure, subsequently as Chairman and CEO, Fred drove the company to new heights, becoming the 700th largest company on the NYSE. An indication of his success came when he was elected to President of the prestigious Wings Club in 1983. Fred served as a trustee and advisor to five universities and colleges, held numerous corporate directorships and was especially proud of being awarded Vaughn College of Aeronautics Honorary Doctor of Sciences in recognition of his contributions to the advancements of transportation. Fred was fond of saying "I feel indebted to West Point for molding me when I was young and for helping me maintain my ideals throughout my lifetime." For all who knew him we can only say "well done". He will be greatly missed by his wife, children and their spouses, grandchildren and everyone who knew him. The funeral will be held graveside for family at Westchester Hills Cemetery. The family will sit shiva on March 23rd from 2pm to 8pm at Jon Einsidler's house, 93 Downey Drive, Tenafly, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to www.pcf.org

KING--Dr. Lambert N.,beloved husband of Sharon B. King, devoted father of Martha Whitney King, brother to Dawn King and loyal friend to many, died at home on March 13, 2014. Dr. King, an internist, served as medical director of two prison health care systems: Cermack Hospital in Chicago and the Montefiore Rikers Island Health Services on Rikers Island in New York City. He was an expert on healthcare within the prison system and dedicated his life to improving and reforming that system throughout the United States. Through his work in landmark prison litigation in Illinois, Rhode Island, and Arizona, Dr. King defined and refined the role of the physician serving as appointed federal monitor to improve health care for prisoners. As the medical director successively of Montefiore Hospital and St. Vincent's Hospital, Dr. King protected patients and guided generations of medical students and residents. He established the St. Vincent's AIDS Treatment Center, the largest in New York City, and served on the New York State AIDS Advisory Council. At the time of his death, Dr. King was the director, Department of Medicine, Queens Hospital Center. He leaves a legacy of love in action and an empty space in many lives. He will be sorely missed.

KING--Lambert ("Bert"). The entire Montefiore community mourns the loss of our friend and colleague Bert King, MD. Bert held a variety of senior leadership positions at Montefiore, including pioneering the Montefiore Rikers Island Health Service where he set the stage for that program's leadership role in curtailing and treating the HIV-TB epidemic. Bert went on to a fabled role in medical leadership at private and public hospitals where he always championed social justice and access to healthcare. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Sharon and their daughter Martha. Steven M. Safyer, MD President & CEO, Montefiore

GARRETT--Robert. The Board and staff of The New York Botanical Garden are deeply moved by the death of Robert Garrett, a wonderful friend and a dedicated member of the Garden's Board for 27 years. A gentleman of the old school, Rob was also very modern in his vision for the wise management of the Garden's endowment during the years of his chairmanship of the Investment Committee. And he was enlightened in his enthusiasm for earned income during the years of his chairmanship of the Budget Committee. His interest in children's education, especially in the Ruth Rea Howell Family Garden, named for his aunt, was also extremely helpful over many years. We will all miss this charming and gracious colleague, and we offer our most heartfelt condolences to his wife Jacquie and his entire family. Maureen K. Chilton, Chairman Lionel Goldfrank III, Executive Committee Chairman Gregory Long, President

JUDGE--Thomas B.,Jr., 83, died on Monday, March 10, at home. For the bulk of his career, Judge managed the AT&T venture capital portfolio for the AT&T Investment Management Corporation. He co-founded the Institutional Limited Partners Association, which has grown to a membership of over one hundred institutions. He had been a frequent speaker at private equity and pension fund conferences and seminars worldwide. He retired from AT&T in 1995, the same year he was inducted into the Private Equity Hall of Fame. He is also an honorary Kauffman Fellow and is designated as a "Venture Capital Great" by the National Venture Capital Association and The Harvard Business School. In his retirement, he continued his work in private equity as a consultant for JPMorgan and others, until very recently. Judge graduated from Pennsylvania State University and earned his MBA at Seton Hall University. He served in the US Army in the 1950s, and as Mayor of the Borough of Little Silver, New Jersey in the early 1970s. Judge is survived by his wife, Barbara, his friend Ellen Catlin, his sisters Jackie Seuffert and Connie Judge, his son Thomas B. Judge III of Shrewsbury, NJ, his daughters Lauren Bartkus and her husband Brian of Bedford, MA, Linda Ferrogine and her husband Jim of Shrewsbury, NJ, and Dana Farabaugh and her husband Jay of Sudbury, MA. He is also survived by his beloved 10 grandchildren, Taylor, Anne, Brooke, Jimmy, Tommy, Kate, Casey, David, Jill and Nick. Donations may be made to the Surf City Volunteer Fire Company & Emergency Medical Services at www.surfcityfire.org.

KSZAN--Peter Joseph, 52, beloved husband of Laura Kszan (Cockburn) died March 6, 2014 at home in Manhattan. Born April 27, 1961 to Anne Kszan and the late Bernard Kszan in Port Colborne, Ontario. Dearly loved by his Baba, the late Mary Rawski. Survived by his sister Katherine Waterson (Ken) and family of Toronto, cousins Ann Loretan of Sheridan, WY, and Michael Loretan, aunt and uncle Wanda and John Loretan of Woodstock, IL, in-laws Joanne and John Cockburn of Barrie, Ontario, and brothers-in-law Blair Cockburn (Dawn) and Grant Cockburn and family. He is sorely missed by his constant companion Trixie. Memorial services at a later date.

DOUGLAS--Hal, age 89, of Lovettesville, VA died peacefully at his home in Virginia on March 7, 2014 with his wife and daughter by his side. Hal was known not only for his incomparable voice, which could be heard on thousands of movie trailers, television and radio promos, commercials, and documentaries, but also for his warmth, humility, humor, and generosity of spirit. Hal once said, "The real art is the art of life - the art of living." He exemplified this philosophy through his devotion to his family and friends, his love of nature and travel, his spirituality, and by sharing the fruits of his labor with those in need. He spent the last 15 years recording from his home studio at the horse farm he shared with his beloved wife, Ruth, in Northern Virginia. Hal was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in 2010, and thanks to his treatment at Johns Hopkins Hospital's Pancreatic Cancer Multidisciplinary Clinic and additional support from The Block Center for Integrative Cancer Treatment, he and his family were able to enjoy another four years of his exquisite life. Hal, who lives forever in the hearts of his family, will be dearly missed by his wife, Ruth, children Sarah, Jeremy, and Jon, and grandchildren Jordan, Jake, and Dylan. Donations "In memory of Hal Douglas" can be sent to Marie Jo Corry Johns Hopkins Medicine; 750 Pratt St. #

HERSHCOPF--Jack, accomplished metal trader, sculptor, and board member for the New York Gilbert and Sullivan players, passed on January 30th in good spirits and with love for family and country. He was buried with military honors. After retiring, Jack became an auxiliary police officer with the New York City Police Force on the Central Park beat. The last phase of his life in NYC he worked both as a docent for the Central Park Zoo and as an assistant for Channel 13. His beloved wife Berta died in 2002 and Jack moved from 875 Park Avenue to California in 2007. He is survived by his two daughters Sheli Nan- Tabachnik and Amy Levine, seven grandchildren: Azriel, Mateo, Aviva, Solomon, Samuel, Asher, Ariel, and two great-grandchildren, Roman and Gemma.

MATHEWS--Joan S.,of Hobe Sound, FL., formerly of Greenwich, CT. died peacefully at home on March 3, 2014. She is survived by her devoted family - sons, Anthony S. Hulme, and Stephen S. Mathews; daughters Lyn M. Perrin and Joan H. Perera; and 14 grandchildren, 33 greats, and many nieces and nephews. Donations may be sent to The Boys and Girls Club of Greenwich or The Goodspeed Opera House, East Haddam, CT.

McADOO--Marguerite de Herczeg. Died peacefully in her home on March 11th, 2014. Miss McAdoo, known to her friends as Mimi, was born on May 26th, 1924 in Los Angeles to Molly Tackaberry and William McAdoo. Her grandfather was William Gibbs McAdoo, builder of the PATH Hudson tunnels, Secretary of the Treasury under President Woodrow Wilson and Senator for California. A graduate of the Hewitt School, Mimi was presented in New York in 1942. She worked at the French Institute, the Parsons School of Design and Brick Church. A long-term member of the Colony Club, Mimi served for many years on the Board of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service. Mimi loved opera and was a passionate Wagnerian. She was hospitable and loved to entertain. Mimi was gracious, considerate, generous and stoic, with impeccable manners in the deepest sense of the word. A remarkable lady, she will be missed by many. But as she always said, "the show must go on". Mimi is survived by her loving niece and nephew-in-law, Sarah Wheatland and David Abbott Fisher, and her loving great-niece and great-nephew, Thea and Otto Wheatland Fisher. Funeral services will be held at 11am on Tuesday, March 18th at St. James' Episcopal Church, Manhattan. After the service the family will be receiving visitors at her residence. A memorial celebration of her life will be held in the spring. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

DURAZZO--Donatella. The Towbin family mourns the passing of their loving friend, Donatella Durazzo, who left us on March 11, 2014. She leaves her loving daughter, Zoe, and son Christopher, and their children Cecilia, Bettina, Charles and Olivia with whom she shared her devotion to art and her career as Docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where she worked for more than 25 years. Her friends and relatives in England, Italy and France, where she had divided her time for many years, will miss her. A wake will be held at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, New York, NY, on Friday, March 21st from 2:00pm to 5:00pm, and 7:00pm to 9:00pm. A Memorial Funeral Service will be held on Saturday, March 22nd at 10:00am, at St. Joseph's Church Yorkville, 404 East 87th Street, New York, NY.

GARRETT--Robert. The Board of Directors of the Cleveland H. Dodge Foundation mourns the loss of our beloved cousin, colleague and friend. A stalwart member of our board for over 33 years, Rob added thoughtful insight to our work supporting many worthy institutions in New York City and around the world. A commanding presence in every way, each of us will forever celebrate his memory, but his wisdom, friendship and humor will be greatly missed. We are a better organization because of him. Our love and thoughts are with Jacquie, the boys and their families. William Dodge Rueckert, President

HANVEY--John P.,69, died suddenly on March 12, 2014. John was a true New Yorker living in Greenwich Village all of his life. Graduated high honors from LaSalle Academy in 1962 and received his Bachelor's Degree from Manhattan College in 1966. He was stationed at the Pentagon during the Vietnam War. His career in technology brought him to Smith Barney, Solomon Brothers and retired from Anderson Consulting in 2002. He is survived by his sister Barbara Sadowski of Lecanto, FL. His nephew Lenny Sadowski, wife Katie and their children, Patrick and Caitlin of Old Bridge, NJ. His nephew Rich Sadowski and wife Patti of Hopatcong, NJ. His niece Christine Sadowski of Hopatcong, NJ. Preceded in death by his mother Petronela, John was very recently preceded in death by his father John J. Hanvey. Funeral service will be Sunday, March 16, 2014 from 2-5pm at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC, 212-674-8055.
KING--Lambert, MD. With love for Bert's gentleness, intellect, off-beat investment choices and love of armadillos, we send our deep condolences to Sharon and Martha. Mary Jo & Gretchen

LAITMAN--Samuel "Sandy" H.,80 years old. Died March 13, 2014, at home in Williams- town, MA. Survivors include his son Andrew, his daughter Catherine Burke (William), his daughter Elizabeth Hughes (Michael), and three grandsons Paul, Eric and Nathaniel. His wife of 39 years Marilyn (Lynn) Laitman predeceased him. Born in Brooklyn, NY to Berdie and Edwin Laitman, he attended Poly Prep Country Day School. He graduated from Williams College in 1955, earning a degree in Political Science. He served as a Navigator-Bombardier in the USAF Strategic Air Command. After becoming a CPA he earned an MBA and both Bachelor's and Master's degrees of Law at NYU. He worked at the New York based law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges for 34 years, rising to become a Partner and Chair of its Trusts & Estates department. After retiring from his legal practice, he moved from Stamford, CT to Williamstown, MA. Throughout his long legal career Mr. Laitman served on many boards and charitable trusts. He served on the Board of Trustees of Low Heywood Thomas School, in Stamford, CT, on The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York Deferred Giving & Legal Committees, and on the Boards of The Williamstown Theatre Festival and The Williamstown Art Conservation Center. In 2012, he was awarded an honorary degree from MA College of Liberal Arts. In 2014, he was awarded a second honorary degree, a Doctorate of Humane Letters from Southern VT College. The family is planning a private burial service, with a later public memorial service in Williamstown.

GARRETT--Robert. With deep sadness we share the death of Robert Garrett on March 12th. He was born on February 27, 1937, in Baltimore, MD, the son of the late Grace and Harrison Garrett. He was a graduate of Gilman School in Baltimore, and then went on to Princeton University and served in the U.S. Army in Germany as a First Lieutenant for three years before attending Harvard Business School. He moved to New York to pursue a long and distinguished career in investment banking and corporate board directorships. At the time of his death, he was a Founding Partner of Media Advisory Partners. He was also serving as a Board Member for the New York Botanical Garden, the Cleveland H. Dodge Foundation, the A. S. Abell Foundation, Board treasurer of the Adirondack Council, Chairman of the Robert Garrett Fund for the Surgical Treatment of Children at Johns Hopkins Hospital, Chairman of the Advisory Council for the Near Eastern Studies Department at Princeton University, and until recently, Chairman of the Board of Penn Virginia Corporation. Hiking and canoeing in his beloved Adirondacks brought him special joy throughout his life. Above all he cherished his wife Jacquie of 48 years, sons Robert and Johnson, daughter-in-law Jennifer and four grandchildren to whom he was their adored "Papa". All who knew him considered him to be a towering figure physically as well as in intellect, achievement, curiosity, and kindness to others. Above all, he was a true gentleman. A memorial service will be held at 4pm on Wednesday, March 26th, at St. James Church, located at 71st and Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made either to NYU Langone Medical Center, Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery or to the New York Botanical Garden.

GARODNICK--Barbara Riotto, beloved teacher and talented visual artist, with a keen eye for beauty, passed away peacefully at home on March 14. An adventurous and independent spirit, Barbara brought joy, amusement, and a little mischief to everyone who knew her, inspiring them with her positive nature right to the end. She is survived by her husband, David, son Daniel, a member of the New York City Council, daughter-in-law Zoe who gave her grandsons Asher and Devin, and siblings Aileen and Anthony. We cannot imagine life without you and will love you forever. In lieu of flowers, family asks for donations to the Barbara Riotto Garodnick '61 Memorial Award at Brooklyn College, her alma mater, for a student with promise in the visual arts. Send c/o The Brooklyn College Fdn, 2900 Bedford Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11210.
KING--Lambert. Your joy and thrill in the game of golf was contagious, inspiring, and brought us together in lasting friendship. Keep it on the short grass. Your golf buddies

LEWIS--Samuel. Israel Policy Forum (IPF) mourns the passing of Ambassador Samuel W. Lewis, a revered public servant who served in many diplomatic and public positions, including U.S. Ambassador to Israel from 19771985. For IPF, and for all who knew him, Ambassador Lewis was a wise and sympathetic advisor, a man of enormous acuity and perspicacity, and a person who could discuss the weightiest issues with aplomb and balance. His very presence in a room elevated the quality of discussion and the motivation to reach solutions and proposals. Members of the IPF family feel that we have lost a critical figure at a crucial time.

FISHMAN--Irving, R.,96, of Manhattan passed away on March 6, 2014. Born in New York on July 17, 1918, he grew up in Bathgate and the South Bronx. He attended DeWitt Clinton High School, University of Wisconsin and Rutgers, ultimately earning a Masters Degree before serving as a Captain in World War II. After the War he spent time in Korea and Washington, DC working as an economist, before returning to New York to start the Knickerbocker Coffee Service. Memorial service at 4pm Sunday, March 16th at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel 353 Second Ave., New York, NY.

EHRLICH--George E.,MD, 85, of Philadelphia, PA on February 28, 2014. Internationally renowned rheumatologist, advisor to the World Health Organization, Professor of Medicine, pharmaceutical industry executive. Graduate of Harvard College (class of 1949) and Chicago Medical School. Commander, United States Navy. Cherished husband of Gail. Adored father and stepfather of Charles E. Ehrlich, Steven L. Abrams (Debbie), Rebecca A. Sayles (David). Treasured grandfather of Margaret, Julia, Arthur, and Nina. Devoted brother of Paul. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, March 30 at 2pm, Congregation Mikveh Israel, 44 N. 4th St., Phila., PA. Donations may be made to The Philadelphia Orchestra via www.philorch.org.

GAREY--Ira S.,81, died peacefully on March 10 at Casa de La Luz Hospice in Tucson, AZ. Beloved husband of Carol and devoted father of Joshua and Matthew; he leaves behind three brothers and three sisters and countless family and friends who he loved dearly and felt their love in return. He served honorably as a member of the US Army in Korea - followed by a distinguished career in publishing, which included his role as Publisher of Seventeen Magazine. Ira lived with Carol and their children in Westport, CT for over 30 years - he spent his work days impeccably dressed in Manhattan helping to champion the magazines he represented, while serving as a trusted colleague and mentor. A talented chef and gracious host, he and Carol resided over many dinner parties with family and friends, resulting in fond memories that will be cherished by all those involved. An avid athlete, coach, and devoted fan of the Yankees, Giants, Knicks, and in later years University of Arizona athletics, he was present for many stirring victories (and some agonizing defeats) in the Bronx, Meadowlands and at The Garden. He and Carol moved to Tucson in 2002 to enjoy a lifestyle in line with the relaxing pace of the Southwest. He was truly a great man who impacted many through his passion for life, selfless support of others and ability to find the good in all of us...he is gone, but will never be forgotten. Donations in his honor can be made supporting Multiple Myeloma research at: https://donate.cancer.org/ index.

AUGUSTSON--Clifford, 96, of Emerson, NJ, died on Thursday, March 13, 2014. Before retiring, Cliff was noted for his work as an animator. He was an animator for Terry Toons, Famous Studios and Hanna Barberra. He spent close to five years in the Army Signal Corps during WWII. Clifford is survived by his wife Jacqueline, his son Jean, his daughter-in-law Sharyn and his granddaughter Meghan. He is predeceased by his first wife Millie, and his son Jan. Donations may be made to the environmental organization, Bergen Swan, P.O. Box 217, Westwood, NJ 07675. becker-funeralhome.com

AUSTIN--Constance Agate, of Los Angeles and New York died at home with her family by her side. Daughter of the late Anita and Sandy Agate, widow of the late Bud Austin, companion to the late Harold Berkowitz, loving and devoted mother to Anita Dann Friedman and husband Harvey, Caroline Dann and partner Chase. Beloved grandmother to Adam and Jonathan Friedman, Emma and Liza Dann. Memorial in Los Angeles. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Barbra Streisand Women's Heart Center c/o C. Noel Bairey Merz, M.D. 127 S. San Vicente Blvd. Suite 3206, Los Angeles, CA 90048.

CORZINE--Jeffrey. The Child Mind Institute mourns the loss of Jeffrey Corzine, youngest son of our treasured friend Jon Corzine. Jeffrey was a gentle and caring man, a devoted son and brother, a cherished stepson, a gifted athlete and talented photographer, and a kind and generous friend. We send our sympathy to his mother Joanne and stepfather Harmon, his father Jon and stepmother Sharon, his sister Jennifer and brother-in-law David, his brother Josh and sister-in-law Amanda, and his extended family and many friends. He will be missed by all of us. Brooke Garber Neidich, Chair, Debra G. Perelman, Vice Chair, and Harold S. Koplewicz, MD, President, Child Mind Institute

CORZINE--Jeffrey. We mourn the loss of Jeffrey Corzine. He was a remarkably brave young man who cared deeply about his family, his friends and the world. Our thoughts and prayers are with Joanne and Harmon, Jon and Sharon and Jenny and Josh. Linda and Harold

CARTWRIGHT--Constance Bauerdorf, died peacefully in her home earlier this month. Born in New York City, she lived here all her life. An independent oil operator for 53 years, her real love was for the arts. A devotee of ballet, she worked with the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. A member of the Junior Council at the Museum of Modern Art, she later served on their International Council, and was Treasurer of the American Federation of Arts. Most recently, she was on the Visiting Committee to the Department of Modern and Contemporary Art and was a member of the Modern Art Collectors' Circle at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. A longtime member of The French Institute Alliance Francaise, she attended classes their up to her final days. Constance is survived by Carroll, her husband for 65 years, her daughter, Georgette, and her son, Carroll, son-in-law, Burgess Nichols, daughter-in-law, Laurie Traktman Cartwright, her grandchildren Constance Nelson and her husband John Nelson, Burgess Nichols and his wife Jessica Lambert, Sarah Blakely-Cartwright, and her great grandsons, Grant and William Nelson. Burial services are private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Animal Medical Center, 510 E. 62nd St., New York, NY 10065.

DECOSMO-CARROLL--Jacqueline, passed peacefully on March 6th, 2014. A life-long performer, Jacque graced many stages and graced life with honesty and caring for countless friends. A memorial service in New York City is planned.

CARR--Joel. The Saltaire Volunteer Fire Company notes with deep sadness the passing of its friend and longtime champion, former Mayor Joel Carr. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Catherine O'Brien, President James Rieger, Chief

CORGAN--Gregory W.,60, of Atlanta, GA, on March 9, 2014, after a 3.5 year heroic battle with lymphoma. A graduate of Notre Dame, Greg spent 24 years with IBM, served as President and CEO of One Chem, Ltd. and held a number of senior executive positions at CA Technologies, Open Text and Infor. He was a gifted leader and a true gentleman. His engaging personality, patience, sense of humor and optimism endeared him to everyone he met. Greg leaves his wife, Kathryn Manfredonia-Corgan, his children, Kevin, Chris and Kelley; his parents Warren and Betty Corgan; siblings Brian, Terry, Marybeth, Karen and Nancy, and 17 nieces and nephews. The family wishes to thank the wonderful staff of Emory University Hospital, most especially, Dr. H. Jean Khoury. Memorial contributions to advance special research should be made payable to: Emory University c/o Dept. of Hematology & Medical Oncology and sent c/o Corgan, 3325 Piedmont Rd, NE, Unit 1501, Atlanta, GA 30305.
CHIN--Hoy Hing, born March 17, 1950, died March 12, 2014, after a year-long fight with nasopharyngeal cancer. Service and donation information at http://gfwd.at/1fEDzti.

BORIS--William Robert "Bob," of Hingham, MA, died peacefully at his home on March 7, 2014. He was born on February 26, 1931 in Queens, NY and grew up in Howard Beach. For complete obituary and guest book, please visit: www.downingchapel.com
