WALSEY--Milton. I feel your love and guidance always. I cherish our memories. Love, Steven

ZWEIMAN--Anne Minsky, passed away on March 15, 2014. Cherished wife of the late David Zweiman, treasured mother of Jessica, Brett and Dara. Mother-in-law of Scott, Ha and Ryan. Beloved grandmother to Jackson and Violet. Loved to bits by siblings Mimi, Neci, and the late Mel Minsky. Adored by all Zweimans. Services Tuesday March 18th at 11:45am at "The Riverside." You are our heart.
BRECKIR--Albert Yale. Happy Birthday it's been 27 long years. We think of you often. Your Family

WALLEN--Grace, In memory of our special friend and neighbor, Grace Wallen. She will be dearly missed by our family. Our condolences to Robyn and Barry, Jill and Daniel, and all the family. Elly and Steve Hammerman
CHARLOP--Meg Felice . 5-13-52 - 3-17-10. We love you! We miss you! We celebrate your life! The Charlop-Powers Family

GOODGOLD--Murray, MD. March 17th. Dearest Dad, It's hard to fathom that its been 18 heartbroken years. You were once here and we had a life and it went by in a flash. You were the back-bone of the family. Nobody loved you more than I did. You died tragically too young. I think about you every day of my life and will forever. Kaddish will now perpetually be recited in Jerusalem for you. Love, Iris

WALKER--Kenneth Brian. Your tender caress, soft voice, and caring words are missed daily. As you continue to transform our lives, know we miss you but understand the universe moves us all. You changed us for good through your grace. With Love and Gratitude, Your husband David, Family and Friends

KORDA--Trudy,of Larchmont, NY, on March 16. Survived by her loving son Peter (Kim), granddaughter Sammi. She loved life and touched many. She will be truly missed. Funeral service Tuesday, March 18 at Riverside Memorial Chapel/Mt. Vernon (914) 664-6800. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Camphill Foundation, www.camphillfoundation.org or Autism Speaks.

PINE--Martin L.,on March 15, 2014. Beloved husband of Anne. Loving father of Lewis (Kathryn). Brother of Stephen and the late Carol. Dear Uncle of many nieces and nephews. He was a Professor of History, Queens College, CUNY, and a member of the Doctoral Faculty at the Graduate School and University Center, CUNY, as well as an author and lecturer. He held a BA from Columbia College, an MA in History and a PhD in History from Columbia University. Dr. Pine was the recipient of the Queens College President's Award for Excellence in Teaching and was awarded a Fullbright Fellowship for Study and Research in Italy. He was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. Services Tuesday, 1:15pm at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

OKIN--Anne R.,passed away peacefully at home on March 15, 2014. Born May 13, 1917, she grew up in the Bronx, and lived in Manhattan after her marriage, in 1940. After graduating Phi Beta Kappa from Hunter College, she taught English at Hunter High School in the 1950s. She received her law degree from NYU in 1958, and went into practice with her late husband, Louis. She took to heart the Phi Beta Kappa motto and was guided by it into old age: "The love of learning is the guide to life." She will be remembered with deep respect, admiration and, above all, love by her children, Elizabeth and Steven; their spouses, Jak Ninyo and Carolyn Okin; her five grandchildren, Adam and Jared Ninyo, and Michael, Rebecca, and Rachel Okin; and by many other family members and friends. The service is private. Donations may be made in Anne Okin's memory to Congregation Shearith Israel at 8 West 70th Street, New York, NY 10023.

McADOO--Marguerite de Herczeg. Died peacefully in her home on March 11th, 2014. Miss McAdoo, known to her friends as Mimi, was born on May 26th, 1924 in Los Angeles to Molly Tackaberry and William McAdoo. Her grandfather was William Gibbs McAdoo, builder of the PATH Hudson tunnels, Secretary of the Treasury under President Woodrow Wilson and Senator for California. A graduate of the Hewitt School, Mimi was presented in New York in 1942. She worked at the French Institute, the Parsons School of Design and Brick Church. A long-term member of the Colony Club, Mimi served for many years on the Board of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service. Mimi loved opera and was a passionate Wagnerian. She was hospitable and loved to entertain. Mimi was gracious, considerate, generous and stoic, with impeccable manners in the deepest sense of the word. A remarkable lady, she will be missed by many. But as she always said, "the show must go on". Mimi is survived by her loving niece and nephew-in-law, Sarah Wheatland and David Abbott Fisher, and her loving great-niece and great-nephew, Thea and Otto Wheatland Fisher. Funeral services will be held at 11am on Tuesday, March 18th at St. James' Episcopal Church, Manhattan. After the service the family will be receiving visitors at her residence. A memorial celebration of her life will be held in the spring. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Metropolitan Opera Guild.
GOLDMAN--Ruth F.,83, passed away March 9, of Delray Beach, FL and Westbury, NY. Loving mother of Michael, Susan, daughter-in-law Judy, and grandchildren Alex and Sonya.

LUCKMAN--Harvey, passed March 15, loving husband of Randi, cherished father to Brett and Jake. Friends to so many. His passion, kindness and incredible sense of humor will be missed forever. Service Tuesday, 10am The Riverside 76 and Amsterdam.
RAITT--Kathleen. Remembering our beautiful, determined, brave and just plain fun friend Kathy. Mickey & Bruce.

CORZINE--Jeffrey. We mourn the loss of Jeffrey Corzine. He was a remarkably brave young man who cared deeply about his family, his friends and the world. Our thoughts and prayers are with Joanne and Harmon, Jon and Sharon and Jenny and Josh. Linda and Harold

KSZAN--Peter Joseph, 52, beloved husband of Laura Kszan (Cockburn) died March 6, 2014 at home in Manhattan. Born April 27, 1961 to Anne Kszan and the late Bernard Kszan in Port Colborne, Ontario. Dearly loved by his Baba, the late Mary Rawski. Survived by his sister Katherine Waterson (Ken) and family of Toronto, cousins Ann Loretan of Sheridan, WY, and Michael Loretan, aunt and uncle Wanda and John Loretan of Woodstock, IL, in-laws Joanne and John Cockburn of Barrie, Ontario, and brothers-in-law Blair Cockburn (Dawn) and Grant Cockburn and family. He is sorely missed by his constant companion Trixie. Memorial services at a later date.

RAY--Herbert F.,age 88, of Boca Raton, Florida died March 15, 2014. Lucille Ray, his wife of 50 years, predeceased him. Survivors include his daughters and son-in-laws, Peggy Ray and Reggie Short, Liz and Steven Arkin, Ellen Ray and Billy Balser, and grandchildren: Rachel Short, Melissa and Josh Balser and Zachary and Sophie Arkin. Funeral services will be held March 18, 2014 at 3:00pm at Temple Beth El Mausoleum in Boca Raton, FL.

CORZINE--Jeffrey. The Child Mind Institute mourns the loss of Jeffrey Corzine, youngest son of our treasured friend Jon Corzine. Jeffrey was a gentle and caring man, a devoted son and brother, a cherished stepson, a gifted athlete and talented photographer, and a kind and generous friend. We send our sympathy to his mother Joanne and stepfather Harmon, his father Jon and stepmother Sharon, his sister Jennifer and brother-in-law David, his brother Josh and sister-in-law Amanda, and his extended family and many friends. He will be missed by all of us. Brooke Garber Neidich, Chair, Debra G. Perelman, Vice Chair, and Harold S. Koplewicz, MD, President, Child Mind Institute

DAVIDSON--Doreen, on March 14, 2014 at 50 years of age after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Gary Gold. Adored sister of Lawrence and Gary Davidson and cherished sister-in-law to Josie. Loving aunt to Andrew, Kristin and Dylan. Dear friend and colleague to many. Doreen was pre-deceased by her parents, Norman and Sally, who loved and adored her. She was a respected member of the publishing industry, where she worked for many years, most recently as an Associate Director of Academic and Library Marketing at Harper Collins Publishers. Everyone who had the privilege of knowing Doreen grew to love her. She was a generous, sensitive and funny woman who was beautiful inside and out. She will be missed beyond measure.
OKIN--Anne, Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her family. Louis M. Solomon, Parnas

RAITT--Kathleen, on Saturday, March 15, at home in Manhattan. Beautiful and adored daughter of Rosamond Landry Shelley of Houston, TX and the late John Smith. Beloved of sister-in-law Sue Riley and her children. Former wife of the late John Raitt. Dear friend of Carole, Patricia, Margo, Frank, Jackie, Susan, Charlotte, Lynne, Suzanne, and Mickey. Longtime and much loved member of the Nederlander Organization producing family, Kathleen's Broadway projects included The Scarlet Pimpernel, The Civil War, Bonnie & Clyde, The Molly Maguires, Grand Hotel and Legs Diamond. Love and gratitude to Evelyn and Visiting Nurse Services/New York, and to Nurse Professional Agency, Inc. At Kathy's request, no funeral or visiting. A party celebrating her life will be announced. Memorial contributions, if desired, to Visiting Nurse Services of New York: www.vnsny.org or 107 East 70th St., NYC 10022.

CORGAN--Gregory W.,60, of Atlanta, GA, on March 9, 2014, after a 3.5 year heroic battle with lymphoma. A graduate of Notre Dame, Greg spent 24 years with IBM, served as President and CEO of One Chem, Ltd. and held a number of senior executive positions at CA Technologies, Open Text and Infor. He was a gifted leader and a true gentleman. His engaging personality, patience, sense of humor and optimism endeared him to everyone he met. Greg leaves his wife, Kathryn Manfredonia-Corgan, his children, Kevin, Chris and Kelley; his parents Warren and Betty Corgan; siblings Brian, Terry, Marybeth, Karen and Nancy, and 17 nieces and nephews. The family wishes to thank the wonderful staff of Emory University Hospital, most especially, Dr. H. Jean Khoury. Memorial contributions to advance special research should be made payable to: Emory University c/o Dept. of Hematology & Medical Oncology and sent c/o Corgan, 3325 Piedmont Rd, NE, Unit 1501, Atlanta, GA 30305.

GRUNIG--George Hugh, on March 15, 2014. Former Employee of Mobil Oil and AT&T. Beloved husband of Elisabeth M. (nee McDermott). Dear son of the late Helene Eberlein Grunig. Loving father of four angels. Beloved uncle of Joseph P. Kennedy, Mary Alice Bigwood, Jeanne Dwyer, the late R. Marty Kennedy, M. Edward McDermott and Lisa Perez. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY 11693. Visiting Monday, March 17, 2014, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Tuesday 9:45am at St. Francis DeSales Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery Middle Village, NY.

HOWELL--John I.,97, of Greenwich, CT and Springfield Center, NY, died March 13. He was a graduate of St. Paul's School and Yale University; director, president, chairman of J. Henry Schroder Banking Corp and longtime director of the American International Group. Survived by two children, five grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Memorial service March 22, 11:30am, St. Barnabas Church, Greenwich.

KOBRIN--Gloria, 62, beloved wife of Ron Froug, younger sister of Trudi Gunsberg (Frank), mother of Alan Kantrowitz (Melissa) and Risa (1974-1991), Grandma Gloria called "G G" by Tyler, Reese and Bradley, aunt to Meredith (Jay Bluestine), Shari (Josh Rayburn), Rachel (Anil Bhatia), great-aunt to many. Great friend to many. Graduated S.J. Tilden, lived in Florida and California. Gloria danced from beginning to end of every party.

ROSENKRANZ--Melvin Harvey. Born Brooklyn, NY, September 14, 1950, died March 6, 2014 at North Shore Hospital, Long Island, surrounded by family and friends. A man of sweet and gentle disposition, he was pre-deceased by his wife Brigitte Maurer. He is survived by his young son Daniel, his father, Sol Rosenkranz, brother Joel and sister Rita, brother-in-law Kurt and sister-in-law Elizabeth. Close family friends include the Jones, Sherman and Cook families. Mel was a career employee of The Department of Labor. Donations in his memory may be sent to: The Museum of Jewish Heritage, 36 Battery Place, NY, NY 10280. Attn: Sol Rosenkranz and Family Fund.

SCHWARTZ--Martin, 99, died peacefully at home on March 17th, 2014. He was a devoted husband to Tibbie, his wife of over 72 years. He is survived by his loving children, daughter Barbara Annis, son Peter Schwartz, grandson Andrew, daughter-in-law Ellen and sister Sylvia Lisman. Before his retirement, he was a partner in Joseph Schwartz & Son, a leading supplier of fine furs to the fur industry, a firm founded by his father. Martin was a passionate golfer and an enthusiastic and constant presence on the course at Old Oaks Country Club where he was a longstanding member. Born in New York City, he was the eldest of the three children of Joseph and Anne Schwartz. He graduated from NYU and NYU Law School. He was an incredible man who will be missed by all those who loved him. A private funeral is being held.

SEGAL--Josh, 54, died on March 16, 2014 after a heroic 40 year battle with heart disease. Josh left his beloved parents Helen and Alvin Segal of New York City. Beloved brother to Marc, his wife Susan and their children Carly and Jeremy who adored him from Stowe, Vermont. Brother to Todd and his children Todd A, Julia, and Thomas. One could not ask for a better son, brother, uncle and friend. Josh attained his Masters from NYU in real estate development and management with a career as a consummate real estate professional. Services Wednesday 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Burial to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery in Long Island. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Mount Sinai Heart Institute, attn.: DR. V. Fuster.

ZWEIMAN--Anne Minsky, passed away on March 15, 2014. Cherished wife of the late David Zweiman, treasured mother of Jessica, Brett and Dara. Mother-in-law of Scott, Ha and Ryan. Beloved grandmother to Jackson and Violet. Loved to bits by siblings Mimi, Neci, and the late Mel Minsky. Adored by all Zweimans. Services Tuesday March 18th at 11:45am at "The Riverside." You are our heart.

ZIEGLER--Elaine. A most wonderful: wife to Arthur, mother to Peter and Evan, educator to innumerable students, friend to so many, grandmother of Scout and Lana and aunt of Nancy, Leslie and Harris. Memorial Service Thursday, March 20, 11am, Gutterman's Woodbury.
DEMETROWITZ--Sarah Ryan. 10/12/26-03/18/13. Kit, a year after your passing we remember you, with enduring love. From your devoted husband and all your family.

WALKER--Kenneth Brian. Your tender caress, soft voice, and caring words are missed daily. As you continue to transform our lives, know we miss you but understand the universe moves us all. You changed us for good through your grace. With Love and Gratitude, Your husband David, Family and Friends

RAITT--Kathleen, on Saturday, March 15, at home in Manhattan. Beautiful and adored daughter of Rosamond Landry Shelley of Houston, TX and the late John Smith. Beloved of sister-in-law Sue Riley and her children. Former wife of the late John Raitt. Dear friend of Carole, Patricia, Margo, Frank, Jackie, Susan, Charlotte, Lynne, Suzanne, and Mickey. Longtime and much loved member of the Nederlander Organization producing family, Kathleen's Broadway projects included The Scarlet Pimpernel, The Civil War, Bonnie & Clyde, The Molly Maguires, Grand Hotel and Legs Diamond. Love and gratitude to Evelyn and Visiting Nurse Services/New York, and to Nurse Professional Agency, Inc. At Kathy's request, no funeral or visiting. A party celebrating her life will be announced. Memorial contributions, if desired, to Visiting Nurse Services of New York: www.vnsny.org or 107 East 70th St., NYC 10021.

MARGOLIS--Magda, 91 on March 16, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Milton Margolis. Survived by her loving niece, Lorraine Miller. Services today, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, The Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st St), NY, NY.

OKIN--Anne R.,passed away peacefully at home on March 15, 2014. Born May 13, 1917, she grew up in the Bronx, and lived in Manhattan after her marriage, in 1940. After graduating Phi Beta Kappa from Hunter College, she taught English at Hunter High School in the 1950s. She received her law degree from NYU in 1958, and went into practice with her late husband, Louis. She took to heart the Phi Beta Kappa motto and was guided by it into old age: "The love of learning is the guide to life." She will be remembered with deep respect, admiration and, above all, love by her children, Elizabeth and Steven; their spouses, Jak Ninyo and Carolyn Okin; her five grandchildren, Adam and Jared Ninyo, and Michael, Rebecca, and Rachel Okin; and by many other family members and friends. The service is private. Donations may be made in Anne Okin's memory to Congregation Shearith Israel at 8 West 70th Street, New York, NY 10023.
LONDON--Anna. Age 100. Widow of Norman London. Sculptor, etcher, printer, painter. Great friend to many and a great mother. We will treasure the wonderful times. Dan and Joe London.

PRIEBAT--Bertha, nee Druyf, 100, passed away peacefully on March 13, 2014 in Maryland. Loving mother of Dennis A. Priebat MD, Bethesda, MD. Born in Amsterdam Netherlands, formerly of Flushing, NY; she with her late husband Ewald M. Priebat imported fine greeting and art post cards. Funeral service to be held at 10am on March 20, 2014 at Schwartz Brothers, Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the American Cancer Society.

KARP--Richard M.,died March 16, 2014, 84. Born August 17, 1929 to Jo and Harry Karp. He was the smartest, funniest, bravest man I ever met. He served in the Army for two tours during the Korean War and went to work after at 20th Century Fox's "Men of Tomorrow Program." He was the Senior Vice President of the Creative Department at Grey Advertising for 30 years creating award winning campaigns. He also served as International Creative Director living in Europe for many years. He leaves his wife Jane (Hausman); son David (Monika) Zisskind; grandchildren Ella and Leo; his niece Katherine Sarasohn; step-brother David (Joyce) and brothers and sister-in-law Martin and Helaine Hausman and Albert Sarasohn. His laughter wit and generosity will be missed forever. Services will be at Temple Emanu-El, March 19th 11am, 190 North County Rd., Palm Beach. The family will receive directly after services, 44 Cocoanut Row, Palm Beach.

POLLACK--Jerry. Beloved husband of Risa, loving father of Martha, doting grandfather of Ben and Sam Hafetz, proud father-in-law of Jonathan Hafetz, loving brother of Herb and Murray, on March 17. Jerry was a child psychiatrist who served as Director of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Brookdale and Physician in Charge, Division of Child Psychiatry at Beth Israel. He taught at Mount Sinai School of Medicine, Downstate Medical Center, and NYU Medical Center. He was in private practice for 40 years. A graduate of Oberlin College, he played varsity lacrosse and was honorary All-American. He graduated from Boston University School of Medicine and was a member of Alpha Omega Alpha honorary medical fraternity. Jerry served on the Board of Directors of Saint Ann's School. His wisdom, kindness, humor and unfailing empathy for friends and family and for all children will be greatly missed and long remembered. Services are Wednesday, 11:30am at Weinstein, Garlick, 1153 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.
RAITT--Kathleen. Remembering our beautiful, determined, brave and just plain fun friend Kathy. Mickey & Bruce.

LAITMAN--Samuel. Our partner and friend Samuel Laitman, who passed away last week, was a member of Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP for 34 years. He joined our Firm in 1966, where he became partner and head of our Trusts and Estates Practice. Sam's love of the arts and culture was evident by his many philanthropic endeavors and steadfast community involvement. He was an excellent lawyer and a compassionate man. We will remember him with the utmost respect and we offer our deepest sympathy to his family; he will be greatly missed by his friends and former colleagues at Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP.

PINE--Martin L.,on March 15, 2014. Beloved husband of Anne. Loving father of Lewis (Kathryn). Brother of Stephen and the late Carol. Dear Uncle of many nieces and nephews. He was a Professor of History, Queens College, CUNY, and a member of the Doctoral Faculty at the Graduate School and University Center, CUNY, as well as an author and lecturer. He held a BA from Columbia College, an MA in History and a PhD in History from Columbia University. Dr. Pine was the recipient of the Queens College President's Award for Excellence in Teaching and was awarded a Fullbright Fellowship for Study and Research in Italy. He was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. Services Tuesday, 1:15pm at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

FLAHERTY--Alfred B.,on March 16, 2014. Proud U.S. Army Veteran and retired senior litigator in the insurance industry. Beloved son of the late Michael and Julia (nee Neary). Loving brother of the late Joseph and the late Mary. Cherished cousin of many. Funeral on Wednesday 8:30am from the Marine Park Funeral Home, marineparkfh. com, 3024 Quentin Rd., Bklyn. Funeral Mass 9:30am, St. Thomas Aquinas R.C.C. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visitation Tuesday 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9:00pm.

MALCOLM--Jeanne. Beloved wife of Robert, loving mother of Yelena and Ari, died March 16, 2014. She is also survived by her sisters, Joanne and Janet, and her son-in-law, James. Services today, 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. "Wherever you go, I will go, and wherever you lodge, I will lodge; your people shall be my people and your God my God."

HUNTER--William Arthur. Born in New York City on May 3, 1935, died in Houston, TX, on March 7, 2014. Bill Hunter was a member of the NYSE for three decades. A memorial event will be held in the New York-New Jersey area. He is survived by a brother, three sisters and his three children.
MARGOLIS--Magda. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to her family. Congregation Emanu-EI of the City of New York

HOWELL--John I.,97, of Greenwich, CT and Springfield Center, NY, died March 13. He was a graduate of St. Paul's School and Yale University; director, president, chairman of J. Henry Schroder Banking Corp and longtime director of the American International Group. Survived by two children, five grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Memorial service March 22, 11:30am, St. Barnabas Church, Greenwich.

MITTENTHAL--Estelle, (nee Weinberg). Beloved and adored wife and best friend of Lawrence for 69 years and forever after. Her beauty of spirit and appearance will always be a source of loving memories, comfort and pride for those who treasured her. She is survived by her husband, sons Mark (wife Donna deceased) of Atlanta and Barry and his wife Annette of Chicago, three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Graveside services Wednesday, March 19, 2014 at 1:30pm at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY.
LEIGH--Mitch. We will miss our dear friend Mitch. But though he is gone, the beautiful music of his soul lives on. Ninah and Michael

ELKIN--Edward M.,died at home in White Plains, NY on March 14, 2014. Born to Jules and Rose Greenbaum Elkin of Newburyport, MA, March 26, 1939. A former resident of Katonah and Hartsdale, NY, he was a pediatrician and public health physician. Brother of Leah (Arthur) Shavit and the late Paul Elkin. Loving father of Elena Elkin and Joshua (Meryl) Elkin. Devoted grandfather of Ezra and Ruby.

HATCHER--Edgar A.,III, 87, died on March 11th in the Upper West Side apartment he loved so much. As a young copywriter Ed penned the famous phrase, "Ford has a better idea." The slogan became the basis of one of the automaker's most successful campaigns, and with ensuing permutations found a niche in the English language. He retired from McCann Erickson as a vice president, and worked on campaigns for Chevron, Kodak, Texas Instruments Beechcraft and Exxon at J. Walter Thompson, Benton & Bowles and BBDO. The Edgar Hatcher Papers, 1952-1992, document his advertising campaigns and are archived at the Duke University Library. Ed grew up in High Point, NC, and graduated from Duke University in 1947, where he served as a Naval Air Force cadet. Some of his happiest times were spent in Roxbury, CT, growing tomatoes and eating homemade barbecue with friends and family. He loved Mozart, George Orwell and Gilbert & Sullivan. Always witty, he enjoyed lively dinner parties, using his sharp intellect and command of language to engage in smart discussions about politics and ideas. He is survived by his cherished wife Barbara, his children Liza Dawson (Havis Dawson) and Edgar Hatcher IV (Angie Cannon), his grandchildren Charlie, Nick, Rebecca and Madeline, his step-grandchild Danny, his older sister Elizabeth Conner and his nieces Chris Levin and Susan Conner. Donations in his memory can be sent to Doctors Without Borders at 333 7th Ave., 2nd floor, NY, NY 10001. A memorial gathering will be held in April.

CORZINE--Jeffery. The Atlantic Golf Club mourns the passing of Jeffery Corzine, son of fellow member, the Honorable Jon S. Corzine. We extend our sincere condolences and heartfelt sympathy to Jon and the entire family. Dennis A. Suskind, President Harvey L. Radler, Vice President

BERGMAN--Alan S. Music lawyer and drummer died March 15, 2014. Born in Brooklyn; graduated Princeton and NYU law; loved jazz and played with the PJQ. A tireless advocate for his clients and a dedicated father, he is survived by loving daughters Jennifer and Leslie Bergman and by Dr. Pat Kirkish. Funeral at Plaza Jewish on March 19, 2014 at 12 noon. Donations to Dr. Cy Stein at COH Medical Center, 1500 E. Duarte Rd., Duarte, CA 91010.

BLOSVERN--Miriam, retired New York City Teacher, beloved wife of Monroe and mother of Ellen Blosvern, passed away Sunday, March 16, 2014. She was 101 years old. Her son Peter and granddaughter Robin survive her. Burial will be at Mt. Moriah Cemetery in Fairview, NJ at 1pm on Sunday, March 23. Contributions to: protect.org.

BORNSTEIN--Maida, 92, of New York City, died on March 16, 2014. Beloved Wife of the late Dr. Jacob Bornstein. Loving mother of Gail Wachtel, Bonnie and Richard Hyken, and Harold and Melissa Bornstein. Dear grandmother of Kari Seletz, Kimberly Boland, Mathew Wachtel, Samuel Hyken, Lauren Hyken Robyn, Joseph, Alex, Jeremee, and Jackson Bornstein. Great-grandmother of Asher and Ariella Seletz, Lilly and Noa Boland. Devoted sister to Sarah Sellinger. Burial services at Sharon Memorial Park in Sharon, Massachusetts on Tuesday, March 18, 2014 at 2:45pm.

BACON--John Bennett, a retired professor and author, died on February 16, 2014; he was 73 years old. He was born in Toledo, Ohio on May 15, 1940 to Frank Rider Bacon, Jr. and Eleanor Bennett Bacon. He graduated from DeVilbiss High School in Toledo, Ohio in 1958 and received his BA from Wabash College in 1962 and in 1966 he received his PhD from Yale University. He was interested in philosophy, semantics and logic and held positions on the faculties at the University of Texas, Austin, The Hebrew University in Jerusalem, Fordham University, City University of New York, Rutgers University, Pratt Institute in New York, and the University of Sydney, Australia. In addition to teaching, he was also an accomplished author. He co-authored titles such as Logic from A to Z: The Routledge Encyclopedia of Philosophy Glossary of Logical and Mathematical Terms; Being and Existence: Two Ways of Formal Ontology; Ontology, Causality and Mind and his works were also cited in the Routledge Encyclopedia of Philosophy, Volume 10. Mr. Bacon is survived by his son David (Karen) Bacon, Katonah, New York and daughter Sara Elsa-Beech (Jennifer Balfour), Somerville, MA, three grandchildren Miles, Calder and Rosalind, brother George (Lai Ling), Toronto, Ontario and sister, Kate (John) Endersbe, Tubac, AZ. He is also survived by two ex-wives, Gertrud Elsasser Bacon (Weilheim, Germany and New York City) and Abigail Rosenthal Martin (New York City and Pennsylvania). He was preceded in death by his parents Frank and Eleanor Bacon. There will be a memorial service at Collingwood Presbyterian Church located at 2108 Collingwood Blvd., Toledo, Ohio 43620 on March 19, 2014 at 2:00pm. The family plans to have a memorial service which will be held in New York at a later date. Online condolences may be made at: www.fothdorfmeyer.com. Those wishing to make a donation in memory of John, may donate to the Collingwood Presbyterian Church or a charity of the donor's choice.

RUBIN--Hal. My dear brother, You would have turned 33 today; ten years after your tragic death. I can still hear your voice, see that twinkle in your eye, and marvel at your intellect. How I wish I could see you now-- done with your PhD, definitely published, perhaps married. We are all doing what we can to honor your memory through a memorial fund that aids youth in distress. My heart is still broken over the pain you felt. You would be happy to know I am living the dream we discussed before your death-- as a rabbi, a wife, and mother (our first son is named for you). I am part of a whole new family, but we will always be one short. Love always, Lisa The Harold Rubin Memorial Fund at Elem.org
SCHNIPPER--Steven. 3/19/09. Five years since angels took your hands. I miss and love you so much. Mom

DENIHAN--Charles Tully. May 24, 1985 to March 16, 2014, 28, of New York City, passed away suddenly on Sunday evening, March 16, 2014. Charlie was the loving son of Benjamin and Barbara Denihan; brother of Kate and Tully Denihan and Chrissy Denihan O'Donovan; brother-in-law to Kevin O'Donovan; godfather to Bud O'Donovan, and loving uncle, as well as friend to all. Charlie was a third generation member of the family's hotel investment and management company, Denihan Hospitality Group, founded by his grandfather Benjamin J. "Bud" Denihan in New York City in 1963. Although the youngest of four siblings, Charlie had an extraordinary bond with his slightly older, special needs brother Tully, and was a 'big' brother to him from the moment he was born. Charlie grew up in Manhattan where he attended St. David's School, and later graduated from Deerfield Academy in Deerfield, Mass. where as both a peer counselor and cheerleader he became known for his larger-than-life personality, a trait that followed him through the rest of his life. Charlie earned his Bachelor of Science degree from the Cornell School of Hotel Administration with a concentration in Finance, Accounting and Real Estate. In addition to his involvement in the family business, Charlie was passionate about music, musical artists and technology. He took an avid role in various start-up technology and ventures, as a founder of Silver Lake to Soho, a cross-platform digital promotion and tour operator for emerging musical artists and as CO-CEO of Vokoder FM, a music web application. Charlie lived life to the fullest and found a way to look at the brightest side of everything. He believed in the possibilities of the dreams of those he knew and loved as fervently as he believed in his own. Those who met Charlie consistently walked away moved by his presence, knowing well that he was a friend who would always be there when it really counted. Charlie's zest for life was contagious and he could light up a room with his smile. Handsome, genuine, funny and magnetic, he inherited his family's generosity, and as many say, would gladly give anyone the shirt off his back. His philanthropic interests included The Benedictine Foundation, The Miami Project, Operation Smile and The Fresh Air Fund. In repose at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY, 10028, Friday March 21 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY, 10028, Saturday at 9:30am. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to The Benedictine Foundation, 14299 Benedictine Lane, Ridgley, MD, 21660; foundation@ benedictineschool.org

FULLER COWLES--Sage. Dancer, philanthropist, activist, and educator, died on November 21, 2013 in Minneapolis, MN. She was 88. A devoted mother of four, Sage was best known for her support of contemporary dance artists. Sage was a longtime board member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Co., toured as a guest artist in the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company's production "Last Supper at Uncle Tom's Cabin/The Promised Land," and earned a Lifetime Achievement "Ernie" Award from Dance/USA in 2004. Sage was preceded in death by her husband, John Cowles, Jr., former CEO of Cowles Media Co. and publisher of the Minneapolis Star Tribune. Sage was born on May 5, 1925, in Paris, to Jane Sage White (sculptor) and Charles Fairchild Fuller (architect). She attended Rippowam School in Bedford Village, NY. After her parents divorced, her mother married publisher Cass Canfield who later became President of Harper and Row. Sage spent the summers of 1936 and 1937 at Perry Mansfield Camp, rooming with actress Julie Harris. Through the late 1930's and early 40's she received dance training from Hanya Holm, Louis Horst, Ella Daganova, Louise Kloepper, The Ned Wayburn School of Dance, The School of American Ballet and Lisa Gardiner's School of Ballet. In 1943 she met Merce Cunningham, who became a life-long friend and inspiration. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin with a B.A. in Art History. A student of Margaret H'Doubler, Sage was also a member of the Wisconsin Dance Group, which included Mary Hinkson, Matt Turney and Miriam Cole. She married Dr. Edmundo Flores in 1946; the marriage ended in divorce in 1950. In 1950, while a dancer on Broadway's "Bless You All" and on TV's "Lucky Strike Hit Parade," Sage met John Cowles, Jr. Two years later the couple married and moved to Kansas, where John was in the Army at Ft. Riley. After moving to Minneapolis in 1953, Sage danced with the Nancy Hauser Contemporary Dance Co., the Joan Skinner Dance Co. and co-founded the Dancers' Forum. Sage also turned her attention to social and civic causes. In 1959 she co-founded the Highcroft Country Day School. During the 1960's she became active in civil rights advocacy with "The Way," Planned Parenthood and the Minneapolis Mayor's Commission on Human Relations. In the 1970's Sage served on the Three School Foundation Board that implemented the merger of Highcroft, Northrop and Blake schools. Interested in body/mind disciplines, Sage became involved with dance therapy and worked with autistic children at Washburn Child Guidance Center. She served as the Movement Coordinator to the Reflective Leadership program at the University of Minnesota and developed her personal workshops "Use of Movement as a Teaching Tool" and "I Can, I Can Choose, and I Can Change." In 2005-2006 Sage was awarded a Louis W. Hill Jr. Philanthropy Fellowship by the U of MN and authored "Getting Ahead of the Curve: Engaging Our Youngest Citizens," calling for movement training as part of early childhood education. From 1976-1983 she collaborated with filmmaker Molly Davies on six film/performance pieces which toured throughout the United States and Europe. "Those pieces were so ahead of their time in the 1970's with the mix of media and live performance," recalls Philip Bither, performing arts curator, Walker Art Center. In 2005 Sage performed the retrospective "Space, Time and Illusion: Sage Cowles and Molly Davies, at Dance Theater Workshop and the Walker. Sage received grants from the NEA (1979), Jerome Foundation (1980) and Affiliated State Arts Agencies of the Upper Midwest (1981, 1982) for her work. She was part of "A Celebration of Collaborations" (1980) in Minneapolis and performed in the Walker Art Center's "New Dance USA" (1981). She choreographed Suzanne Lacey's "Whispers" (1987), taught "Dance for Non-Dancers" at the Minneapolis YWCA and Metro State University and helped found the Minnesota Independent Chor-eographers Association. During 1990-92 Sage and John toured the USA and Europe as guest artists in the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Co. production "Last Supper at Uncle Tom's Cabin/The Promised Land." Sage served for 29 years, over five decades, as a Board member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Co., including as Co-Chair from 2000-2004. Sage supported the multidisciplinary exhibition Art Performs Life in 1998 at the Walker, which featured the work of Cunningham, Meredith Monk and Bill T. Jones. She helped to secure the Merce Cunningham Dance Co.'s 15-plus engagements in Minnesota, as well as to bring Cunningham and John Cage's monumental work-in-the-round "Ocean" to a granite quarry near St. Cloud, MN in 2008. During the late 1980's and '90's Sage was a competitive racewalker, setting two U.S. records in her age group and she then became an aerobics instructor. In 1997 Sage teamed with her husband and children to launch a new professional women's fastpitch softball league and later Sage and John made the lead gift for the U of MN's Jane Sage Cowles Stadium for fastpitch. The league continues today as National Pro Fastpitch. In 2001 the Ordway Center honored Sage with a Sally Award for her decades-long support of the arts. In 2005 the annual Sage Awards for Dance were created to honor her extensive contributions. And in 2011, after fourteen years of planning and fundraising, Sage helped launch the Cowles Center for Dance and the Performing Arts, giving Minnesota its long-awaited flagship for dance. Sage is survived by her four children, ten grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. A memorial celebration will be held on April 5, at 1:30pm, at the Cowles Center in Minneapolis.

ALEXANDER--Marvin, on March 17. Loving spouse of 70 years to Murray Fishman. Survived by great-nephew David Reitner and nieces Jill Silverman and Gail Silverman. Services Wednesday, 11:15am, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

BARKER--Sylvia M.,99, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan, surrounded by close friends. She was a giant among professional nurses of her generation, graduating from the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing in 1936 and serving in various leadership positions at The Mount Sinai Medical Center for more than 50 years. She served as Associate Director of Nursing until 1984, when she stepped down, and continued her service to Mount Sinai as a consultant to Nursing Administration until her retirement in 1994. She was widely recognized for her distinguished work in advancing the areas of risk management, quality assurance, and labor relations in nursing. She earned her BSN and MA degrees from Teachers College, Columbia University, and she received numerous awards throughout her long career. These included the Jane Delano Distinguished Service Award from District 13, New York State Nurses Association, in 1982; the Distinguished Alumna Award from the Alumnae Association of The Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing in 1990; the R. Louise McManus Medal for Nursing Service from Teachers College in 1994; and the Distinguished Membership Award from the American Nurses Association in 1998. She co-authored the book "The Sinai Nurse" with Marjorie Lewis, BS, RN, which described 150 years of nursing experience, invented devices to facilitate the care of patients, and was the esteemed and beloved teacher of many generations of nursing students and co-workers. Her passionate dedication to the profession included holding positions as president of Nurses House, the only national organization that aids nurses in distress, and president and board member of The Alumnae Association of The Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing. As a member of the bylaws committee of the New York State Nurses Association, she was an acknowledged leader in the development and revision of by-laws for nursing organizations. Sylvia was an active member and leader for sixty years of The Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, United Methodist, in Manhattan. In the 1970s she helped found there both the West Side Campaign Against Hunger, now the largest emergency food program in New York City and a pioneering Meals on Wheels Program now serving 500 seniors six days a week. She was also instrumental in founding the church's homeless shelter for women and after-school tutoring program. Sylvia was a national leader in the United Methodist denomination in civil rights, gay rights and interfaith work. She will be missed by all whose professional and personal lives were touched by her brilliance and generosity of spirit. Donations in her memory may be sent to The Alumnae Association, The Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing, 1 Gustave Levy Place, P.O. Box 1143, New York, NY 10029-6574; and The Church of St. Andrew, United Methodist, 263 West 86th Street, New York, NY 10024. A memorial service will be held at Mount Sinai Medical Center at a future date. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew on May 10 at 5pm. Theodora Sirota PhD, APRN-BC President Alumnae Association The Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing

BERKOWITZ--Harry. 81, died Saturday, March 15, 2014 while recovering from surgery in New York City. His career as a retail executive at Neiman Marcus, Saks Fifth Avenue, Sakowitz, and the Zale Corporation spanned 30 years. He served as President of the Yale Co-op for seven years until he retired in 1998. Born in San Antonio, TX on November 15, 1932, to Sidney and Rosalie Berkowitz, Harry was educated at Andover and graduated from Princeton in 1955. He was a founder of Princeton Project '55, now part of Princeton Alumni Corps, and worked to connect recent graduates with non-profits in Connecticut for internships. He was also a member of the Princeton Prize in Race Relations committee. Harry is survived by his partner, Donna Dean, his brother, William, and four children: Ann Berkowitz, Peter Berkowitz, Edward Berkowitz, and David Young. A memorial service in celebration of Harry's life will be held Wednesday, April 9, 2014 at St. Luke's Parish, 1864 Post Road, Darien, CT. The service will begin at 11am, followed by a reception at the Parish. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Princeton Alumni Corps., in Princeton, NJ, or Norwalk Community Health Center in Norwalk, CT.

LANDAU--Gerald Leonard, 95. Loving husband of 67 years of Miriam Landau, proud father of Jonathan Landau, and wife Barbara, David Landau, and wife Gretchen, loving grandfather to Kate Downey Landau, and Charles Downey Landau, and Jennifer Yankeliovich, and, in the last four months of his life, great- grandfather to Gerald Yankeliovich Landau. The second of four children, he was predeceased by his older brother Herb, younger brother Martin, and younger sister Bernice. Born in 1919, in his early years he developed a passionate interest in jazz and baseball. Among his many heroes were Louis Armstrong, whose music he was still listening to just last month, and Willie Mays. During World War II he served as a paratrooper, and made 22 jumps during the war. After the war, he attended Brooklyn College and became a school teacher and historian until he was blacklisted by the New York City school system in 1952 for his political activities. In 1959, he began a second career when he joined the new Acoustic Research company and went on to be become its Vice President before retiring. Gerald was a lifetime student of language and always spoke with precision and clarity. He was an intellectual who followed the news and history of the world around him with great care and understanding. He had a talent for inventing children's stories and his tales about "Bruin the Bear" are considered classics, especially by his grandchildren. A charming and handsome man, with a twinkle in his eyes, a relaxed and friendly manner, he was always a natural, interesting, and witty conversationalist. Over the course of his 95 years, the most important thing to him was the love he shared with Miriam, Jonathan, Barbara, David, Gretchen, Kate, Charles, and young Gerald--his family, who loved him with all their heart. Plans for a memorial will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

SCHWARTZ--Martin, 99, died peacefully at home on March 17th, 2014. He was a devoted husband to Tibbie, his wife of over 72 years. He is survived by his loving children, daughter Barbara Annis, son Peter Schwartz, grandson Andrew, daughter-in-law Ellen and sister Sylvia Lisman. Before his retirement, he was a partner in Joseph Schwartz & Son, a leading supplier of fine furs to the fur industry, a firm founded by his father. Martin was a passionate golfer and an enthusiastic and constant presence on the course at Old Oaks Country Club where he was a longstanding member. Born in New York City, he was the eldest of the three children of Joseph and Anne Schwartz. He graduated from NYU and NYU Law School. He was an incredible man who will be missed by all those who loved him. A private funeral is being held.

KARP--Richard M.,died March 16, 2014, 84. Born August 17, 1929 to Jo and Harry Karp. He was the smartest, funniest, bravest man I ever met. He served in the Army for two tours during the Korean War and went to work after at 20th Century Fox's "Men of Tomorrow Program." He was the Senior Vice President of the Creative Department at Grey Advertising for 30 years creating award winning campaigns. He also served as International Creative Director living in Europe for many years. He leaves his wife Jane (Hausman); son David (Monika) Zisskind; grandchildren Ella and Leo; his niece Katherine Sarasohn; step-brother David (Joyce) and brothers and sister-in-law Martin and Helaine Hausman and Albert Sarasohn. His laughter wit and generosity will be missed forever. Services will be at Temple Emanu-El, March 19th 11am, 190 North County Rd., Palm Beach. The family will receive directly after services, 44 Cocoanut Row, Palm Beach.

RAINS--Muriel, born in Bronx, New York July 20, 1918, died peacefully in her home in Fort Myers, Florida on March 13, 2014 with her family by her side. Muriel was predeceased by her beloved husband of 55 years Harry H. Rains in 1999. She is lovingly remembered by her daughter Peggy Goodman, her two grandchildren Adam Goodman and Margaret Goodman Ford, and by her four great- grandchildren: Ella Ford, Noah Goodman, Lucas Ford, and Amelia Goodman. She will also be remembered with great admiration and fondness by her numerous friends and acquaintances. Muriel's was a life well lived.

GIBBONS--James Davis, 78, passed away from pneumonia on March 14, 2014, after keeping multiple myeloma at bay for six years. He died as he lived, having a wonderful time sharing reminiscences with his family, giving witty retorts and offering tax law insights at his bedside, pen and paper in hand. Born to Frank and Laura Gibbons in West Roxbury, MA, Jim graduated first in his class from Boston Latin School in 1953. In 1957 Jim graduated from Harvard College where he received a B.A., Magna Cum Laude, in Economics. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa in the top 1% of his class and first in the Economics Department. In 1959 he received his MBA from Harvard Business School, where he was a George F. Baker Scholar. His additional awards, scholarships and honors are too numerous to list. For the next 39 years Jim served as a financial executive at Exxon Mobil, including posts as Assistant and Acting General Manager in the Philippines, Senior Managing Director in Japan, and Treasurer of Esso Europe in London. James retired as Treasurer of Exxon Corporation, International based in Florham Park, NJ. Jim loved golf (he was proud of his nine handicap and his a hole-in-one at London's Highgate Country Club), the Red Sox, family gatherings, parties with dear friends, his "Exxon Family" and challenging suspicious bills, but above all he loved his wife, children and grandchildren. Jim and his wife Liz, his rock for over 50 years, retired to Old Lyme, CT in 2004, living Jim's last years in a home they built in the woods overlooking Hamburg Cove. His memory will be treasured by the family he leaves behind. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth (Sullivan) and four children: James and his wife Jeanne of Brooklyn, NY; Adrienne Brooslin and her husband Andrew of Medfield, MA; Julie Murray and her husband Philip of Santa Fe, NM; and Peter and his wife Alina of Kew Gardens, NY. His later years were also warmed by the love of seven grandchildren lucky enough to have felt the glow of this beautiful man: Joseph, Genevieve, Susannah, Johanna, Fritz, James and Marie. We will miss him forever. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11:00am on Friday, March 21st at Christ the King Church in Old Lyme, CT. A reception will follow at The Old Lyme Country Club. Burial will be private and at a later date. Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home of Old Lyme is in charge of services. Visit fultontherouxoldlyme.com for directions, tributes and more service information. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations in Jim's name may be made to Boston Latin School Association, through their website www.bls.org or by mail at 27 School Street, Suite 300, Boston, MA 02108.

The Board of Trustees, his fellow Honorary Trustees, and staff will deeply miss this caring museum friend, and extend their deepest condolences to Jacquie and his whole family.

ELLERIN--Milton Harry, 89, passed away on March 19, 2014. He is survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Betty Weinberg Ellerin, his cherished children, Seth and Sharon Ellerin, Bruce Ellerin, Bunny Ellerin and Geoffrey Vincent, and his adoring grandchildren, Ashley Ellerin, Alexandra Ellerin, and Michael Vincent. Milton was born on February 8, 1925, to Beatrice and Sol Ellerin in Middletown, NY. He graduated from Union College and Harvard Law School. He was a D-Day Veteran of WWII and a member of counter-intelligence in the Korean War. Milton was a man of integrity who practiced law for over 50 years, and derived the most satisfaction from defending those in need. He was a generous person with an infectious sense of humor who was not easily forgotten even if you met him only once. Funeral service will be held at 1:15pm on Friday, March 21st at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. No flowers please. Donations in Milton's memory can be made to Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Hospice & Palliative Care.

GIBBONS--James Davis, 78, passed away from pneumonia on March 14, 2014, after keeping multiple myeloma at bay for six years. He died as he lived, having a wonderful time sharing reminiscences with his family, giving witty retorts and offering tax law insights at his bedside, pen and paper in hand. Born to Frank and Laura Gibbons in West Roxbury, MA, Jim graduated first in his class from Boston Latin School in 1953. In 1957 Jim graduated from Harvard College where he received a B.A., Magna Cum Laude, in Economics. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa in the top 1% of his class and first in the Economics Department. In 1959 he received his MBA from Harvard Business School, where he was a George F. Baker Scholar. His additional awards, scholarships and honors are too numerous to list. For the next 39 years Jim served as a financial executive at Exxon Mobil, including posts as Assistant and Acting General Manager in the Philippines, Senior Managing Director in Japan, and Treasurer of Esso Europe in London. James retired as Treasurer of Exxon Corporation, International based in Florham Park, NJ. Jim loved golf (he was proud of his nine handicap and his a hole-in-one at London's Highgate Country Club), the Red Sox, family gatherings, parties with dear friends, his "Exxon Family" and challenging suspicious bills, but above all he loved his wife, children and grandchildren. Jim and his wife Liz, his rock for over 50 years, retired to Old Lyme, CT in 2004, living Jim's last years in a home they built in the woods overlooking Hamburg Cove. His memory will be treasured by the family he leaves behind. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth (Sullivan) and four children: James and his wife Jeanne of Brooklyn, NY; Adrienne Brooslin and her husband Andrew of Medfield, MA; Julie Murray and her husband Philip of Santa Fe, NM; and Peter and his wife Alina of Kew Gardens, NY. His later years were also warmed by the love of seven grandchildren lucky enough to have felt the glow of this beautiful man: Joseph, Genevieve, Susannah, Johanna, Fritz, James and Marie. We will miss him forever. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11:00am on Friday, March 21st at Christ the King Church in Old Lyme, CT. A reception will follow at The Old Lyme Country Club. Burial will be private and at a later date. Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home of Old Lyme is in charge of services. Visit fultontherouxoldlyme.com for directions, tributes and more service information. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations in Jim's name may be made to Boston Latin School Association, through their website www.bls.org or by mail at 27 School Street, Suite 300, Boston, MA 02108.

ROTHBERG--Henry M. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are saddened by the loss of Henry Rothberg of Manalapan, Fla. and Guilford, Conn. Mr. Rothberg was a Technion Guardian, a designation reserved for those who have reached the highest level of commitment. He and his wife Lillian supported numerous Technion projects, including the Henry M. and Lillian R. Rothberg and Family Scholarship Fund. We extend our deepest sympathies to Lillian, sons David and Henry, daughter Celia Rothberg Meadow, and the entire Rothberg family. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

FARNSWORTH--Kathryn M.,age 90, formerly of Englewood, NJ, died March 12, 2014 at Kendal at Oberlin in Oberlin, OH. She was an educator and renowned storyteller often telling at the Hans Christian Andersen Statue in Central Park. Survived by daughter Ann E. of Scarsdale, NY; sons John E. of Brewster, MA, William C. of Melrose, MA, James R. of Scarsdale, NY; eight grandchildren. Memorial services will be held April 26th in Oberlin followed by a service later in the spring in Englewood. Contributions may be made to Stevens Staff Education Fund, 600 Kendal Drive, Oberlin, OH 44074 or Hans Christian Andersen Storytelling Center, Inc. http://hcastorycenter. org/support.html. For full obit see dickenfuneralhome.com

HEISLER--Irving. Beloved husband of Ruth, greatest dad ever of Ethan and Julia, adored grandpa of Tasha, Nat, Kyle, Alicia, and Kira, and father-in-law of Robert and Michelle, who retired as a NY attorney after a career in civil law spanning a half-century, died at the age of 93 after a long illness from Alzheimer's disease. SCHWARTZ--Martin. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend and fellow member, Mr. Martin Schwartz. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his entire family. Benjamin Kirschenbaum, President

FORD--William Clay. Freedom Institute extends its sympathy to the family of Mr. William Clay Ford. His support of our work in the prevention and treatment of alcohol and substance abuse and addiction was unwavering. His generosity and commitment to our cause leaves a lasting legacy. With gratitude, Freedom Institute

FRIEDMAN--Herbert V.,born November 2, 1918, cherished husband of more than 70 years of Marion (nee Rosenfeld), adored father of Barbara Altman (Ron) and Ken (Joanne), beloved grandpa of Andrew Altman, Lynn Altman, Melissa Wolfson, and Jeff Wolfson, and superpappy of Hannah, Brent, and Jared Wolfson. After graduating from NYU, Heights in 1939 and Columbia Law School in 1942, Herb enlisted in the Army Air Corps. Following the war and the birth of their children, he and Marion made their home in Rockville Centre, NY, for 55 years, joining Central Synagogue of Nassau County and becoming founding members of Middle Bay Country Club in 1955. A lifetime member of the Million Dollar Round Table, Herb established an extraordinarily successful insurance business, specializing in association group and group health insurance. An avid golfer, Herb had six holes in one, scoring his last one at age 88. In addition to golf and a good gin game, Herb loved going out with Marion and family and friends, to enjoy a great meal, a good martini, and lots of laughs. All who knew him delighted in his upbeat personality, his joie de vivre, his warmth, and his sense of humor. His smile was magnificent and his laughter contagious. Services are private. In lieu of flowers, a donation to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

KLEIMAN--H. Lylla. Beloved wife of George, daughter of the late Samuel and Bess Zeigen and sister of the late L. Marshall Zeigen, passed peacefully at 86 years, after a long illness on Monday, March 17th. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York City at 11:15 am, Sunday, March 23. Her loving husband, George

SHANKY--Myrna. We are deeply saddened by the death of Myrna Shanky on March 19, 2014. Loving mother, grandmother and friend. Lover of food, fine film, Fire Island and all manner of festivities. Beloved mother of Jane and Chris, daughter-in-law Julia, grandchildren Zach, Alix, Reid, Sam and Nick. Donations to Dr. Mears Research Fund, Herbert Irving Pavilion, 161 Fort Washington Avenue 9th Floor, New York, NY 10032. Memorial Service to be held April 6th, 2014. For information call Jane Shanky.

FEIST--Gene. Founder and Artistic Director of Roundabout Theatre Company (1965-1988), passed away on March 17. Gene and wife Elizabeth, brought numerous acclaimed revivals and adaptations to the stage. A WWII veteran, Carnegie Mellon and NYU alumnus, and recipient of 1996 Lucille Lortel Foundation's Lifetime Achievement Award. Gene is survived by his daughters Gena and Nicole and will be missed by his Roundabout family.
WELGOSS--Theodora March 16 in Lawrenceville, N.J.,age 67. Born Long Beach, CA. Survived by her children, Benjamin and Alexis, and by her sister, Cynthia Martz.

FREEMAN--Stephen. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on February 25, of Stephen Freeman, who served as the Orchestra's Bass Clarinet, 19662009. We extend our deepest condolences to his widow, Judith; his sons, Eric and Gene; and the rest of his family.

VAN HOUTEN--Leonard E. Civil Engineer, 89, of Greenwich, CT, died Sunday, March 16, 2014. In his 60 year engineering career, he held executive positions at Frederic R. Harris Inc; Van Houten Associates; Dravo Engineers and Constructors; and Parsons, Brinckerhoff, Quade and Douglas; and later was in private practice. His reputation for technical excellence and innovation was developed in port and harbor design, ship berthing and mooring facilities, off-shore structures, oil storage and handling facilities, dry docks, shipyards and special industrial facilities. He co-invented the bow mooring, first deployed for Esso in Libya in 1965 and later for clients in the Middle East, Africa, and Asia. He pioneered early efforts for the development of marine LNG terminals worldwide. He authored technical papers and served as a technical expert on litigation issues. Leonard was an Honorary Fellow of the American Society of Engineers, Life Member of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, and Life Member of the Moles. A life-long sailor, he was a member of the New York Yacht Club and Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Born December 20, 1924, in Jersey City, NJ, to Leonard and Margaret Van Houten, he graduated Spring Garden School, Nutley; St. Benedict's Prep, Newark; and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, BCE and MCE, 1945 and 1947. A veteran of World War II, Leonard was in the Navy 1942-46. On December 20, 1947, during the Blizzard of '47, he married Marie Regan. He was predeceased by Marie R. Van Houten, his wife of 65 years, and his brother, Thomas G. Van Houten. He is survived by children: Elizabeth M. Van Houten of San Francisco and Westbrook, CT, and Peter J. Van Houten of New Milford, CT. Viewing will be Friday, March 21 from 4 to 6 pm, Knapp Funeral Home, 267 Greenwich Ave. Funeral Mass will be Saturday, March 22, at 10:00am, St. Mary Parish, 178 Greenwich Ave, followed by a reception at the church. Private burial at a later date, Butler, NJ.

KETIVE--Samuel, born Samuel Gershon Ketive on March 26, 1942 in New York City, Sam was the son of his beloved parents Nathan and Shirley Ketive. Sam, a resident of Fort Lee, N.J. and Palm Beach, FL, passed away on March 20 after a hard fought battle with cancer, his wife Randy and daughter Kim faithfully by his side. Sam's life was remarkable for his ability to garner life-long friends and his love of sports and family. Beginning in Brant Lake Camp in the 1950's where his natural athleticism and leadership qualities made him Camper of the Year, to the Barnard School for Boys where he was an "All City" basketball star, to his years at Michigan State University and ZBT fraternity (class of 1963) Sam's friendships endured over the course of his lifetime. His friends' unwavering love and support during his illness are a testament to those longstanding relationships. Sam retired from Bellemead Development where he rose to the level of Senior Vice President. In this role, Sam was instrumental in transforming New Jersey into one of the largest office markets in thecountry. Sam also served his country in the National Guard. But above all Sam was a family man. Sam married the love of his life, the former Randy Kalikow and remained married for 43 years. They produced a loving daughter, Kimberly. Sam is survived by wife Randy, daughter Kim Sunshine, son-in-law David Sunshine, grandchildren Ella and Nate, devoted sisters Alice Rudin and Harriet Lerner, nephews Mitchell (Bonnie) Rudin, Robert (Alissa) Rudin and Jack (Amy) Lerner, niece Rebecca (Robert) Schoenberg. His wisdom, generosity and humor will be greatly missed and fondly remembered by many who knew and loved him. Donations in his memory may be made to either "New York-Presbyterian Fund, Inc.," New York Presbyterian-Weill Cornell Medical Center, Office of Development, 525 East 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10065 or the Andrew Dreyer Memorial Fund, c/o Brant Lake Camp, 7586 State Route 8, Brant Lake, NY, 12815. The funeral will be held at 12 noon on Sunday, March 23 at the Gutterman and Musicant Funeral Home, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ 201-489-3800.

PARISER--Sanford, died peacefully in his sleep on March 18, 2014 in his apartment at The Carlisle Palm Beach. He was 89-years-old. A caring man who loved life and was dedicated above all to his family, he was married for 55 years to his beloved bride Marilyn, who passed in 2005. He is survived by his sons, Howard, Paul and Evan and their wives, Mary, Erin and Nataly, together with six grandchildren, who he so enjoyed indulging: Andrew, Spencer, Sheldon, Ariel, Ali and Rachel. He is also survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Lenore and Marshall Lesser. Sandy also enjoyed seven beautiful years with Leila Kaykoff, who passed in 2012. Sandy graduated as a member of Phi Beta Kappa from New York University in 1944, and from NYU College of Medicine in 1947 as a member of Alpha Omega Alpha, graduating first in his class. He served his internship and residency in Internal Medicine at Mt. Sinai Hospital, followed by a fellowship in Hematology at Mt. Sinai in 1950. From 1953 to 1955, Sandy was a Captain in the US Air Force stationed at Scott Air Force Base in Illinois. Sandy was Board certified in Internal Medicine in 1954, and later received certifications in Medical Oncology and Hematology. He opened up his medical office in Freeport, LI in 1955, which he later relocated to Rockville Centre, LI. He was appointed to be a Police Surgeon with the New York City Police Department, serving from 1961 to 1979. He lived for many years in Freeport and East Hampton, LI. After retiring from practice, he moved to Somers, NY and Boca Raton, FL, and in 2006, to Palm Beach Gardens, FL. For the past two years, Sandy was surrounded by wonderful caregivers, "Team Doc," including Jackie, Chris and Keisha, who loved him like family and allowed him to live independently and with gusto until the end. As a young man, he was a member of the New York Oratorio Society, and loved going to the opera throughout his life. In his later years, he was known to break out in song with his still beautiful tenor voice and with only the slightest provocation. We know he's still singing. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The American Cancer Society. Services will be held on Friday, March 21st at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

LERNER--Dennis David, 89 on March 20, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Lillian, loving father of Andrew (Dianne) and James (Liz), adoring grandfather of Adam, cherished brother of Norman and Lester. For those who had the honor and privilege to know him, his love will continue to live with us each and everyday. BRENNAN--Jeanne (Fonseca) nee Devlin on March 19. Beloved wife of the late Philip Brennan and Francis Fonseca. Loving mother of Joseph Fonseca and Catherine Chapman. ELLERIN--Milton Harry, 89, passed away on March 19, 2014. He is survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Betty Weinberg Ellerin, his cherished children, Seth and Sharon Ellerin, Bruce Ellerin, Bunny Ellerin and Geoffrey Vincent, and his adoring grandchildren, Ashley Ellerin, Alexandra Ellerin, and Michael Vincent. Milton was born on February 8, 1925, to Beatrice and Sol Ellerin in Middletown, NY. He graduated from Union College and Harvard Law School. He was a D-Day Veteran of WWII and a member of counter-intelligence in the Korean War. Milton was a man of integrity who practiced law for over 50 years, and derived the most satisfaction from defending those in need. He was a generous person with an infectious sense of humor who was not easily forgotten even if you met him only once. Funeral service will be held at 1:15pm on Friday, March 21st at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. No flowers please. Donations in Milton's memory can be made to Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Hospice & Palliative Care.

STRAUSS--Robert P. Longtime Manalapan, Florida resident, Pep Boys executive and scion, renowned arbitrageur, and beloved father and husband Robert Perry Strauss passed away peacefully on March 20th, at his home surrounded by family. He was 82. Born in Philadelphia, Robert "Bob" was raised in Merion, PA, where he was a graduate of the Episcopal Academy. An outstanding athlete Robert led Episcopal in Varsity basketball and alone, was chosen All-Philadelphia in years 1948 and 1949, awarding him honor athletic scholarships to both Brown and Duke University. He chose Duke where he was coached by the legendary Red Auerbach, and quickly named "All Southern Conference" during his Freshman year. During college Bob helped his father, Maurice "Moe" Strauss, Founder of Pep Boys Auto Stores - Manny, Moe and Jack move the family out to California, where they purchased the famed "Vistra Bel-Air", a former 60 acre estate in Bel Air. Known for his "Cary Grant" strikingly handsome good looks, sharp wit, romantic charm and distinguished reserve, it was in Los Angeles where after a brief audition, Robert was discovered for his stage acting ability also and was cast in the starring role of Shakespeare's "Hamlet". In 1952 he met dancer/movie and television actress and co-star of Walt Disney's "Mark of Zorro" Eugenia (Popova) Paul during a celebrity party at the Hollywood Bowl. They were married in 1958, until her death in 2010. Robert and Eugenia relocated to Dallas, Texas where Bob became regional Vice President for Pep Boys and in 1970 returned to Philadelphia again, making Bryn Mawr his home to join Pep Boys' board of directors and serve as an executive at company headquarters for the next 30 years. In the mid-1980s when financial leveraging was all the rage, Robert's conservative business philosophy, like that of his father's, inspired Bob to sell his share of company stock at its all time high and leave Pep Boys to foray into his own capital investment management, namely risk arbitrage wherein he amassed a greater fortune, revered and respected by those known to him in the industry. His oldest daughter Kimberly explains: "Even those with whom he clashed, admired and respected him both personally and professionally. He was strong, resolute and steadfast, and also very sweet. He let his business acumen speak for itself and despite his accomplishments my father was never too proud, nor pretentious. Instead he was always genuine and sincere. He had values; he personified nobility." In 1985 he and Eugenia retired to Boca Raton, Florida and in 1987 they purchased the magnificent c.1925 ocean side estate "Mia Encantada" in Manalapan, Florida. A long time, ardent philanthropist, both personally and through his trusteeship of the national Strauss Foundation, Robert's charitable contributions were broad and vast. Most recently he and Eugenia were best known for their leadership contributions to Duke University's Fuqua School of Business, Miami City Ballet, Palm Beach Opera, and the Jewish Federation in Palm Beach County. Robert is survived by his children: Kimberly V. Strauss of New York, NY, Wendy L. Strauss, of Winnetka, IL, Baron K. Strauss, of Calabasas, CA, and grandchildren: George, Ryan and Brody Dowd.

WEINBERG--Robert S. Son of Norman and Beatrice Weinberg, born in New York City on November 17 1927, died in St. Louis, Missouri on February 27, 2014 from an acute myocardial infarction. Robert served as a Naval Aviator during WWII, earned a DFC as an Air Force fighter pilot during the Korean War, and worked as an economist for the DoD throughout the Cold War. From 1951-1953 he was assigned to Project SCOOP where he helped George Dantzig's team pioneer the use of high speed computers in large scale national security planning problems. From 1953-1956 he worked for the Naval Warfare Analysis Group and was the first economist on a team of MIT analysts that helped the Chief of Naval Operations formulate U.S. military needs on both a nuclear and conventional level. In 1956, Robert joined IBM and, over ten years, became IBM's chief management scientist. During this period he wrote the first paper ever published to discuss an actual integrated corporate planning model and one of the first books to apply mathematical models to marketing problems. In 1966 Robert joined Anheuser-Busch as the VP of Corporate Planning. He established AB's long term strategic planning programs, built the first three generations of their planning models, and spearheaded key strategic shifts. His efforts are credited by Beer Marketers Insights editor Ben Steinman for helping AB lead beer industry growth for decades. August Busch III, was quoted by Mr. Steinman as saying that Bob was a "Good friend with a great mind". Pat Stokes, told Mr. Steinman that "Bob came to AB from IBM at a time when the company was moving from family management to a more professional management structure. He brought along many innovations, a fresh way of thinking and was responsible for recruiting many of AB's future leaders. In his short time with AB Bob made a major impact". During the following 34 years, Robert became the foremost analyst for the brewing industry. Beer industry economist Lester Jones said "There are literally decades of research and insights from Bob in the Beer Institute archivesHis work on the beer industry will be a must have...for a long time to come". Although Robert made a living as an applied economist, his true vocation was as a student, a teacher, and a mentor. He studied philosophy, mathematics, physics, economics, and corporate strategy. Every room of his home was filled with books. He taught at the university level on a part time basis throughout his career, and eventually took a permanent position as a Professor of Marketing and Management at Washington University. He enjoyed adopting bright young minds, and delighted in watching them grow into powerful intellects. His stories and jokes captured our imaginations and inspired us to pursue greatness. Robert was preceded in death by his wife Lois Nelson Weinberg. Robert is survived by a community of acolytes who he lovingly adopted, and a body of intellectual work that will endure for generations. He will be remembered for his stories, wisdom, generosity, and massive book collection. A memorial service is scheduled for Saturday, May 3, 2014 at Washington University in St. Louis. Contact Allen McCoy at: allenbmccoyiii@yahoo.com for further details.
KETIVE--Samuel "Sambo," our mentor, golf buddy, the best friend any two sisters could have had. Allie and Harriet

SCHWAB--Christine L.,passed away peacefully on March 9th, 2014. She was born in Jersey City, NJ. Predeceased by her father, Charles G. Maphet and her first husband Andrew E. Kobus. Resident of Tenafly, NJ, for thirty years. Survivors include her beloved husband Gerard K. Schwab and her adored children Susan Schwab and Peter Schwab. Chris had many professional accomplishments, but the title she was most proud of, and the role she cherished the most, was "MOMMY". Chris endured many years of illness and disability. When she could no longer endure life, death came and set her free. There will be no service, at her request. Instead, she prefers that, if you are able, you go out for a walk, or a run, or ride a bike, or take a hike! And think about how much she wished she could still do those things. Chris would be gratified if donations were made to Camp Michikamau, in care of YMCA of GBC, 360 Main Street, Hackensack, NJ, 07601, so that more children will have the opportunity of the life-changing experience of summer camp, as her own children did. This was written by Christine Schwab on January 26, 2014. An Online Guestbook is available at: treasurecoastseawinds.com

KETIVE--Samuel, born Samuel Gershon Ketive on March 26, 1942 in New York City, Sam was the son of his beloved parents Nathan and Shirley Ketive. Sam, a resident of Fort Lee, N.J. and Palm Beach, FL, passed away on March 20 after a hard fought battle with cancer, his wife Randy and daughter Kim faithfully by his side. Sam's life was remarkable for his ability to garner life-long friends and his love of sports and family. Beginning in Brant Lake Camp in the 1950's where his natural athleticism and leadership qualities made him Camper of the Year, to the Barnard School for Boys where he was an "All City" basketball star, to his years at Michigan State University and ZBT fraternity (class of 1963) Sam's friendships endured over the course of his lifetime. His friends' unwavering love and support during his illness are a testament to those longstanding relationships. Sam retired from Bellemead Development where he rose to the level of Senior Vice President. In this role, Sam was instrumental in transforming New Jersey into one of the largest office markets in thecountry. Sam also served his country in the National Guard. But above all Sam was a family man. Sam married the love of his life, the former Randy Kalikow and remained married for 43 years. They produced a loving daughter, Kimberly. Sam is survived by wife Randy, daughter Kim Sunshine, son-in-law David Sunshine, grandchildren Ella and Nate, devoted sisters Alice Rudin and Harriet Lerner, nephews Mitchell (Bonnie) Rudin, Robert (Alissa) Rudin and Jack (Amy) Lerner, niece Rebecca (Robert) Schoenberg. His wisdom, generosity and humor will be greatly missed and fondly remembered by many who knew and loved him. Donations in his memory may be made to either "New York-Presbyterian Fund, Inc.," New York Presbyterian-Weill Cornell Medical Center, Office of Development, 525 East 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10065 or the Andrew Dreyer Memorial Fund, c/o Brant Lake Camp, 7586 State Route 8, Brant Lake, NY, 12815. The funeral will be held at 12 noon on Sunday, March 23 at the Gutterman and Musicant Funeral Home, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ 201-489-3800.

RAFEL--Sol. Died peacefully March 19, 2014, age 94, surrounded by his family. He is survived by his two children, Ellen St. Denis of Norwalk, CT and Anthony Rafel of Seattle, WA and three grandchildren: Jesse Burk Rafel, Emily St. Denis and Molly St. Denis. Oral surgeon, athlete, intellectual, musician, mentor, he lived his life fully in the present engaged in all he did and with everyone in his life. See Bernheim-Apter website for funeral details. Contributions may be made to the JCC Metrowest, 760 Northfield Ave., West Orange, NJ 07052.

D'AMELIO--Marilyn. 1933-2014. Beloved wife to Joseph, mother to Chris and Dan, grandmother to Chloe and Axel. Lynn lived for others every day. Her love will resonate in the world. May God give us the strength to live as she did, and bless her soul. Service was held Friday at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62nd St. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be made to the North Shore Animal League.

THOMAS--Charlotte Rodney, passed away March 20th at her Manhattan, NY home after a long illness. Born in Republic, PA in 1922, she grew up in nearby Uniontown, PA, where she graduated from Uniontown High School. Afterwards, she worked as a radio actress and stenographer. On moving to Washington, DC in the World War II years, she met her future husband, William Thomas (Bill), on a blind date and they married in December 1944. They moved to New York City to be near family and to establish a family business which became a post-war pioneer in ladies sportswear. Charlotte and Bill settled their family in Teaneck, NJ in 1950, where their children, Susan, Stephen and Aaron grew up. They later moved to Englewood, NJ where they lived until Bill's death in 1985. In Teaneck, they were active supporters of Temple Emeth, where Charlotte directed plays and helped with fundraising events. They were also founding members of Congregation Beth Am. They spent every summer with extended family in Tamiment, PA, where Charlotte played tennis and anagrams every day, and enjoyed the close-knit community's activities. She is survived by her children, Susan and Stephen of New York City, and Aaron of Danvers, MA, and their respective spouses, Peter, Celeste and Suzette, and also by her grandchildren, Daniel, Noah, Michael, Sarah, Rachel and Matthew, as well as two great-grandchildren, Maeve and William. A funeral service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel in Manhattan on Monday, March 24th at 11:30am, followed by burial at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ.
WALSH--Hon. Lawrence E. A true American hero. My sympathies to his family and staff. Michael Jude Lane, Columbia College '81
