KORMAN--Marvin, born in the Bronx, June 23, 1927 died on March 9, 2014 a long time Village resident. He was much loved by family and friends for his warmth, genial spirit and graciousness. He shared his life long passions for baseball, art, baking, sketching, American political history, music, travel, good writing and food with everyone he met. He loved to work starting in his father's bakery then becoming a copy boy for The New York Times and PM as a college student. He graduated NYU in 1948, and attended its Art Institute which led him to a career in art galleries including establishing the Korman Gallery on Madison Avenue, the forerunner of the Zabriski gallery. He worked in advertising and publicity for MCA, Dell Publishing, CBS Radio, and Columbia Pictures where he rose to be vice-president of Advertising. After a three year stint at NBC TV he left the corporate world to establish his own boutique Advertising agency Korman, Mohamad, Korman. After retirement, Red Rock Press published his recipe book When the Kaiser Roll was King' and his memoir 'In My Father's Bakery' which is now available in e-book form. He taught many people to bake bread and has an Onion Roll recipe in The New York Times Jewish Cook Book. He is survived by many friends, several cousins, nieces and nephews his beloved wife of sixty-one years Eleanore Zolotow Korman, (retired Dean of the NYU Silver School of Social Work), and two loving daughters Candy Korman and Justine Korman Fontes. Both of his daughters have followed his path as authors. Donations in his memory can be sent to CF Care C/O Dr. Gwen M. Engelhard, 55 East End Avenue Suite 14D New York, NY 10028.

LERNER--Dennis David, 89 on March 20, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Lillian, loving father of Andrew (Dianne) and James (Liz), adoring grandfather of Adam, cherished brother of Norman and Lester. For those who had the honor and privilege to know him, his love will continue to live with us each and everyday. WILDERN--Jean M.,89, on March 17, 2014 in San Francisco, CA. Born in Cleveland, OH July 1, 1924. Jean was a general assignment reporter/feature writer on four major metropolitan newspapers: the Los Angeles Herald, Los Angeles Herald Examiner, Los Angeles Mirror and Cleveland Press. She did public relations for Rick Nelson, the Ozzie & Harriet Show, Kathy Crosby, Bing Crosby Productions, and Louis Armstrong. Teacher in Glendale, CA Public Schools for 13 years. Jean was predeceased by first husband, Charles E. Davis Jr., and second husband, Arthur Wildern. She is survived by her daughters, Jean Davis and Diane Hultquist; sons, Charles E. Davis III, Richard Davis, Kip Wildern, Tim Wildern; son-in-law Pi Ra; granddaughters Darci Davis, Cherille Davis, Faith Jones; and grandsons, Charles E. Davis IV, Travis Davis, Barry Wildern. McKENNA--Jeremiah B. 80, died Tuesday, March 18, 2014 in New Milford, CT following a long illness. Upon graduating from Columbia University Law School, Jerry served as Assistant D.A. for Manhattan District Attorney Frank Hogan from 1958 through 1965 in the Organized Crime Bureau. Jerry also represented the City of New York before the United States Supreme Court in the case Berger v. New York, 388 U.S. 41 (1967), which helped to define the limits of legal wiretapping. He later served as Counsel to the New York State Legislative Committee on Crime and Correction under State Senators Ralph Marino and Christopher Mega, where he played a role in the shaping of the Rockefeller drug laws and other important pieces of New York State Crime legislation. In 1975, Jerry ran an unsuccessful campaign for District Attorney of Staten Island against Democrat Thomas Sullivan. Jerry is survived by his wife of 57 years, Nettie; his sisters, Dorothy Treyball, Rosaleen McKenna and Pat Colbert; three daughters, Hilary McKenna, Abigail McKenna and Amy Omana; and five grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Francis Xavier Church, New Milford, CT, on Monday, March 24, 2014. The service will begin at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to New Milford Visiting Nurse Association, Hospice Care Program; The Alzheimer's Association; or St. Francis Xavier Parish, LifeTeen Program. Arrangements by the Lillis Funeral Home, 58 Bridge St., New Milford, CT.

ZIMMERMAN--David, on March 22, 2014. Research Chemist. Beloved husband of Lila Broude. Loving father ot Jory-Bard, Adam Henry, Rainey and Jackie Straus. Father-in-law to Regina Katz and Alfred Kahn. Cherished grandfather to Maya and Willem. Passionate lover of Opera, Ballet and the Arts, with an unquenchable thirst for knowledge. Service Monday 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

PARISER--Sanford, died peacefully in his sleep on March 18, 2014 in his apartment at The Carlisle Palm Beach. He was 89-years-old. A caring man who loved life and was dedicated above all to his family, he was married for 55 years to his beloved bride Marilyn, who passed in 2005. He is survived by his sons, Howard, Paul and Evan and their wives, Mary, Erin and Nataly, together with six grandchildren, who he so enjoyed indulging: Andrew, Spencer, Sheldon, Ariel, Ali and Rachel. He is also survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Lenore and Marshall Lesser. Sandy also enjoyed seven beautiful years with Leila Kaykoff, who passed in 2012. Sandy graduated as a member of Phi Beta Kappa from New York University in 1944, and from NYU College of Medicine in 1947 as a member of Alpha Omega Alpha, graduating first in his class. He served his internship and residency in Internal Medicine at Mt. Sinai Hospital, followed by a fellowship in Hematology at Mt. Sinai in 1950. From 1953 to 1955, Sandy was a Captain in the US Air Force stationed at Scott Air Force Base in Illinois. Sandy was Board certified in Internal Medicine in 1954, and later received certifications in Medical Oncology and Hematology. He opened up his medical office in Freeport, LI in 1955, which he later relocated to Rockville Centre, LI. He was appointed to be a Police Surgeon with the New York City Police Department, serving from 1961 to 1979. He lived for many years in Freeport and East Hampton, LI. After retiring from practice, he moved to Somers, NY and Boca Raton, FL, and in 2006, to Palm Beach Gardens, FL. For the past two years, Sandy was surrounded by wonderful caregivers, "Team Doc," including Jackie, Chris and Keisha, who loved him like family and allowed him to live independently and with gusto until the end. As a young man, he was a member of the New York Oratorio Society, and loved going to the opera throughout his life. In his later years, he was known to break out in song with his still beautiful tenor voice and with only the slightest provocation. We know he's still singing. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The American Cancer Society.

THOMAS--Charlotte Rodney, passed away March 20th at her Manhattan, NY home after a long illness. Born in Republic, PA in 1922, she grew up in nearby Uniontown, PA, where she graduated from Uniontown High School. Afterwards, she worked as a radio actress and stenographer. On moving to Washington, DC in the World War II years, she met her future husband, William Thomas (Bill), on a blind date and they married in December 1944. They moved to New York City to be near family and to establish a family business which became a post-war pioneer in ladies sportswear. Charlotte and Bill settled their family in Teaneck, NJ in 1950, where their children, Susan, Stephen and Aaron grew up. They later moved to Englewood, NJ where they lived until Bill's death in 1985. In Teaneck, they were active supporters of Temple Emeth, where Charlotte directed plays and helped with fundraising events. They were also founding members of Congregation Beth Am. They spent every summer with extended family in Tamiment, PA, where Charlotte played tennis and anagrams every day, and enjoyed the close-knit community's activities. She is survived by her children, Susan and Stephen of New York City, and Aaron of Danvers, MA, and their respective spouses, Peter, Celeste and Suzette, and also by her grandchildren, Daniel, Noah, Michael, Sarah, Rachel and Matthew, as well as two great-grandchildren, Maeve and William. A funeral service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel in Manhattan on Monday, March 24th at 11:30am, followed by burial at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ.

At the time of her passing she was working as a private chef and completing her cookbook. Memorial services are pending.

SCHWAB--Christine L.,passed away peacefully on March 9th, 2014. She was born in Jersey City, NJ. Predeceased by her father, Charles G. Maphet and her first husband Andrew E. Kobus. Resident of Tenafly, NJ, for thirty years. Survivors include her beloved husband Gerard K. Schwab and her adored children Susan Schwab and Peter Schwab. Chris had many professional accomplishments, but the title she was most proud of, and the role she cherished the most, was "MOMMY". Chris endured many years of illness and disability. When she could no longer endure life, death came and set her free. There will be no service, at her request. Instead, she prefers that, if you are able, you go out for a walk, or a run, or ride a bike, or take a hike! And think about how much she wished she could still do those things. Chris would be gratified if donations were made to Camp Michikamau, in care of YMCA of GBC, 360 Main Street, Hackensack, NJ, 07601, so that more children will have the opportunity of the life-changing experience of summer camp, as her own children did. This was written by Christine Schwab on January 26, 2014. An Online Guestbook is available at: treasurecoastseawinds.com

REDNOR--Joshua A.,passed away on March 19, 2014 at the age of 91. Survived by his wife of 70 years, Blanche Rednor and two sons; Fred, wife Elana and daughter Hillary and Jordan, wife Elizabeth and their two sons; Matt and wife Rachel and Scott. JOSEPH--Yolanda, The Lady Joseph, passed away peacefully at her home on March 9, 2014 at the age of 89. Born in Egypt, she grew up on the banks of the Nile before moving to New York City. She led an extraordinary life dedicated to children and education, founding a children's center in Cairo; as member of the Board of Trustees of the Brearley School; founding Bandwagon; and in her involvement with Homestart and the Nambale Magnet school in Kenya. She was married to Leonard Sheriff, a pioneer in merger arbitrage. She was later married to Keith Joseph, the noted British politician. Much loved mother of Margaret, Marina, Antony (and Danielle); sister of Guido; stepmother of James, Emma, Julia and Anna; and grandmother of nine. She touched everyone she met with her generosity, love, kindness, wit and enormous sense of style. A British Prime Minister was once moved to call her a "precious, precious bundle". A private funeral service will be held in Washington, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: www.jdrf.org or www.cornerstoneproject.org

FRASER--Russell A.,86, of Honolulu, HI, died March 10, 2014. Veteran of the U.S. Navy's V-12 program at Dartmouth College, A.B. 1947; Harvard University Ph.D. 1950. Author/editor of 20 books, master teacher, University administrator at Princeton, Vanderbilt, and the University of Michigan, where he was Austin Warren Professor of English Language and Literature Emeritus. Shakespearean scholar, biographer, travel writer, essayist (140), fiction writer--he was a true man of letters. Survived by his wife of 33 years, Mary Zwiep, daughter Karen, son Alexander, three grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

FUCHS--Anna-Riitta. Pioneering endocrinologist and educator. Anna-Riitta was born in Helsinki, Finland in 1926, the youngest child of Martti and Rut Olsson. At the age of 13 she enlisted in the junior corps of the women's auxiliary when the country was attacked by the Soviet army in the aftermath of the Molotov-Ribbentrop pact between Stalin and Hitler. At age 17, she joined the regular women's auxiliary corps of the armed forces and served as a communications specialist and air raid observer with various combat units. After the war, she married the Danish doctor, Fritz Friedrich Fuchs and settled in Copenhagen. The couple eventually had four children. In 1950, she received a Master of Science in Chemistry with honors from the University of Helsinki. She and Fritz spent a year in the US in 1951 as research fellows at the Carnegie Institution in Baltimore. The family moved permanently to the United States in 1964. Initially, she worked as a researcher in endocrinology at the Rockefeller University. Later, she became Professor of Endocrinology at Cornell University. Already an established scientist, she received the D. Sc. Degree from Copenhagen University in 1978. Her research focused on the endocrinology of childbirth. Her work elucidated the role of oxytocin in the onset of labor and led to pioneering research on the use of ethanol as a treatment for premature labor. She volunteered to be a test subject herself when she went into labor prematurely with her last child, Lars, who was born to term two months later. In her long scientific career, she published over 200 peer-reviewed journal articles and numerous book chapters and several textbooks. She served as a visiting scientist in Salvador, Brazil, Bangkok, Thailand and Hamburg, Germany and was appointed a member of the New York Academy of Sciences. Dr. Fuchs was an active promoter of women in science throughout her career. Among the researchers she mentored in her lab are several successful women doctors and scientists. In 2001, she was appointed Professor Emerita at Weill-Cornell Medical College at Cornell University. In 2003, Dr. Fuchs became the second woman to receive the Carl G. Hartman Award, the highest honor conferred by the Society for the Study of Reproduction. Anna-Riitta is survived by her four children, Anneli, Martin, Peter and Lars, and five grandchildren.

KOBRIN--Gloria, 62, beloved wife of Ron Froug, younger sister of Trudi Gunsberg (Frank), mother of Alan Kantrowitz (Melissa) and Risa (1974-1991), Grandma Gloria called "G G" by Tyler, Reese and Bradley, aunt to Meredith (Jay Bluestine), Shari (Josh Rayburn), Rachel (Anil Bhatia), great-aunt to many. GALOSIC--Andrew. Andy, 76, of Astoria, NY passed away on Saturday, March 8, 2014. He was an avid New York Times reader, spending hours with each issue. FULLER COWLES--Sage. Dancer, philanthropist, activist, and educator, died on November 21, 2013 in Minneapolis, MN. She was 88. A devoted mother of four, Sage was best known for her support of contemporary dance artists. Sage was a longtime board member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Co., toured as a guest artist in the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company's production "Last Supper at Uncle Tom's Cabin/The Promised Land," and earned a Lifetime Achievement "Ernie" Award from Dance/USA in 2004. Sage was preceded in death by her husband, John Cowles, Jr., former CEO of Cowles Media Co. and publisher of the Minneapolis Star Tribune. Sage was born on May 5, 1925, in Paris, to Jane Sage White (sculptor) and Charles Fairchild Fuller (architect). She attended Rippowam School in Bedford Village, NY. After her parents divorced, her mother married publisher Cass Canfield who later became President of Harper and Row. Sage spent the summers of 1936 and 1937 at Perry Mansfield Camp, rooming with actress Julie Harris. Through the late 1930's and early 40's she received dance training from Hanya Holm, Louis Horst, Ella Daganova, Louise Kloepper, The Ned Wayburn School of Dance, The School of American Ballet and Lisa Gardiner's School of Ballet. In 1943 she met Merce Cunningham, who became a life-long friend and inspiration. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin with a B.A. in Art History. A student of Margaret H'Doubler, Sage was also a member of the Wisconsin Dance Group, which included Mary Hinkson, Matt Turney and Miriam Cole. She married Dr. Edmundo Flores in 1946; the marriage ended in divorce in 1950. In 1950, while a dancer on Broadway's "Bless You All" and on TV's "Lucky Strike Hit Parade," Sage met John Cowles, Jr. Two years later the couple married and moved to Kansas, where John was in the Army at Ft. Riley. After moving to Minneapolis in 1953, Sage danced with the Nancy Hauser Contemporary Dance Co., the Joan Skinner Dance Co. and co-founded the Dancers' Forum. Sage also turned her attention to social and civic causes. In 1959 she co-founded the Highcroft Country Day School. During the 1960's she became active in civil rights advocacy with "The Way," Planned Parenthood and the Minneapolis Mayor's Commission on Human Relations. In the 1970's Sage served on the Three School Foundation Board that implemented the merger of Highcroft, Northrop and Blake schools. Interested in body/mind disciplines, Sage became involved with dance therapy and worked with autistic children at Washburn Child Guidance Center. She served as the Movement Coordinator to the Reflective Leadership program at the University of Minnesota and developed her personal workshops "Use of Movement as a Teaching Tool" and "I Can, I Can Choose, and I Can Change." In 2005-2006 Sage was awarded a Louis W. Hill Jr. Philanthropy Fellowship by the U of MN and authored "Getting Ahead of the Curve: Engaging Our Youngest Citizens," calling for movement training as part of early childhood education. From 1976-1983 she collaborated with filmmaker Molly Davies on six film/performance pieces which toured throughout the United States and Europe. "Those pieces were so ahead of their time in the 1970's with the mix of media and live performance," recalls Philip Bither, performing arts curator, Walker Art Center. In 2005 Sage performed the retrospective "Space, Time and Illusion: Sage Cowles and Molly Davies, at Dance Theater Workshop and the Walker. Sage received grants from the NEA (1979), Jerome Foundation (1980) and Affiliated State Arts Agencies of the Upper Midwest (1981, 1982) for her work. She was part of "A Celebration of Collaborations" (1980) in Minneapolis and performed in the Walker Art Center's "New Dance USA" (1981). She choreographed Suzanne Lacey's "Whispers" (1987), taught "Dance for Non-Dancers" at the Minneapolis YWCA and Metro State University and helped found the Minnesota Independent Chor-eographers Association. During 1990-92 Sage and John toured the USA and Europe as guest artists in the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Co. production "Last Supper at Uncle Tom's Cabin/The Promised Land." Sage served for 29 years, over five decades, as a Board member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Co., including as Co-Chair from 2000-2004. Sage supported the multidisciplinary exhibition Art Performs Life in 1998 at the Walker, which featured the work of Cunningham, Meredith Monk and Bill T. Jones. She helped to secure the Merce Cunningham Dance Co.'s 15-plus engagements in Minnesota, as well as to bring Cunningham and John Cage's monumental work-in-the-round "Ocean" to a granite quarry near St. Cloud, MN in 2008. During the late 1980's and '90's Sage was a competitive racewalker, setting two U.S. records in her age group and she then became an aerobics instructor. In 1997 Sage teamed with her husband and children to launch a new professional women's fastpitch softball league and later Sage and John made the lead gift for the U of MN's Jane Sage Cowles Stadium for fastpitch. The league continues today as National Pro Fastpitch. In 2001 the Ordway Center honored Sage with a Sally Award for her decades-long support of the arts. In 2005 the annual Sage Awards for Dance were created to honor her extensive contributions. And in 2011, after fourteen years of planning and fundraising, Sage helped launch the Cowles Center for Dance and the Performing Arts, giving Minnesota its long-awaited flagship for dance. Sage is survived by her four children, ten grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. A memorial celebration will be held on April 5, at 1:30pm, at the Cowles Center in Minneapolis.

GOODMAN--Lillian Horowitz, died March 15, 2014 in Miami, Florida at age 98. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Joseph Goodman, her sister Pauline Horowitz Grossbard and her brother Murray Horowitz. A graduate of Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, she was a member of the Kagathos honor society and the female academic honor plaque winner of her class. After graduation she worked to help support her widowed mother and two siblings. A long time Brooklyn, NY then Miami resident, she taught shorthand in the Brooklyn College adult education program, was a legal and executive secretary, and later a paralegal, both in New York and Miami. After retiring, she attended continuing adult education classes through the Institute for Learning in Retirement (formerly the IRP). She also volunteered in Janet Reno's Office during Ms. Reno's term as State Attorney for Dade (now Miami-Dade) County. Beloved wife, mother, aunt and grandmother, she was a blintz maker extraordinaire and shopper par excellence. The highlight of her shopping career came when she won a $10,000 spending spree at Bloomingdales. She is survived by her son Richard Goodman of Miami, Florida; daughter Phoebe Goodman Bressack and her husband, Michael Bressack, of Los Altos, CA; and granddaughters Leah and Gabrielle Bressack.

FRIEDMAN--Herbert V.,born November 2, 1918, cherished husband of more than 70 years of Marion (nee Rosenfeld), adored father of Barbara Altman (Ron) and Ken (Joanne), beloved grandpa of Andrew Altman, Lynn Altman, Melissa Wolfson, and Jeff Wolfson, and superpappy of Hannah, Brent, and Jared Wolfson. After graduating from NYU, Heights in 1939 and Columbia Law School in 1942, Herb enlisted in the Army Air Corps. Following the war and the birth of their children, he and Marion made their home in Rockville Centre, NY, for 55 years, joining Central Synagogue of Nassau County and becoming founding members of Middle Bay Country Club in 1955. A lifetime member of the Million Dollar Round Table, Herb established an extraordinarily successful insurance business, specializing in association group and group health insurance. An avid golfer, Herb had six holes in one, scoring his last one at age 88. In addition to golf and a good gin game, Herb loved going out with Marion and family and friends, to enjoy a great meal, a good martini, and lots of laughs. All who knew him delighted in his upbeat personality, his joie de vivre, his warmth, and his sense of humor. His smile was magnificent and his laughter contagious. Services are private. In lieu of flowers, a donation to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

GOBER--AJ, of Port Washington on February 13, 2014 Beloved English teacher. Father of Matthew, CJ and JJ. Cherished grandfather of Cal, Molly and Mina. Memorial to be held on April 13, 2014, at 2pm, Flower Hill hose co., Haven avenue in Port Washington.
GOLDMAN--Ruth F.,83, passed away March 9, of Delray Beach, FL and Westbury, NY. Loving mother of Michael, Susan, daughter-in-law Judy, and grandchildren Alex and Sonya.

KETIVE--Samuel, born Samuel Gershon Ketive on March 26, 1942 in New York City, Sam was the son of his beloved parents Nathan and Shirley Ketive. Sam, a resident of Fort Lee, N.J. and Palm Beach, FL, passed away on March 20 after a hard fought battle with cancer, his wife Randy and daughter Kim faithfully by his side. Sam's life was remarkable for his ability to garner life-long friends and his love of sports and family. Beginning in Brant Lake Camp in the 1950's where his natural athleticism and leadership qualities made him Camper of the Year, to the Barnard School for Boys where he was an "All City" basketball star, to his years at Michigan State University and ZBT fraternity (class of 1963) Sam's friendships endured over the course of his lifetime. His friends' unwavering love and support during his illness are a testament to those longstanding relationships. Sam retired from Bellemead Development where he rose to the level of Senior Vice President. In this role, Sam was instrumental in transforming New Jersey into one of the largest office markets in thecountry. Sam also served his country in the National Guard. But above all Sam was a family man. Sam married the love of his life, the former Randy Kalikow and remained married for 43 years. They produced a loving daughter, Kimberly. Sam is survived by wife Randy, daughter Kim Sunshine, son-in-law David Sunshine, grandchildren Ella and Nate, devoted sisters Alice Rudin and Harriet Lerner, nephews Mitchell (Bonnie) Rudin, Robert (Alissa) Rudin and Jack (Amy) Lerner, niece Rebecca (Robert) Schoenberg. His wisdom, generosity and humor will be greatly missed and fondly remembered by many who knew and loved him. Donations in his memory may be made to either "New York-Presbyterian Fund, Inc.," New York Presbyterian-Weill Cornell Medical Center, Office of Development, 525 East 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10065 or the Andrew Dreyer Memorial Fund, c/o Brant Lake Camp, 7586 State Route 8, Brant Lake, NY, 12815. The funeral will be held at 12 noon on Sunday, March 23 at the Gutterman and Musicant Funeral Home, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ 201-489-3800.

KARP--Richard M. On behalf of the Board of Directors, volunteers, staff, individuals and families of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, we offer our heartfelt condolences to the family of our longtime friend and benefactor, Dick Karp. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Jane Hausman Karp; brother-in-law and former board president Martin Hausman; his son David (Monika) Zisskind; grandchildren Ella and Leo; his niece Katherine Sarasohn; step-brother David (Joyce) and brothers and sister-in-law Martin and Helaine Hausman and Albert Sarasohn. Gary Geresi, President Edward R. Matthews, CEO United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc.

ELLERIN--Milton H. We extend our deepest condolences to the family of Milton H. Ellerin. May his wife Betty and their children and grandchildren be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Susan L. Bender Phyllis Chesler Ariel and Shannon Chesler

HAVEMEYER--Horace, III, died March 19, 2014, in his home in New York City of complications from CIDP, a chronic neurological disorder that rendered him quadriplegic in mid-2011. He was 72. He is survived by his beloved and loving wife Eugenie Cowan Havemeyer, his mother Rosalind E. Havemeyer, his siblings Rosalind H. Roosevelt, William E. Havemeyer, and Christian Havemeyer, and his uncle Harry W. Havemeyer. He was a lifelong sailor and a watercolorist. Horace achieved his life-long goal of being a publisher. His trajectory lead from his childhood on a family farm in Dix Hills, Long Island, where sailing became a passion, and the family summer home in Islip designed by Grosvenor Atterbury. He went to East Woods School on Long Island, graduated from Pomfret School and from Hobart and William Smith Colleges, in Geneva, New York, in 1964. He served on the Hobart Board of Trustees from 1980-85 and 1991-97. After college, as the fourth generation of eldest sons, he joined the family business, the National Sugar Refining Company; he began in the Philadelphia factory, learning the chemical processes. When the family business was sold in 1969, he moved to New York City and was Production Planning Supervisor at Doubleday book publishers for a decade. There he learned the editorial and business operations of book publishing and nurtured his thirst for learning, from medieval to contemporary, which he stored in his immense memory bank. Courses at the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies led to his working for Skyline, the IAUS journal, until it closed. In 1981, he founded Bellerophon Publications and served as Publisher of Metropolis magazine and of Metropolis Books, a joint venture with DAP since 2002. From its first issue, Metropolis was in the vanguard of architecture and design, encompassing environmental sustainability, and ranging from preservation to contemporary planning. Horace's intellectual and practical curiosity framed his vision for Metropolis: to posit and answer the questions what, why, how, and to focus on the collaborations and challenges involved in any project. Its editorial perspective has been described as "the conscience" of the field. The magazine's reach now includes educational tours led by long-time Editor-in-Chief now Publisher - Susan S. Szenasy. Its competitions, such as Next Generation, discover new talent and new resources, such as the 2013 focus on low-cost solutions for the disabled. Through Metropolis, Horace was instrumental in developing the annual International Contemporary Furniture Fair, held each May at the Javits Center, and included a vanguard lecture series sponsored by Metropolis. In 2006 the American Society of Interior Designers, New York Metro Chapter, created the Horace Havemeyer III Award to honor his on-going dedication to the design community. Its annual State of Design lectures provide a platform for an open, constructive dialogue on what shapes 21st century design. In December 2006, Horace and Susan were awarded honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degrees by the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena. In 2007 Horace, Susan and Metropolis received the August Heckscher Award from CIVITAS "for their twenty-five years pursuing enlightened and intelligent documentation of life in urban America, especially New York City". In 2009 the American Institute of Architects awarded Horace, in behalf of Metropolis magazine, the Institute Honor for Collaborative Achievement, "reaching a broad cross-section of design disciplines, touching all elements of design excellence, it speaks to elemental and contextual innovation, including, but not limited to ecological insight, livability, and community development; in short, the spectrum of all goals of the architectural profession." He was a co-founder and director of Exploring the Metropolis, Inc., a non-profit organization led by his wife Eugenie Cowan, focused on the built environment, specifically solving workspace issues facing New York's performing arts and cultural communities. A memorial service will be held on May 2, 2014, at 11:00am at St. James' Church. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions in Horace's memory be made to Exploring the Metropolis, Inc., 61 West 23rd Street, New York 10010, or to Hospital for Special Surgery: ALS Research c/o Dr. Dale J. Lange, 525 East 71st Street, 5th floor, New York, NY 10021.

FLEISCHMAN--Dr. Morton, Family Physician for 65 years. 97 years old, passed away on March 21, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Nina and Bill Koppelman and Richard and Clara Fleischman. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Funeral services Sunday 10am at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY.

FERGUSON--Thomas Dudley, died peacefully at home in Oak Park, IL on March 16, 2014. Wise and witty to the end, he was 75. Oak Park River Forest High School history teacher, world traveler, bibliophile, ace photographer, jazz fan. Beloved husband of Carole (nee Lindner), father of Sarah (William Neuman) and Heather (Annika Fjelstad), loving grandfather of Max, Emma and Romy Neuman, Josiah and Gabe Ferguson. He will be forever in our hearts.

ELKIN--Frances. 91. Wife of the late Arthur Elkin; loving mother to Elissa and Marjorie; mother-in-law to Richard Birnbaum; grandmother to Madison Birnbaum; sister to Claire Tive and Sidney Krumholz; and cherished aunt and friend. Funeral service Sunday, March 23, 10:30am at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, New York.
KETIVE--Samuel. A gentle guiding hand to so many, he will be forever loved and missed. Marvin and Carol Sunshine

BELLUCCI--Ronald (Ron). Passed away on Monday, January 27, 2014. Born on February 26, 1930 in Essex, New Jersey to Frank A. and May (Santini) Bellucci he grew up in Douglaston, New York was a graduate of Brooklyn Preparatory and Saint John's University. Ron is survived by his children Patricia Bellucci, Carleen (Charlie) Krueger, Diane (Peter) Grandelli, Kathleen (Jack) McCann, Ronald (Kathy) Bellucci, Richard (Tracey) Bellucci, Robert (Susan) Bellucci and Raymond (Denise) Bellucci; as well as his 15 grandchildren and great-grandson. He is also survived by his brother Thomas Bellucci. Ron is preceded in death by his brother Anthony F. Bellucci and his sister Judith Horowitz. Services will be held at 10:30am on Saturday, March 29th at St. Rosalie Catholic Church www.saintrosalie.com located at 31 E. Montauk Highway in the Hampton Bays, NY 11946. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made at www.lung.org in his name.

CARR--Dr. Arthur C. (Art) Age 95. Art died peacefully listening to Mahler's Resurrection Symphony on Monday, January 13, 2014. Dr Carr was a distinguished Professor of Clinical Psychology at both Columbia and Weill Cornell Medical College where his expertise was clinical psychiatric diagnoses utilizing psychological testing. He shared this knowledge with his many colleagues in treatment and research and with his many students. He was also a lifelong lover of art, especially Pop Art. He was an early collector of distinguished artists such as Robert Indiana, Agnes Martin, and Andy Warhol. His apartment, filled with art, was a joy to visit. Art was a remarkable man, intelligently kind, talented and steadfast. A funeral service was held in Lancaster, NY.

BELKNAP--Robert L. The Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation mourns the loss of our former President, Robert L. Belknap, a distinguished scholar and tireless advocate for excellence in the humanities. During his twenty-seven years as a Trustee and then President of the Foundation, he created fellowship programs that provided crucial support to young researchers and teachers. His brilliant mind, collegiality, and passion will be sorely missed. Our condolences to his family. The Board and staff of the Foundation

CORZINE--Jeffrey Dougherty, 31, passed away on March 10, 2014 in Puebla, Mexico. His passing is deeply mourned by his parents, Joanne Brown and Jon Corzine, his sister, Jennifer Pisani, his brother, Joshua Corzine, and five doted upon nieces and nephews. Jeffrey's immediate family, including his step-parents, Sharon Corzine and Harmon Brown, are joined in their sorrow by an extended group of family and friends whose lives he touched. Jeffrey lived most of his adult life in Malibu, California where he was an active member, sponsor and counselor in the Alcoholics Anonymous (A.A.) community. He devoted much of his time to helping others overcome the challenges he had faced of addiction, depression and recovery. Many in the A.A. community have expressed that Jeffrey's passion and loving efforts brought hope and change to their lives. Jeffrey also was an aspiring creative photographer and writer. His body of work will bring pleasure and hope to admirers in the future. Jeffrey was born in Summit, New Jersey and lived there through his childhood. He graduated from the Pomfret School in Connecticut and then went on to receive a B.A. in History from NYU. He also attended the Brooks Institute of Photography in Santa Barbara, California. Jeffrey's generosity, spirit of service to others and creative works will be an inspiration to many. To honor his life, charitable contributions may be made in Jeffrey's name to: United Cerebral Palsy Wheels for Humanity http://www.ucpwfh.org 12750 Raymer St., Unit 4 North Hollywood, CA 91605 Attention: Kat Heiden. Ocean Park Community Center http://www.opcc.net 1453 16th St. Santa Monica, CA 90404 Attention: Andy Nichols

COHEN--Ted, Philosopher, died March 14 in Chicago, aged 74. A highly-regarded scholar and teacher, he joined the University of Chicago faculty in 1967 and taught there until his death. He received his PhD from Harvard in 1972, studying with the analytic philosopher Willard Van Orman Quine. Cohen's own scholarly interests were wide-ranging; he published four books and more than sixty scholarly articles, focusing most recently on how we use art, narrative, and even sports and jokes to create empathy and connection ("Becoming the Other," and "Thinking of Others" are two recent titles). His many awards include the Quantrell, the University of Chicago's award for excellence in teaching. His elegant thinking and writing brought him the Pushcart Prize in 1991 for "There Are No Ties at First Base." His role in Chicago's famous annual "Latke-Hamantash Debate" led to the 2006 book, The Great Latke-Hamantash Debate, in which Cohen both explicates and sends up analytic philosophy. Famous as a joke teller, his 1999 book, Jokes: Philosophical Thought on Joking Matters, explored the role of humor in creating intimacy and community. Professor Cohen is survived by his wife Ann (Andy) Rutherfurd Austin Cohen, his daughter Shoshannah Cohen, son-in-law Elmer Almachar, son Amos Cohen, grandson Asher Cohen, as well as his brother Stephen of Sydney, Australia, aunt, Peg Kay of Washington, DC, and stepdaughter Alexandra Austin-Schmidt, son-in-law William Schmidt, Jr. and grandchildren Camilla and Russell Schmidt. He was buried in his hometown of Hume, Illinois. A memorial will be held at the University of Chicago on April 12. Memorial donations should be made to the American Civil Liberties Union.

CORZINE--Jeffrey. The Child Mind Institute mourns the loss of Jeffrey Corzine, youngest son of our treasured friend Jon Corzine. Jeffrey was a gentle and caring man, a devoted son and brother, a cherished stepson, a gifted athlete and talented photographer, and a kind and generous friend. We send our sympathy to his mother Joanne and stepfather Harmon, his father Jon and stepmother Sharon, his sister Jennifer and brother-in-law David, his brother Josh and sister-in-law Amanda, and his extended family and many friends. He will be missed by all of us. Brooke Garber Neidich, Chair, Debra G. Perelman, Vice Chair, and Harold S. Koplewicz, MD, President, Child Mind Institute

DUMONT--Jean M. Beloved partner of Wayne Brelowski passed peacefully away on March 20, 2014. Despite many years of MS, Jean never lost her joy of life and active involvement with many friends and family. Wayne was always the "wind beneath her wings" and Jean was always the life of any party she attended. In her earlier years Jean was a most accomplished artist, with great expertise in watercolors and silver jewelry. She leaves behind a very loving family: Her sister and brother-in-law, Peggy and Roger Froehlich; nephew Scott (Shannon) Froehlich and their children, Will and Drew; niece Karen Froehlich and Kevin Angus; Wayne's mother Lorraine Brelowski; sister Karen Brelowski, and nephews Brian and Randy Magda. Jean will be lovingly remembered and missed by all.

D'AMELIO--Marilyn. 1933-2014. Beloved wife to Joseph, mother to Chris and Dan, grandmother to Chloe and Axel. Lynn lived for others every day. Her love will resonate in the world. May God give us the strength to live as she did, and bless her soul. Service was held Friday at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62nd St. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be made to the North Shore Animal League.

CLIFFORD--Mary Lawrence, died peacefully in her home on March 15th, 2014, surrounded by family. "How could they fit so much pizzazz into such a small person?" That is the sentiment most commonly expressed by the legions of people who loved Mary Clifford, but most of all by her adoring husband of nearly 60 years, Donald K. "Obie" Clifford. Mary was a devoted lifetime mom, not only to her own five children, but to so many others who needed a mother in their lives. She was a loving grandmother to her fourteen grandchildren, delightful friend and relative, lover of dogs and other furred or feathered creatures, creator of beauty out of nature's offerings, enthusiastic athlete, voracious reader, and playful initiator of fun and games. Mary was a natural leader, rising to leadership roles in many volunteer activities the Nature Conservancy's eastern chapter, Emma Willard School, The Big Wolf Lake Association, The Wild Center, Rusticus Garden Club and book groups. In her unassuming way, Mary was a builder of people and institutions. She left every person and organization enhanced and buoyed up through her attentions and no-nonsense support. She will be deeply missed and will remain, always, a bright light in our hearts. A service of remembrance will be held at the Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea in Elmsford, NY on Saturday, March 29th, 2014, at 11:00am. Longtime resident of Mt. Kisco, NY, Mary was a graduate of Emma Willard School and Vassar College. In lieu of flowers, Mary's family would deeply appreciate gifts to The Wild Center, 45 Museum Dr., Tupper Lake, NY, 12986; wildcenter.org.

EHRLICH--Daniel J.,of New York City and Cold Spring, NY, son of the late Ann and Sydney Ehrlich of Bayport, NY, died on March 21, from brain injuries due to a fall. He was 86. He leaves his beloved wife, Edith, two devoted daughters and sons-in-law Nina Ehrlich-Foley and Joe Foley; Jennifer Rimmer and David Rimmer; four loving grandchildren, Amy and Caroline Rimmer, and Dylan and Jackson Foley, as well as his brother, Dr. Fred Ehrlich. He was an involved uncle and cousin and was "there" for many people. Dan was a warm, generous, and concerned man, both for friends and for many causes. He was a kind person who will be missed. A funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street), in New York City at 1:30 on Tuesday, March 25th. Interment is private. The family is grateful to all who helped him and requests donations in his memory to Camphill Village USA, Inc, 84 Camphill Road, Copake, NY 12516, or to the charity of your choice.

BELKNAP--Robert L. The Brearley community deeply mourns the passing of Columbia University Professor Emeritus Robert L. Belknap, an Honorary Trustee of the Brearley School and father of three Brearley alumnae. A distinguished educator and a wise and highly regarded member of the Brearley Board (1978 to 1989), he served as President (1982 to 1987) during the School's Centennial celebration. We send our sincere condolences to his wife, Professor Cynthia Whittaker, and to his family.

EBERHARDT--John Henry, 92 of Palm Beach FL, Cherry Grove, NY, and Water Mill, NY passed away March 17, 2014. He was born November 18, 1921 in Newark, New Jersey. The son of Ulrich Seth Eberhardt and Ruth Schmidt Eberhardt, and is survived by William Eberhardt. John was one of four children. A child prodigy artist, he was painting murals in his church at the age of nine. John became a scenic artist and set designer. He worked for CBS, numerous Broadway productions, and also owned his own display business "On Display". He was a pioneer developer of Cherry Grove, Fire Island, NY. A self-taught architect, he built over fifty unique houses and his own personal residence, the magnificent "Belvedere", a Baroque Fantasy Palace that is now a Hotel. A long time Palm Beach resident, his home "Villa Fontana" is a showcase of his extraordinary talent. He was always the gracious host, opening the doors to many memorable parties and charity events. He will be remembered for his love of life and positive attitude no matter the circumstances. John had a great passion for animals, especially rescue dogs. He was never without a Dalmatian, his favorite breed. Memorial donations may be made to Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League, 3100/3200 North Military Trail, West Palm Beach, Florida 33409. Special thanks to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

BELKNAP--Robert Lamont. Professor Emeritus of Slavic Languages and Literatures at Columbia University, died on March 17 after a month of fighting idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Fortunately, he experienced no pain or discomfort, so he retained his signature smile, genial personality, and brilliant mind to the end. Bob has long figured as an internationally renowned Dostoevsky scholar, especially for his monumental studies of The Brothers Karamazov. Remarkable for the depth, breadth, and nuance of his knowledge, Bob wrote dozens of articles that elucidated diverse corners of 18th- and 19th-century Russian literature. His work always reflected a passionate, comparative quality, and he possessed encyclopedic knowledge of European ancient and modern literature. His ability to relate one work of literature to another will be amply demonstrated in his last book, Literary Plots (forthcoming from Columbia University Press). His was a beautiful, labyrinthine mind. Professor Belknap was magisterial--and fun--in the classroom. The intellectual excitement he generated among students was legendary. Figuratively and in reality, at 6'5", he was a towering presence. At Columbia for over fifty years, he championed the teaching of Literature Humanities and co-authored a book on the subject, Tradition and Innovation: General Education and the Reintegration of the University. Just last month, his colleagues and graduate students honored him with a festschrift, Teaching Nineteenth-Century Russian Literature: Essays in Honor of Robert L. Belknap. Bob was a good citizen of the many communities to which he belonged. He was chairman of the board at the Brearley School, which his daughters attended, and he served as president of the Giles Whiting Foundation. At Columbia, among other posts, he was department chair, director of the Harriman Institute, and acting dean of the College. His last position, Chair of the University Seminars, combined his zeal for interdisciplinary studies with his ability to get people to work together harmoniously, even if they warmly despised each other. Bob, a native New Yorker, was born on December 23, 1929. He was educated at the Buckley School, Philips Exeter Academy, and Princeton University, from which he graduated summa cum laude in 1951. After serving in the U.S. Army, he completed his doctorate at Columbia in 1960 and also studied at the University of Paris and Leningrad State University. During summers, Bob loved the ongoing project of building his house on Cliff Island, Maine. There was a sense of nobility about Bob, and perhaps his best achievement was never to have faltered at being honest, fair, wise, of good will and good cheer and thoroughly decent. He was the perfect gentleman. His survivors include: his wife, Cynthia Hyla Whittaker, a Russian historian; his daughters from his previous marriage, Lydia Duff of Baltimore, Ellen Belknap of Portland, Maine, and Abigail Krueger of Boston; his stepchildren, Erica Whittaker of Windsor, England and Andrew Whittaker of New York; and his sisters, Louise Belknap Carter of New Haven and Barbara Belknap of New York. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, on September 12 at 2pm.

ATHANASSIADES--Ted, (1939-2014). In Memoriam. The Independent Trustees of EQ Advisors Trust pay tribute to the extraordinary contributions that Ted Athanassiades made to the Trust. His deep experience in the insurance industry and his astute analysis of investment issues, coupled with his caring and warm style, added so much to the work and the culture of our Board. For more than a decade, his consistent focus on those whom the Board serves was an inspiration. We are deeply saddened by his passing. He will be greatly missed. The Independent Trustees of EQ Advisors Trust

BARKER--Sylvia M.,99, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan, surrounded by close friends. She was a giant among professional nurses of her generation, graduating from the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing in 1936 and serving in various leadership positions at The Mount Sinai Medical Center for more than 50 years. She served as Associate Director of Nursing until 1984, when she stepped down, and continued her service to Mount Sinai as a consultant to Nursing Administration until her retirement in 1994. She was widely recognized for her distinguished work in advancing the areas of risk management, quality assurance, and labor relations in nursing. She earned her BSN and MA degrees from Teachers College, Columbia University, and she received numerous awards throughout her long career. These included the Jane Delano Distinguished Service Award from District 13, New York State Nurses Association, in 1982; the Distinguished Alumna Award from the Alumnae Association of The Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing in 1990; the R. Louise McManus Medal for Nursing Service from Teachers College in 1994; and the Distinguished Membership Award from the American Nurses Association in 1998. She co-authored the book "The Sinai Nurse" with Marjorie Lewis, BS, RN, which described 150 years of nursing experience, invented devices to facilitate the care of patients, and was the esteemed and beloved teacher of many generations of nursing students and co-workers. Her passionate dedication to the profession included holding positions as president of Nurses House, the only national organization that aids nurses in distress, and president and board member of The Alumnae Association of The Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing. As a member of the bylaws committee of the New York State Nurses Association, she was an acknowledged leader in the development and revision of by-laws for nursing organizations. Sylvia was an active member and leader for sixty years of The Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, United Methodist, in Manhattan. In the 1970s she helped found there both the West Side Campaign Against Hunger, now the largest emergency food program in New York City and a pioneering Meals on Wheels Program now serving 500 seniors six days a week. She was also instrumental in founding the church's homeless shelter for women and after-school tutoring program. Sylvia was a national leader in the United Methodist denomination in civil rights, gay rights and interfaith work. She will be missed by all whose professional and personal lives were touched by her brilliance and generosity of spirit. Donations in her memory may be sent to The Alumnae Association, The Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing, 1 Gustave Levy Place, P.O. Box 1143, New York, NY 10029-6574; and The Church of St. Andrew, United Methodist, 263 West 86th Street, New York, NY 10024. A memorial service will be held at Mount Sinai Medical Center at a future date. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew on May 10 at 5pm. Theodora Sirota PhD, APRN-BC President Alumnae Association The Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing

STAVIN--Abraham Jed, DDS, passed away on March 22, 2014 at age 68 after an illness of several months. After graduating from Yeshiva University and the NYU College of Dentistry, he had a dental practice in New York City. He is survived by devoted sisters Deborah David and Andrea Hayman, brother-in-law Alan Hayman, and nieces Jessica Piafsky and Lauren Reves. Funeral services were held on March 23. For information on Shiva, please contact Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel at (718) 263-7600.

CREAGHAN--Ellen Manning. We have spent four long years without you. If conceivable, we miss you more and love you more each day. Happy Birthday Mum. Your forever faithful and loving children Patricia, Dennis & Georgina
TANCER--Michael. Forever remembered, forever missed, forever loved. Your Family
MESSNER--Charles "Chuck" March 24, 2009 With us always. Fay, Rob and Daniel

COHN--J. Gunther 3/6/11-3/24/08 I'm sure you're awaiting the Supreme Court decision that will allow the EPA to regulate more greenhouse gases. As a scientist, throughout your career of more than 50 years, you were dedicated to improving our environment. Your inventions include the catalytic converter used on cars worldwide. You are dearly missed by family, friends, colleagues and most of all your loving daughter, Vicki

FERGUSON--Thomas Dudley, died peacefully at home in Oak Park, IL on March 16, 2014. Wise and witty to the end, he was 75. Oak Park River Forest High School history teacher, world traveler, bibliophile, ace photographer, jazz fan. Beloved husband of Carole (nee Lindner), father of Sarah (William Neuman) and Heather (Annika Fjelstad), loving grandfather of Max, Emma and Romy Neuman, Josiah and Gabe Ferguson. He will be forever in our hearts.

JOSEPH--Yolanda, The Lady Joseph, passed away peacefully at her home on March 9, 2014 at the age of 89. Born in Egypt, she grew up on the banks of the Nile before moving to New York City. She led an extraordinary life dedicated to children and education, founding a children's center in Cairo; as member of the Board of Trustees of the Brearley School; founding Bandwagon; and in her involvement with Homestart and the Nambale Magnet school in Kenya. She was married to Leonard Sheriff, a pioneer in merger arbitrage. She was later married to Keith Joseph, the noted British politician. Much loved mother of Margaret, Marina, Antony (and Danielle); sister of Guido; stepmother of James, Emma, Julia and Anna; and grandmother of nine. She touched everyone she met with her generosity, love, kindness, wit and enormous sense of style. A British Prime Minister was once moved to call her a "precious, precious bundle". A private funeral service will be held in Washington, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: www.jdrf.org or www.cornerstoneproject.org

EHRLICH--Daniel J.,of New York City and Cold Spring, NY, son of the late Ann and Sydney Ehrlich of Bayport, NY, died on March 21, from brain injuries due to a fall. He was 86. He leaves his beloved wife, Edith, two devoted daughters and sons-in-law Nina Ehrlich-Foley and Joe Foley; Jennifer Rimmer and David Rimmer; four loving grandchildren, Amy and Caroline Rimmer, and Dylan and Jackson Foley, as well as his brother, Dr. Fred Ehrlich. He was an involved uncle and cousin and was "there" for many people. Dan was a warm, generous, and concerned man, both for friends and for many causes. He was a kind person who will be missed. A funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street), in New York City at 1:30 on Tuesday, March 25th. Interment is private. The family is grateful to all who helped him and requests donations in his memory to Camphill Village USA, Inc, 84 Camphill Road, Copake, NY 12516, or to the charity of your choice.

REDNOR--Joshua A.,passed away on March 19, 2014 at the age of 91. Survived by his wife of 70 years, Blanche Rednor and two sons; Fred, wife Elana and daughter Hillary and Jordan, wife Elizabeth and their two sons; Matt and wife Rachel and Scott. Joshua served in the Army Air Corps in WWII and went on to receive degrees from CCNY and NYU Law School. He was a well respected tax lawyer and CPA, loved his work, and always had time for family, friends and clients. It was always important for Joshua to give something back to the community, in both his time and money. He found it hard to say no, sometimes to the point he had little spare time. He will be missed by family and friends. Memorial Service will be held at Temple Or Olam East 55th Street, 308 East 55th St, NYC on Tuesday, March 25, 2014 at 7pm.

DENIHAN--Charles. The Headmaster, Trustees, Faculty and Staff, Students, Parents and Alumni of Saint David's School, note with profound sadness the passing of Charlie Denihan, Class of 2000, son of former Trustee Ben Denihan and Barbara, and brother of Tully, Kate and Chrissy. The entire Saint David's community, past and present, extends its deepest sympathies to the Denihan family. Charlie will be forever remembered in the hearts of the Saint David's community: Ut Viri Boni Sint.

SCHAEFFER--Ruth, on March 22, 2014. Ballerina and Broadway dancer. Beloved wife of the late Henry, devoted aunt to Adam and Jory Zimmerman, loving daughter of the late Dorothy and George Dolgin, dear sister of the late Charlotte and Joseph. Memorial Service Thursday, March 27, 2014, 1:30pm, "The Riverside," 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

BLOOMFIELD--Donald Robert, on March 22, 2014 following a long illness. He is survived by his beloved wife Susan, children Alison and Daniel, son-in-law John, and siblings David, Steven, and Susan. Services will be held at noon on Tuesday, March 25th at Gutterman's, Woodbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in his memory to the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation (www.liaf.org).

SCHRAMM--Arthur E.,72, attorney and longtime senior executive with shopping center owner and developer Westfield Group, died March 18, 2014 at his home in Los Angeles, California. Mr. Schramm was born in Flushing, New York and grew up on Long Island where he developed his love for watersports and sailing. He received his MBA from the University of California Berkeley, and his law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. He established law firms in Philadelphia prior to joining Westfield. Mr. Schramm joined Australia-based Westfield Group in 1977 as a young 34 year old attorney where he helped shepherd more than three decades of strategic growth. Noted for his wisdom, innate knowledge of the retail real estate industry and extraordinary intellect, the breadth and depth of his contributions to Westfield touched all disciplines within the company. While his business successes have been significant Mr. Schramm also brought that same focus to his many efforts on behalf of his community. He was especially committed to the battle against Multiple Sclerosis, where he served on The National MS Society Board Southern California Chapter, and most recently helped found the Tom Sherak MS HOPE Foundation in Los Angeles. He has also served on other boards including the Make A Wish Foundation. Survivors include his wife of 48 years Britta Schramm of Los Angeles, California, two children including Kimberle Schramm of Los Angeles, and Katrina Schramm-Dorsey of Stamford, Connecticut. He is also survived by son-in-law Riccardo Conti of Los Angeles, and six grandchildren, Bryce Schramm, Bianca Conti, Chiara Conti, Lucia Conti, Mya Dorsey and Cole Dorsey. Memorial contributions may be made to the Tom Sherak MS Hope Foundation at http://mshopefoundation.org.
KETIVE--Samuel. A gentle guiding hand to so many, he will be forever loved and missed. Marvin and Carol Sunshine

PIERSON--W. Lee, The Collegiate community mourns the loss of W. Lee Pierson, our headmaster from 2004 to 2006. Lee provided thoughtful and steady leadership during an important time of transition for the School. He brought reserves of patience, warmth and wisdom to his work and life. We are eternally grateful to him for his service to Collegiate and extend our deepest condolences to his beloved family.

PEREIRA--Dorothy, of Manhattan, passed away on March 23, 2014 at age 90. Wonderful wife of Mortimer for over 50 years. Wonderful mother to Dr. Jeffrey Shaw and adopted son Marshall Pereira, and three grandchildren. Caring, intelligent, and hard-working person throughout her life.

MYER--William Howard, 83 passed away on March 22, 2014 of Atlantic Beach, NY. Loving husband of Muriel, father of Regina (Jeffrey), Martin (Francine), Amy, Julius and (Felisa), grandfather of Alex, Isabelle, Rachel, Emily, Ian and Jordyn. Funeral Services Monday, March 24, 2014 11:30am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

MARKELSON--Stephen, How will we remember Stephen? A man with a big intellect, a big heart, a quiet elegance and so much more. A real friend, never to be forgotten. Linda and Stuart Schlesinger and Family
MARKELSON--Stephen. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

MARKELSON--Stephen. Died peacefully, March 22nd, 2014 with his beloved wife at his bedside. He is survived by his wife Ann, sons George and Jeffrey, daughter-in-law Zana, and grandchildren Lia and Matthew. Stephen lived his life to the fullest, enjoying time with his family, tennis, a good book, fine dining, a vodka rocks, and being surrounded by friends at the card table. His family and friends were his world, and he will be missed dearly by all who had the privilege of knowing him. The family will be sitting Shiva on Wednesday, March 26th from 6:00 - 9:00pm at The Harmonie Club, located at 4 East 60th Street, NYC.
